PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Apartheid in South Africa
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That they are committed to the elimination of the abominable and inhuman system of apartheid in South Africa, as practised by the minority Government of that country, consistent with the promotion of human rights and civil liberties.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Urge the Federal Government to formally request the South African Government to immediately cease the practice of apartheid, by repealing all laws and regulations relating thereto, and by the release of any political prisoners detained by virtue of such laws, and by any other means consistent with the human rights and civil liberties of all its people.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Industrial Chemicals (Notifications and Assessment) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 231.
24 August 1990
Senator the Hon. Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No. 231, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 23 August 1990.

Regulations 14 and 15 provide for the Director to waive or remit certain fees, as he or she``thinks fit''. Although the range of circumstances in which fees may be waived or remitted is restricted, there appears to be no criteria at all to guide the exercise of this discretion. In addition, there appears to be no provision for review of the merits of an adverse exercise of the discretion. Some of the fees in respect of which the discretion is exercisable are $25,000 and $28,000.

The Committee believes that in circumstances at the present it should be possible to redraft the Regulations to provide for mandatory waiver or remission, thus removing the discretionary element altogether. Alternatively, a right of review to the AAT should be provided for an adverse decision. The Committee notes that the parent Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 provides AAT review for a number of important discretions.
Yours sincerely,
Mal Colston
Chairman
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations
and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT
Dear Mal,
I refer to your letter of 24 August l99O about the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No. 231.

I am reluctant to impose a mandatory system for remission of fees because the complexity of the issues involved makes it difficult if not impossible to specify in a legislative framework the precise circumstances in which fees will be waived.

However, I agree that criteria to guide the exercise of the discretion and a right of review to the AAT in the event of an adverse decision are desirable and I will take steps to ensure that the legislation is amended accordingly.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook

Livestock Export (Merino) Orders (Amendment), as contained in Livestock Export Orders No. 2 of 1990.
20 September 1990
The Hon John Kerin MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Livestock Export (Merino) Orders (Amendment), Livestock Export Orders No. 2 of 1990, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 20 September 1990.
In clause 1 the definition of `designated export auction' refers to-

`an export auction designated as such by the Australian Association of Stud Merino Breeders Ltd, as published prior to the coming into effect of the Livestock Export Orders No. 2 of 1990 (that is, the present Orders) in respect of the 1990 export ram selling season . . .
This incorporation appears valid, as the reference is to an already existing published set of auction dates.
There may, however, be a separate problem of incorporation. To come within the definition an auction is required to be-
`subject to such guidelines determined and published in the``Guidelines and Conditions for Export Sales'' by the Australian Association of Stud Merino Breeders Ltd.'

As long as the Guidelines and Conditions for Export Sales is an existing publication and it is only that publication as it exists as present that is being incorporated, there is no difficulty. But if it is intended that the Orders refer to Guidelines and Conditions for Export Sales as they exist from time to time, then without express provision for this in the parent Act, s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 would preclude such incorporation. If there is no such express provision, the Committee would welcome your assurance that it is not intended to amend the Guidelines and Conditions for Export Sales without making a fresh instrument to incorporate them.
In addition, after referring to already published 1990 auctions, the definition goes on to refer to auctions-
`as published prior to the commencement of each subsequent export ram selling season . . .'
As the yearly auction list was not in existence at the time of the making of this present set of Orders then, unless expressly authorised by the parent Act, such reference may not be valid.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
1 November 1990
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman

and Ordinances

CANBERRA ACT 2600

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Aulich)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training undertake a national inquiry into adult and community education and report on or before the first day of sitting of the 1991 Budget session and that the tasks of the inquiry be as follows:
(a) Examine and describe existing policies and practices in adult and community education, with particular reference to the roles of:
(i) Commonwealth Government agencies,
(ii) State Government and Territory agencies,
(iii) centres of adult and continuing education in the higher education sector,
(iv) technical and further education,
(v) voluntary and community programs,
(vi) industry based training agencies, and
(vii) professional associations and trade unions;
(b) consider the impact of current demographic, economic and social change on patterns of adult and community education, on education providers and on education funding;
(c) identify barriers to participation in adult and community education and recommend means by which they might be overcome;
(d) examine the educational, employment and personal outcomes of participation in adult and community education;
(e) consider the training and supply of adult and community educators; and
(f) recommend policies, strategies and processes to provide a coherent approach to the provision of adult and community education and to enhance its role and contribution.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the procedures laid down by standing order 81, Senator Hill has raised with me a matter of privilege. Under the standing order, I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence over other business on the day for which the notice is given. In making that determination, I am required to have regard only to the following criteria laid down by the Senate:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and,
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

The criteria do not allow me to make any judgment as to whether the facts are as alleged by the senator, or the strength of the evidence. In a number of determinations made since March 1988, I have indicated how I apply the Senate's criteria. I have given precedence to a motion where the matter raised is such that it is capable of being regarded by the Senate as conforming with criterion (a), and if there is no other readily available remedy. I have given precedence to a number of matters since that time, and I have not given precedence to some other matters raised.

The matter raised by Senator Hill refers to material contained in the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority presented to the Senate on 17 October 1990, and it has two aspects. Senator Hill states, first, that that material reveals that a person was given directions, the effect of which was that the person was not to give evidence before the Joint Committee without the approval of the National Crime Authority. Having regard to relevant authorities and precedents, Senator Hill concludes that the directions may have constituted an improper interference with a witness and a contempt of Parliament. Senator Hill states, secondly, that the material discloses that, at a hearing of the Committee, officers of the Authority were asked whether the person concerned had been restricted in any way in the evidence the person should give to the Committee, and they answered in the negative. Again having regard to relevant authorities and precedents, Senator Hill concludes that this may have constituted the giving of false or misleading evidence to a committee and the contempt of Parliament.

Having regard to the relevant declarations of the Senate in its resolutions of 25 February 1988, other relevant authorities and relevant precedents, including recent reports by the Senate Committee of Privileges, it is clear that any allegations that witnesses have been interfered with or that false or misleading evidence has been given to a committee have been regarded as matters of great seriousness. The matter raised by Senator Hill therefore clearly satisfies criterion (a) of the Senate's criteria, and there is no readily available other remedy. I therefore determine that the motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges shall have precedence in accordance with standing order 81. I therefore call Senator Hill to give a notice of motion, and I present to the Senate the letter I received from Senator Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (POWERS OF PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Crichton-Browne) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to avoid a doubt concerning the powers of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.
Motion (by Senator Crichton-Browne) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to express the Parliament's repudiation of an interpretation of its powers, privileges and immunities, put forward by government lawyers, which, if uncorrected, has the potential to undermine the operations of both Houses and of their committees.
The interpretation in question arises in relation to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is established under the National Crime Authority Act 1984.
The National Crime Authority has made a claim that the secrecy provisions of section 51 of the Act inhibit the Authority in providing information to the Joint Committee.

Section 51 is framed in substantially the same way as a great many other secrecy provisions in statutes establishing statutory authorities. Basically it provides that a person who discloses information gained under the Act, except in the course of the performance of duties under the Act, is guilty of an offence, and that a person shall not be required to produce in a court documents or information gained under the Act except for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Act. The section is not expressed to apply to inquiries by the Joint Committee, and the terms of reference of the Committee, including specific restrictions on inquiries by the Committee, are set out in another section of the Act, section 55.

The Committee sought the advice of the Clerk of the Senate in relation to this matter. That advice is to the effect that the secrecy provisions of section 51 of the Act have no application to inquiries by the Joint Committee, because:

- the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 explicitly declares that the immunity of parliamentary proceedings from impeachment or question in a court applies to the giving of evidence and the submission of documents to a committee, including any joint committee and a committee established under a statute
- therefore a person cannot be prosecuted for an offence in respect of the submission of documents or the giving of evidence to the Joint Committee

- it is a long-established legal principle, hitherto upheld by the Government's legal advisers, that the powers, privileges and immunities of the Houses of the Parliament and their committees are not set aside by a statutory provision unless such a provision explicitly says so, and section 51 does not
- the restrictions on the Joint Committee's powers of inquiry contained in section 55 are quite distinct and have nothing to do with the secrecy provisions of section 51.

The Joint Committee received an opinion from the Solicitor-General, to which the Government has indicated it intends to adhere, to the effect that parliamentary privilege is irrelevant and the secrecy provisions of section 51 apply to inquiries by the Joint Committee. As the Clerk of the Senate has pointed out in a commentary on the Solicitor-General's opinion, the opinion cites no authority for these propositions, but simply asserts them, and appears to contemplate that section 51 in some way operates in relation to the Joint Committee as soon as it goes beyond its terms of reference, which the Solicitor-General interprets very restrictively. As the commentary points out, this confuses two separate issues. If the Joint Committee were to go beyond its terms of reference, the remedy is not that the criminal sanction of the secrecy provisions is invoked. That is the equivalent of saying that when the Houses of the Parliament pass a Bill which is later found to be unconstitutional, their proceedings on the Bill are retrospectively stripped of the protection of parliamentary privilege.

As has also been pointed out, if the Solicitor-General's opinion is to be accepted, all the other similar secrecy provisions in statutes may be invoked as barriers to the provision of information to parliamentary committees. There are over 300 such secrecy provisions.

It will be clear from what has been said that the approach taken by the Solicitor-General has the capacity to undermine not only the ability of the Joint Committee to perform its task but the ability of the Houses and any of their committees to perform virtually any of their functions. Once it is accepted that a general secrecy provision prevents the provision of information to Parliament, and that a person may be prosecuted for giving information to Parliament in duly constituted parliamentary proceedings, the very basis of parliamentary operations is destroyed.

The Solicitor-General's opinion is clearly contrary to the express provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, which were intended to remove all doubts about the absolute nature of the immunity attaching to proceedings in Parliament, including proceedings in all parliamentary committees. The opinion is clearly misconceived. It is apparent that the Government has not properly considered the opinion before giving support to it.

In order to repudiate decisively the destructive approach taken by the Solicitor-General, the Bill would declare that section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act has no application to inquiries by the Joint Committee. This declaration would be made without prejudice to the proper interpretation of other provisions in other statutes, including the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987.
I table an explanatory memorandum for the Bill. The documents to which I have referred have been published by the Joint Committee, and are included in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CATTLE TRANSACTION LEVY BILL 1990BEEF PRODUCTION LEVY BILL 1990CATTLE EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1990CATTLE AND BEEF LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1990CATTLE INDUSTRY LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CATTLE TRANSACTION LEVY BILL 1990

This Bill is one of a package of Bills that will introduce new levy arrangements for the cattle and beef industry from 1 January 1991. The other Bills in the package are: the Beef Production Levy Bill; the Cattle Export Charge Bill; the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill; the Livestock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill; the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill and the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill.
The new arrangements have been developed by the industry through the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council (AMLIPC).

The AMLIPC is a statutory body established by the Government in 1984 to provide a forum for the industry wide consideration of industry issues and to inquire into areas of concern to a number of sectors. The Council brings together the leaders of industry, with producer, meat exporter, processor, wholesaling, retailing, union and domestic marketing interests being represented.

Levies are raised from the meat and livestock industry to fund the operations of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC).

The Government matches dollar-for-dollar the industry's expenditure on research and development up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production, in line with primary industries research and development policy.

Levies are also collected to fund the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign (BTEC), to which the Government contributes 20 per cent of funding, and to fund the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, to which the Government contributes 50 per cent of funding.

The current levy arrangements for cattle, sheep, buffalo and goats consist of a flat rate per-head ``live-stock slaughter levy'' at the point of slaughter and a flat rate per-head ``live-stock export charge''. These levy raising mechanisms have been a bone of contention within the industry, and a cause of friction between livestock producers on the one hand and processors and exporters on the other. The major dissatisfaction arises from the question of who actually bears the cost of the levies and charge. Both the producer and the processing and exporting sectors believe they bear the full cost.
This dissatisfaction has increased as levies have risen substantially in recent years.
The 1987 annual general meeting of the industry requested the AMLIPC to undertake an investigation into levy raising mechanisms for the meat and livestock industry.

The AMLIPC recommended a new levy and charge raising mechanism for the cattle and beef industry, with the mechanisms for sheep, buffalo and goats to remain unchanged. The Council has resolved to review the new levy mechanisms during their third year of operation.

The basic mechanisms recommended by the AMLIPC for cattle and beef are: a flat rate per head levy on all cattle sales and transfers of cattle from the production to the processing stage, payable by the vendor or the owner at the time of transfer; a beef production levy on a cents per kilogram basis on beef and veal produced, payable by the owner of the carcass; and a charge on live cattle exports on a cents per kilogram basis, payable by the exporter.
Dairy cattle traded for dairy purposes are to be exempt from the transaction levy and the export charge.

The initial rates of levy and charge have been set in the bills to yield an income equivalent to that yielded under existing arrangements. Future adjustments to the rates will need to be approved by the industry annual general meeting, as is the current requirement.

The initial levy rates have been set so that the producer and the processor and exporter sectors share equally the cost of the AMLC and AMLRDC operations and this apportionment will apply during the first three years of the new arrangements. The producer sector has accepted the responsibility for the funding of the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign, known as BTEC, and the National Residue Survey, or NRS. The NRS is currently collected as part of the inspection fee collected from export abattoirs. Rather than collect a very small separate levy designated for the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, funding for this organisation is to be collected in with the AMLC levy and paid to the Consultative Council by the AMLC.

Given the experimental nature of the collection mechanisms, provision has been made for a three year trial period of the new arrangements. The current levies and charge can be reinstated at the rate operative at 31 December 1990 up to 30 June 1994. This provision will only be exercised in consultation with the AMLIPC.

The new arrangements are designed to achieve what the industry perceives as a more equitable and visible division of levy payments between producers and processors by clarifying their relative contributions to the AMLC and AMLRDC.

As part of this package the AMLIPC has also recommended the restructuring of the register of livestock producers established and maintained by the AMLC. Producers entered on this register are entitled to vote at the industry annual general meeting, along with those persons entered on the register of processors and exporters. The producers' register is to be divided into two registers-one for cattle producers and one for producers of sheep, buffalo and goats. The Processors' register will remain unchanged.

The practical difference resulting from this restructuring will be that only cattle producers and all meat processors will be able to vote on matters relating to rates of levy and charge on cattle, and only producers of livestock other than cattle and all processors will be able to vote on motions relating to levies and charge on those animals.

The AMLIPC has been able to demonstrate that there is a firm consensus within the Council on this issue, and that any objections to the new arrangements from outside bodies affected by the proposals have received detailed consideration.
The industry is aware of the increased costs of collection associated with the proposal, and has assured the Government it is willing to meet these costs.

Since 1988 the Government has recovered from industry the costs incurred in the collection of levies and charges. To contain these costs to some extent, the AMLIPC has requested that there be a lesser degree of audit in some minor collection areas. Again, the Council has assured the Government that it is aware that this measure could result in leakage.
The purpose of this Bill is to impose the levy on cattle sales and transfers of ownership and transfers from production to processing where no sale has taken place.

Separate rates of levy are struck for adult cattle and for bobby calves, and both rates contain separate components for the AMLC, AMLRDC, BTEC and the NRS. The Bill provides that the rates of levy may be altered by regulation, but specifies the maximum rates of levy that may be imposed in such a manner.
The operative rate of the transaction levy will be $5.83 for an adult beast. The maximum is set at $12.25. The equivalent rates for a bobby calf are $1 and $2.25.
Recommendations to adjust the rates of levy for AMLC and AMLRDC purposes must first be supported by an industry annual general meeting.
The levy is imposed on the person owning the cattle immediately before the change of ownership or immediately before delivery for processing.

The new arrangements will yield revenue approximately equal to that yielded under the present arrangements, and as the Commonwealth recovers all of its costs incurred in collection of levies and charges, there will be no net effect on consolidated revenue.

As mentioned earlier, the proposal has been initiated by the industry through the AMLIPC. The Government is pleased the industry has been able to come to the government through the policy council mechanism to present a united view on such a complex policy issue.
I commend the Bill to the honourable senators.
BEEF PRODUCTION LEVY BILL 1990
This Bill is another of the package of Bills that will introduce new levy and export charge arrangements for the cattle and beef industry from 1 January 1991.

The purpose of this Bill is to impose a levy on the production of beef at an operative level of 2.17 cents per kilogram of the gutted and trimmed carcass weighed within two hours of slaughter, or the hot carcass weight as it is termed in the trade. The levy is payable by the person owning the carcass immediately after its hot carcass weight is determined. This levy, in combination with the cattle transaction levy, will replace the current levy on the slaughter of cattle, calves and bobby calves imposed by the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964.
The levy contains components for the funding of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation.

As I have already outlined, the initial rate of levy has been specified in the Bill. This rate may be altered by regulation up to the specified maximum, which is 5 cents. Recommendations to adjust the rates of levy must first be supported by an industry annual general meeting.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
CATTLE EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1990

This Bill is another of the package of Bills that will introduce new levy and export charge arrangements for the cattle and beef industry from 1 January 1991. The new arrangements have been developed by the industry through the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council.

The purpose of this Bill is to impose a charge on the export of cattle from Australia. The charge will be on a cents per kilogram live weight basis, as opposed to the current per head charge imposed under the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977. The industry has recommended this change to bring the charge into line with the Beef Production Levy, which is on a cents per kilogram carcass weight basis. The rate of charge is set at half that of the beef production levy, or 1.09 cents per kilogram, to put it on a carcass weight equivalent basis, as about half the live weight is lost in gutting and trimming.
The charge contains components for the funding of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation.

While the initial rates of charge have been specified in the Bill, this rate may be altered by regulation up to the specified maximum of 2.5 cents per kilogram. Recommendations to adjust the rates of charge must first be supported by an industry annual general meeting.
The charge is payable by the owner of the cattle at the time of export.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
CATTLE AND BEEF LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1990
This Bill is part of the package of Bills that will introduce new levy and export charge arrangements for the cattle and beef industry from 1 January 1991.

This Bill provides the collection mechanisms for the new levies and charge imposed under the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill 1990, the Beef Production Levy Bill 1990 and the Cattle Export Charge Bill 1990.

To enable a more cost effective levy and charge collection procedure, the Bill provides for the collection of moneys from intermediaries such as selling agents, abattoir operators and feedlot operators. The Bill also provides for the reimbursement by persons primarily liable for levy and charge to these intermediaries. These arrangements will assist in keeping costs to a minimum by significantly reducing the number of collection points.

The Bill also provides for the due dates of levy or charge to be prescribed by regulation. This will allow flexibility in the collecting of moneys by permitting different collection periods depending on the amount of moneys to be collected and the sector of the industry it is to be collected from. This measure also has the potential to minimise the costs of collection.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
CATTLE INDUSTRY LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS)
BILL 1990
This Bill is part of the package of Bills that will introduce new levy and export charge arrangements for the cattle and beef industry from 1 January 1991.

This Bill amends the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Collection Act 1964 to allow payment of the moneys collected under the new levy and charge arrangements to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation and to the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account.

The Bill also amends the AMLC Act and the AMLRDC Act to allow the Corporations to make recommendations to the Minister on the rates of levy and charge under the new arrangements, and to restructure the register of livestock producers as outlined earlier.

The Bill also amends the AMLC Act and the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989 to provide for the Corporation to make an annual payment into the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account of the cattle industry's contribution.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the motion which includes the extra week of sitting from Monday, 26 November to Thursday, 29 November. Whilst the Opposition will meet the Government's program in relation to this week, we protest that it is being introduced at this time. We plan our diaries and commitments according to the program that the Government sets down for us. That program had this particular week as a week in which the Senate would not be sitting. Yesterday we received notice that the Senate will sit which not only is of great inconvenience to honourable senators but, more importantly, is an inconvenience to those with whom they had made appointments for that week. A number of my colleagues have important obligations that week covering all of Australia, and those commitments cannot now be met.

SPEECH.PARA: The important point is that, if the Government had planned its program with any degree of reasonable competence, it would have known a long time ago whether that week had to be a sitting week. Of course, it did not do that. I have protested before that when this sitting of the Senate started there was next to no Government business to be transacted, as a result of which an enormous backlog has developed and the Government now requires these extra sitting weeks to overcome the result of its mismanagement.

As of a couple of days ago, apart from the Appropriation Bills, which have to be dealt with, the Government expected the Senate to process about 87 Bills before it rises at Christmas time. After discussions and negotiations yesterday, the Government has reduced that number of Bills to about 68, plus the Appropriation package.

It is obvious as we are now well into November that that workload cannot be dealt with in any reasonable way between now and Christmas. In an effort to find some further sitting days, the Government has sought to add this sitting week. It is a reasonable expectation that there will be another notice of motion before too long from the Government looking for the Senate to sit yet another week at the end of the program, which will take the Senate through to Christmas. As I said at the outset, I rise simply to protest that the Government cannot get its business in order. Any reasonable degree of competence would have meant that the Government knew the weeks it would require the Senate to sit. I only hope that it can lift its game in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to oppose the motion but I wish to raise a matter now which I referred to briefly yesterday-the question of time not being made available to discuss very important issues in this chamber. One of the very important issues that needs to be discussed in this chamber-indeed, we are obliged to discuss it-relates to treaties. Twice every year a bundle of treaties is brought into this chamber and dumped on the table and we have virtually no time to discuss them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that time be made available to discuss these treaties. The reason for that, of course, is the existence of the constitutional provision, section 51.(xxix.), the external affairs power. The Government can use that power in order to implement the articles of conventions or the provisions of treaties to, for example, supersede State laws.

Yesterday, the Government came in here and dumped another 31 treaties on the table. One of those treaties was the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Another was an International Labour Organisation convention relating to disability. The first, in particular, is contentious. A number of valid and reasoned criticisms have been made of articles of the Convention or, more particularly, of the possible interpretations of articles in the Convention by informed critics.

I raised this point yesterday and indicated that I was to move a motion at the appropriate time for the suspension of Standing Orders to enable the discussion on these treaties to take place. I did not proceed with that because when it was discussed around the chamber it was felt that it was not appropriate to bring it on immediately but time should be made-I think that was the general view around the chamber-for discussions of these treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proper debate.

—And as Senator Walters said, a proper debate. I am informed that during the Whips' meeting this morning that matter was raised by, I think, the Opposition Whip, Senator Reid, and, perhaps, the Australian Democrats Whip, Senator McLean. The response, I am informed, from the Government is that time will not be available until next year.
—Too late.

—Senator Walters interjects, `too late'. It possibly will be too late because, as I understand it from messages emanating from the office of the Attorney-General, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) intends to recommend the ratification of the treaty within the next six or eight weeks. If that takes place before the Parliament has had an opportunity of discussing it, that would be an action of the Government thumbing its nose at the elected representatives of the people about a very important matter. It would also be a clear dereliction of duty on the part of the Government to receive the considered views of elected members of the Parliament in the context of a formal debate about treaties in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of my rising is to say that if we are going to have another week of sittings, surely the Government should be able to put aside sufficient time in which these important matters are able to be discussed in this chamber. Mr President, I appreciate the tolerance that you have had in allowing me to make these remarks, but I think that they are pertinent to the question of an additional week. I hope that the Government will act honourably and properly in this matter and allow time for debate on these very important matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill made the point about diary problems because of the institution of the extra week's sitting. I am very conscious of that. I regret that this extra week was necessary and I regret the inconvenience caused to honourable senators. I think it was first flagged by Senator Richardson when he was Acting Manager of Government Business that we may have to sit that week, and I must say that from that point I resisted trying to put in the extra week for as long as I could. But having looked at the remaining essential program and the time that I thought the Senate would need to devote to it, I could not imagine our doing that in nearly three weeks of sittings rather than four. I think most of us assume that the Appropriation Bills will not be concluded until the end of next week. In spite of the reforms brought in by the Procedures Committee, I do not expect to save one minute in the Estimates Committee when it goes into Committee of the Whole. That should not surprise anyone here. Reforms here last about five seconds.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Senator Hill went on to make the point that we should improve the situation. I agree that we should, but Bills come in too late as they did under Senator Hill's Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We never sat on until 21 December. We never sat as late as that.

—Of course, but you never had the same obstructionism as we sometimes meet. Although I must say that if I had to make a choice between Senator Walters and Senator McLaren, I would probably prefer Senator Walters when it comes to obstructing business.

SPEECH.PARA: To try to be a little more constructive and to try to tackle this particular problem, we have changed the cut-off points for drafting instructions for future Bills so as to force Bills to come in earlier. That will not be seen this session but hopefully it will be seen in the next session. Unless a Bill is absolutely urgent and unless departments and Ministers meet those drafting instructions, those Bills will not be listed on the timetable next year.

Secondly, the point has been made in this chamber, and has been implied again today, that maybe we do not sit enough. Next autumn the House of Representatives will sit for 10 weeks and the Senate will sit for a minimum of 12 weeks. That will make far more time available to debate legislation and other matters. I am quite happy to sit for 14 weeks by the way, right through until the end of July; it does not bother me.

The third point in those reforms-I think it is essential and I think the message got through-is that once the House of Representatives finishes with the Bills that the Senate will look at this year, it should get on and start passing some Bills for us for next session-not ones we will consider this session, but Bills that are drafted and available. I am hoping that at least 10, 15 or 20 Bills will go through the House of Representatives later this year after the cut-off point and be available for the Senate early next year. That has two advantages. First, that we will start with a large stockpile and, secondly, everyone here gets a lot more notice of what is coming up and can do an analysis of it. As yet this is all hope rather than necessary realisation, but I will certainly be pushing the process along.

It was said that at one stage we ran out of business. I remind the Senate that we did have business. We could have taken the industrial relations Bill and other material, but because of necessary arrangements and as honourable senators were fulfilling duties elsewhere we could not bring on that Bill at that particular time. I do not put any blame on that, but I am saying that as much as possible on this side, when spokesmen are not available on this side or among the Australian Democrats or elsewhere, we try to fit that program around those spokesmen too. Sometimes that is the reason for not having sufficient information.

The final point is that the cut-off motion sounded a great thing in theory when former Senator Michael Macklin first moved it. At the time of the shift in the Liberal Party leadership just before the last election it was suggested that it was not such a great concept any more. I do not know whether that was because an election was about to come up and those opposite were confident that they would be in government. But at times it is forcing an unnecessary guillotine through the House of Representatives, and I do not think that it is as productive as it once was. I will not oppose it this time, but I ask honourable senators to think about the overall consequences of the cut-off and whether it is working as effectively and as originally intended.

In summary, we do not like to add this extra week. I know the diary problems it would have caused for honourable senators not only on the Opposition side but also right around the chamber. That is a matter for regret. I hope that by setting out a clear sitting pattern for the first half of next year we will be able to stick to that pattern. Basically it will be two weeks on and two weeks off, with one or two modifications. It will be a 12-week sitting aimed to end at the end of June if, having been given that amount of time, the Senate can put its mind to passing legislation in that timeframe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek the leave of the Senate to allow the Manager of Government Business in the Senate to answer the points I raised in my response to the motion.
—It is a matter for Senator Ray.

—I have taken on board Senator Harradine's comments, but I have no response at this stage. They are not matters that I have a detailed knowledge of and I do not intend to respond now. But I do not intend to totally ignore them either. When I get a chance I will look at the point he has made.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1990-91APPROPRIATION BILL (No.2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening when I was able to commence my comments on the Appropriation Bills I concentrated on the important relationship between this year's Budget and the outcomes of the recent Premiers Conference, particularly their effect on regional and northern Australia. This morning I would like to concentrate more specifically on the effects of the Budget on northern Australia across a number of portfolios.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that in the last six months there has been a Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Senator Collins is charged with that ministerial responsibility. Therefore, we would normally have expected that there would have been a great deal of coordination, cooperation and improvement in many of the areas that affect the northern Australian portfolio. Unfortunately, as we all know, Senator Collins is a Mr Fix It and a hatchet man. He is a man of great confusion and conflict, particularly when it comes to his portfolio. I seriously contend that in his exercising of ministerial responsibilities Senator Collins has been a pathetic and miserable failure. He demonstrates a real dichotomy of character that can probably be described as a very public and caring Dr Jekyll in the electorate but yet a savage Mr Hyde in his official ministerial roles. He has not contributed in any way to improving things in northern Australia.

Looking carefully at the issues that I raised last night arising from the Premiers Conference, a number do require major new reforms for northern Australia, particularly as they affect the administra- tion of areas such as Aboriginal land rights and the national parks in the Northern Territory, as well as taxation, especially sales tax and the goods and services tax which has been proposed by the Opposition. We have seen a contrary and opposing stance taken on these issues by Senator Collins rather than a cooperative one.

One of the things that concern me most is the fact that the Government is seeking to camouflage its capital works program. During the Estimates I ascertained from both the Department of Finance and the Department of Administrative Services that the Government no longer intends to produce the capital works program documentation that enables us to see the projects as they operate in the construction industries around Australia, particularly northern Australia. There is no longer confidence of planning in the construction industry of northern Australia. There is no longer an underpinning of the economics of that area. I know that groups such as the Master Builders Association and the Confederation of Australian Industry share my concern in these areas.

The second area I wish to address is that important portfolio that impacts on northern Australia, Aboriginal affairs. Obviously Senator Collins has a coordination role in this area. We all know that in the last Parliament he was not able to achieve much of a relationship with the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. Things have not improved under the administration of the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner. We are again seeing a procrastination in producing both results and, more importantly, information to this Parliament.

On 23 August this year I put a question on the Notice Paper-it is question No. 155, if honourable senators would like to refer to it-requesting information about Government expenditure on all Aboriginal programs affected by Commonwealth departments. Not one skerrick of that information has been provided. Yet, in past years, the Government crowed from the roof tops about its record and achievements in all of those areas. But because it has been subjected to Senate accountability and scrutiny and it is obviously now embarrassed, the Government is no longer game to produce that sort of statement, just like the capital works program, which would identify project slippage. We now see that the Government is not prepared to own up and show its total expenditure in the very important Aboriginal areas.

I have continually asked questions about issues such as the Arnhem Land plebiscite that was held for Aboriginal people months ago in the Northern Territory. The answer to my question on notice No. 190, which came back this week, can only be described as tomfoolery and humbuggery. I have had to put another question down to pursue that issue further.

The turnout in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election in the last fortnight was pathetic. What do Ministers Tickner and Collins seek to do? They seek to hide behind the camouflage of comparing the election to local government. That is a totally inappropriate way to approach these Aboriginal issues.

Very important issues relating to Aboriginal people, such as the plebiscite, need to be addressed. The Barunga bark painting that was presented under controversial circumstances to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) several years ago is still locked up in Mr Hand's office. That matter has not been pursued; what should happen to it has not been settled with the Aboriginal leaders of northern Australia. The bark painting is a very important symbol to Aboriginal people. It is causing major problems. Aboriginal leaders are arguing that it is even causing death in the Aboriginal community.

Questions asked at the Estimates this year about the Northern Land Council (NLC) have again been ducked and shoved. I put a question on notice about a possible libel and defamation claim against the NLC Chairman for $1m. The first time round I got a wrong answer and sent it back. I now have a second qualified answer. But, of course, it contains nothing to substantiate whether the Government will have to stand behind a possible $1m defamation. The cover-up is obvious.

The community development employment projects (CDEP) scheme, whereby communities elect to go off the various social security pensions and put in place appropriate community projects, is very important. The definitions of the entitlements on these projects obviously need a lot of cleaning up. They are very unclear. When there are groups such as creches and pensioners who undertake only home duties being identified as recipients for CDEP funds, it calls into serious question matters which the Government has not addressed.

When we look at the other associated portfolios we see that Senator Collins is not having the effect that he should. There are continuing problems in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs, which is of crucial importance to northern Australia. A large number of migrants have come to, developed and settled well in northern Australia. Fishing incursions into our waters beg other priorities. We have had refugees and boat people. We still have all those continuing issues.

It is obvious that the animosity and the tension between Ministers Hand and Collins continue. I have received a copy of an administrative circular from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, dated 23 October 1990, which in effect sets down guidelines for section heads and regional officers in dealing with Senator Collins. It talks about certain arrangements and how information should be provided to Senator Collins. I quote from this document:
Consequent upon this arrangement officers must ensure that appropriate material is sent to Mr Hand's office.
Further down it states:
Officers should be alert to identifying appropriate material and forwarding it in the usual way to the Minister's office.

Senator Collins has been invited to contact, in the first instance, Mr Hand's office for information on immigration and ethnic affairs matters and Ms Fatin's office for information on local government issues.

Any member of parliament should be able to approach the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on important matters that relate to either policy or administration and not be constrained. But obviously there is a great deal of tension and sensitivity between Mr Hand and Senator Collins, to the extent that Senator Collins is now being nobbled. This makes sure that the Department now ensures that this will be dealt with in a very different and suspicious manner. I find the particular administrative memo of serious concern to the constituents of northern Australia, who are vitally affected by such an area.

If we look at the important portfolio area that Senator Collins has to administer within the range of activities in transport and communications, again we see a number of confusions and conflicts. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, of course, has been making a number of initiatives with regard to telecommunications and some of them have met with support and development by the Opposition in this very important area. But I seem to recall that in early September Senator Collins came in to the Senate and tipped a bucket over the development of policies in that area by the Opposition, particularly with regard to the funding of telecommunications for remote and rural Australia. He went all out on that stance. However, a day or so later his senior Minister, Mr Beazley, said:

I do give the Opposition credit for one thing ... there is only one way to meet Community Service obligations and that is to put them on budget. There is no other way of doing it, and at least the Opposition has had the honesty to acknowledge that.
What a different stance that is from that taken in this place, in public forums and in the media by Senator Collins. Obviously he has unsettling differences in that area with his own senior Minister.

Similarly, in relation to transport, in early September I put down a series of questions on notice in the Estimates committee hearings relating to airports, airport leasing and remote air services. I have received several of those answers in the last few days. They have dribbled in. They are inadequate and they will have to be pursued. Probably the most important one, with regard to the construction timetable for the Darwin and Alice Springs airports and with regard to the provision of information from the Federal Airports Corporation concerning funding programs for those projects, is still outstanding. Yet Senator Collins-who right through the recent Northern Territory election was out leading the charge on many of those issues-because I was absent from the country, was obviously keeping all of these questions and answers under wraps so that they would not surface as issues in the Northern Territory election campaign.

I find it totally inappropriate that a Minister should treat the electorate with such contempt on such important matters. It is some six or eight weeks since these questions were first put down and they have not yet been properly answered. When we get down to talking about the important needs relating to those airports at Darwin and Alice Springs, there has to be an early determination with the airlines to ensure that the travelling public will not be fleeced with additional costs and additional air fares as a result of the outstanding matters, but we have not yet seen those areas addressed.

Similarly, there are concerns with the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, who is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, the portfolio in which Senator Collins is involved. Given their factional differences, it must be a very hard task to reconcile properly a number of common issues in that area. For example, the Australian Labor Party currently has a special committee with regard to the review of the uranium mining policy in its Federal platform. That committee's work has somehow been kept under wraps-I presume by Mr Snowdon's factional groups in the Left-to prevent it from reporting in any way that would have contributed to the very proper debate at the recent Premiers Conference. That report has now been extended and dragged out and it does not look like it will surface at all. Senator Collins is an important member of that committee but we cannot yet get any obvious commitment with regard to the future of the important uranium projects in northern Australia.

Mr Snowdon, from the socialist Left, obviously has the upper hand in thwarting Senator Collins in these important developments. It puts Senator Collins in a unique situation that certainly is not complimentary to his administration of the portfolio, and is certainly not in the interests of the people of northern Australia who need to see these important economic projects developed. We all know that there are adequate safeguards environmentally and economically in place, and the market will well and truly look after the sales that need to take place.

It is also of concern that in the recent Northern Territory Government election Senator Collins was not able to provide any decent leadership to the Labor Party. It is very important to note that he took a high profile position in the election and in supporting particular candidates. I respect him for the role he played with regard to Stanley Tipiloura, who is ill, and I give credit to Senator Collins on the help he gave. However, with regard to promoting the Commonwealth record in the Northern Territory, he obviously failed to achieve any success, because the result speaks for itself.

We know that Senator Collins ran most of the press campaign for the election from his office. The journalists constantly gathered like honeybees to the pot around Senator Collins's office for the duration of that campaign, yet the paid election advertising-particularly on television-featuring Senator Collins did not mention the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Mr Terry Smith. It was very cunning politics. Obviously Senator Collins knew that the slippery slide was well oiled and that Mr Smith was disappearing. There was no support forthcoming in that particular area and any political analysis of the Northern Territory election campaign will show that Senator Collins does not stand out with any credit.

One of the issues that was very transparent in that campaign was Mr Smith's proposals for a dramatic new Labor shipping policy for northern Australia encompassing relationships with Papua New Guinea. Coincidentally, one of my questions that did not get answered in the Estimates committee until last week related to that issue-and in that answer the Commonwealth Government walks away from any recognition or identification with such a policy. It just shows the very transparent nature of Senator Collins's two-faced failure in the election campaign.

Finally, I would like to comment on the issues relating to constituents of northern Australia who have to face the important problems created by isolation. There are a couple of issues that surface in this year's Budget that drastically affect people living in isolation. One is the servicing, through the Department of Transport and Communications, of the remote area services subsidy which provides finance to enable people living in remote areas to receive their mail in an appropriate way and, in particular, to receive the education material for children studying in isolated areas. I am well aware that the Isolated Children's Parents Association has made many representations on this issue.

The Estimates question which surfaced on this matter last week, again after the Northern Territory election had been finalised, and which had been put on notice six or eight weeks previous to that-is just a restatement of the facts. It is no commitment to any change, it is no commitment by the Government to recognise the needs that relate to people, particularly the children, living in isolated parts of Australia.

The other matter that came up, after being on notice since 19 September, related to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the provision of particular programs on children's educational radio. I invite honourable senators and any interested person to look carefully at the detailed answer that has been given by the ABC that, yes, these important children's educational programs are going to be cut because of the Government's adjustments to, and harsh Budget treatment of, the ABC and, similarly, that there is now an indication that Budget cuts will also flow over to children's television educational programs. I was given the following answer when I asked which programs would be involved:

All program purchasing will cease and there will be no new ABC Education production. Children's programs (`The Afternoon Show', `Play School' and `Mr Squiggle') will continue. Transmission of schools programs will be reduced from five hours a day this year to two hours per day of primary and secondary programs next year. Production of `Behind the News',` Asia Wise,' and `For the Juniors' will continue. School's television service for the remainder of 1990 will not be affected. In 1991 the service will be reduced to between one and two hours per day for 30 to 40 weeks of the year. In 1992 there will be no school's service.

So we see a very dramatic change that is going to affect many people who rely heavily on these programs. It is important to recognise that remote parts of Australia, including northern Australia, are in confusion. There are major conflicts being caused by the lack of attention by Ministers, and in particular by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, Senator Collins. I referred to him earlier as a public Dr Jekyll in the electorate and a savage Mr Hyde in his official role. Perhaps I am wrong in that definition, because Senator Collins does not even have to take a magic potion to fulfil his dichotomy of character.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today discussing the Government's Appropriation Bills which are intended to implement the Government's Budget strategy, which in turn is intended to give direction to this nation in its economic and social advancement. Unfortunately, it does nothing of the sort.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I enter into the debate in substance, I wish to express my personal appreciation for the speech delivered here two days ago by Senator Peter Baume, who I think challenged both his own Party and the Government on the substance of the direction we are taking as a nation. The Government is abdicating responsibility to the market-that is what this Government's Budget does-egged on by the other old parties, the Liberal-National Party coalition. Senator Peter Baume called on the Senate to make judgments on values and priorities which take account of human values. Unfortunately, we have abdicated that responsibility to the markets and Senator Peter Baume's voice will be missed when he leaves. I note that his voice of conscience is now a little less muffled than it was before he had decided to leave this chamber.

Unfortunately the party system, which is not even in the Constitution, has shackled the intellect and consciences of many honourable senators and members in the other House so that they place more importance on secondary objectives, party politics and staying in power than on the direction that this nation should take and on the direction that we in this House should take in attempting to fulfil the aspirations of Australians. Fortunately, not all members of this House have been shackled in this way. I refer to the other speech in this debate which I think has been noteworthy, and that is the speech by Senator Barney Cooney, who similarly has expressed independent and humanitarian principles which I think the Senate as a whole should take note of.

There are a number of essential objectives that we as a nation should pursue. We should attempt to become economically productive yet fair, sustainable, and independent. Our society should be just, and culturally we should be creative and intellectually rigorous. We should be the clever as well as the just society. Unfortunately, the prevailing fashion-I should say dogma-is that this is not the responsibility of government; that it is not our responsibility as parliamentary representatives of the nation to work towards and realise the aspirations of Australians, and to work towards such a just society. Instead, we are prepared to abdicate that responsibility to financial markets and foreign financiers. This abdication of responsibility has not served us well as a nation. A society should be judged by the Rawlesian principle; that is, how it deals with those people who are most disadvantaged in society.

When we look at the position we have arrived at, it does us no credit at all. The Smith Family has reported that in the last four months there has been a 40 per cent increase in emergency relief requests. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has documented that currently we still have 310,000 children living in absolute poverty. The Australian Council of Social Service has documented that 10 per cent of Australians own 60 per cent of the nation's wealth and that 72 per cent of incomes are below average weekly earnings, and yet we are a low taxed country. We are eighteenth of 23 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries at the moment. We are also the meanest in terms of expenditure on income support, health, housing and employment. We spend 12.8 per cent of gross domestic product on these, while the international average is 18.8 per cent. For example, France spends 20 per cent in those areas and the Netherlands spends 29 per cent.

Three million Australians are entitled to health cards and are therefore officially classified by the Government as disadvantaged. We can see what this policy does to some members of our society who, I would say, are the least advantaged. Let us look at our Aboriginal community. Life expectancy for ordinary non-Aboriginal male Australians is 72 years; for Aborigines, depending on the region, it ranges from 48 to 61. For non-Aboriginal females life expectancy is 79 years, while for female Aborigines, again depending on the region, it ranges from 57 to 65 years. The infant mortality rate-a very good measure-for all Australians is 9.6 per thousand; for Aborigines it is 29 per thousand. In other words, it is three times as bad. Income per head for all Australians is $9,395, while for Aborigines it is $4,829, which is approximately half.

Let me turn to the other area of concern. If we are to develop a society which is indeed a sustainable society, we must consider the environment. For 200 years we have chopped down forests, polluted rivers, degraded farmland and wasted energy. The old parties have learnt nothing. A recent report found that Federal government funding for renewable energy sources has fallen 88 per cent in real terms in the 12 years since 1978. In December 1987, in response to pressure from the Australian Democrats, the Government undertook to spend $5m over five years through a renewable energy research trust account funded from oil tax revenue. This commitment has been broken in the Budget we are now discussing.

Recently the Federal Government set a heavily qualified target of a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2025, but the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has found that CO2 emissions would have to fall from the present global average of 1.45 tonnes per person to 0.35 tonnes, a drop of 76 per cent, in order to stabilise atmospheric concentrations. I should compare that with Australia, where emissions are approximately 4.5 tonnes per person. Thus, we would have to reduce our emissions to less than 8 per cent of current levels to meet the global average. Anything less implies an indefinite continuation of the existing global inequity in access to energy.

The third essential element is to build Australia as an economy which is independent and competitive in the international environment-an economy for Australians. Here the prospects and the current situation are getting worse by the day. On 5 November, the Age reported that the current net outflow of interest is $11.9 billion per annum-in other words, $700 per head of population for every woman, man and child. There is another measure for that. It is 20 per cent of export income, and at the level of 25 per cent international bankers start cutting off credit. Clearly, the high interest rate strategy that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has instigated to bring down our foreign debt has not worked, but it has had its costs. We have rising unemployment and a rising wave of bankruptcies in business, both small and big. The result of blind faith in dogma and the primacy of haphazard or, worse, manipulated market forces has not been successful. It has been demonstrated to be devoid of any consideration for human values.

This lack of consideration for human values and aspirations has been deplored by Senators Baume and Cooney, and the Australian Democrats would call on both old parties to take heed. It might, of course, suit them not to do so because it relieves them of the responsibility to tackle priorities on the basis of human needs and on the long term future of this country. Why is this so? Perhaps one of the sources for this trend can be found in the way in which we treat our education and the way in which our bureaucrats influence our decision makers.

Dr Michael Pusey, Associate Professor of Sociology at the University of New South Wales, has documented in a recent paper the dominance of New Right economists in Canberra. Seventy-one per cent of the Senior Executive Service consists of economists, and most of them in his view and on the basis of his research are right wing conservatives. They represent the technical view of economics; in other words, the value free characterisation of economics. Three quarters of them approve of total deregulation of the labour market and all of them, according to Dr Pusey, exhibit:
. . . a residual view of society as some kind of stubbornly resisting sludge that inhibits and obstructs the economy.

In other words, we exist for the economy rather than the economy for the people. It is therefore not surprising that this attitude is reflected in the parliamentary action of the old parties. In recent years both of them have combined to vote against some Democrat initiatives which are worth noting. There were the amendments to the social security legislation which opposed the deferral of indexation increases for pensioners and opposed the increase in the rent assistance threshold, which has deprived many needy people of rent assistance, and the postponement of poverty trap measures. Both old parties have voted against those amendments.

There was also a Democrat amendment to disallow tax deductibility for tobacco advertising and other promotional activities which are a source of danger for the health of the nation, and yet both parties voted against it. Both of them also opposed our amendment trying to stop increased charges for freedom of information access. They opposed the amendment that sought to initiate greater use of environmental impact statements, as well as the private member's Bill and amendments to protect the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania. And so it goes on.

I note with a great deal of satisfaction that some of the Independent members of Parliament, and in this place in particular-Senator Brian Harradine, Senator Jo Vallentine, former Senator Irina Dunn and former Senator Robert Woods-have in most cases supported initiatives of this type which advance the interests of the nation in attempting to get a country which is economically vigorous, socially just and environmentally responsible. I note with a great deal of pleasure that former Senator Robert Woods has now joined the Australian Democrats in New South Wales. His joining is a sign of things to come. In the long term it is inevitable that the independent spirits who care about human values combine to fight the old parties in this House.

This continuing trend was given a push at last weekend's National Executive meeting of the Australian Democrats which passed a resolution calling on all State divisions to establish committees and working groups to work with like-minded organisations and parties to bring about a common direction in perhaps the most important challenge facing us in politics in the next few years.

In my line-up of amendments and initiatives which both of the old parties have obstructed, I should have included some recent amendments that I moved in this place. I would have thought that they were obvious ones for both of the other parties to support. However, they were rejected. They were the amendments which sought to exempt from sales tax equipment used by disabled people, recycled paper products to the extent that they were not already exempted, and recycled plastic products.

These were rejected by the Government saying that at some stage it may well introduce similar amendments. They were rejected by the coalition parties with Senator Watson saying that the coalition parties basically did not think they should interfere with the Government's Budget strategy. Clearly, that has now been shot to bits-it is rather a joke-with the coalition's recent attempt, for the sake of $1m of postal charges, to stop the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for ordinary annual services and to run the risk, were that Bill to come back, of ultimately deferring or stopping Supply.

How can Senator Watson or anyone else on that side now say that he will not vote for an amendment that seeks to improve a Government Budget Bill-a money Bill that is not Supply-on the ground that the coalition should not interfere with the Budget strategy of the Government? Does the coalition really wish to become totally impotent and agree to everything the Government puts forward? Does not the coalition accept the role of this place as a House of review?

If the members of the coalition wanted to amend the Supply Bill why could they not have taken $43.5m from the defence budget item No. 230 and reallocate it to step up action on youth homelessness? That has been shown to have been neglected again by both State and Federal governments and by both major parties. Mr Burdekin, whose report entitled Our Homeless Children was published two years ago, recently released a summary and overview by the Victorian Council of Services which stated:
Both Federal and Victorian governments have had a minimal response despite the evidence of Our Homeless Children and the continued advocacy from community organisations.
If the Opposition really wanted to mess around with the Supply Bill, why did it not pick up that issue?

In considering whether a Budget strategy is sacrosanct, one need not rely on this last little escapade of the coalition parties. A quick check of the business in this place over the past two years would reveal at least five occasions on which the Opposition parties were not loath to amend Budget or money Bills. That clearly shows the Opposition will only deal with amendments when it suits it. It is not prepared to judge them on the value they represent to the nation's economic and social well-being. I will name a few of the amendments. Senator Haines moved an amendment to alleviate potential and actual disadvantage to a particular group of people as a result of changes following the legislation on assets in the break-up of marriage. The Opposition supported that yet that was a money Bill. Senator Bishop moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) to excise the whole of the 15 per cent tax on investment income in the hands of complying superannuation funds.

I do not express any value judgment on the amendment. I am simply pointing to the fact that the Opposition parties have not resiled, when it has suited them, from amending money Bills. Therefore, I challenge them that if they really want to change the direction of the Government, if they really want to achieve some of the reforms they say that they are serious about, it is in their hands to do so.

Fortunately, it is possible to do that, as the Australian Democrats have indeed done, and as they have shown in their alternative Budget which was put forward before the Treasurer submitted his. We have shown in that Budget that it is possible to increase revenue by $7 billion to create room for those measures which we believe are important for this nation. We have provided increased child-care and support services for psychiatric and heavily disabled persons and a 20 per cent boost to the home and community care program for a total of $163m. We have doubled the funding for grant in aid workers for ethnic communities and provided for a 20 per cent boost in real terms for legal aid.

We have increased the young homeless allowance and the disability allowances-a total of $32.5m. We have provided an incentive that the first $1,000 of interest earned will be free of tax through a tax rebate of 39 per cent, at a cost to revenue of $600m but with a potential to gear up the savings ratio of this nation so that we can accumulate our own funds instead of relying on foreign loans. And so it goes on.

We have also shown in this alternative Budget that it is possible to achieve this by increasing the Government's revenue. That is the strategy that should have been followed instead of the strategy that has brought us to our knees with bankruptcies and unemployment. We have suggested a 39 per cent withholding tax on interest paid to overseas lenders to stop tax avoidance rorts which have been recently disclosed in this area. This would raise $600m-and that is a conservative estimate. We have suggested a one per cent Commonwealth land tax on the improved value of land held by absentee foreign landowners.
