A similar tax was applied between 1910 and 1953. That would yield $100m. A tightening of tax haven legislation would yield $250m. Taxing trusts as companies with imputation rights and exemptions for public charities and other genuine trusts would yield $100m.

The abolition of negative gearing on properties would yield $100m and the phasing out of existing arrangements would yield another $200m. An individual's wealth tax of one per cent per annum on net wealth over $1m-the millionaire's tax-with an additional $500,000 exemption for genuine family farms would yield $500m, and so it goes on. This time we have documented where the money is coming from. It is now up to the other parties, the old parties, to deny that this can be done and shrink back from those measures that need to be taken to make us a nation that is independent, environmentally responsible, socially just and economically vigorous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bills, it is a sad and sorry tale that has to be told. Although there might be some feeling of respite this morning for the Government, the overall picture for Australia, despite the wish of the Government not to use the word `recession', is a most depressing one. On this morning's television it was easy to see interviews with people who have lost their jobs and people who are facing complete readjustments to their lives because the economy has plummeted, and there is no hope at all being offered by the strategies of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at our debt, our balance of trade, our interest rates and our unemployment numbers, we see that, although once they may have been beautiful figures to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to the ordinary Australian they are monuments to his policy failings. Unemployment is running at 7.4 per cent. Motor vehicle registrations have fallen on last year's figures by almost 3 per cent each month since August. The percentage annual change of dwelling approvals has been in negative figures for every month since June 1988. New capital expenditure and manufacturing production are in steep decline. We have a debt of $150 billion and still climbing.

Let us not allow the Government's jargon to mislead people. This is not just an economic downturn. It is a recession. High interest rates have led to record levels of personal bankruptcies and small business failures and collapse in investment. High interest rates have made the balance of trade worse, not better, and maintained our exchange rates at above long term competitive levels.

So to inflation-and the brief respite that came through this morning. No doubt the Government will attempt to grandstand on what appears to be a reasonable inflation figure of 6 per cent announced this morning, but a couple of points have to be made. First, the figure was achieved during the period of the price freeze on petrol prices. This means that to a certain extent the figure is illusory because actual fuel prices were being blown out of the water by Hussein during this period. Secondly, and in some ways more importantly, the figure is a direct consequence of the collapse in asset prices brought about by policies of this Government. In other words, the trend of corporate decline from the television industry to the likes of Elders and Adsteam and smaller business failures is now being reflected in the general price level. This provides no reason for gloating. It provides good reason for concern.

With the trend towards higher unemployment and a lower although unsustainable inflation rate, the Treasurer will find an even bigger problem on his hands with the Australian Labor Party. This is the two-edged sword for a Labor government. With Caucus members rolling the Treasurer on the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank earlier this week, they will definitely be wanting to flex their muscles. The old style left wing will emerge; there will be pressure to control unemployment through fiscal expansion. During the entire period that stringent measures have been tightened in the economy, we have had the bleep from the Government that it came to office with high unemployment, that it has indeed succeeded in lowering that unemployment and that that has been its big success-whereas, of course, we are seeing the turnaround of that, and as a result of the Government's own policies. The left of the Party certainly will be moving to try to alleviate what it sees as a problem for its side of the faction debate.

Without appreciating the linkages of wages to fiscal policy under this Government, which I will deal with later, as I said, the left of the Labor Party and the union movement will aim to trade off lower unemployment for the higher inflation figure. Should this happen, then the Government's attempts to control the aggregate demand through monetary policy will have been for nought. Perhaps today will not be the joyous one that the Treasurer may have thought it would be for him personally, although the lower inflation rate certainly is pleasing for the Australian economy as a whole.

The 1990-91 Budget itself tells a sorry story of lost opportunity for a government failing to inject incentive into our taxation system, failing to rein in government spending and failing to boost national savings. In the current financial year total public sector spending is set to grow at 2.75 per cent-faster than our national production-and the Budget cut only $350m from the forward projections in a total Budget of $93 billion. That represents a cut of only 0.4 of one per cent.

To put the Government's expenditure cuts into perspective, the coalition outlined $3 billion worth of expenditure cuts in our Economic Action Plan prior to the last election. It was almost 10 times what the Government has achieved in its last Budget. It makes a lie of the Government claim that it was a tough Budget. It was not. What little restraint in fiscal policy that has occurred under Labor over the previous seven years has been achieved by cutting Commonwealth Government capital expenditure. But in the 1990-91 Budget, even capital expenditure has proved resistant to further cuts. It is of concern that the winding back of the public infrastructure spending has occurred without any clear vision of what will take its place. This is evidenced by the total lack of public debate on the privatisation of public infrastructure. Indeed, as long as we go on having a system of cash accounting to deal with public expenditure and as long as we do not start to provide for the maintenance in an on-going way for our infrastructure costs, we will continue to meet this problem.

Recurrent expenditure has been left virtually untouched. There are no significant cuts in welfare spending, which is set to rise by 5.7 per cent in real terms. This amounts to the biggest increase in the last seven years. So much for tax reform in the latest Budget. The Treasurer handed back a meagre $1.2 billion in tax cuts. What he neglected to say was that he took double that amount in bracket creep from taxpayers in the last financial year alone.

The Budget has already been totally discredited by the unrealistic Budget assumptions. Saddam Hussein may have blown the Treasurer's prediction on oil prices out of the water, but he can blame no-one when his own figures on growth, unemployment and inflation have been inaccurate. The Treasurer's failure on the assumption has torn apart the Government's strategy on wages, interest rates and foreign debt. We have heard, since the last election, a lot of focus on the micro-economy and I will say a few words about that a little later. But there is a need to look at the macro-economy also.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a lot of his so-called unholy trinity-fiscal policy, monetary policy and wages policy-but there is nothing solemn about the way the Government has chosen to exercise these policies. Fiscal policy has been tied to wages policy through the wage-tax trade-off. This has reduced the flexibility of fiscal policy. It now seems obvious that this decision has led to the limit of fiscal restraint which has now been reached. What is needed is further fiscal restraint to enhance national savings as an anti-inflationary device to complement monetary policy.

However, there was nothing in the Budget to boost national savings. There was no increase in total public sector savings as the Commonwealth surplus was broadly offset by deficits in the States. I would, however, single out, as Mr Whitlam seems to have done this morning, New South Wales and say that Mr Greiner has proved to be a man who is tackling the problems of the 1990s in a way that the Labor Premiers have neither the inclination nor the ability to do. Due to the exaggerated growth forecast in the Budget, there may actually be a drop in national savings.

With the interaction of the wage-tax trade-off, the effect of fastening together fiscal and wages policies has been to impose the bulk of the burden of aggregate demand restraint onto monetary policy. Monetary policy is of limited effectiveness in achieving the objectives of low inflation and a smaller current account deficit. What has happened is that a tight monetary policy has led to an unnaturally high exchange rate, despite some Reserve Bank intervention in the foreign exchange market, and crippling interest rates.

High interest rates have strangled investment demand and caused considerable hardship for ordinary families struggling to meet their mortgage payments. There is a need for an expressed anti-inflationary policy. The Government is totally without any realistic strategy to fight inflation. The expression of unexpected surprise and delight on the Treasurer's face this morning simply shows that the result that we have had this morning was in no way planned nor anticipated from Government planned policy.

What the Treasurer has failed to appreciate is that inflation reduction has little to do with monetary policy. The centralised wage fixing system and the accord have institutionalised the expectation of inflation and therefore increased wages. That has ensured a maintenance of high inflation. The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has already indicated that, because the inflation rise was less than expected, it will be asking for a top up. On each hand, policy will have failed again.

The Reserve Bank of Australia has not helped. Besides low inflation, the Reserve Bank has stable employment as one of its objectives. This means that there has been no such thing as independent monetary policy in this country. The Reserve Bank is constantly looking over its shoulder to see the decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission and couching its policies partially around its employment objective. This does not allow the Reserve Bank to trade off higher unemployment with lower inflation. We need a genuinely independent Reserve Bank with a clear mandate to fight inflation as its primary objective. This should be the centrepiece of any anti-inflationary policy.

This brings me to the question of the Opposition's announced policy and the need in our economy for a goods and services tax, but only as part of genuine tax reform-and genuine tax reform that makes the law simpler for the ordinary citizen to understand and simpler to comply with. It is not without significance that, after the Australian Taxation Office published its book to try to explain taxation law to Australian citizens, the number of ordinary taxpayers who used the services of tax agents actually rose. I think the complicated system explained in the book simply frightened them to death.

Tax reform is long overdue. We have a taxation system which stifles incentive and actively discourages savings. Within the framework of an overall reduction in taxation and the introduction of a goods and services tax, we will see the restoration of incentives to save and invest. The current wholesale sales tax is a ramshackle affair, with five different rates covering a multitude of goods. It is absurd that caviar is not taxed while chocolates and biscuits attract a 10 per cent tax; that televisions are hit by a 30 per cent tax while books and newspapers are exempt; and that Coca Cola is taxed at 10 per cent while mineral water is exempt.

We have seen the Treasurer's intellectual dishonesty on the goods and services tax question. Who could forget Mr Keating's proposal for his own consumption tax with his tax cart in 1985? If the tax was acceptable when Mr Keating advocated it in 1985, how have things changed? The reasons that he gives are not convincing. Indeed, they are spurious.

In 1990 the need for such a tax and tax reform to abolish the wholesale tax concept and replace it with a more just and equitable tax is certainly the sensible way to go. The Treasurer has shied away from his original commitment to tax reform by the use of a consumption tax simply because he has remained the captive of the trade union movement. We all remember that the demise of his proposition occurred when he was summoned in the dead of night to meet with the head of the ACTU in a motel room down the road from where the official meeting was taking place.

But, unlike the Treasurer, some of us who espoused a consumption tax in 1985 have not changed. In 1985 I made a submission to the Economic Planning Advisory Council in connection with the Tax Summit. At that stage, I recommended a broadly based consumption tax in the form of a retail sales tax levied at a flat rate which should include services and with only a narrow range of exemptions. Five years later my view remains exactly as it was then. It is now in line with coalition policy. A task force, of which I am a part, has now been established to sell the concept of tax reform, which includes the imposition of a goods and services tax.

The fact remains that consumption taxes are accepted worldwide. Twenty-one out of the 24 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries have a goods and services tax. Such a tax is both fair and efficient. It is fair because the richer the person is the more that person spends and the more that person will be taxed, income earners will have more disposable income in their pockets and lower income earners will be fully compensated. The incentive to avoid punitive levels of income tax is reduced and it is levied at one uniform rate. A goods and services tax is efficient because it is cheaper to collect than other forms of taxation. It closes loopholes in the wholesale tax system, it encourages productive activity and it will encourage savings and investment.

The micro-economy, about which I said I would also say a few words, is, despite the announcement which the Government is to make later today concerning how strong it has been with regard to micro-economic reform, still sad and sorry within our economy. Perhaps the greatest failure of the Hawke Government has been to starve the economy of micro-economic reform and thereby starve our economy of incentive and opportunity for increased productivity. Our labour market is not really a market at all. Wages are determined by the ACTU leadership and the Treasurer and employers are excluded. The centralised process is anti-productive and anti-competitive as wage increases are applied across the board, irrespective of the condition or strength of particular firms and industries. In the rare cases where we have seen exceptions to this broad-based approach, we have seen that the union movement has moved in to penalise those areas. That is demonstrated by what is happening in Queensland where an advantage that was given to a particular firm, in that it was able to negotiate its own terms and conditions, is to have that advantage taken away from it by the new Goss Labor Government.

Instead of there being a solution from the accord, the accord is indeed part of the problem. The Government has failed completely to understand the micro-economic implications of the accord and its failure to generate any micro-economic incentives. The coalition alternative is an increased focus on the workplace negotiations to determine wages and conditions. Our industrial relations system features voluntary enterprise-based agreements, guaranteed voluntary unionism ensuring freedom of workers, and productivity improvements to be shared amongst employers and their employees. This is the only way in which we will arrive at internationally competitive wage outcomes which tie wages to performance and genuinely protect the interests of workers and their jobs.

Overall, over the last seven years perhaps the saddest comment is that regarding industry policy-or the lack of it-the failure to have a successful industry policy. There has been a systematic failure to bring about the revitalisation of Australian industry. Whether this has been brought about by sectoral plans, the bounty and grants schemes, procurements and offsets policies, partnership for development, or the failed MIC scheme, Senator Button and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce have failed to establish sustainable benefits for manufacturers, exporters or consumers. The possible collapse of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) has revealed that the Government is totally without an integrated and cohesive policy which would enable Australian manufacturing to confront the world, and a quick dash off in a plane by the Prime Minister to visit one of the latest meetings of GATT will not be the solution to that problem. We have a government boasting about its propensity to pick export winners when it is evident that it is truly merely subsidising wailing losers. Only yesterday the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, gave a vast plea for more government intervention, saying that Australia is somehow different from the rest of the world. It is different in that while the rest of the world was improving its performance during the 1980s, we were not improving our performance.

What we have seen is that, yes, we are different from the rest of the world and we should have taken advantage of the terms of trade with which we were presented during the 1980s, but to say that we are different and, therefore, we can apply different rules of trade to ourselves is a nonsense. We are part of the world trading pattern; we cannot say, `Stop the world, I want to get off'.

With unjustified subsidies to firms like Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd that have been made with scant regard to the main sufferers of the industry policy, ordinary Australians such as taxpayers and consumers have been the losers. I can see no social justice in punishing local car buyers to the tune of $4,000 a car, which is the cost of protection in that industry. How is it fair to tell consumers that we pay $1.6 billion worth of protection for an inefficient car industry? Or that we pay, on average, 67 per cent more for clothes, 63 per cent more for shoes and 25 per cent more for textiles than we would if the protectionist policies were not in place?

Protection is a problem, and Mr Dawkins's cry for more protection in his speech to the National Press Club yesterday will not solve this country's problems. The withdrawal of trade barriers to negligible levels-as is, indeed, our policy-together with micro-economic measures and reforms, will, indeed, give benefits to consumers, taxpayers and manufacturers alike.

Labor has frittered away Australia's chances through the 1980s and it does not have the guts to make the hard decisions in the 1990s. What we need is new vision and new courage, and a sensible mix of macro-economic reform and policies that complement each other and provide the necessary incentives to save and invest. When that is matched with micro-economic reform and the appropriate structures that invite competition and productivity, then we will start to see hope on the horizon for the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise during the Appropriation Bills debate to refer particularly to appropriation matters, but I feel I must say something about what Senator Bishop has just been referring to, because she referred to protection. In a very broad and sweeping statement she claimed that protection should be eliminated. It is typical of the statements of the Liberal Party of Australia on these matters: in the future it is going to do things. Of course, it has no real plan, other than the slogan of micro-economic reform, to solve the problems of industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very impractical policy that the Liberal Party refers to when it is contrasted with what two Labor governments-the Whitlam Government and this Government-have done to reduce tariffs in this country. In all the period of the Fraser Government there was no movement on tariffs at all. On the other hand, we have reduced those tariffs, but it has been done on the basis of trying to protect people and prepare them for change in industry. A series of industry plans has been developed to make sure that people in industry would not be thrown on the scrap heap, as theorists would have it, by simply the blunt instrument of the reduction of tariffs without adequate preparation for all the industries concerned.

Senator Bishop talked about the car industry and a range of industries that she is concerned about. Of course, these industries would have dire consequences for Australia if tariffs were to be reduced dramatically without taking into consideration the consequences for the human beings concerned.

I hope Senator Bishop is not leaving the chamber for any length of time, because I want to be critical of her and some of her colleagues in relation to the minority report that members of the Opposition have put out on Estimates Committee A. The report of Estimates Committee A has come in late to the Senate because of the inordinate time we have taken in preparing it. Indeed, I think Estimates Committee A can claim a record because we sat for 58 hours on eight sitting days, with one session starting at 10.08 in the morning and going through until 4.05 a.m. the next day. The Committee has worked very hard in terms of examining witnesses and has said that the Senate might need to examine the work load and review the distribution of portfolios.
I think that is fairly unexceptional. I was, then, surprised to see in the minority report that Senator Bishop and other Opposition senators said:

The length of hearing was partly due to lack of preparation by some departmental officers, a reluctance by others to convey complete information and a deliberate attempt by Senator Button to prevent officers of his Department to answer questions of the Committee. This was particularly evident in relation to the Oztech exhibition and the Midford case.

I will deal briefly with those matters. I do think that I have to say in view of that attack on Senator Button that Senator Button-and I have chaired a number of Estimates committees with a number of Ministers-is very tolerant in the way he answers questions. He is a courteous Minister, but even his courtesy was put to the test by Senator Bishop's technique of asking questions and believing she could determine which person should answer them, rather than following the basic principle that the Minister decides whether he will answer a question or will seek the assistance of an officer.

Unfortunately Senator Bishop, by virtue of this belief that she should be able to determine who will answer questions, has persuaded her colleagues to make that criticism of Senator Button. I believe it is unfounded and I believe there is a danger that if we do have unreasonable questions asked and hectoring of witnesses by senators, we will have a tendency for Ministers to answer more and more questions themselves and to be less cooperative than they have been.

As far as I am concerned, there was a greater effort by the departments that we examined to get answers quickly than ever before, and only a small percentage of questions has not been answered. When we consider the vast number of questions asked, particularly by Senator Bishop, it is insulting to say of Minister Button that he has been anything but superlative in the way he has had his departmental officers work through the night to give us the answers on time.

I would like briefly to refer to the minority report of Opposition senators, and I shall mention those two matters to which Senator Bishop has referred. But there is also another matter which I think is cause for concern as it affects this chamber itself and the way our committee system works. Senator Bishop spent a great deal of time, not to put too fine a point on it, attacking officers of the Senate-that is the way it appeared to me-because of a decision to allow committee secretaries and other researchers to go to a Labor Lawyers Association conference. It is a yearly function, a very respected conference attended by a wide range of the legal fraternity who discuss in a proper academic atmosphere the many issues dealt with. The minority report reflects the cross-examination undertaken by Senator Bishop. Part of the report states:

The Opposition members of the Committee believe that if officers of the Parliamentary Departments wish to attend conferences which are associated with a particular political party, such as the Labor Lawyers Association, then they should do so in their own time and at their own expense. The actions of the Departments, in approving expenditure to send officers to such conferences, raise serious concerns about the perception of political neutrality.

We do not accept the proposition that because the Labor Lawyers Association is not formally affiliated with the Australian Labor Party that the conferences of the Association are not politically partisan.

What concerns me about this minority report is that it raises serious concerns about the perception of political neutrality. This is a thinly veiled attempt to imply that the people involved from the Senate would be partisan. The Clerk of the Senate in replying to the questions made it absolutely clear that officers go along to such conferences maintaining their complete neutrality, and that he would expect them to do that-and there is no suggestion that they have not-and that they use the information that comes from the debates of the conference to further the work of the Senate committees which they serve, particularly in the legal area. Indeed, the Clerk answered the questions about all the details because there was an inference that something was wrong in respect of the way in which those officers went to the conference. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the Clerk's reply, which is three pages long and is headed `Attendance of officers at conferences'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ATTENDANCE OF OFFICERS AT CONFERENCES

In response to the questions asked at the hearing of Estimates Committee A on 11 September 1990 by Senators Bishop, O'Chee and Short, the following information describes the position with respect to Senate officers whose attendance at conferences of the Australian Society of Labor Lawyers was, or is to be, funded by the Department of the Senate. This information responds to all of the questions asked. The facts in relation to particular conferences are first set out, and information applying to all attendances is then provided.
(1) Attendances at conferences
1989 conference

Attended by: Ms Bronwyn McNaughton, secretary to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and formerly secretary to the Joint Select Committee on the Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals.

Matters relevant to committees' inquiries: privacy issues (Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs had recently concluded an inquiry on the tax file numbers proposal and related privacy issues, and the speakers included the Federal Privacy Commissioner); judicial independence (relevant to the Joint Select Committee's inquiry; the secretary of the Joint Select Committee did not attend).
1990 conference

To be attended by: Mr Stephen Argument, secretary to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and until recently acting secretary to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

Matters relevant to committees' inquiries: the rights of accused (relevant to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee); the cost of justice (current reference before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in which Mr Argument may again in the future be involved).
Ms Bronwyn McNaughton, secretary to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
Matters relevant to Committee's inquiry: the cost of justice (current reference before the Committee).
Previous conferences
1988: Ms Bronwyn McNaughton, secretary to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

1986: Ms Susan Gibb, then secretary to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; Mr Peter O'Keeffe, then secretary to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, who presented a paper.
(2) Applications
The applications to attend the conferences are attached.
(3) Consultations with committees

The minutes of the committees do not record any formal consultations with the committees. The Chairman of the Committees has approved the attendances, in writing only in the case of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as shown in the attached note. Ms McNaughton recalls her attendance at the 1989 conference being discussed with at least some members of the Committee.
(4) Reports

Officers are expected to provide written reports of their attendances at conferences. Oral briefings have been provided. Ms McNaughton has not yet provided a written report of her attendance at the 1989 conference. It has been indicated to staff that they need not provide comprehensive and detailed reports, but that brief summary reports suffice.
(5) Costs

The department pays for registration fees for the conference, the officers' travel and travel allowance. At the hearing, as recorded at pages 20, 21 and 24, reference was made to Mr Argument paying part of his costs of attendance. Mr Argument made this suggestion, but it has been decided that the full costs of his attendance will be met by the department. As indicated at the hearing, the costs are charged to the office to which the officer belongs; if they are regarded as attributable to a particular committee they are charged to that committee.
(6) Status of officers attending and participation in proceedings

Officers whose attendance at the conferences is funded by the department are attending in their official capacity. They attend on the same basis as all other persons who attend the conference. Apart from presenting a paper, as Mr O'Keeffe did in 1986, they receive copies of papers, listen to discussions and may ask questions and participate in discussions. Ms McNaughton does not recall whether she participated in discussions at the 1989 conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document sets out the financial circumstances which prevailed and the officers who attended those conferences. I should draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that there has been an attempt to say that officers of committees, secretaries of committees and senior research officers of Senate committees are insufficiently mature to be able to go to a conference, listen to the arguments, take notes, make appropriate reports and use the information to further their work. There is no question that any officer of this standing within the Senate could go to any such meeting and be able to conduct himself or herself with the honour and dignity we associate with Senate staff.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way I would point out that although the Labor Lawyers Conference has the word `Labor' in its title and deals with Labor issues, in the broadest sense it is not affiliated with the Australian Labor Party and has no direct links with the Labor Party in an organic way, but is simply a conference that deals with Labor issues.

I now turn to two other matters which Senator Bishop raised in giving her reasons for the Estimates Committee A hearings being such a lengthy process. She mentioned the Midford case. I have referred to Senator Button and I would like now to clarify a few points for the record because Senator Bishop asked a lengthy series of questions and made statements, some of which were quite inaccurate.

Senator Bishop referred to an injunction being sought by and granted to the Malaysian Government to stop Australian Customs Service (ACS) investigation officers obtaining documents in Malaysia. The fact is that no injunction was sought by or granted to the Malaysian Government. An injunction was sought by solicitors acting on behalf of Midford Malaysia, and that was granted by the court.

Senator Bishop also alleged that documents were taken illegally by Customs officers in Malaysia. In fact, the position of the Australian Customs Service is that the documents in question were proffered voluntarily to the ACS by company officials. The officers had left Malaysia before the injunction was put into effect. A subsequent appeal by the Royal Malaysian Customs and the Australian Government against the injunction resulted in its being set aside. It was claimed that prosecution proceedings were contemplated against Australian Customs Service officers in Malaysia. There is no such contemplation.

Senator Bishop purported firstly that the officers departed Malaysia under some subterfuge, such as being smuggled out in the back of a car, which is a very serious allegation; secondly, that they had sought refuge in the Australian High Commission in Malaysia; and, thirdly, that they left Malaysia unbeknown to the Malaysian Government. Those are three very serious allegations against the two officers.

Let us deal with the first claim, which is that refuge was sought in the Australian High Commission. Of course, refuge was not sought and the denial in that respect is made emphatically. The passports of the two officers bear departure stamps indicating their official departure from Malaysia. It was indicated in the Estimates Committee that it was believed that the officers were transported to the airport by Royal Malaysian Customs officers, and this has since been confirmed. Senator Bishop tendered affidavits from employees of companies in Malaysia alleging coercion by Australian Customs Service officers in seeking documents. These allegations have been completely repudiated by the two officers involved. The question is at a certain point whether we believe officers of the Australian Government or whether we believe anything that is said in a foreign country.

Senator Bishop, in raising the matter of public interest in a debate in which I also participated, said that the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) decided to lay a prosecution in the Midford case after relying on information and evidence provided by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC). It was said that the provision of that information was subsequently found by the presiding magistrate to be unreliable and that the departmental witness was totally discredited.

A brief of evidence was provided to the DPP by the ACS, including statements by DITAC officers. The brief was obviously considered by the DPP and discussions took place with counsel prior to the decision to prosecute Midford. During the committal proceedings further evidence came to light under cross-examination which caused the Director of Public Prosecutions to withdraw charges. It is regrettable that the evidence was highlighted only at this stage, but after all that is the system of justice that we work under. The committal proceedings were intended to test whether the defendants should prima facie be committed to trial. The Director of Public Prosecutions had taken the decision to prosecute based on the brief presented to him and on his subsequent discussions with and advice from counsel, who supported the prosecution proceedings. Based on developments occurring during the committal proceedings, the DPP had little option other than to withdraw. Costs were awarded to the defendants.

Senator Bishop also raised the issue of the Australian Customs Service subsequently pursuing charges of valuation fraud against Midford. The answer is that settlement of this matter was effected following offers from the company in September 1990. I do not think anything further needs to be said on that matter, when clearly the company made the offer that resolved the issue. Senator Bishop relied upon extracts from the submission from the Law Council of Australia to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in order to allege improper practices by Customs investigation officers. Suffice to say at this stage that the Law Council has not backed its generalised complaints with any specific details. The Australian Customs Service denies the substance of the generalised complaints. It is to be noted that the Law Council appeared before the House of Representatives Committee in Sydney on 30 October to answer questions in relation to its submission. I have not had the opportunity to find out what happened at that Committee.

We have here a series of issues. Senator Bishop has raised numerous matters of minutiae, which the Department has responded to at great length. The significant thing about the Midford issue is that it is basically an embarrassment to members of the Opposition because of a secret deal negotiated by none other than Prime Minister Fraser during the time of the Fraser Government. It is incredible that the Opposition, through Senator Bishop, should raise this issue to prominence when the secret deal made in Malaysia was the reason why that case objectively failed. The officers concerned did not realise that the Fraser Government had made a secret and sordid deal so many years ago.

I would just like to refer briefly to the other matter to which Senator Bishop referred and that is the Oztech Trade Exhibition. This is an issue on which I think we spent a great deal of time. An organisation came forward that had a concept for an exhibition. It suggested it to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and Austrade also entered into contracts. The amount of money totalled $75,000. The Committee believes that there should be a process of evaluation before contracts of this type are entered into so that we drew attention to the Department that it needs to look more closely at the procedures to be followed. I am quite certain that it will take note of the Committee's recommendation.

There is nothing wrong, sordid and improper in what has happened in this particular case when one takes into consideration that the particular organisation was putting forward an idea and the Department liked the idea of an exhibition next year and decided to accept it. Although we have spent a good deal of hours on that matter, the reality is that there is nothing in it. This is so typical of many of the issues that have been pursued by Senator Bishop.

I think that any objective analysis of Estimates Committee A would indicate that Senator Bishop's method of asking questions at length, hoping that finally something might come up, has been unsuccessful and the lengthy minority report that has been presented by the Opposition senators has not any substance in it. I will not take the time of the Senate to go through all the other aspects, because I hope I have illustrated that this particular minority report is not worth any further consideration by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill and the implications of the Budget, there are certain matters that I want to bring to the attention of the chamber. The setting must be taken against a couple of things which, I believe, are of crucial importance for the future and well-being of Australia. The first part in that is our current national debt which is in excess of $124 billion. Our current account from last year was significantly above the estimated $18 billion by something like $2.5 billion or $2.7 billion. The projection for this year in terms of the current account has been put at $18 billion but under current circumstances I would suggest it will be much closer to $25 billion than the projected $18 billion. In terms of Budget settings, I believe Australia is now caught in a debt trap, and unless very drastic and quick action is taken, we will find ourselves in much more difficult circumstances through the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also here make a comment on the current situation in the wool industry, because I believe the wool industry is heading down a very similar route to that taken by the Australian economy and unless we address the national debt problems it will be very difficult for effective Government policy in a number of areas which I will come to later.

I have something else to say about the debt trap. The National Debt Summit which was held some 12 months ago identified-and it has not been refuted-that Australia needed over the next decade a 4 per cent net growth in exports to stabilise its debt. I really think that Budget settings in the future should address this aspect, and the last one certainly fails in that context. One thing I know-as the Alan Bonds and others have found out in this world-is that a person cannot go into debt indefinitely because sooner or later the bank manager will tap him on his shoulder and say, `No more'. The economic newsletter of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia states:
Main Features

While the Budget surplus is projected to increase marginally to $8.1 billion, compared with $8.0 billion in the previous year as a proportion of gross domestic product it will fall to 2.0 per cent from 2.2 per cent in 1989-90. Continuing the recent trend, both aggregate revenues and outlays are expected to decline as a percentage of GDP. However, in each case the decline will be very slight.
This is the important part:

In real terms (ie after adjusting for inflation), total outlays are expected to rise marginally by 0.6 per cent compared with a real decline of 0.2 per cent in 1989-90. Budget data over recent years have been distorted by special factors (in particular asset sales and the transfer of State debt). After adjusting to take these in account, the real increase in outlays is 1.1 per cent.

The point that I want to make is that at a time such as this when it is essential that we have a policy direction or setting which in fact addresses our national debt situation and our current account problem, we should be reducing outlays not increasing them.

If we do not address these things we will not be creating an environment where we can have profitable business and maintain or improve living standards, social justice or an effective environmental policy. If we are to look at achieving that 4 per cent net growth in exports, Australia must become internationally competitive. Right now we are not internationally competitive in terms of inflation, interest rates and in other aspects or measures.

I will quote some figures on interest rates. While the recent reductions in interest rates are certainly welcome, the question has to be asked: where does it leave us? In a consideration of real interest rates in selected Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries it is worth looking at the figures for the United States of America (USA), Japan and Germany. In June 1990-the latest period for which figures are available-the retail interest rates were: Australia, 18.75 per cent; USA, 10 per cent; Japan, 7.2 per cent and Germany, 7.83 per cent.

If I analyse those percentages for those countries that are our competitors in the international market-and that is why I am talking about international competitiveness, I find that the Americans have an advantage of 8.75 per cent over us, Japan and Germany have an advantage of about 11 per cent over us. If I take into account what has occurred since then, I find that our retail interest rates-and these figures are from the Department of the Parliamentary Library-have fallen to 17.9 per cent which takes one per cent off those figures I have just quoted.

Equally as important are the real interest rates and this is where inflation, which is a very important component of the total equation, comes into it. In June 1990, the real interest rates were: Australia, 10.34 per cent; USA, 5.39 per cent; Japan, 4.69 per cent; Germany, 5.4 per cent and the United Kingdom, 4.89 per cent. So we consistently see a difference of 5 per cent in interest rates. I understand the rationale or the reasoning behind the Government's monetary policy but I have to say that I believe it is wrong. What it has done is make us non-competitive on an international basis. Unless we are competitive there we cannot address those particular aspects that I raised earlier on. The real crunch is when we start looking at some of the reasons behind our problem.

Whilst I certainly welcome the drop in inflation figures which were announced yesterday, we must once again examine these against those of our competitors to see where it leaves us. In June 1990, our inflation rate was 7.6 per cent, that of the United States was 4.4 per cent, Japan's was 2.4 per cent and Germany's was 2.3 per cent. We have an enormous gap in that aspect of our policy setting and, in terms of the direction we have to take in Budget settings, that is the most crucial issue in front of us.

Let me go through some of the other aspects of addressing this problem. One must come to two areas which, above all, are the most important. The first one is our taxation system combined with our industrial system. We currently have a taxation system and an industrial system which, in my view, totally militate against incentive. If we are to create a situation where we lift our productivity so that we can compete and reduce our inflation rate, our interest rates and other aspects which will allow us to address those two areas I will keep emphasising-the trap we are in with our national debt and our current account problems-we must have systems which reward people who are prepared to perform. We will not get people to perform when the major parts of the economy which either reward or penalise them are disincentives. That is precisely what both those areas do.

I emphasise my earlier comments about the Budget setting and the need to reduce total government outlays. It is worth noting that a cut of 4 per cent in total government expenditure would allow income tax levels to be reduced to two rates of the order of 30 per cent and 20 per cent. In itself, that would be very important in lifting productivity and allowing the Australian economy to address some of the very crucial matters. I am not trying to suggest that that will be easy. I do not think it is a case of things being easy. It is really a case of whether we have the courage to correct some of the difficulties that Australia has as an international competitor. It does not matter whether we are talking about agriculture or mining or about the development that is now occurring in some of the manufacturing industries. Unless Australia can compete internationally, it is all done in vain.

I have long been an advocate for major changes in our taxation system, particularly in the levels of personal income tax rates and the wholesale sales tax regime. One reason I have for a number of years supported very strongly the introduction of a goods and services type tax is because of the anomalies in our wholesale sales tax and the way in which it penalises our exporters when compared with our major competitors in international markets.

Let me cite a number of inequities in our current wholesale sales tax. Under current arrangements, there is no sales tax on antique clocks, oysters, pornographic magazines, caviar, and mineral water. A sales tax of 10 per cent applies to refrigerators, vacuum cleaners, toys-for goodness sake-chocolate biscuits, Coke, bicycles and radios. The sales tax on tool boxes is 20 per cent and on televisions it is 30 per cent. We can go down the list. Anybody who tells me that that is equitable within a community in terms of the taxation system has his assessments totally wrong.

I reiterate the necessity in the current situation in Australia of having in place systems which encourage increases in productivity by giving people reward in their hip pockets. One of the most important things for us to do is to use the hip pocket nerve to encourage people to perform better. I have every confidence in the Australian community. If they are given that incentive, the vast majority-in excess of 95 per cent of people-will perform; whereas in our current situation there is no incentive. In fact, we have seen the accord-this is its down side-lower people's living standards without any reward for that extra effort. Effectively, it has handed control to Kelty for the setting of wages when much more emphasis should be put on that being set at the enterprise level between the participants involved.

The next equation which I see as being very important in our current situation is micro-economic reform. I am absolutely sick and tired, firstly, of talking about it and, secondly, of hearing other people talk about it. It has been going on for as long as I can remember. Since the Second World War there have been about 30 inquiries either directly or indirectly into the waterfront and numerous inquiries into the transport industry-I think four have been held since this Government has been in power. But no government, neither this one nor previous governments, has effectively tackled the issue of micro-economic reform-and there are enormous rewards in it for Australia.

While one must say that what we see happening now is welcome, why has it taken so long to have a Premiers Conference to talk about micro-economic reform when it has been on the public agenda for so long and when the benefits are so obvious? In a moment I will put some figures on the record. Why do we not just get on with the job and do it, because it will be beneficial for all Australians and particularly the Australian economy? Let me just quote from the National Farmers Federation policy overview:

The appropriate policy response is to accelerate the pace of micro-economic reform. The benefits of micro-economic reform vastly outweigh the selected intervention. For example, protection elsewhere in the economy costs each Australian farm about $6,000 per year. Waterfront inefficiencies add another $3,000 per export farm per year.

In a wider context, the IAC estimated the long term gains from microeconomic reform would be an annual gain in real GDP of almost 5 per cent, equivalent to $16 billion per year in 1988/89 dollars, or $1,600 per household. An additional 35,000 jobs would be created.

When we look at the current unemployment figures that are unfolding and the projections for the next three, six, nine and twelve months, we see that if ever we needed those 35,000 jobs, we need them now. It is about time we got on with the job. Unfortunately, in the current Budget settings that aspect is not effectively addressed.

I will now provide a couple of examples of things which I have observed in the short time I have been here and which I think focus on a much broader problem. One thing in the Estimates committee meetings which caused me great concern was the expenditure for advertising detailed in the budget in the draft annual report of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In this last year there was an increase from $54m to $69m for advertising promotion. In anyone's language that is an enormous amount of money. Firstly, why do we need to spend that sort of money in that particular area when, I believe, it could be spent much more effectively elsewhere? Secondly, why must there be an increase of $15m in that expenditure? Has any analysis been done on the effectiveness of some of these programs and the resultant expenditure? As we run through the list of expenditure, we find $15m here, $20m there, $30m somewhere else, and suddenly we start to ask ourselves some questions when we suggest the necessity to look at total government outlays.

I suggest that in fact there is an enormous wastage in some of these programs which achieve very little. They certainly do not go to the core or to the heart of the Australian problem now which, as I said earlier, is our national debt and current account problem. We need to place some priorities in our expenditure on the benefits of making sure that we are creating an environment which will allow us to address some of the issues that I have mentioned. I am also rather appalled by the pattern of this expenditure. In the July-September quarter it was $14,806,000; in the October-December quarter it was $11,512,000; and we find in the January-March quarter that it was $23,925,000, almost $24m. I just ask the question: Is it coincidental that that was the quarter in which the election was held?

The next point I raise is the 100 per cent write-off for fencing for farm plans. While I welcome this and it is something that the industry has been seeking for some time, I just pose the question, because it is linked to an approved farm plan: When are we going to have the mechanism put in place that is required so that the people who are prepared to put a farm plan together can get that farm plan approved and can benefit from this particular initiative?

When mechanisms are in place which will allow individual land-holders to avail themselves of initiatives in the challenges that we face in Australia in relation to land degradation and conservation in our farming and pastoral areas some of these measures will be effective. I have two properties 12 miles apart. One has had the farm plan approved but I am told by the Department of Agriculture that it could take another four or five years before I can get the other farm plan approved. So there is the inequitable situation in one business enterprise where part of the property qualifies; the other part does not. I happen to be one of the lucky ones because I have at least part of my farm plan approved. There are many farmers throughout Australia who have no hope, under the current situation, of having a farm plan approved before it is well into the future-possibly, as I have suggested, up to four or five years.

Another point I make relates to protection. I will not go through the figures on protection because they have been quoted by other speakers. I am pleased to see that the coalition has adopted the Garnaut reform report in relation to protection. Why, when it was welcomed with open arms by the Prime Minister, has the Government failed to act on it? Maybe I should pose the question in the positive and ask: When will it act on that report? It was commissioned by the Government and welcomed by the Prime Minister and yet it seems to be another one of those reports that will be put on the shelf and no action will be taken on it. The challenge that I am throwing down in this debate is that many of these things we have talked about for many years but we have seen no action. We have had inquiries, reports--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish and you know it.

—There are many reports that we have had no action on. I did not say all reports. I was addressing the Garnaut report in particular. When will we see some action on that report? I want to come back to where I started in this appropriations debate. It is absolutely crucial that Australia, in its Budget settings and policy settings, take action to address the debt trap that I believe we are in, to make sure that we get on top of it. That involves taking action in terms of our current account.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that I do not believe we can be effective in a number of our policy arenas, particularly in our social policy and our environmental policy, unless we put those two aspects of our current situation on the top of the agenda.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trends of thinking within the Government, I believe, have produced a Budget strategy which reflects the views of powerful interests and elite groups within Australia and some overseas. The burdens of the Budget, of the tight economic problems in Australia, are being unjustly born domestically by families and by the increasing number of unemployed, particularly youth unemployed. Those powerful elites are projecting policies which cut across the rights of many people in our community who are not fully equipped to protect their rights and whose rights we in this Parliament should stand up for.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my intention, on some other occasion in this chamber, to develop those arguments for the benefit or otherwise of my parliamentary colleagues. But in speaking to the Appropriation Bills today it is my intention to direct my remarks specifically to the appropriations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and within that budget specifically to the appropriations for the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB). It is my view that the Budget, as it relates to those areas, is also driven by policies which are certainly not appropriate to a caring and creative society.

The $96m cut in the overseas development assistance aid budget is the action of a self-centred government more interested in what the polls say than in responding to the cries of poverty stricken people in the Third World. Some of the poorest areas have been most savagely targeted by the 1990-91 Budget of the Commonwealth Government. Emergency humanitarian assistance, food aid, aid to some of the poorest regions of Africa and village level assistance provided by non-government organisations are amongst the hardest hit.

The Government has attempted to put a gloss on its inhumane treatment by stating that its level of expenditure in the 1990-91 Budget is estimated to yield an overseas development assistance (ODA) to gross national product (GNP) ratio of 0.33 per cent. That is the initial gloss that was put on the matter in Senator Evans's statement in Budget Related Paper No. 4. Reading on in his statement and the details contained in that paper and Budget Related Paper No. 1, one deduces that Australia's overseas development aid budget has been slashed by $96m. The reason for that is that there had been some longstanding commitments that the Government had to two international financial institutions-the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank-and these payments of $100m were rescheduled into last year's Budget.

One can see that in order to maintain the level of overseas development assistance we in Australia this year should have increased the budget by a similar monetary amount. There is no argument but that the overseas development assistance budget has been slashed by almost $100m. We must ask ourselves whether we can live with that. We must ask ourselves the reason why the Government has made what I believe is a heartless decision. Is it because of the results of a survey that was conducted by AIDAB in 1989? That survey indicated in essence that most Australians support foreign aid, but few would support more, and 26 per cent would provide less. There is a view that charity begins at home. There is also some concern about where our foreign aid money is going-such as the purchase for a project in Burma of motorcycles that were far too large for the requirements of the Burmese who were to use them.

Some people have questioned why, for example, Australia should have announced a $35m aid package to India last year when the Indian Government could find this money itself by buying one fewer fighter plane. There have also been a number of published critiques of foreign aid, including the recent work by Graham Hancock entitled Lords of Poverty, which makes some very interesting observations about international aid bureaucracies.

As legislators we must face up to the ranges of opinion and to the reality that in the community at large there is a growing concern on the issues surrounding the provision of foreign aid. The challenge to our aid community and to AIDAB is to ensure that aid is well targeted and not abused by groups that do not have the true interests of people, especially poor people in developing countries, at heart.

It is no good saying that the ODA to GNP ratio is maintained at 0.33 per cent when that is not the case if account is taken of our rescheduled debts to the two financial institutions to which I have referred. The fact is that over the past few years the ODA to GNP ratio has been declining. We must ask ourselves whether that is the action of a caring and creative society such as ours. Certainly we are not in the lap of luxury; certainly there are concerns in Australia about the drop in our standards of living. But that does not entitle us to ignore the enormous poverty that is being suffered by poor people in the less developed countries.

To give one example of the cut in the aid budget to organisations that assist at village level, I quote a press release by the Overseas Service Bureau in relation to Australian Volunteers Abroad of 10 September 1990:

The Overseas Service Bureau announced today that it is cancelling its 1991 mid year departure group of Australian Volunteers Abroad. This means that approximately 50 Australian volunteers will not be able to participate in development assistance work in poor countries of the world. The cutback is directly due to cuts in Australia's overseas aid budget announced in August. As well as the cancellation of the mid year group, the size of the January group will be curtailed.
Is that an action of a caring, creative society or of a government that cares when there are volunteers ready to go?

Let me give another instance which has long term implications. I refer to a cut of 11 per cent to international agricultural research funding. The Australian Government through AIDAB contributes to international agricultural research through two major channels-the International Agricultural Research Centres and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. Funding is provided primarily to those agricultural research centres belonging to the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research. A recent Government document describes the work of those organisations as having made `a large contribution to increases in agricultural production in developing countries'. That statement is contained in Budget Related Paper No. 4 for the 1990-91 Budget.
Important themes pursued by the IAR centres include agricultural sustainability and forest research.

That statement appears at page 37 of Budget Paper No. 4. A 1988 AIDAB publication notes that these centres `focus on increasing food production in developing countries so that the nutritional level and general economic well-being of low income people are improved'. The publication concludes that they have made considerable contributions to agricultural output in the Third World.

The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research was established in 1982 to promote research into the agricultural problems of developing countries and activities in which Australia has special competence. The research activities in which the ACIAR is involved include animal and crop sciences, fisheries, forestries, soil and water management and socio-economics.

What has the Federal Government done to these groups in the 1990-91 Federal Budget? Following several years in which it appeared AIDAB was committed to increasing support for international agricultural research, the 1990-91 Budget has slashed funding. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard tables on funding.
Leave granted.
The tables read as follows-
International Agricultural Research Centres:

A grant in 1990/91 of $7.0m would have been required to maintain the real value of the 1989/90 contribution. The 1990/91 grant, therefore, represents a decision by the Government to cut IARC funding by 20% in real terms.
Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research:

A grant in 1990/91 of $18.5m would have been required to maintain the real value of the 1989/90 contribution. The 1990/91 grant, therefore, represents a decision by the Government to cut ACIAR funding by 8.1% in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I now refer to my questions to AIDAB at a Senate Estimates committee hearing held in Canberra on 18 September. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Can I go to the international agricultural research organisations which are also mentioned on page 36, which appear to have had a drop from $6.6m to $5.6m.
Mr Dolan replied:

That is correct. The heading `International Agricultural Research' covers quite a basket of organisations. They include, as an example, the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines. There are over a dozen of these organisations, about half of which belong to the international grouping called CGIAR which is organised by the World Bank. As a result of budgetary stringencies this year a decision was made to reduce contributions to that basket of organisations.
I asked:
Would not AIDAB consider that agricultural research is of crucial importance to alleviating malnutrition and poverty?
The answer by Mr Dolan was:
Certainly. I think the same could be said of quite a few other activities within the aid budget. Within the constraints of overall budgetary policy it is necessary to pull in the belt somewhere.
I asked:
It is a budgetary matter on the part of AIDAB. There is no question, is there, about the efficacy of the international agricultural research organisations?
The officer from AIDAB, Mr Dolan, answered:

No. There is no question about the efficacy of them. They are believed to be effective organisations that promote very useful research in developing countries. Perhaps the most prominent example of the success of these institutions is that institution that I referred to IRRI, the International Rice Research Institute, which gave us the green revolution in South East Asia.

The Budget cuts funds to those organisations. That is a disgraceful situation. Whilst, on the one hand, the Budget is cutting the amounts to those organisations, on the other hand it is substantially increasing the payment of taxpayers' money to international population control organisations which support population control programs which involve gross violations of human rights. The International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) has received an increase of 100 per cent this year from the Government. On the one hand, the Government cuts payments to those agricultural research organisations that are doing the fine work and alleviating poverty-it is admitted that their work is important in alleviating poverty-and, on the other, it increases its funding to population control bodies such as the IPPF and UNFPA-the United Nations Population Fund, which is up by 100 per cent in the first instance and 44 per cent in the second instance.

The United States Government refuses to fund those organisations because of their support for programs involving coercion. On 7 June 1989, one of those organisations-namely, the United Nations Population Fund-three days after the Tiananmen Square massacre, with Australian support, contributed $US57m to assist the world's most inhumane population control program in China.

In the Committee of the Whole I will be pursuing questions that were raised initially by Senator Olsen about the supply by Australia, through the development import finance facilities, of ultrasound machines to the organisation in control of population control programs in China-namely, the State Family Planning Commission, which is involved in population control measures that are coercive in nature and involve a gross violation of human rights.

We must hang our heads in shame if we in this country have, on the one hand, savagely cut worthwhile aid programs, including reafforestation programs, and, on the other, increased funding to those organisations which adopt the attitude that the fertility of poor women in poor countries is to blame for everything from war to famine to damage to the environment. That sort of philosophy that is being adopted by international bureaucracies has to be challenged. It has to be challenged because the thinking behind it now has been accepted by this Government, and particularly the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, as its benchmark.

I invite honourable senators to look at the extraordinary statements that Senator Evans made at an Estimates committee hearing about population control measures having a high priority in his thinking. When I mentioned the work of one well-known author in the field of development assistance, Senator Evans did not even know who that person was. Yet that person had previously advanced a theory in the World Bank that population measures were vastly important but was able to say in this article that there was no consensus that population growth was a significant negative factor in the development of developing countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I will now call on matters of public interest. I remind Senator Harradine that he has five minutes left when the debate resumes. Before calling on matters of public interest, I call the Minister.
