DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November 1990, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill, which is designed to meet Commonwealth Government obligations under the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances so that Australia can ratify the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the convention is defined in Article 2.1 as being the promotion of cooperation among the parties so that they may address more effectively the various aspects of illicit traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances having an international dimension. Under the terms of the convention, member states are required to take certain steps to suppress drug trafficking. They are required, pursuant to Article 3, to make manufacturing, growing and dealing in drugs and money laundering of drug proceeds, criminal offences under domestic law. There is a requirement in Article 4 to give domestic courts jurisdiction over drug crimes.

Article 5 requires that member states must further provide for the tracing, freezing and confiscation of drug proceeds and for the extradition of drug criminals under Article 6. There is a requirement in Article 7 for member states to provide each other with mutual legal assistance in the investigation of prosecutions, and in Article 9 for them to cooperate with each other in the provision of channels of communication and in the training of law enforcement officers.

Pursuant to Article 12, substances used for the manufacture of drugs are to be subject to strict control, and there is an obligation in Article 13 to eradicate the illicit cultivation of narcotic plants. Article 15 stipulates that commercial carriers are not used for the commission of offences. Pursuant to Article 17, member states have an obligation to cooperate with each other in the prevention of illicit traffic by sea, in conformity with international law.

Articles 18 and 19 respectively set out requirements to suppress illicit traffic in free trade zones and free ports and to outlaw the use of the mails for illicit traffic. Finally, pursuant to Article 20 member states are obliged to furnish information to the Commission on Narcotic Drugs of the Economic and Social and Council of the United Nations regarding the workings of the convention.

Most of these obligations are already covered by various Federal and State laws. Relevant Federal laws include the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988.

We note the statement in clause 5(1) that the Bill is not intended to exclude or limit the operation of any other law of the Commonwealth or any law of a State or Territory. The Opposition welcomes the Government's recognition in this instance that all levels of government should work together to fight the drug problem in Australia. We believe that an important opportunity such as this should not be used by the Commonwealth to encroach upon areas of State jurisdiction. I understand that consultations have been taking place between the Commonwealth and the States and that ratification of the convention cannot take place until those consultations are concluded.

The Bill basically extends Australia's extraterritorial jurisdiction over crimes relating to drugs. Clauses 10 and 11 establish an offence of dealing in drugs on board Australian aircraft and ships. Two new offences for dealing in drugs outside Australia are created by clause 12: firstly, where the crime is committed by an Australian national outside Australia and, secondly, where a foreigner commits the crime outside Australia, but is subsequently located in Australia.

Pursuant to clause 13 of the Bill, it is also an offence to deal in drugs outside Australia with a view to committing a drug crime in Australia. Clause 14 creates a Commonwealth offence where a person outside Australia conspires, attempts, aids, abets, counsels, procures or is in any way involved in dealing in drugs which constitutes an offence against a State or Territory law.

This convention is focused upon the suppression of illicit trafficking. This is just one of the approaches recognised in the declaration of the International Conference on Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking in Vienna of June 1987 as forming part of an effective strategy to combat the worldwide drug problem. We strongly support the strategy outlined in that declaration, which encompasses the prevention and reduction of demand, the control of supply, treatment and rehabilitation, as well as the suppression of illicit trafficking.

In our view, although this convention is essentially based on the more traditional law and order approach, it in no way prevents the examination of these other options for dealing with the drug problem. This is in line with the coalition's policy which recognises that a range of approaches must be used in the fight against drugs. The Opposition is therefore supporting this Bill as we believe that it will be a useful measure in attacking the traffic in illicit drugs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition parties for their support of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill 1990. The Clerk has drawn my attention to the fact that it was in 1976 that I last participated in a debate on this Bill, so it has been around for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: The support of the Opposition demonstrates the commitment of all political parties in Australia to the fight against the evils of drug trafficking, as Senator Hill said in his closing remarks. The Bill demonstrates Australia's commitment to working as part of the international community in fighting to stem the trade in illicit drugs. It is only by concerted international effort that significant progress in this area will be made.

The Bill will have the effect of enacting those provisions of the United Nations Drug Trafficking Convention which come within areas of Commonwealth responsibility. We point out that it still remains for the States to take the necessary steps to ensure that their laws and practices are in accord with the obligations Australia will assume once it ratifies the convention.

It is hoped that the States will now give this matter priority so that Australia, having taken a prominent role in the drafting of the convention, will not be seen to be dragging the chain in meeting its international obligations in this area. I thank the Senate for supporting the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

When this Bill was debated in 1976 I asked Senator Chaney what psychotropic substances were. He said he thought that they were mad dogs or Englishmen and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, made the same slip a moment ago.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 12.56 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to comments on industry policy made by the Treasurer in another place yesterday. I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: If Australia goes back to the interventionist policies of the past and if it turns in on itself and believes that it can extract wealth from subsidised industries, it will make a grave mistake.

With whom does the Minister agree-the Treasurer or the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who yesterday advocated `taking a step beyond adherence to the principles of the market and a level playing field'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say that the two things are not mutually exclusive. Senator Kemp, in his question, has quoted one passage from the Treasurer's answer but not another passage, in which the Treasurer says that, in particular circumstances, from time to time the Government has, in terms of industry policy, engaged in what might be called `mild interventionist activities'.
—Kodak.

—He did not mention that one; he mentioned the steel plan. Seeing Senator Hill interjects about this issue, let me say that when we came into government the steel industry was going out of business. It has now been re-established as Australia's largest exporter of manufactured products, and has seen enormous cultural change in both management and work force and I believe is operating successfully.

ANSWER.PARA: I certainly agree with the Treasurer that if Australia goes back to the interventionist policies of the past we will be in deep trouble. They were the policies we inherited. We inherited policies of made-to-measure tariffs for particular firms, depending on which electorate they were in. We inherited those policies. And they are the sorts of policies we will certainly not go back to.

Mr Dawkins referred to taking a step away from the level playing field, and I agree with that too. There are two level playing fields-the playing field of a domestic economy and arriving at neutrality between industries in the domestic economy and also the playing field of an international economy, where the playing field is a vastly different thing indeed. If one asks whether the countries to the north of Australia, from South Korea to Singapore, operate on a level playing field in terms of export markets, one reaches the conclusion that they do not. They have enormous tax holidays provided to industries to establish there. They have a whole range of export incentives and so on. That is a different playing field from the level playing field of the domestic economy, on which a number of Australian economists are still fixated. They got locked into those views in the 1960s and the 1970s. I do not see any inconsistencies. It is an obvious question that can be put here today. I congratulate Senator Kemp on seizing the obvious, but I do not think there are inconsistencies, particularly if the Treasurer's answer is read in full.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I notice that the Minister, as usual, has come down hard on both sides of the fence on this issue. In the latter part of his answer he mentioned the unfair competition from overseas firms that he felt some Australian firms were suffering. I think he mentioned the term `export subsidies'. Will he then adopt the proposals of the new Dawkins line and move in that direction?

—Senator Kemp did not have as much time to think about his supplementary question as he did about his original question. Part of his supplementary question is of course a statement, which I will be happy to deal with on another occasion. We must not debate issues during Question Time. The answer to the supplementary question, in so far as it is one, is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. At a public meeting I attended last week, organised by zone 13 of the United Farmers and Stockowners at Western Flat in the south-east of South Australia, evidence was presented that the rural sector has been hard hit by the big drop in world commodity prices, particularly for wool and wheat. The meeting requested that the assets test be reviewed. In light of this submission and submissions made to the Prime Minister by the National Farmers Federation and the Government's rural task force, can the Minister advise what decision, if any, has been made regarding the review on the assets test to be introduced on 1 January 1991 regarding family allowances and the family allowance supplement (FAS)? Can the Minister advise whether the Government will be giving some consideration to reviewing the assets test for the Austudy allowance to provide assistance for those farmers who may be faced with either a nil or a negative income because of the disastrous drop in agricultural commodity world prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, the Government has been considering this matter over the last few weeks, not only because of the submission made to us by the National Farmers Federation but also because we had Senator Burns and Senator Schacht and some of our more courageous members of the back bench attending a series of meetings around Australia--
—Only one.

—Excuse me; I just named two who went. I have not inquired about everyone who might have gone, but certainly Senator Schacht and Senator Burns are to be commended for having done so. Also, representations were received from a range of members on both sides of the House. Our rural task force, and Brian Courtice in particular, were pushing Government Ministers very hard.

ANSWER.PARA: It would appear that farm incomes will drop alarmingly during this year and maybe next year, given the crisis in wool and wheat. In particular, the intervention in the last couple days of the United States of America in some wheat sales would suggest that there will be some difficult times ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you don't know that.
—I will try to have a policy of ignoring Senator Walters's objections. Unlike my colleague here, I cannot claim her as a good friend.
—Thank goodness for that.

—Hear, hear! I have to retain some credibility. I was a bit worried about Senator Tate. Even since the Cabinet was considering Budget measures a few months ago, even in the past three to four months, it is certainly true to say that the rural crisis has continued to worsen. In view of that, the Government has decided to look at how we might ease some of those Budget decisions. The first place to look would be the family allowance supplement, which of course affects those with the lowest incomes. Honourable senators may recall that in the Budget we introduced a $200,000 limit assets test. That decision has now been reversed.

ANSWER.PARA: The original FAS limit, which was $322,000, as indexed will now be a new figure of about $347,000. In so far as family allowances are concerned, in the Budget we had announced a $300,000 assets test for family allowance. That will now be a $500,000 assets test. It must be remembered that these assets figures are net figures-they are net of debt. I think that is something that many people have missed in the argument over the last few months, and it cannot be stressed often enough.

Having announced that, it would be difficult for the Government to proceed with an Austudy test which was radically different from the family allowance supplement, in particular. That being the case, Austudy and assistance for isolated children will also be indexed to increase to $347,500. That will be the new Austudy test figure, with, of course, the 50 per cent discount which applied before. Although Austudy is, of course, not within my portfolio, I throw that in because these three announcements are being made together.

Family allowance will go from $300,000 to $500,000, family allowance supplement from $200,000 to $347,500, and Austudy will be at $347,500, with a 50 per cent discount. This will mean that thousands of families who were to suffer some loss will no longer have to suffer that loss and it will certainly mean that extra payments will be made to children, particularly those of farmers who are being hardest hit. I hope that that will be of some comfort and some assistance to them during what will undoubtedly be a difficult year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen the comments made by Mr Stewart West in today's Australian Financial Review that the Minister and the Prime Minister should take the views of the parliamentary Left regarding war in the Gulf more seriously and that, if they do not, `they have a nasty shock coming' and that the parliamentary Left could `wreck the stability of the Government'? How does the Minister reconcile this statement from a former senior ministerial colleague with his answer in the Senate yesterday that he, Senator Evans, need not take much notice of the views of the parliamentary Left? Will the Minister now agree that the views of the Left could undermine the capacity of the Government to make an effective contribution to the Gulf operation? What steps will the Government take to reassure our allies that this split within the Government will not compromise our Gulf policy?

—Assuming that those comments to which Senator Durack refers were accurately reported, let me say this: I can understand the emotion and, indeed, the memories of situations in the past which led my colleague to make the remarks that he did. None of us want to see a war in the Gulf, and the decision that Australia will be faced with about the extent of our involvement, if it does come to that, will be a very difficult and sensitive decision indeed. All I can further say is that, if and when the time comes to make such a decision, we will do so on the basis of our perception as to what is in the interests of this country and not on the basis of threats of any kind.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to a radio interview earlier this week in which the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, Mr Howard, discussed the extent to which some employers were not complying with provisions of industrial awards? Did Mr Howard in this interview appear to be advocating that some employers should, in effect, break the law by not complying with awards? Can the Minister inform honourable senators what the Government's response will be in the event that employers take Mr Howard's advice?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it appropriate for the Minister to be giving his interpretation of what Mr Howard was saying in an interview?

—I thought that the first part of the question was possibly leading to a question that could have been out of order, but the honourable senator is now asking what action the Government would take in a certain set of circumstances, and I would allow that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the radio broadcast, which was on radio station 5AA in Adelaide yesterday, although a number of complaints have been received from listeners who thought that law breaking was being advocated. I have obtained a transcript of the broadcast, which I must say is marked `E &OE-proof only', and I acknowledge that now. I say at the beginning that award provisions carry the force of law and that anyone who breaks them breaks the law and then not only has to amend his behaviour but also would frequently face a fine in the Industrial Court. So it is a serious matter to advocate the breaching of those standards.

ANSWER.PARA: In the interview Mr Howard was asked whether he expected that small companies over the Christmas period would approach either the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia or the metal trades unions to remove the annual leave loading. Mr Howard agreed to that proposition. He then went on-I quote from the transcript I have-and said:

I would also expect that some of the small outfits would do it, but not tell anybody, and hope that both the unions and the Arbitration Inspectorate would have the common sense to turn a blind eye to it. I'm not encouraging anyone to go that path. But bearing in mind that they're getting an award varied under the centralised system is an horrendously complicated task, in reality that will probably happen in some cases and if it does happen then people should be sensible about the technical award breach that would be involved.

There are several things that can be said about this. The first is that Mr Howard does expect award breaches to occur and says that, if they do, by an act of omission by the responsible authorities, nothing should be done about it. Secondly, he has been careful to distance himself from anyone breaking the law, and that should be acknowledged. Thirdly, on a fallacious premise that it is horrendously difficult in this centralised system to achieve change, he has then said that if law breaking does occur nothing should be done about it in those circumstances, which I think is a bit like someone saying, `Fair cop' if they get caught smuggling a watch into Australia after returning from a holiday in Bali but saying that nothing should be done about it. I think that is a cavalier approach in all of the circumstances.
Senator Hill interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —When the law is breached, if it is breached-and Senator Hill is a lawyer, so he would know this-it is both technical and factual. If it is breached, it is breached-one cannot just breach it technically and assume that there is no other breach. If a person is in breach technically that person is gone and he or she should be dealt with according to the due processes of the law.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three points I make about this. The first point is that the premise that it is horrendously difficult to vary agreements in the workplace, which Mr Howard has based his views on, is in fact wrong. The assumption by those who argue that the arbitration system is inflexible and that it should be decentralised to the enterprise depends on them believing that proposition. But it is wrong, because section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act enables certified agreements to be reached and then to be registered in the Industrial Relations Commission. It does mean that employers cannot do deals privately and it means that they cannot engage in the sort of negotiation which says, `If you don't agree with this you'll get the sack'. There ought to be some way in which those private negotiations are policed properly so that they occur without exploitation.

The second point I make is that, while not advocating law breaking in the true sense-because there was a disclaimer in that statement-it comes awfully close to it in advocating that people who do break the law should not be dealt with. I would have thought that Mr Howard, as a former Treasurer, a former Leader of the Opposition and an aspiring Minister, would have said something better and more sensitive with regard to the rights of law.

I am not prepared to draw the conclusion that he has in fact advocated law breaking. I want to be generous and say that he has engaged in a bad choice of language in these circumstances; and that he should now acknowledge that he has, correct his position, draw attention to section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act and acknowledge the flexibility that exists there. If he wants to advocate industry level deals, which is fair enough, he should also stipulate that they should be conducted out in the open where they can be seen, that they are fair and that the rights of all parties are protected.

The Industrial Relations Commission does have a role to play in seeing that they are within wage fixing guidelines and that there is proper dealing between the parties. I think that Mr Howard should be very careful to remove any doubt from the public mind that a person in a responsible position such as he holds is coming close to or blurring at the margins any inference that law breaking is somehow or other a proper course in any circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports of Malaysia's withdrawal yesterday of its invitation to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Richard Woolcott, to attend official talks in Kuala Lumpur. I ask the Minister: Is the report correct? If so, what are the reasons for the withdrawal of this invitation? Has Malaysia also suspended officials' visits to Australia, or other official contacts? Is this yet another incidence, along with Fiji and India, where Australia's bilateral relations with important regional neighbours are less robust than the Minister would otherwise have us believe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some negative reaction at senior government level in Malaysia to what has been perceived as some offensive elements in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) television series Embassy. It is a reasonable assumption-although it has not been communicated officially in these terms-that the deferment of high level officials' talks involving Mr Richard Woolcott, which was reported this morning, is part of that reaction.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to that, let me just say that it has been made clear-by the Prime Minister publicly, by me in discussions that I have had with my Malaysian foreign ministerial counterpart and by the ABC-that the series was not intended to portray Malaysia, that it could not be reasonably regarded as portraying any specific country, and that it was certainly not intended to cause any offence to Malaysia.

There can be no question of the Australian Government seeking to exercise control or direction over, or to otherwise interfere with, the ABC or any other section of the media, however much we might wish on occasion, I suppose-whether we are talking in a domestic or a foreign policy context-that there was a bit more evident understanding of various sensitivities that are involved.

I simply say as to the future that I am hopeful that any lingering misunderstanding on this issue will shortly be resolved. The relationship between our two countries economically, politically and multilaterally through such processes as the Asia Pacific economic cooperation arrangements, the Five Power Defence Agreement and so on, is much too important to us both and has been much too stable in the past to be diverted by something of this kind. I do not deign to comment on the latter part of Senator Hill's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether I am correct in interpreting his answer to mean that in his assessment there is no reason, other than the program Embassy, for which Malaysia is taking this rather extreme action. Secondly, as he has raised the question of the program Embassy, I ask him whether it is the case that an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been providing specialist advice in the production of that program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my belief that there is no other stimulus for the present situation than that particular program. It may well be that that program is regarded as the culmination of a series of references to Malaysia, either direct or indirect, in the media in the past which are thought to have given rise to similar concerns and may in that sense be part of a longer chain of things, but it certainly has absolutely nothing to do with any other aspect of Government policy.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the remaining part of the supplementary question, it is the case that a former Australian head of mission in a number of posts-Beijing and Rangoon as well as Kuala Lumpur-Mr Garry Woodard was among the consultants for the series, but his activities in that context were and are now those of a private citizen. It is the case that there was some marginal consultation, I understand, with the public affairs division of my own Department in ensuring that the series presented embassy life realistically. The division was consulted about some aspects of that, but not in any way as to the advice that went to the present matters in issue, as I understand them.
Senator Walters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly not the case that the Department officially endorses the program or that it has any control over, or responsibility for, its location or its content. The situation is that the public affairs branch of my Department is available helpfully to all sorts of organisations when assistance is sought. I repeat that the media is perfectly free to make its own decisions about these things.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope, from the tone and tenor of Senator Hill's question and, more particularly, Senator Walters's interjection, that there is no hint of a suggestion that we should be responding in some way to this situation which involves acknowledging the legitimacy of reactions of the kind we have had from the Malaysian Government when the media does something that a country does not like. I would be very surprised if that was the position of the Opposition.

It is very important indeed that we maintain our principles intact in these situations. The truth of the matter is that the Government has no responsibility, and can have no responsibility, for the media in this situation. We can hope that they exercise a little sensitivity and are educated to understand the implications of what they do, but beyond that there is simply no action that we can take.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: What is the import duty on paints used by artists in Australia? Are these duties limiting the range of paints available in Australia and inflating the prices to unreasonable levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney gave me notice of this question in anticipation that I would not have known the rate of duty on paints. I can inform the Senate that the paints referred to are dutiable at the rate of 10 per cent when imported from general source countries and 5 per cent when imported from developing countries. These rates were set after the wide ranging review of the chemicals and plastics industries in 1986. I think the Senate would agree that tariff rates at these moderate levels are unlikely to be limiting the range of paints that could be imported into Australia. It is also unlikely that the import duties of themselves would be inflating prices to unreasonable levels. I am also informed that tariff concessions apply to some of those artists' paints which would mean that those paints could be imported into Australia duty free. This would supplement the range of paints available to Australian artists.

ANSWER.PARA: I add, on another note, as to whether or not the painting industry in Australia might be regarded as competitive, that last year Australian painters exported some $63m worth of paintings, which seems to suggest that there is not a hugely uncompetitive burden imposed on their raw materials by tariffs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McLEAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The question relates to the integration of repatriation hospitals into the general hospital system of each State. I preface my question by reminding the Senate of assurances offered by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the other place on 11 November 1988, as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister and I have given guarantees to the veterans' community, guarantees that are ironclad. If the veterans' community has any problems whatsoever in relation to integration and the rationalisation of the repatriation hospital systems, we will deal with those problems.

Honourable senators will also have seen the Minister's press release of 22 October 1990 in which he describes the integration as a `plus for veterans and the community'. However, the New South Wales Health Minister, Mr Collins, has said in the media that the State does not and will not hold out any guarantees of priority for veterans. I therefore ask: Does the Minister stand by his and the Prime Minister's ironclad assurances to the Parliament, veterans and the community? If the States refuse to guarantee priority to veterans, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that integration is indeed a `plus for all'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer for Senator McLean, who was courteous enough to give the Minister for Veterans' Affairs prior notice of his question yesterday. However, the honourable senator having been courteous in that regard, I regret to say that last night he released an uncharitable and incorrect press release, making judgments on the issues he is raising today. That seems to be something of a contradiction when he is seeking information, one would have thought in a genuine way, from me in this chamber. I think it reflects rather poorly on the honourable senator, and his press release of yesterday will cause unnecessary anxiety among veterans.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, let me start this answer with the assurance that the Commonwealth will always retain responsibility for veterans, war widows and their dependants. This Government has maintained a separate Ministry for Veterans' Affairs, a Department of Veterans' Affairs and a Repatriation Commission, and there will be no backing away from the compensation principles underlying the Government's and this Parliament's commitments to veterans.

The Government announced in 1988 the intention to integrate the repatriation hospitals into State health systems. It gave certain undertakings to veterans and staff. The Government stands by its promises to the veteran community and staff that their concerns will be addressed before integration of the repatriation hospitals takes place. The guarantees do not mean, however, that the Government will allow the negotiations to be frustrated by inflammatory remarks which distort the debate.

Senator McLean quotes the New South Wales Minister for Health, Mr Collins, as saying that New South Wales will not give any guarantee of priority for veterans. I remind the Senate that Mr Collins's comments came before the commencement of financial negotiations. The comments should not, therefore, come as any great surprise to informed political observers. More to the point, Mr Collins was also reported as saying that services for veterans in New South Wales public hospitals would be maintained. Senator McLean conveniently ignores this.

To put the integration debate into some context, might I inform the Senate that in New South Wales only about 33 per cent of all veterans admitted to hospital actually go to Repatriation General Hospital Concord-the rest are already treated in local public or private hospitals. Of those veterans and war widows living in the Sydney metropolitan area, surveys show that nearly 70 per cent say their preference is for public or private hospitals. The honourable senator makes no mention of the Commonwealth's proposal for a veterans' private patient scheme, which is being developed and refined through discussion and negotiation with affected parties.

The Government is not asking the public hospital system in New South Wales to admit veterans ahead of other patients with a greater medical need. Indeed, the phrase `priority of access' has never embraced the proposition that a veteran would get priority over anyone with a more critical medical need. It does not happen now, and it never will. Apart from anything else, that would constitute a breach of medical ethics. But the Commonwealth's private patient scheme would ensure that veterans and war widows in need of hospital treatment get the hospital access they need through a wider and better use of private hospitals, the public hospital system and the integrated repatriation hospitals.

For those honourable senators who may not have the background, the private patient scheme being offered would ensure that veterans have direct access as private patients in public hospitals. This gives a wider choice of doctor than the current arrangements. Those in medical need can enter private hospitals designated by the Department of Veterans' Affairs as preferred private hospitals if no public hospital bed is available within a reasonable time at no cost to themselves.

Where no public or preferred hospital can meet the medical needs, the Department will approve treatment at a non-Department of Veterans' Affairs preferred private hospital and pay all the costs. Treatment at an integrated repatriation general hospital will also continue to be available and be free of charge to the veteran.

I realise this answer is rather long, but I am afraid the question was rather long. I feel I should allay the fears and misgivings that have been aroused by Senator McLean in his press release of last night.

With integrated repatriation hospitals continuing to serve the ex-service community, the private patient scheme will mean that veterans will enjoy access to a range of hospitals and treatment which is unrivalled in this country and surely amongst the best in the world. Indeed, there have been expressions of support nationally from significant ex-service organisations, including the war widows, Legacy, totally and permanently incapacitated, and Korea and Vietnam veterans organisations. Naturally, these organisations expect the Government to satisfy them on the question of access and quality of care, and this care has been given.

An increasing number of veterans will prefer not to travel to a repatriation general hospital for their necessary medical treatment. As they age, most veterans will continue to want ready access to local hospital treatment, secure in the knowledge that the repatriation hospitals will be there if they need them. Hospital integration addresses all of these changing needs.

I conclude by observing that the option of increasing the numbers of community patients in the repatriation hospitals which has been advanced by some opponents of the scheme is not a viable one. The fears and misgivings aroused by Senator McLean can be well allayed by the answer I have just given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Tate for his long answer, which contradicts the statements I read out to the Senate. The point of the question is: Is the Minister not prepared to admit that because of the uncertainty of the response of State governments of a different political colour from the Federal Government, the Government is putting in place a system of hospitalisation which guarantees veterans nothing, assures them of nothing, despite the ironclad statements of 1988 and despite the contrary statements of October 1990? Is the Minister not prepared to acknowledge before the Senate and before the veterans community that there is an inherent contradiction and that a Federal Government of neither colour can guarantee veterans anything once this policy is implemented?

—Mr President, Senator McLean had already made his prejudiced mind up on this issue by issuing a press release last night, before he heard my answer. So I am not taking much notice of his assessment of the answer I just gave to the chamber. As for his claim that because politicians of different political persuasions are involved in the discussions-such as Mr Peter Collins-the matter will not be resolved and there will be great uncertainty in the community, I regard that as a slur on Mr Peter Collins. I am sure he would want to create a situation in which veterans in New South Wales receive the best possible hospital treatment. I am more confident that the discussions between Mr Peter Collins and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Ben Humphreys, will be fruitful and constructive on behalf of veterans.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen reports in today's media regarding Du Pont (Australia) Pty Ltd announcing today a cut of 30 per cent in its work force? Given the recent state of the industry report from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, can the Minister tell the Senate whether this proposed restructuring at Du Pont is consistent with the objectives of the textiles, clothing and footwear TCF plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the media reports today and the fact that the company is restructuring its Fibremakers Australia Pty Ltd operation. The company saw me last week regarding this matter; it also saw the Opposition spokesman and the unions. I would like to say at the outset that no-one certainly on this side of the Senate likes to see jobs disappear. In this case, I think the shedding of the 350 jobs announced today will ensure the continuation of the remaining 700-odd positions at Fibremakers. When Du Pont purchased Fibremakers, it was quite open about the fact that restructuring would need to take place in order to make that establishment into a world class fibre producer, especially in a non-tariff, non-bounty assisted environment.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that at the time that Du Pont took over the Fibremakers factory, the turnover rate had been about 40 per cent. The company had hoped at that time that any loss of jobs would be able to be accounted for by natural attrition. It also gave the commitment that there would be no redundancies before the end of this year. Since taking over the company, the labour turnover rate has fallen to 10 per cent, so restructuring without redundancies has become impossible. However, the company is keen to ensure that the employees are given plenty of time to plan and consider their options, and extensive counselling and outplacement services will be provided.

The recently released state of the industry report by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority made the point that the Australian textile in- dustries must restructure and invest to survive with lower assistance. The restructuring at Du Pont has already started, with the introduction of improved technology in production methods, and technology transfer is being achieved through an exchange program whereby United States technical employees are working short term in Australia and Australians are being trained in Du Pont plants overseas. In 1991 Du Pont will invest another $12m in equipment and processes in line with its commitment at the time of accepting the bounty capitalisation grant. That is entirely consistent with the objectives of the TCF plan. The phasing out of old processes and the new investment I believe will secure long term competitiveness for Fibremakers, which is what Du Pont has been all about. As I said before, while no-one likes to see job losses in industry, in the case of TCF industries it is a matter of restructure or be faced with the possibility of no jobs at all in the longer term.

I must say that the company Du Pont has been totally frank with the Government about these issues right from the beginning. The company from which Du Pont bought this plant clearly had too many employees engaged there. It was a recipient of government assistance on a continuing basis. Older parts of the plant were not being restructured or brought up to date, and the decisions made by Du Pont are necessary in terms of improving the company's performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. In light of recent statements made by the Minister and other members of the Government, including the Prime Minister, criticising the substantial salary increases allegedly given to chief executives in the private sector over the past couple of years, is it a fact that the chief executive officers in government business enterprises in general have received increases in their salary packages of two to three times the rate of increase in average earnings over the same period with some packages, such as in the case of Telecom, increasing in one year by more than $100,000 a year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should in the first instance say there is nothing alleged about what I have said about excessive senior executive remuneration. Everything I have said about that has been thoroughly documented and those documents have been tabled in this chamber. Those documents show a pattern in the private sector of massive increases for executives well above those going to ordinary wage and salary earners.

ANSWER.PARA: To the part of the question dealing with government business enterprises, I reply that the Senate will be aware that, under guidelines for government business enterprises, the Government cut free of control from the government the regulation of internal affairs of those enterprises to a very large extent. Subject to their complying with the wage fixing guidelines and things of that nature, they are basically free to negotiate their own management conditions. It is a poor reflection, I think, that in order to attract executive talent to head up some of those government enterprises, they have had to trade in the private sector where high senior executive salaries have been the norm. As a consequence, the disease that afflicts the private sector has to some extent been introduced into the government business sector because the Government has wanted to put those business enterprises on a fully commercial footing. That is not the fault of the Government; it is the fault of high level executive salaries obtaining in the private sector. In order to put some restraint on those government business enterprises, the Government has required, in the case of the main ones, them to submit any executive packages to the Remuneration Tribunal to ensure that they are not excessive in the sense of what obtains in the elite market of senior executives. That is being done.

I come back to the conclusion that if the market were not distorted in the first place, this problem would not exist, and when we are dealing with calls for restraint on the work force-restraint that has been observed massively by ordinary wage and salary earners in this country-such as the one initiated more recently by the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations in the other place, Mr Howard, who called for further restraint, we should look at senior executive salaries, I resile not one whit from that position. If that includes government business enterprises, which I believe it should, so be it, and let government business enterprise executives suffer-if that be the right word-the same restraint that we expect their work forces to suffer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Affirmative Action Agency in its report to Parliament named a number of companies which, despite the best efforts of the agency, have not complied with their obligations under the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act? Is it not also a fact that one such company, Suttons Investments of Sydney, has now been named in such a way three times; that is, on each of the three successive occasions on which the Agency has reported? Has the Minister any information which he can give honourable senators which explains or excuses the behaviour of this company? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what action is possible or would be appropriate against the company for its refusal to comply with the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that in the report tabled in the Senate yesterday 100 per cent of tertiary institutions in Australia complied with Affirmative Action Agency guidelines and 93.6 per cent of companies in the private sector complied as well. What we have here is a very high level of compliance, which means that the affirmative action legal structure gives legal force to the moral imperative for employers to more rapidly recognise the diversity of their work force and to apply affirmative action policies, in particular for women, migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds, disabled persons and Aborigines. Only 75 companies have refused to comply after exhaustive follow-up to encourage compliance and, I would say, a quite indulgent approach to delay and late returns. As a consequence of the naming of those 75 companies yesterday, three have rung the Affirmative Action Agency and promised to rectify the situation and put their returns in. I think that speaks very well of the fact that we are now seeing emerge in Australia a more tolerant workplace where human resource management recognises the diversity of labour, the need to run positive programs to promote that diversity and the fact that, where that is done, there are efficiency and productivity gains as well. That is a very welcome change.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Giles has referred to the company, Suttons Investments, which has not once, not twice, but three times refused to comply with the rules of the game. It is the only company in Australia that has done so. In the face of getting the two finger salute from Suttons three times in a row, we have to conclude that it is dinkum about being a militant non-complier. It seems to think that its act of non-compliance is some form of political statement. The only sanction we have in the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act is the sanction that the company shall be named and exposed, and so it should be.

Suttons is a major trading company in New South Wales. It could be compared with other companies in the service industry which are praised as models of affirmative action. Let me acknowledge with praise and pleasure, Westpac, Lend Lease, Esso, Hewlett Packard and the National Roads and Motorists Association, all of which have won best practice awards from the Affirmative Action Agency as model examples of what can be done. Suttons, however, stands out against that trend. Suttons has some small Commonwealth contracts in New South Wales, and it has been put to the Government that in this case we should sanction the non-compliance of Suttons by terminating those contracts.

At this stage I repeat: the only sanction we can take under the Act is to name the company. However, in the face of its militant, non-compliance the Affirmative Action Agency will now consult with major industry bodies and the Australian Council of Trade Unions to see, in the face of such a consistent determination not to join the civilised community in Australia but to stand out against the tide, what should be done. When those consultations have been completed, a decision in this case will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the disastrous locust situation in Western Australia where practically the whole agricultural area is in danger of being eaten clean, spelling disaster not only to farmers but also to the environment. Has the Government of Western Australia asked the Federal Government for help whether by way of extra funds or having the Royal Australian Air Force fly in extra spray? If so, can the Minister tell the Senate the result of those requests? If not, is the Government monitoring the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not advised by my colleague and the Minister whom I represent in this place, John Kerin, as to whether or not there has been an approach from the Western Australian Government for assistance to those farmers suffering the devastating effects of the locust plague in Western Australia. Since that question has now been explicitly asked, I will refer it to the Minister and obtain an answer on that point.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether we are monitoring the situation: yes, of course we are. I think one of the reasons why John Kerin is widely regarded as the best Minister responsible for primary industry that this country has had is that the groups in the primary sector recognise him as being an able representative in Parliament of their industry and acknowledge his expertise in keeping a check on situations such as this. I am absolutely certain that we are monitoring the effects, and I will get a reply directly on that point later.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to an article in the Melbourne Age newspaper last Monday which states that the interest payable on Australia's foreign debt now represents 20 per cent of Australia's export income and equals $700 per year for each woman, man and child in Australia. Does the Minister agree with the recent comments of the Minister for Finance, who predicted that the Budget estimate of 7.5 per cent unemployment by June next year will be exceeded? Does he agree that the high interest strategy has failed, despite the high cost of job losses, small business and farm failures and increased poverty? Will the Minister indicate whether the Government is now prepared to pursue more equitable policy measures to reduce Australia's foreign debt, including: higher withholding taxes on interest paid to foreign lenders; controls on large scale overseas borrowing by private corporations; accelerated depreciation allowances for export oriented projects, as recommended by the Australian Manufacturing Council; and protection for Australian primary producers equal to the subsidies foreign farmers receive from their governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that this question was asked towards the end of Question Time because the question was long and the answer could be longer. Let me say by way of summary that I recall the article to which the honourable senator referred. I have not checked the figures contained in that article, but it was an article by a reputable journalist and I have no reason to disbelieve the figures which are incorporated in that Age piece of 5 November.

ANSWER.PARA: The first question that Senator Spindler asked me was whether I thought the Budget predictions in respect of unemployment, the estimate of 7.5 per cent by June next year, will be exceeded. The current figure, as I understand it, is 7.6 per cent on an annualised basis. It would be wrong to say at this time that the projection in the Budget is discredited, although I concede that there are difficult times in respect of employment.

There has been a substantial fall in full time jobs which has been partly offset by growth in part time jobs. There has been no change in the participation rate when one might have expected a change in the participation rate, given the current labour market pressure. As to whether the high interest rate strategy has failed: yesterday the inflation figure, the consumer price index (CPI) figure, was published, and I think it is safe to say that the pressure which is exerted on inflation by a high interest rate regime has probably had an effect of dampening the inflation figure for the September quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably? Have you got some doubt about it?

—As Senator Crichton-Browne knows, there are always extraneous factors in the CPI in Australia. The figure in the previous quarter was enhanced by the effects of floods on fruit and vegetable prices. This did not happen in the September quarter. I think that can be seen to be a beneficial result of tight monetary policy and higher interest rates.
—And unemployment.

—If Senator Powell had her head together, she would recognise that both consequences flow from tightened demand, which results from high interest rates. She really has to work out what is the cause and what is the effect before she starts interjecting on the basis of the interjection she has just made. Let me say, however, that the cost of high interest rates for a substantial period of time has imposed very big difficulties on businesses. It has, as the Budget forecast, reflected itself in higher unemployment. It has had something to do with farm failures, but I think that one of the great underlying problems in relation to farm failures is market access for products such as wool, wheat and grains and that it is wrong to say that interest rates have been the most significant cause of farm failures.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Spindler then goes on to ask me whether the Government is now prepared to pursue more equitable fiscal policy to reduce Australia's foreign debt. I do not know what he means by `more equitable fiscal policy measures' when he specifies them as being higher withholding tax on interest paid to foreign lenders and controls on large scale overseas borrowings by private corporations. These two things I will direct to the Treasurer and ask for a more detailed reply. At least one of those things, the control on overseas borrowings, is something which the Australian corporate sector may have learnt something about from the patterns of the 1980s. Whether controls ought to be necessary or not is a totally different matter.

With regard to the question of accelerated depreciation allowances for export oriented projects as recommended by the Australian Manufacturing Council, I do not think the Government will accept that recommendation in the form in which it is made. However, that does not mean that the issue does not require examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any empiric evidence to help your cause?

—Well, Senator Crichton-Browne's Government always used to explain the resources boom of 1981-82 as being greatly supported by the investment allowance in place at the time. Whether that is empiric evidence or whether that is just political rubbish, I do not know. But certainly that Government used to claim that at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: The final question I am asked is whether Australia will match subsidies paid to overseas farmers. If we had all been in Venezuela or in the Parliament in Paraguay instead of in Canberra, we would have known, even in the dark, that that question had come from the Australian Democrats. Nobody else would ask a question like that. The answer to that question is no, we are not in a competitive world race to out-subsidise each other.

I do not know where Senator Spindler has been hiding in those Democrats offices all these years but, if he knew anything about the history of this country, the policy stances of various governments and so on, he would know that that was a silly question, because Australia cannot compete in the business of out-subsidising Europe and the United States. If he just has a quick perusal of the earlier part of his question, he will know precisely why we would not want to be in that business. So while I congratulate him on the comprehensive nature of his question, I cannot congratulate him on its total rationality. The rational parts will be examined and a further answer given in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister is prepared to give in at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of negotiations without standing up for our farmers. But I refer specifically to his offer to refer the higher withholding taxes query to the Treasurer. May I refer him to a similar promise he made two weeks ago to refer my question about removing the exemptions to the withholding tax to the Treasurer, to which so far no answer has been forthcoming.
—Senator Spindler notes my answer to the earlier question. I hope that, as the Italians say, Senator Spindler nota bene-he notes well-because he will get an appropriate answer in due course.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. In light of the Minister's humiliating admission that the Government made a monumental mistake in the Budget by not recognising the extent of the rural crisis, which he now describes as a disaster, and by setting what the Government now regards as clearly unrealistic assets test limits on the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, can the Minister please explain on what facts or consultations the original Budget decision was based? Will he also concede that the cavalier decision to send out forms to all family allowance recipients, based on the now altered figure, before the legislation had gone through the Parliament has resulted in another $400,000 going down the drain? What will be the cost of sending out new family allowance and family allowance supplement forms to additional recipients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I do not recall any humiliating backdown- far from it. The Government has properly analysed a change in circumstances. Estimates coming from the rural community when we were discussing these things in May and June are at wide variance with estimates that come now. The rural crisis was descending faster than anyone predicted last May and June. That is just a fact.

ANSWER.PARA: What do governments do? Do they simply ignore the facts? The reality is that if the Government examines the facts and reacts to them, the Opposition says that we are humiliatingly backing down; if on the other hand we ignore them, the Opposition says that we are too hard. The Government has done exactly what governments are supposed to do. We have analysed the facts as they have been brought to us. We have shown something that is simply unknown and foreign to Senator Alston: it is called compassion. Once again we have done that.

I am delighted that Senator Alston has now referred me to the `cavalier decision' to send out other forms. Senator Alston has been very active of late in coming out with estimates about what the Department of Social Security has been spending. We have been told how terrible it is that we have pot-plants in our offices-a shocking thing it is; we should have no pot-plants, according to Senator Alston. We have also been told that we use telephones in the Department of Social Security. We actually ring up clients! Senator Alston says, `This is terrible; no more phone calls'. One wonders what Senator Alston would have us do. Now we cannot send out forms either. That comes back to the privatisation idea. Do honourable senators remember the privatisation idea? It lasted two weeks. Now all that Dr Hewson's office will say is, `We have no comment; we have referred it to our policy making body'. It has disappeared and has died the natural death it should have before it started.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. On this occasion, you have to acknowledge that even the gesticulations indicate that the Minister was debating the answer to that question. It would be impossible on this occasion not to rule him out of order and follow the precedents of your predecessors.

—Order! There is no point of order. Before I call Senator Alston for a supplementary question, I point out that today's Question Time has been marked by some of the longest questions, the longest supplementary questions and the longest answers that I can remember, and has one of the lowest totals of any Question Time that I can remember. Next week I hope we can improve on it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We share your concern. What the Minister did a couple of minutes ago was perhaps to try to entertain his own troops and boost their morale, but he abjectly failed to answer either of my two questions. I ask them again: First, will the Minister please explain on what conceivable basis he made the decision two months ago in the Budget to bring in these draconian limits which he now says are quite unrealistic? Secondly, what will be the cost of the forms that he will now have to send out, given that he has already wasted $400,000 in sending out forms which now turn out to be thoroughly inappropriate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston should not have asked his supplementary question. I had not finished. I was interrupted by Senator Bishop. I am happy to continue with the answer that I was giving earlier.
—Just stop gesticulating.

—I will not gesticulate, Mr President. The cavalier decision-as Senator Alston referred to it-in sending out the forms is one that the Department of Social Security takes every year, and it has to when there are big Budget changes. It is the only way the Department will be able to get information to clients in time to give them plenty of warning. A change will now have to be made to a number of those forms. It is a change that the recipients of the notifying letters will welcome. It means that thousands more Australian families will have an opportunity to claim the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. They will not be complaining about receiving the letters nor the cost of them.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the cost of sending out whatever extra forms are required, I will attempt to get details for Senator Alston. I will attempt to do that as quickly as I can. I hope that by the time I have done that, however, Senator Alston will give us an answer on the $3 billion that the Opposition wants to cut from social security. We would all like to know where that will come from.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: ELECTORAL AND PLANNING SYSTEMS

ANSWER.PARA: The conference agreed that areas to be given the highest priority over the next 12 months are the home and community care program, health, aged care, housing, training and labour market programs, child-care and the supported accommodation assistance program. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November Senator Knowles asked me several questions concerning the so-called `blue file' marked `Govt' seized by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) from the office of convicted Western Australian private investigator, Robert Smith, in December 1988. The first question was: Was the then Attorney-General briefed on the content of the file? I answer: The AFP briefed me as the Minister for Justice on six occasions during 1988 concerning the AFP attention to the matter and their investigation into the commission of possible Commonwealth offences.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, I was asked: Did not the material indicate that in his work Mr Smith was investigating Liberal politician Mr Ross Lightfoot and was paid for this work at the expense of the then Labor Government headed by Brian Burke? Thirdly, I was asked: Does not the material suggest that instructions were given by Mr Burke and his services officer and driver, Vince Sherington? I am advised that there are ongoing inquiries being conducted by the Western Australian police concerning this matter, and it would therefore not be appropriate for me to provide a detailed response concerning matters that may subsequently be determined by a court.

I was then asked: Were the Federal Police satisfied that the file did not contain any evidence whatsoever of breaches of any Commonwealth legislation? I am advised that the file contained a reference relevant to part of the investigations conducted by the AFP into illegal telephone interceptions. In the opinion of the AFP the remainder of the subject file related to possible offences against the laws of Western Australia.

Finally I was asked: Why was the file delivered to the Western Australian Police Commissioner? Commissioner McAulay of the AFP directed that the file be passed to the Commissioner of the Western Australian police because of the view that the documents may have disclosed State offences which quite properly came within the jurisdiction of that force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling asked me a question in the Senate on 6 November relating to the changes in rosters for safety officers. I advised Senator Tambling that this had been drawn to my attention. I think it was about a week ago that I asked for it to be examined, and it has been. In fact, an answer was in my office as I discovered when I got back from Question Time yesterday. I must say that it was a very interesting answer indeed. Perhaps Senator Tambling should have contacted me before he leapt into print.

ANSWER.PARA: The revised airport safety officer roster was introduced two weeks ago; that is, Thursday, 25 October after numerous discussions with both unions and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) staff. This follows the recent review of the airport security officers' roster and is consistent with the Corporation's policy of effectively utilising resources to provide safe, effective and cost efficient operations at airports-a policy which I said in the chamber yesterday that I support. The hours of duty are 0630 hours to 2200 hours daily. There is currently a minimum number of regular public transport flights arriving in the Darwin Airport outside those hours. The number of flights that arrive per week in Darwin outside those hours is four-that is less than one flight a day.

The Corporation still has a 24-hour a day security presence at the airport along with 24-hour a day personnel from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), airport rescue and fire fighting services and 24-hour a day Royal Australian Air Force and CAA air traffic control service presence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Security is not safety.

—Senator Tambling does not understand what they even do. Documented emergency procedures reflect response requirement should an aircraft emergency occur. Off airport emergency services including police, ambulance and medical personnel respond in the event of any major emergencies on or off the airport. Corporation staff respond to aircraft emergencies with the safety officer providing the aviation communication link at the crash site for the Northern Territory police who have overall control and command of the incident. In such an event, the airport safety officer is but one of a number of FAC personnel who are required to respond. Airport safety officers were originally employed at airports to monitor the works in progress adjacent to aircraft movement areas and, as such, changes to safety officer rosters have not compromised aviation safety at the Darwin Airport.

ANSWER.PARA: Darwin Airport is not alone in this respect. Airports around Australia, and I am happy to provide Senator Tambling with a list of them, with far greater aircraft and passenger movements than Darwin, do not provide a 24-hour safety officer coverage. Airports are not required to have a safety officer in attendance for each aircraft movement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) I table a statement relating to transport and communications reform, and seek leave to make a statement relating thereto and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
PARLIAMENTARY STATEMENT BY THE
LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE
TRANSPORT AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS REFORM
8 NOVEMBER 1990
Mr President,
I wish to announce today a series of decisions affecting telecommunications and aviation-decisions which will help turn these industries into world-class performers.

These decisions are yet another instalment of the Government's drive for micro-economic reform-a process that is creating a more dynamic and efficient Australian economy, an economy that can take on and compete with the world's best.

These decisions are also just one part-albeit a critical part-of this Government's agenda of reform. They fit closely with the progress made at the Special Premiers' Conference on improving the efficiency of the processes of Government throughout Australia, such as in the important area of rail freight. They fit closely, too, with our real and steady progress in making our waterfront more efficient.

All of this activity has one central goal-a vital goal for every Australian: to equip our economy to deliver to its citizens the quality of life to which they justifiably aspire. For too long Australia was content to live with inefficiencies and low productivity in too many of our domestic industries. It is this Government's task vigorously and rapidly to sweep away those old arrangements and reshape our economy as a genuinely modern and competitive one.

That is the simple and unarguable logic that has driven this Government's commitment to, and achievements in, micro-economic reform. The sometimes arcane jargon of the micro-economic reform debate must not be allowed to obscure the urgency and importance of that goal.
Mr President, as I have indicated this is not the first time this Government has been able to report to Parliament on micro-economic reform-and it will most certainly not be the last.

However the decisions I will detail today represent perhaps our most significant achievement to date in this field. We have in the seven months since the election identified the issues in telecommunications and domestic aviation reform, consulted widely with those most directly affected by the changes, and formulated imaginative and bold policies.

I mention in passing, Mr President, that we also managed to fit into this tight timeframe an historic Special National Conference of the Australian Labor Party which altered our Party's platform to accommodate these changes. By any standard the speed of the Government's action in this area and our persistence in pursuing change is proof of our commitment to reform of telecommunications and domestic aviation.

Above all, Mr President, these reforms are marked by one special characteristic-they are real-world solutions to real-world problems. In this respect they are the antithesis of the half-baked ideas floated almost daily by the Opposition Leader and his front bench colleagues. Our reforms Can be implemented and they Will be implemented.
It is my important duty today to outline these reforms to the Senate in the context of a broader progress report on the micro-economic agenda.
Telecommunications

Mr President, for most Australian households, the telephone provides an essential lifeline to society; it is perhaps the most important instrument of modern life. For Australian business, it is literally an indispensable tool. It is no surprise that providing telephones and related equipment to Australians is a multi-billion dollar industry-in fact, it is one of our largest industries providing 143,000 jobs.

Telecommunications pose a number of unique challenges. The pace of technological change regularly sees the major advances of a few years earlier superseded by new discoveries. This can easily render regulatory structures out of date; it can also mean new export markets and employment opportunities can swiftly emerge for an efficient industry equipped to take them up.

So for Australia, we need to improve the efficiency with which we deliver telecommunications services within our country. It is equally clear that we must ready ourselves to take advantage of new export and job opportunities that will be created around the world, particularly with rapidly rising living standards in the Asia-Pacific region. The nations of the Asia-Pacific region have half the world's population but only 17 per cent of its 500 million telephones. Meeting the region's demand for new telecommunications services, servicing these vast new markets, poses an enormous opportunity for Australia.

So it is entirely right that this industry should be-as it has been-the subject of intense scrutiny and decisive action by this Government. Indeed we are taking one of Australia's biggest industries and reshaping it into a new, vastly more dynamic structure.

In 1987 and 1988, amid claims that sound familiar today about threats to Telecom jobs, we initiated a series of reforms allowing competition in the provision of customer equipment and value added services, and we established three far-reaching reviews which have resulted in today's major reforms.
These reforms may be divided into four parts:
establishing a new competitor;
developing new services;
strengthening the regulator; and
ensuring a strong publicly owned telecommunications company.

Each of these elements contributes to the same outcome: benefits for Australia that are potentially limitless. We will see massive new private investment in the Australian economy; an expansion-not a contraction-of total jobs; a fall in STD prices on major trunk routes by as much as 40 per cent; and the creation of substantial and enduring export opportunities.

The underlying conviction of these reforms is that introducing a new competitor into Australia will stimulate Telecom into lifting its performance for the customer-whether that customer is business or an ordinary household. But to ensure early benefits are obtained, it will be important to manage the first phase of competition carefully. In this first period with only one competitor to Telecom, AUSTEL and the Trade Practices Commission will be able to ensure Telecom is not able unduly to exploit its entrenched position of great strength. If this duopoly is to serve its purpose and if the possibility of collusion is to be avoided, it must have a finite term. We have decided that after 30 June 1997 the duopoly will terminate, paving the way for there to be no limit on network competition.

AUSSAT will form the base for the new competitor and it will have unrestricted rights to provide all telecommunications services. Legislation to this effect will be introduced to Parliament this evening.

AUSSAT will be sold and the new competitor will be up and running before the end of 1991. The sale will be carried out by a Task Force responsible to the Minister for Transport and Communications, based in his Department, and reporting both to him and to the Minister for Finance. All restrictions preventing AUSSAT from providing the full range of services will be removed by the end of this year.
Telecom's representatives on the AUSSAT Board have been directed to resign forthwith and the Government will purchase Telecom's shareholding at its commercial value as at 24 October 1990.

The new carrier will interconnect to the existing network at a price that will allow Telecom/OTC to recover the additional costs it incurs in providing facilities and services to the new carrier, and to underpin community service obligations.
Regulatory safeguards will be put in place to ensure effective competition:

We will require Telecom and OTC-separately, and after their merger into a new entity-to provide interconnection on an equal access basis to the second carrier for both domestic and international services;
We will subject Telecom/OTC to separate price caps for local, trunk, and international services;

We will ensure that Telecom carries and completes calls without diminution of quality on behalf of the second carrier, and provides it with all ancillary and supplementary services such as billing, operator and directory services, and full access to information about customers and traffic flows;
and we will insist on transparency in the financial transactions of both the new OTC/Telecom entity and the new carrier.
Our intention is to see new services develop both during the period of duopoly on the basic network and beyond.
During the period of the duopoly, up to 1997, a broad range of competitors to Telecom and the new entrant will be encouraged in markets other than the basic network.

First, we will licence a third mobile phone operator. The area of mobile telephony is booming; further technological and service improvements can be expected. It is, effectively, an alternative to local exchanges and, while expensive at present, it may, with further technological change, be the way of the future in telecommunications.
Additional mobile licences may be made available in 1995.
