Second, and in support of the decision on mobile telephones, the Government has adopted the AUSTEL report on Cordless Telephone services, allowing unrestricted competition in this area.

Third, we will remove all restrictions on resale, including on domestic and international telecommunications capacity. There will be no diminution of the rights of existing operators in this area. Furthermore, AUSTEL will review the terms of resale, including the extent to which resellers can establish their own switching equipment. These changes will provide a major boost to value added service operators, their business clientele and to research and development efforts.

Fourth, as the first phone monopoly held by Telecom ends on 30 June 1991, the Department of Transport and Communications, in conjunction with AUSTEL, will bring forward a Cabinet Memorandum on the appropriate network termination point for both licensed carriers prior to any new carrier arrangements coming into place. Telecom will, in any event, continue to offer a first telephone.
Mr President, the role of the regulator in conjunction with the Trade Practices Commission, in promoting early and effective competition will be pivotal.
In order to strengthen AUSTEL for this role, the Government has decided that AUSTEL's decisions on issues under its control will be absolute and final.
AUSTEL will be given the power and the resources to:
arbitrate on all interconnection charges between the two network carriers;
control numbering;
manage Australia's input to international standards
prevent the misuse of market power; and
report annually to the Government on safeguards and their effectiveness, and, importantly, on customer satisfaction.
AUSTEL will also have a role in ensuring that Australian industry benefits from these changes without compromising the overall objective of improved services for consumers.

Mr President, throughout our deliberations we have been determined to maintain a strong public-sector presence in Australian telecommunications, particularly because of its important role in discharging community service obligations. We will not place in the hands of future Treasurers or Ministers for Finance the responsibility for delivering services in areas where competition does not eventuate, nor do we expect a new philanthropic owner for Telecom could be found who would provide them.
We will not attempt to deceive the people of Australia into believing that such an option is practical.

We will ensure that the community's expectations are met: that prices fall in real terms across a range of services; that untimed calls continue to be offered to households; and that rural and remote services do not vanish.

Telecom operates, for principally domestic purposes, a well-balanced telecommunications network but it does not have a major export focus. In part, this is due to an artificial barrier between Telecom and OTC. This barrier will be removed by the Government, and a new corporate focus provided by merging the organisations.
That focus will have three basic purposes:

first, under the challenge posed by a new, privately-owned and fully-resourced competitor, to pass on to customers in the form of lower prices and better service, the huge productivity gains that are inherent in this industry's technological explosion;

second, to provide the basic opportunity for the new entrant to compete, encouraged both by the decisions of a newly-strengthened AUSTEL and the incentive created by the terms of the merger process itself; and
third, to market its combined strengths overseas aggressively and to pursue with much greater vigour than previously its undoubted abilities in research and development.

A fee will be paid to the Government as a result of the merger of Telecom/OTC. The level of that fee will be set by the Government in consultation with the new entity. It will also pay a fee for its mobile phone licence.

In order to ensure that interconnect and equal access arrangements between the carriers are not unnecessarily delayed, AUSTEL will have to certify that these are in place in all capital cities and will soon be available in provincial cities before the merger is finalised.
Until that time, OTC and Telecom will operate independently but with the benefit of an interim group board to oversee their collective operations in the transition to competition.
Aviation
This month marks the beginning of deregulation, with the abolition of the Two Airlines Agreement.
By terminating this infamous relic of Coalition inertia, we have opened the door to dramatic growth in this vital sector of modern transport.

The latter-day converts to micro-reform who sit opposite displayed their true colours when they were in Government with their consistent failure over decades to remove this Agreement. They were responsible for slowly strangling domestic aviation and pushing high costs onto the Australian consumer.
As a result of our decision to terminate the Agreement, we see new services, lower prices, a new airline-hard evidence of the value of the decision to Australian consumers.

In order to strengthen the hand of current and future entrants into domestic aviation, and in order to provide an appropriate environment for the sale of Australian Airlines and part of Qantas, the Government has decided to:
lift the foreign investment limits relating to investment in Australian domestic airlines by foreign airlines servicing Australia from 15% to 25% for an individual holding, and to 40% in aggregate;
maintain a stable policy environment for aviation for the remainder of this Parliament.

This decision to put further major policy change in this area on hold is sensible. It would be madness to introduce a major change such as deregulation and not give it a chance to work. It would similarly be stupid to attempt to sell the airlines while shifting the goal posts for potential purchasers. Our decision preserves future policy options.

The foreign investment changes offer clear opportunities for the New Zealand carrier to enter the Australian market. In addition, we have opened up the freight route across the Tasman and are now nominating two additional carriers to serve that market. In the light of these decisions, we will also discuss with New Zealand the question of closer aviation relations in the context of next month's review of the Closer Economic Relations arrangement.

Mr President, the sale of 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of Qantas will strengthen them and enable them to provide much improved services to Australians and Australian businesses. They will be recapitalised. They are likely to form strategic partnerships. In all, they will be more competitive, and this nation will be better off as a result.

The sale of both airlines will be handled by the Minister for Finance in close consultation with the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Government will take its own decisions on the issues related to sale, but it recognises that the airline boards have a right to be heard.

Special arrangements will apply to the part-sale of Qantas. In order to accord with our bilateral air service agreement, the foreign investment limit in Qantas will be set at the generally accepted international benchmark of 35%.

In addition, although Qantas will remain as our single designated international passenger carrier for the foreseeable future, the Government recognises that-with the success of our reforms of international charter programs for air freight-there is a potential role for a second designated freight carrier. A process is currently under way to assess expressions of interest.

Australia, Qantas and our tourism industry will continue to benefit from our intention to continue to sign new bilateral Air Service Agreements and to welcome charter programs. There are gains still to be made, both from traditional markets and from a more intense focus on regional opportunities.
Land Transport

It is not a well-recognised fact that of all the areas of micro-economic reform, land transport offers the greatest potential gains. The Industry Commission has estimated these to be worth over $4 billion a year.

At the recent Special Premiers' Conference, the Premiers, Chief Ministers and the Prime Minister cut through the remaining disagreements to set in place fundamental reforms in both road and rail operations in this country.

As the Prime Minister made clear earlier this year in calling the Special Premiers' Conference, our rail systems in this country cannot operate efficiently with their present structure. Inter-state freight alone loses $300 million a year, excluding efficiency losses from traffic now on the roads which might more appropriately be handled by rail.

Our commitment to improving competitiveness required us to redress these imbalances through seeking State agreement to form a National Rail Freight Corporation: this will involve new investment, new industrial relations standards and new rail management. A Heads of Agreement has been signed by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, committing all Governments to work towards a start-up date of July 1991.

Following the Premiers' Conference, the hard bargaining on asset values, equity considerations, reform of labour practices and other issues will commence. The Commonwealth's role is clear. We are prepared to contribute significantly to the success of the venture. We expect the States and the unions to do so as well, including particularly in respect of manning levels and work practices.

The new Rail Freight Corporation will not justify the effort necessary from unions and governments if the heaviest road transport vehicles do not themselves bear a proper share of the costs of using roads. Current efforts by some States to recover costs through registration fees have been frustrated because transport operators have simply been able to register their vehicles interstate. But the damage to the nation's roads continues.
The Commonwealth, States and Territories have agreed to the following objectives:
first, introduction of nationally uniform technical and operating regulations and driver licensing arrangements;

second, the progressive introduction of nationally consistent road user charges having regard to principles established by the Interstate Commission, with a view ultimately to achieving full recovery of the cost of road use; and
third, clearer definition of responsibilities between different levels of Government for funding and managing elements of the road system, aimed at eliminating duplication.
The Government intends to take a continuing interest in the implementation of these changes. We expect that the Premiers will do likewise.

We all recognise that the road transport industry is vital to our future. It is the lifeblood of many of our industries. As we introduce the changes I have detailed today, we will keep the industry informed and respect its views. In turn, we expect that the industry will acknowledge the common sense underlying these reforms.
The Waterfront
Mr President, more has been said about the waterfront than perhaps any other industry issue in this country. This Government has not, however, joined the queue of people who complain but do not act.
The waterfront reform plan which we adopted last year has already yielded significant results:
new stevedoring arrangements for bulk grain ships, reducing manning levels by 70%
retirement of 280 gangway watchmen
recruitment and training of 200 new waterside workers
development of an interim award agreement to facilitate award restructuring and the negotiation of enterprise agreements; and
most importantly, enterprise agreements currently being concluded at two of the largest terminal operations in Sydney and Melbourne.

These agreements are expected to be forwarded shortly to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority for its independent assessment. National Terminals (Australia), the company negotiating these agreements, has publicly stated that it expects productivity gains of up to 60%.

The continuing process of waterfront reform also includes involvement by the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority to enhance the competitive environment on the waterfront and ensure that users receive the benefits of reform.
Improvements in the efficiency of the Australian shipping fleet continue to be made under our Shipping Reform Strategy.

To date, in excess of 350 seafarers have accepted voluntary early retirement packages. At the end of June 1990, the average crew size for the Australian fleet was 25 compared with 33 six years ago. By June 1992 it is expected that the average crew will be 21. All this continues to be achieved with no industrial disputation.

Mr President, at the outset of my comments today I described this Statement as a progress report. I emphasise the word `progress'; Australia is now making progress, achieving fundamental and lasting reform, in industries that for decades had seen no progress, no reform.

So I repeat the Government's challenge to the Opposition. Let them point to a period of Australian history that has seen faster or more profound micro-economic reform. That challenge remains unanswered of course because, as the Prime Minister has said in the past, there is no earlier period that comes within a bull's roar of the progress we have made and are continuing to make.

For 31 of the 34 years before we came to office, Australia was ruled by the dead hand of conservative inertia in which notions of reform to achieve productivity and efficiency were totally alien. That legacy of neglect and of abrogated leadership is a heavy burden still borne by the Coalition parties.
Let me conclude by discussing the method of progress: its pace and process.

The Senate should note that the progress we have made has been with little industrial disputation and with the emphasis on patient negotiation with all the parties involved. The Government has not failed to be firm where firmness is needed, but we have refused to indulge in the confrontationist tactics that are so often urged on us. That is why it has been swift reform.

Against this, some professional commentators outside the Parliament, and most of the amateur ones opposite, often call for a faster pace of reform. The secret of faster reform, we are told, lies in the amount of hair on the chest of Government: solutions should be imposed unilaterally by Government and let the devil take the hindmost.

One can tell these commentators are not living in the real world by the way they float new proposals. When they are presented with irrefutable evidence of Government progress in micro-reform, their sole response is to play catch-up: `Oh, we'd do that-and more'-as if the mere wish could be the father to the deed.

Fortunately for the nation, those in this Parliament who indulge in these stupidities do so from the safe impotence of Opposition. It is fortunate, because their whole approach is a recipe for disaster.

Lacking any sort of detailed strategy of how they would actually achieve reform, they are forced to peddle the pleasant deception that easy reform and painless change can be won through confrontation.

Of course real progress is not made by bringing the nation to a stand-still in some pointless industrial confrontation; real progress can only be made by harnessing businesses, trade unions, and governments in a cooperative pursuit of their common interests.

Mr President, there are no easy reforms or painless changes to be made. Reforming entrenched community attitudes and institutions is hard work-but it is hard work this Government is determined to undertake and to bring to effective conclusion.

That way, Mr President, there will be many more progress reports from this Government describing our continued, effective and rapid progress in micro-economic reform, creating an increasingly efficient, productive and competitive nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a document entitled Micro-economic reform: Progress, Telecommunications and seek leave to move a motion to take note of the statement and document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I listened to the radio this morning and read the press reports about what was likely to be contained in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today on micro-economic reform I was surprised and almost excited because it sounded as though at long last, after seven and a half wasted, barren and destructive years, the Government was going to produce something meaningful in the crucial area of micro-economic reform. I should not have been surprised nor should I have been excited because that was very quickly shown on the briefest of glances at the Prime Minister's statement not to be the case -and I thank the Government for the advance notice of the statement which I received a couple of hours ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement is long on rhetoric as is customary with the Prime Minister and the Government, but it is short of any new proposals. There is virtually nothing in this statement today that is new, with one important exception in the telecommunications area where the Government has announced a policy change which is an important concession and acceptance of a point that we have been making on this side of the chamber about competition in the area of telecommunications.

But one must ask, having looked at the Prime Minister's statement, just how fair dinkum the Prime Minister and the Government are on the question of micro-economic reform. It is patently obvious that they are not. Back in August 1987, just after the 1987 election, one of the leading commentators in Canberra reported:

For the last three years the PM and several of his Cabinet colleagues have, on each State election, wrung every ounce of fear out of the cost of privatising various State government instrumentalities . . . Now, only weeks after the Federal election, Mr Hawke has undergone a St Paul like conversion . . . called on his party and the community to debate the virtues of privatisation.

Of course, privatisation is a major plank of the coalition's policy-a very cohesive, constructive and comprehensive set of policies-to promote micro-economic reform. The Prime Minister had a conversion. It is only now that he is beginning to act on it. Many of his colleagues have not yet been converted. One of the great battles to be fought within the Australian Labor Party over the period ahead, just as it has been in the last year or so, is the fight between the Left and Right over what should happen by way of ownership in Australia's public business undertakings. That fight is by no means concluded. Indeed, to date the fight has been won by the Left and not by the Right because the measures that the Prime Minister and his Government have taken in relation to the privatisation of public enterprises has been minimal at best.

The Prime Minister has made much of micro-economic reform as a major instrument and area for policy. That is a statement with which the coalition would fully agree. Indeed, it is the coalition that has been making that very point and heading the debate on this issue for many years. Surprisingly-perhaps it is not surprising-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) once again disagrees with his Prime Minister. It is only a few months ago, in fact a year ago almost to the day, I think, that the Treasurer was reported in the Canberra Times as saying:
Compared to macropolicy it's relatively small beer.

It is about time that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, ostensibly the two chief architects of economic policy in this country, got their act together and decided what is important and what is not important in the interests of this economy.

Urgency and speed of reform has been a constant theme today of the Prime Minister's speech. This is surprising since this has been the major failing of the Government. The Government has failed to act on reform, particularly micro-economic reform despite the rhetoric that it was the prime objective of his Government's third term. I remind the Senate that it was micro-economic reform that the Hawke Government said, on coming into office in 1987 for its third term, would be the prime requisite of government consideration during that term. The Prime Minister was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 27 August 1987 as saying that:

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, yesterday committed Labor to sweeping economic efficiency reforms involving reduced protection, transportation deregulation, work practices reform and asset sales; establishing microeconomic adjustment as his third term priority.

Who could forget the salutary, positive and accurate comments after the last election by the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, lamenting the fact that the Hawke Government had lacked the guts to take the hard decisions in terms of policy reforms in the micro area. Now into the fourth term of government we still have only, to use the Prime Minister's own words today, `a progress report'. Opportunities in this fourth term continue to pass the Government by and, if today's statement is any indication, they will continue to pass the Government by throughout this fourth term in office.

There are other problems of a major nature looming on the Government's own front, and within the Government. It is only six months ago that Mr Dawkins called for an announcement of major reform measures pre-Budget, possibly in the form of a separate micro-economic statement or, he said, `face annihilation at the next election'. There was a deafening silence from the Government at that time. Just last month the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Fraser, said, `It's disappointing that we didn't find more references to micro-economic reform in the Budget'. They are very perceptive statements because they accurately reflect the situation so far as this Government's actual performance in the micro-reform area is concerned.

Micro reform is in many ways a very arcane word. Very few people actually understand what the term means, and it probably means different things to different people. My understanding of micro reform is that it is really about removing impediments to efficient and effective operation of the economy. It is essentially about making markets work better.

The improvements that the Government is proposing to make with one hand will be more than offset by putting greater impediments in new areas. I interpose to say that there are aspects of the Prime Minister's statement today, and there are aspects of other Government activities in recent times in this area, which the Opposition welcomes and applauds. Many are actions that we have been advocating for some time. The problem is that they go only a minuscule way down the necessary road.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are half-baked.

—As my colleague said, they are half-baked; they are Mickey Mouse advances. Yesterday-and here comes the problem for the Government-Mr Dawkins, one of the senior Government Ministers, said that we need to take a step `beyond adherence to the market and the level playing field', and that we need to be `supporting those of our best performers who have prospects of doing better'. If support means getting the economy back on the right track, that is fine, but not if it means selective subsidies and support measures, as I think the Minister meant.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button was reported in the Australian Financial Review yesterday as having `signalled to his Cabinet colleagues that he would be proposing selective measures aimed at boosting the export and import replacement capacity of Australian manufacturing industry'. It has also been reported to the effect that specific forms of assistance across a wide range of areas were being considered not only by Mr Dawkins and Senator Button, but also by Ministers Kerin, Beazley and Howe. Those statements coming out of Cabinet and out of the Government spell very grave danger for the Government in keeping anything like a coherent economic policy. It has not been able to adopt such a policy to date. It has been all over the ship in terms of its economic policy. Obviously that will be a more difficult task in the months ahead, given the restlessness and divisiveness between Ministers and senior Ministers of the Government.

I would make one other comment before getting into the detail of the Prime Minister's statement-the statement is more notable for what it does not mention as for what it does mention. There is no mention at all in the statement about the critical linkage between micro-economic policy and macro policy. There is no mention of the crippling damage that the Government's failure in macro-economic policy has done not only to the economy but also to the very process of micro-economic reform itself. There are several other critical areas requiring reform that are not mentioned in the statement at all. I note in particular that there is not one word in the Prime Minister's statement today on the question of the reform of wages and industrial relations policies-reform which is almost the sine qua non of creating a productive, competitive and efficient economy.

I now turn to the Prime Minister's statement. My colleagues, Senator Kemp and Senator Alston, will be commenting on several specific items in the statement so, given the arrangement with the Government concerning time, I shall attempt to be selective. I welcome the Prime Minister's statement that the need for micro-economic reform and the need to make progress in terms of the creation of a competitive and efficient economy are essential above all. What I criticise greatly is that one would have to doubt, given the Government's record, the commitment and the achievements.

The Prime Minister says that the Government has been driven to a commitment to and achievements in micro-economic reform. What is the commitment of this Government in terms of micro-economic reform? If there were a commitment, we would have seen achievements. What are the achievements? The achievements in terms of micro-economic reform in the 7 1/2 years that this Government has been in office are virtually nil. He went on to say:

. . . the decisions I will detail today represent perhaps our most significant achievement to date in this field. We have in the seven months since the election identified the issues in telecommunications and domestic aviation reform, consulted widely with those most directly affected by the changes and formulated imaginative and bold policies.

What the Prime Minister is really saying there is that it is really only in the last seven months that the Government even started looking at these matters. That is as great an indictment as anyone could make, certainly from one's own mouth, of a sterile, barren failure in the preceding seven years that the Labor Party has been in government.

It is almost as if the Prime Minister in his statement today has been in a time warp. What has happened to the seven years between 1983 and 1990? I will tell the Senate. What has happened is that the Government has produced a set of macro-economic policies which has led this country down the path to lower living standards, lower productivity, lower efficiency and a lack of competitiveness in an increasingly internationally competitive world. That is the reason why we have foreign debt in excess of $125 billion. That is why we have inflation, despite yesterday's figures, still running at twice the average of our trading partners. It is why we still have the highest interest rates and almost the lowest productivity in the Western World.

The standards that have been achieved in Australia in all those areas-the pace of economic reform of which the Prime Minister has been boasting in terms of micro-economic reform and the speed of the Government's actions-are certainly not the standards of the rest of the world. Anyone who has been to Europe recently will know that Europe is leaving us for dead in terms of its improvements in the areas of productivity, competitiveness, efficiency, opening up of markets internally, and the like. We are lagging badly behind many of our Asian neighbours. One has only to look at the four dragons-Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea-and increasingly at more and more countries in our region, notably Thailand in the last couple of years. We are getting further and further behind the eight ball and, if statements of the nature produced by the Government today are indicative of the Government's serious intent in this area, it is obvious that we will fall further and further behind.

My colleague Senator Alston will deal at some length with the Government's statement today in relation to telecommunications decisions. For that reason, I will not touch on that in the time available.

In the area of aviation, the Prime Minister has confirmed the 100 per cent sale of Australian Airlines Ltd by the Government and 49 per cent of the equity of Qantas Airways Ltd. He has also mentioned that the Government has decided to lift the foreign investment limits relating to investment in Australian domestic airlines by foreign airlines servicing Australia from 15 to 25 per cent for an individual holding and to 40 per cent in aggregate. That is a welcome decision. In the case of Qantas, the Government has raised the figure for foreign participation to 35 per cent. That figure is the generally accepted international benchmark.

I note that the sale of both airlines is going to be handled by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) in close consultation with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). Presumably that means that the sales are going to be handled by the Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales, which is established within the Department of Finance and which I would have to say has a quite appalling record to date in terms of its handling of such matters as the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. I note that Mr John Langmore, the Labor member for Fraser, in a letter today to the Minister for Finance, has said that the Federal Government has not got a cracker out of the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. Indeed, it has probably cost the Commonwealth a net $8m to give it away.

The handling of that Housing Loans Insurance Corporation sale is appalling as is the absolute botch-up taking place at the moment in terms of the attempted sale of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline. Everything is shaping up for a similar botch-up to occur in the case of the sale of the 30 per cent equity in the Commonwealth Bank. Setting that aside, although one wonders what that means for the sale of Australian Airlines and Qantas, the question that the Opposition would ask is why the Government is selling only 49 per cent of Qantas. Why is it not taking the proper route that it knows it should take and selling 100 per cent of Qantas?

It is only a few months ago that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were trying to talk up that path within the Australian Labor Party. They were rolled by the left wing of their Party and hence they have had to settle for second best by selling 49 per cent of the equity. That does not do anything to increase the efficiency or the competitiveness of Qantas. There is no change as a result of that in the management, the operations and the functions of Qantas. They should have bitten the bullet, defied their left wing and gone ahead and done something in the interests of the nation. They should have sold the whole of Qantas, just as they have proposed to do-and welcomingly so-in the case of Australian Airlines.

What the Prime Minister has said in relation to the reform of the waterfront in his speech today was, at best, highly misleading. For example, he said that the waterfront reform plan which the Government adopted last year had already yielded significant results. He said that the new stevedoring arrangements for bulk grain ships had reduced manning levels by 70 per cent. That is right, although it is an upper estimate. What he did not say was that none of the manning that has been freed up from that has left the industry; it has just been put into different parts of the industry. Excessive manning remains a net cost to the waterfront industry because those people have gone back into general labour pools.

The Prime Minister says in his statement that the reform plan has led to the retirement of 280 gangway watchmen. But that is not true in the sense that it followed from the reform plan because that was set in train long before the reform plan was introduced. So that result is quite independent of the Government's reform actions. He talks about the development of an interim award agreement to facilitate award restructuring and the negotiation of enterprise agreements and says that enterprise agreements are currently being concluded at two of the largest terminal operations in Melbourne and Sydney. Again, that is misleading in the extreme. There have been no agreements signed as yet, either in Melbourne or in Sydney. Given the history of the waterfront and the negotiations of the waterfront, one would not be wanting to hold one's breath until the agreements have been signed and the ink has dried.

One could make similar comments about the final area he mentioned, namely, land transport. We would agree with the Prime Minister that land transport does hold the potential to be the most important of all the micro-economic reforms and that it is not a well-recognised fact. We would point out to the Senate that the reason it is not a well-recognised fact is that the Labor Government has not cared about roads and land transport at all. Road funding has fallen by over 25 per cent in real terms since the Government came to office and rail has not had any funding from this Government until this financial year.

Time does not permit me to proceed any further. Let me conclude by saying that micro-economic reform is vitally important-it is something that we on this side of politics have pursued for a long time-and it should be treated as such. It should be comprehensive and cohesive. The Government's approach is none of those things. That is confirmed today by the very disappointing statement by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This prime ministerial statement formalises the greatest sell-out by this Australian Labor Party Government of its responsibility to govern in the interests of all Australians. It demonstrates the agenda of this Government: a bias towards big business and a selling off of the family silver, masquerading under the description of micro-economic reform. That is why I believe it was incorporated in this chamber and not delivered by the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley).

SPEECH.PARA: This prime ministerial statement is full of copybook propaganda and unsupported assertions and it reeks of past claims made in the name of deregulation and competition-claims which have been shown not to have been delivered. Micro-economic reform, macro-economic reform, competition, deregulation, and free trade are the buzz words of this decade. I agree that we do need increased productivity and changes in work practices in some areas, and this will yield significant benefits. But we need to agree upon where such reform is really needed. It is probably most vital on the waterfront.

I recently heard a Business Council of Australia spokesman saying that micro-economic reform in telecommunications is not urgent. So who is the Government seeking to please in this? Is it the econocrats in Canberra or is it this simple tactic of wanting to usurp the Opposition? After asking us to accept in blind faith all the details, the Government is now going to tell us how it proposes to allow private interests to profit from publicly owned $10 billion per year businesses. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says in this statement that these reforms will help turn these industries into world-class performers. He refuses to acknowledge that the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) Ltd is already widely recognised as one and that Telecom Australia is already widely recognised as a leader in the provision of new services to business and fibre optic technology.

The Prime Minister talks about equipping our economy to deliver to its citizens the quality of life to which they justifiably aspire. Perhaps he is talking about a quality such as in the United States of America and the United Kingdom, where 20 per cent of citizens cannot afford to own a telephone. He knocks Telecom's inefficiency. Last year Telecom reported a $1,291 billion profit. Its return on assets was 12.3 per cent. It invested $3 billion in new capital works, which will reduce costs. It showed a productivity improvement of 9 per cent-three times that of Australian industry as a whole.

The Prime Minister also talks about not letting the arcane jargon of micro-economic reform obscure the urgency and the importance of that goal. In fact, I believe that the Government deliberately uses this jargon to obscure the reality of the ramifications of these proposed reforms.

Sixty-three per cent of respondents to a recent Newspoll survey described the Government's handling of the telecommunications debate as confusing; 27 per cent thought it was just a revenue raiser; only one in 20 thought it was designed to help the economy-a rather astute observation, I think-and 79 per cent said that they would stay with the merged Telecom-OTC Ltd in the form of Auscom.

I do not believe that this Government reform is really motivated by micro-economic reform. It is simply an attempt to cover up bad decisions made in the past, such as the decision made on Aussat Pty Ltd. Mr Keating and the econocrats have been amazingly successful in achieving their backdoor privatisation through starving our government business enterprises (GBEs) of funds.

The Prime Minister, in this statement, claims that wide consultation helped the Government formulate imaginative and bold policies. The contact I have had with consumer groups and with people from within the affected industries themselves indicates that this consultation was rather restricted and probably with the Prime Minister's mates in big business. This Government suffers a cultural cringe and it is simply attempting to implement failed models of overseas telecommunications. This is not imaginative and it is not bold; it is just plain stupid.

The Prime Minister calls these reforms `real world solutions to real world problems'. The reality is that Australia, as Mr Dawkins said yesterday, is a country with a Third World economy. The Prime Minister's solution to this is to sell off the family silver, as well as the farm, which he has been successfully selling off for the past few years, in a short term garage sale. This is no substitute for micro-economic reform.

The Prime Minister claims that this will be a major boost for Australian industry, particularly for telephone manufacturers. The United States example shows that, because of cheap equipment from South East Asia, the majority of telephone manufacturing companies in the United States no longer exist. The foreign competitor allowed into Australia will have existing supply arrangements and I believe these will continue for its Australian operation. Workers in this industry have every reason to be concerned for their jobs.

The Prime Minister talks of cheaper subscriber trunk dialling rates. Yes, this will be to the benefit of big business users, but it will make little difference to ordinary consumers. Their small benefits will be eaten up by higher rates for other services. The Prime Minister talks of no timed local calls but says nothing about alterations to the boundaries which define `local'. He says that rural and remote services will not vanish but says nothing of the cost of obtaining these services-a clever exercise in semantics.

Finally, we get official notification sneaked in the middle of the document that the much vaunted duopoly arrangement is to finish on 30 June 1997. This is the date the Labor Government has decided to finally implement the policies of the Opposition. The Prime Minister's vitriolic attack in this document on the Opposition now seems decidedly hollow. I am sure that he will get the same reward from traditional Labor voters as that received by the New Zealand Labour Party just recently, and deservedly so.

This new competitor is to interconnect to the publicly owned Telecom network at a price which takes no account of the huge investment that each and every Australian family has already made to that basic network. That investment is about $3,500 for every ordinary household. Ordinary Australians have paid to establish a network from which big business will gain an enormous profit at their expense.

In addition to this bargain basement interconnect price, the new merged Telecom-OTC will be prevented from competing effectively and on open terms or on the so-called `level playing field' by government imposed price caps. The terms of the competition are to be overseen by Austel, which is to be beefed up somewhat. While it is all very well to give the regulator more power-and is it not ironic that the more we deregulate, the more we have to set up these stronger regulatory bodies?-we must ensure that it will indeed represent the interests of all consumers and not just those of big business.

In the statement, the Prime Minister addressed reform in aviation. He again resorted to abusing the Opposition and talked about the infamous relic of coalition inertia. Once again, we see that he has set the stage for implementing the Opposition's favourite policies. It is rather hypocritical of him to keep pointing to the past in this way. He claims that the Government's deregulation of this industry has given us new services, lower prices and a new airline. I can count the number of new services, those which fly after curfew hours, on my right hand. The claim of lower fares rings hollow to all those people who are trying to make bookings to fly over the Christmas period. There are all sorts of restrictive conditions on these so-called lower fares. And to hold up an airline company which operates only two leased aircraft as a shining example of deregulation is a joke. No offence is intended to Mr Gray of Compass Airlines.

I turn to land transport. I agree that perhaps the greatest test of the Government's micro-economic reform process will be land transport. For years the public has subsidised road transport. It is true that rail offers huge benefits in terms of reducing environmental impact and lowering the number of road fatalities. We need to ensure that these modes of transport are-to quote another current buzzword-on the level playing field.

We support the establishment of the National Rail Freight Corporation. But it seems somewhat ironic that we are setting up a rail freight GBE at the same time as we are flogging off others to private enterprise. It causes me to wonder whether the same thing will happen to this new one a few years down the track. I ask the question that I always ask: Why is it seen as wrong for the Government to own profitable and valuable enterprises which bring returns to all Australians?

The Government starved Aussat of the funds it needed to compete aggressively in the areas of data services, private networks and the carriage of television services. In a market worth around $800m a year, Aussat captured only 2 per cent of the market when it could have attracted around 9 or 10 per cent. The Government also denied Aussat access to the potentially lucrative South East Asian market. So now the inevitable has occurred-Aussat is to be privatised, and the carrot for the buyer is a licence to compete on the basic network. And that is what this so-called micro-economic reform debate is really about-a failed decision, a bad decision, on Aussat and a failure to admit it.

Australian Airlines is clearly outperforming Ansett Airlines of Australia. Yet the Government has chosen to deny Australian access to the capital it desperately needed. Now its need for funding is used as the justification for privatising it. Similarly with Qantas Airways Ltd and its large capital requirements. Removal of the requirement for Loan Council approval would allow Qantas to borrow in the same way as any other private enterprise. In another classic pincer movement, the Government has effectively strangled Qantas and now sees the only solution to be partial privatisation.

I share the concern that Mr Barry Jones recently expressed in the other place that the privatisation of our GBEs will only exacerbate the unequal distribution of wealth in this country. When speaking about privatisation recently, Mr Jones said:

When ownership of strategic resources lies in a few hands, there is a danger that governments can be forced into action which confers further benefits on the wealthy to the cost of the community at large.

It gives me absolutely no pleasure to receive this prime ministerial statement-a statement from a Labor Party Prime Minister which implements Liberal-National Party policy. I think this is a shameful day for the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief comments on the previous speech, by Senator Kernot. I agree with her that the prime ministerial statement is a sell-out to the Australian people-the Government has brought down a very poor statement-but it is not a sell-out to big business; it is a sell-out to the trade union bosses. All Opposition senators listen very closely when the Australian Democrats get up to speak. We listen to their attacks on big business and to their occasional attacks on the public sector, but we never hear any attacks on the trade union movement. The major blockage to reform in this country and to tackling the productivity problems which Senator Kernot mentioned in her speech is not management-indeed, in some cases, we cannot even blame the Government-it is the trade union movement and the reactionaries and troglodytes in that movement. When will we see one proposal from the Australian Democrats to actually tackle those rorts?

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to turn now to the major subject of the debate, the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which has been brought before us today. It would take a high degree of optimism, given the Government's record on industrial reform, to believe that at last Mr Hawke and his divided Cabinet have got it right. When we survey the wreckage of our communications industry, the failure of the Button car plan, the disarray and uncertainties in our forest and mining industries, the huge and mounting problems in the finance sector and the now-acknowledged disasters that Mr Dawkins has inflicted on the tertiary education sector, we have to ask ourselves this question: Is it possible that the Government has been able to put together successfully a program of micro reform in the telecommunications and transport sectors?

As expected, the Prime Minister has laid out a mishmash of policy changes. Let me assure Senator Kernot that these policy proposals are, by and large, not the Liberal Party's policy proposals. It has to be said that some of these proposals will be detrimental to the efficiency of the telecommunications and transport sectors and the capacity of these sectors to deliver better services to the Australian economy and Australian consumers. In fact, where these reforms have the potential to achieve some micro-economic gains, as Senator Short pointed out, they will also have the effect of limiting the potential benefits that could have been obtained by consumers.

The statement before us has had a tortuous and painful birth. We have been subjected to months of Cabinet leaks, brawls between Cabinet Ministers, public fights between government departments and agencies, and the inevitable unhelpful and unseemly brawls between Australian Labor Party (ALP) faction bosses. Today we have before us a statement from the Prime Minister which is not so much a statement of reform, but something which resembles more of a treaty-a treaty setting out the best terms that the Government could extract from its divided Cabinet, warring factions and union bosses. The program that we have before us today has not been governed by the national interest but by the overriding desire to protect the factional interests of the Labor Party and the interests of Labor's paymasters-the trade unions.

It is interesting that the Business Council of Australia (BCA) has argued that an essential part of micro reform and the process by which that can be achieved is commitment and leadership, not politics and accommodation. Mr Hawke is clearly sensitive about the slow pace of micro-reform under his Government, and rightly so. He argues in the early part of his statement that:
. . . for too long Australia was content to live with inefficiencies and low productivity in too many of our domestic industries.

One might ask: Who has been in government for the last seven years? Mr Hawke, time and time again in this statement, seeks to excuse his Government's lethargy in the area of micro-reform. Let us read the last section of the statement before us. Instead of leadership, which the BCA, as I have said, has emphasised, Mr Hawke excuses himself by pleading the old line of consultation and the need to avoid confrontation. We are all in favour of consultation and, indeed, we are all in favour of avoiding confrontation; but we reject the politics of capitulation-capitulation to union bosses which is writ large in this ministerial statement, and which Senator Kernot did not mention once.

As usual, Mr Hawke indulges in gratuitous insults and gross overstatements. This is my favourite: he argues that these reforms are the antithesis of the `half-baked ideas floated almost daily by the Leader of the Opposition'. Mr Hawke clearly chooses to ignore, on the issue of micro-reform, as in so many other areas of policy making, that it is the coalition that is setting the directions for change. I do not recall that the need to privatise comes from the Labor Party as, indeed, the Labor Party has been dragged screaming into this whole area. I do not recall that it was the Australian Telecommunications Employees Union that was calling out for increased competition in the telecommunications area. I do not recall Labor Party documents that stressed the need to open up the whole area of telecommunications to competition. I do recall, however, that the coalition has long set out comprehensive policies in this area. The shadow Minister for communications, Mr Neil Brown, has shown the way with a telecommunications policy which is effective and which will deliver cheaper services.

I recall that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and, I suspect, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook)-if anyone ever listened-saying in election campaign after election campaign that the ALP Government would never be prepared to privatise Australian Airlines Ltd or Qantas Airways Ltd. Does the Government remember that promise that it made? Yet today the Prime Minister announces what he calls the most significant achievement to date in the area of domestic aviation. What is that most significant achievement? It is the 100 per cent privatisation of Australian Airlines and the 49 per cent part privatisation of Qantas.

If the term `half-baked' has to apply, let us apply it to the policy prescriptions which are before us today. The partial privatisation of Qantas means that our international airline is still shackled to government control and all of the inflexibility that that entails. The Government has largely ignored the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations concerning the need to tackle the web of regulations which bind the aviation industry and prevent it from becoming a properly functioning competitive market. In doing so, the Government has damaged the prospects of our vital tourism industry. With these confusing attitudes, is it any wonder that the pace of micro reform has been desperately slow under this Government? We support the full privatisation of Australian Airlines and we would move Qantas to full privatisation as soon as practicable.

The reforms that have been read out in the area of telecommunications are not only inadequate but also the third best option that the Government had before it. One does not have to go to this side of the chamber to find out what is wrong about Mr Beazley's efforts on telecommunication reform. The senior Ministers in Mr Hawke's Cabinet opposed these megacom reforms. Senator Cook probably opposed them, for all we know.

But even Mr Beazley, as Senator Short said, has now changed his mind. Do senators remember how Mr Beazley argued vigorously and ferociously that it was essential to maintain a duopoly in the area of telecommunications? Do they remember how he attacked our proposals to increase competition in Telecom? How pleasing it is to read today that after 30 June 1997 the duopoly will terminate, paving the way for there to be no limit to network communication. It is no wonder no-one ever believes anything the Government says; it cannot hold the line on anything.

How ironic it is that the very day that Mr Hawke makes a statement boasting about waterfront reform we read in the Australian that negotiations with waterfront unions have broken down after reaching an impasse on several core issues of reform. I ask Mr Hawke and, indeed, probably Senator Cook, why, if these reforms in the waterfront are so far reaching, as Mr Hawke told us today in this statement, it still takes two men to drive one fork-lift on our wharves. Why does it take one supervisor for every five workers? Why are the minimum gang sizes effectively set down in law for each dock regardless of its size and the amount of work? Do we have to have months-indeed, years-of negotiations or further inquiries before we rid ourselves of the gross inefficiencies which are harming our export sector and reducing the living standards of all Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your record? It is zero.

—Senator Cook should not get excited. His record is so bad that when the history of this period is written he will be typed as one of the worst Ministers, so he should not shout out and get excited about it. He spends a lot of time justifying a pretty miserable record, let us face it. In protecting the rorts of his ALP mates, Mr Hawke is hitting the job prospects of other Australians who should have the opportunity to work in a thriving export sector.

SPEECH.PARA: We are very pleased to read in today's statement that the average crew size on Australian ships has been reduced. But a noticeable omission from today's statement is how many working days per crew member compare with other countries. It appears that not one watersider has left the industry as yet under the redundancy provisions of the Waterfront Industries Reform Authority agreement, but today we learn that 213 extra employees have commenced work. Mr Hawke calls all this progress.

We might ask ourselves why has the Government not done better? The answer is simple. The trade union bosses and the Labor Left have vetoed a comprehensive reform package. The Government's refusal to consider privatisation of Telecom reflects its fear of taking on the power brokers of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. It has been asserted that there are 30,000 excess employees in Telecom. If full and open competition in telecommunications had been part of this statement it would have ended a few cosy lifestyles.

Why did we not see a comprehensive policy on waterfront reform? The answer to that question lies with the Waterside Workers Federation and Mr Bull. Mr Keating is reported, during the telecommunications debate, as walking out of the Cabinet meeting, casting his eye over his colleagues and describing them as useless. Senator Walsh said, on resigning from the fourth Hawke Ministry, that he did not believe the fourth Hawke Government had the will to tackle micro-economic reform. It has to be said, regrettably, that Mr Keating and Senator Walsh were right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on this attempt to pretend that somehow there is real change taking place in the telecommunications arena. The fact of the matter is that this is just another tawdry exercise in shuffling the pack. There will be remarkably little change at the end of the period although it has to be said that, belatedly, the Government has recognised the wisdom of a number of things that we have been saying for some years, and which the rest of the world has been saying since the early 1980s.
—You are even smiling at this.

—I am smiling very much because of all the rhetoric we used to hear about how the Government could not possibly touch a monopoly, which has recently translated into how it could not possibly go further than a duopoly and we now find that by 1997 it will be open slather. I will believe it when I see it. The experience of the United Kingdom and Japan has been that five years down the track the dominant player has the lead mover advantage to the extent of about 95 per cent of the market, and I would be very surprised if Telecom is not in the same boat.
—You can criticise us from the Opposition benches in 1997.

—If that is the best Senator Cook can say it is hardly worth waiting for. It is very clear from this statement that it is only a matter of time. I thought we were going to get something worth while. One thing is very clear from this and perhaps Senator Cook would like to deny if it is not so, and that is that it is only a matter of time before this desperate and beleaguered Government--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook should listen. I am about to make a Cabinet announcement for him.
—Order! Senators, I wonder whether you might indulge yourselves and address your remarks through the chair.

—I certainly will endeavour to do that, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is abundantly clear from this document that it is only a matter of time before we will see timed local calls imposed on the business sector. Mr Hawke makes that very clear by not mentioning business in saying that untimed calls will continue to be offered to households. That is very much a confirmation of what Senator Collins said, and he went out of his way to say that if we had been paying attention to what Mr Beazley said in the House we would know that there was certainly no commitment to maintain untimed calls in relation to business. I say it is a matter of time, and I would have thought sooner rather than later with the way the economy is going downhill.

SPEECH.PARA: We do certainly welcome the end of the duopoly, belated though it may be. We have given the rest of the world about a six-year start in terms of legislative action but, I must--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we have to copy the worst of the rest of the world?

—We do not have to copy the worst of the rest of the world. I would hope that the lessons from the rest of the world are that this can really be a very exciting and dynamic industry with enormous growth. But one thing that one does notice around the world is that every other Telco had a reduction in employment last year. That is a natural outcome of the rate of technological progress. But not Telecom. Telecom managed to jack up employment even in this year. I can understand that there might have been great demand for lobbyists and, no doubt, the queues at the Hyatt are largely explained by the fact that Telecom has had hordes of them up here. Truckloads have been coming up here mercilessly ensuring that it has got its way. But surely that cannot explain why there has been an increase in employment in the last financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is still very disappointing that the Government is not prepared to rebuke Telecom when it continues to pretend that somehow it is suffering from massive community service obligations (CSOs). The fact is that the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics long ago blew this pretence out of the water. The figure is between $120m and $240m a year, depending on what rate of return one expects. Yet Telecom says in its annual report, `If you take the bureau's methodology, the CSO figure has, in fact, fallen but if you take ours, it has gone up 10 per cent'. Telecom says it has gone up to almost $900m. Really, this is pathetic and spurious. It is a tragedy that the Government is so captive of the telecommunications union and Telecom itself that it is prepared to perpetuate this monstrous distortion of reality.

The other thing that I note with some satisfaction is that at long last a massive conflict of interest has at least been partly resolved with the Government's order that Messrs Ward and Liggett should resign from the board of Aussat forthwith. That is a long overdue decision. I cannot understand how the conflict of interest has not been recognised long before now.

I would hope that not only will there be that resignation forthwith but also that in some way or other the Government will endeavour to ensure that Telecom does not take advantage of information gained when two of its most senior people were sitting on the board of Aussat. It is worse than having the coach of Essendon sitting in the Collingwood football change rooms just before the teams run out on to the ground. I can assure the Senate that Collingwood would still have won the Grand Final. Nonetheless, it is not a situation that is any way healthy.

We also are very pleased with the decision that there will be extensive resale and that the regime will be very much liberalised. But I am not at all satisfied, from what I see here-I will wait to see the legislation-that indeed we will have the sort of transparent accounting and structural separation that will be necessary to ensure that there are not any hidden cross-subsidies and that liberalised resale does in fact take place. It will be very much dependent upon Austel having the power to determine just what rates there ought to be for resale, and what protection ought to be accorded to resellers. I think there is a very real prospect that what we might see is that Telecom and any new resale entrant might come in and negotiate a deal behind closed doors, and Austel will then be effectively disempowered from overriding that decision. That is certainly not in the best interests of consumers.

This statement is a basic recognition of the inevitability of competition and yet it is extraordinary, as my colleague Senator Kemp points out, that not one Labor Party wimp has been prepared to come in here and even defend the Prime Minister's statement, let alone face up to the facts of life and acknowledge that, belatedly, Australia is going to be prepared to give the rest of the world only an eight-to nine-year start. It is an extraordinary state of affairs. Senator Cook can be amused about this, but he must know in his heart of hearts, as does everyone around the Cabinet table, that Keating got it right; that Keating was absolutely right when he talked about the need for full and frank competition, and that the Beazley approach was simply there to accommodate the Left and all those who were somehow frightened of getting out into the real world. That is a tragedy for Australia.

This statement is a recognition of the fact that it is simply impossible to justify that position in the public arena, but it still falls short of what is desirable. I for one will very much continue to reserve my judgment. I think the sheltered workshop is alive and well. There is not much prospect that we are going to see efficiencies if we are still prepared to adhere to the July 1991 date for the dismantling of the first phone monopoly, and I am sure there will be a number of other egregious work practices that will be as easy to eliminate as those on the waterfront have proved to be. So there is certainly a great deal more that needs to be done in this area. It ought to be clear to any intelligent observer that Telecom has already taken advantage of the Government's extraordinary dilatoriness in finally recognising reality--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have delivered a great service to the majority of Australians.
—Telecom?
—Yes.

—Any fool could do that. If an organisation has the game to itself and it has unlimited resources, and it has revenue of $8 billion and assets of about $17 billion and is a law unto itself, it can do what it likes. It has technological progress delivering to it the opportunity to reduce rates, but it never does it. We are now told that this outfit will be able to give a 40 per cent reduction in STD rates. We could have had those 10 years ago.
—For whom?
—Rural consumers.
—You were in government 10 years ago. Why didn't you?
—If I had been, I would have.

—Order! Senator Alston, at the risk of appearing to be left out of this debate I might ask you again to direct your comments through the Chair, and it might help all of us if there were fewer interjections.

—I am outraged too, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would have thought blind Freddy knows that Australian consumers have had a very raw deal for a very long time. I hope Senator Kernot does not get sucked in by things like Telcats. Do honourable senators know how Telcats operates? This is a consumer assessment exercise. For example, they might ask Senator Kemp, `Do you have any complaints about the way we come and tend your phone?'. He might not have had Telecom around for a few years, so he says, `No'. So, they write him down as having had no complaints. Everyone who has called Telecom over the last financial year has complained, but because they are only 2 per cent of the population Telecom says there is a 98 per cent satisfaction rate. That is the sort of nonsense we have to weave our way through, and I hope Senator Kernot is able to do that in due course. I assure the Senate that the rest of the world has conclusively demonstrated that there is no risk to consumer services, there is no risk to community service obligations, but there are enormous opportunities to introduce very real benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement belatedly recognises that; nonetheless it has not stopped Telecom from signing up people on long term deals, no doubt with heavy discounts, and because of the lack of transparency we will probably never be able to determine the extent to which Telecom is cross-subsidising these contracts. There is no doubt, either, that it has been hoarding some of its microwave frequencies, and in all sorts of ways playing the games that we have come to expect.

Mr Hawke's statement does recognise the enormous opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region. The Prime Minister is absolutely right. But I have much less confidence that Telecom, with its very unimpressive external track record, will be well placed to take advantage of those opportunities. It may well be that the competitor will come in and start to clean up in this area. Unless there was some chance of that happening, we would not have had any prospects at all. It is deplorable that OTC Ltd has not been allowed to get out and compete on its own. It has a very good record; it could have handled the game very satisfactorily. This sordid deal which saw OTC folded into Telecom will simply mean that the worst of both worlds will be achieved in the dominant player.

This statement is a welcome but belated recognition of the need to do away with the duopoly, the need to introduce resale, and the need for a third mobile phone operator. Of course Mr Beazley got rolled on that, too. The facts are overwhelming. Unfortunately, Cabinet does not base its decisions on fact; they are all based on how we can pander to interest groups-what will the unions say, can we somehow hoodwink the Australian Democrats into thinking that life, religion and CSOs are all at risk in the one go, and what sort of a deal can we sell to the media. This is another attempt at least to catch up with the rest of the world, and to that extent it is very welcome. Unless and until Austel is given the power to ensure that there is structural separation, adequate accounting arrangements and the ability to monitor activities at all levels, I for one have little confidence that in terms of a level playing field, the big bulky Telecom, already in the goal square, will not continue to receive massive free kicks from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance. It is to be noted that there is not a Labor Party senator prepared to come in and defend this statement. I am a new senator, and I am interested to know whether there is any procedure by which we can provide Senator Cook and his colleagues with some time to find a Labor senator to come in and debate the statement.
—Senator Alston can seek leave to continue his remarks.

—I am very much indebted to you, Mr Acting Deputy President. On the basis that Senator Cook, for one, would be delighted to explain to us all the virtues of this belated recognition of reality, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This annual report of the Australian National Gallery is an interesting document because it outlines some significant achievements and some problems facing the Australian National Gallery. It is also significant because in this year's annual report the Chairman, Mr Gough Whitlam, has not bagged the Government. I presume that after last year he thought that maybe he had had enough of a go.

However, there are some areas where perhaps a bit of bagging might have been appropriate. Nonetheless, as the shadow Minister for the arts, I have every confidence in the new management of the Australian National Gallery, particularly under its Director, Mrs Betty Churcher. The Gallery has set out on a direction of consolidation and is concentrating less on acquisition this year. In particular, it is extending its exhibitions and its travelling exhibitions to rural areas, which I think is a good and proper course to adopt.

However, a couple of things bother me about the annual report and maybe there are some simple explanations for them. For example, in Mr Whitlam's foreword he says that the outstanding and excellent Ancient Treasures from the British Museum exhibition drew over 190,000 visitors to the Gallery. However, on page 78 the attendance figures show that something like only 100,000 people attended the Gallery during the months when that exhibition was on. We may get an explanation about why the figures at the back of the report do not tally with the figures at the front.

I was interested to see that Mr Whitlam reports that benefactors, particularly American benefactors, will require the Government to contribute to the core funding of the Gallery and that benefactors such as the Americans do not intend to take over the Government's responsibilities in this regard. That is one reason I was disappointed to see that no mention is made of a major disagreement which is going on at the moment in the National Gallery about the nature of the arrangements with the National Gallery Foundation. A report into the running of the National Gallery by Mr Early recommended that the National Gallery Foundation take over all the fundraising activities of the Gallery. Mr Whitlam rejected that out of hand, as I outlined to the Senate some time ago. There is no mention of that in this annual report.

It is also disappointing to note that the $3.5m required to fix the roof of the building will mean that there will be no blockbuster events in the Gallery, no huge and successful displays such as the Ancient Treasures of the British Museum exhibition, over the next couple of years. Mr Whitlam's report does not note the disruption that will take place in the Gallery because of this re-roofing requirement.

It is worth noting, in respect of this disagreement about the Australian National Gallery Foundation, that the back pages of the report reveal that the Foundation raised a surplus of $2.3m. It is vital that the National Gallery Foundation be strengthened to provide a greater opportunity for providing non-governmental funds to this organisation. The Gallery is certainly something of which Australia can be proud, but I hope that the problems it is clearly having with the Foundation, where the Foundation says it should have an integral role to fulfil in the Gallery's activities and a vital part to play in the development of the National Gallery and the national collection of art, will be overcome. We want to know what that role is to be. This report is short on detail on that matter; in fact, it is so short on detail that the disagreement is not even mentioned by the Chairman of the Gallery, Mr Whitlam, in his otherwise adequate, but in this case inadequate, introduction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERVISING SCIENTIST FOR THE ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region has once again produced a thorough report which raises some interesting issues. Concerns about the implementation of environmental requirements were raised in the annual report last year and again by Professor Geoffrey Taylor in his review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS).

Environmental requirements were prepared as an outcome of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry. They were intended to ensure strict environmental standards, as promised by the Government in the face of considerable opposition to uranium mining in what was to become Australia's most well-known World Heritage area. It is apparent from this report and from the review of the OSS that the situation in which the Northern Territory Government can disregard the advice of the Supervising Scientist in respect of adherence to the environmental requirements is unacceptable. The review of the OSS was tabled in Parliament in December last year. As yet there appear to have been no responses to the recommendations to ensure that environmental standards are rigorously maintained.

Although the report tabled today indicates that most of the environmental protection goals appear to have been met, there are grounds for concern that ground and surface water quality is deteriorating near both the Ranger and Nabarlek operations. There is also some concern over the decommissioning and rehabilitation of the Nabarlek mine site. I fully support the suggestion that Queensland Mines Ltd be required to lodge an appropriate financial security to ensure that it does not walk away from the problem, and that work begins immediately to halt any leakage of salts or radionuclides into the ground water system.

In particular, I want to look at the situation of the Coronation Hill joint venture (CHJV) in the very much misnamed conservation zone. The report states many times over in pages 60 to 64 that the CHJV is inadequate and unsatisfactory. These words crop up again and again: for example, in the transport of materials to and from the site, extra hazards will be associated with transporting toxic material such as cyanide, caustic soda, and hydrochloric acid, the assessment of those hazards is not adequate, and the increase in vehicular access could also cause some environmental damage, at least in the short term.

The OSS has some reservations about the strategy for water management, as no provision has been made to determine the toxicity of the water so as to estimate a safe dilution before it is allowed to enter the aquatic ecosystem. The OSS believes that aspects of the proposed residue management system are unsatisfactory. Management and disposal of tailings is such an important element of mine site operations that a detailed assessment needs to be carried out before approval for the project is given, not an ad hoc, on the job assessment as it goes.

In respect of the waste rock dump, the original plan was to have two huge rock dump areas; this plan has now been contracted down to one, and the OSS is very concerned that a large run-off from the waste rock will enter the river, giving rise to possible harm to the aquatic ecosystems. The OSS is concerned about rehabilitation in the matter of the waste rock dump, the residue dam, the mine pit and revegetation. All of these areas are of concern to the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

I hope that when the Resource Assessment Commission finally brings down its report next April these concerns about the inadequacy of the planning will be reflected in whatever advice it gives to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I believe that the integrity of the South Alligator River system can be maintained only if Coronation Hill is left intact, not subject to mining. As this report clearly shows, there are many unanswered questions; therefore, there are too many potential risks on environmental grounds alone.

Another aspect is that of Aboriginal heritage. The Jawoyn people know this as sickness country and they do not want mining to go ahead there. On that ground, too, it should be left alone. The most pressing need is for the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to act on recommendation 14 of the review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. This requires amending the existing arrangements to require the Northern Territory Government to give effect to the advice of the Supervising Scientist and so ensure that adherence to the environmental requirements is both unavoidable and enforceable.
