SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

When discussing the Department of Community Services and Health annual report for 1989-90, I would like to focus on an issue which has had some coverage in the media in recent days. That issue is the proposed charter of rights for nursing home and hostel residents. I note that in the section of the report which deals with residential care it says under the heading `Quality of Residential Care':
This sub-program aims to ensure that aged people in residential care receive quality care and quality of life outcomes.

One of the ways in which the Government intends to provide those quality of life outcomes is enshrined in this proposed charter of rights. However, it is obvious from recent actions and comments by the Minister responsible for this area, the Hon. Peter Staples, that these quality of life outcomes are those to be determined by him and not by the caregivers or the residents who may choose to enter a particular nursing home.

He may have backed down in his fight with the Catholic bishops over some of the objections to the charter, namely those of a sexual nature, but he refuses to do so about doctors who may advocate practices contrary to Catholic belief and teaching. This backdown does not negate the fact that, if the Minister had not been taken on, he would have forced his moral and social views on every resident of nursing homes and hostels throughout Australia.

What we have to keep in mind in this issue is that the residents of these homes are already vulnerable. We are not talking about married couples who live together in retirement villages. Rather, we are talking about residents of nursing homes and hostels. In many cases these residents are in the homes because they cannot totally and completely care for themselves, and that includes others in our society such as those who are physically or mentally handicapped as well as the aged. These people do not need to be made more vulnerable. To have followed the Minister's way of thinking is to add yet another burden to the shoulders of these residents.

I believe it is our community responsibility to lessen those burdens, not to increase them. Whether one is a parent with a handicapped child or a child who has to place his parent with professional care in a home, one has the right to expect the same social and moral standards as one sets in one's own home. So too do these residents have the right to the same social and moral standards they would have experienced at home. If one does not agree with the standards of the church, why then become a resident of a church-run institution? That is where, I believe, the freedom of choice comes into the issue. Parents who choose to send their children to a church-run school have the right to expect that the church's teachings on social and moral issues would be practised in those schools.
An editorial in the Australian newspaper put this disagreement with the Minister very simply:

Church groups have a right to their moral standards. Indeed, they have a duty to uphold them. They are entitled to expect that as their nursing home residents enter their care voluntarily, they will agree to the standards laid down. If not, the solution is simple-they are free to seek care elsewhere.
As the editorial pointed out, the church's basic point and objection is that its members have a right not to have their consciences offended.

The Minister, Mr Staples, while claiming that his charter extends rights to behavioural choices evenly to all nursing home inmates, was in fact denying aged people with Christian principles the right to choose a morally acceptable environment. Worse still, he insists that an environment in which moral deviance is welcome should be imposed on all, whether they like it or not.

But this is not the first time Mr Staples has wanted to ride roughshod over the nursing home industry. When he first proposed this charter the original legislation had provided for the Minister and his department to set up the charter at whim. It was then that amendments had to be forced onto the Minister so that anybody concerned with the operations of nursing homes and aged peoples' homes had the opportunity to consult with the Minister about the form and the wording of the proposed charter. The changes also meant that the charter is subject to the approval of the Parliament, which means that members can debate the charter and make amendments to the final wording if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to speak to the annual report of the Department of Community Services and Health and to compare and contrast two issues. The first one I wish to mention is dealt with on page 23 of the report, where there is a section dealing with drug abuse reduction and adverse reactions. I would like to mention the particular use of a drug called Depo-Medrol. The drug is not recommended by the manufacturer for epidural use, and it has come into quite widespread use in this country precisely for that purpose. The National Health and Medical Research Council, moreover, does not recommend the drug for that particular purpose, yet, as I say, it has come into quite widespread use.

SPEECH.PARA: There appears to be no requirement that adverse drug reactions be reported. Large numbers of patients are suffering adverse reactions from the use of the drug in this way, which, as I say, is not recommended by the manufacturer or by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Moreover, this Government provides government benefits for this particular treatment despite the fact that it is not a treatment recommended by the body which is authorised to make recommendations as to the adequacy and appropriateness of medical treatment. I personally have attended a meeting in Perth, Western Australia, attended by some hundreds of patients who have suffered adversely from the particular application of this drug.

I want to contrast that with the desperate situation of another patient in Western Australia who is suffering from advanced cancer and who is attempting to obtain a drug with which this patient has been treated in Germany, but which at this stage is not a recommended treatment in Australia. On the one hand, we have a drug being used very widely causing a large number of adverse reactions and being used in a way which is not recommended, and that treatment attracting medical benefits; yet on the other hand we have a patient who seeks treatment with a drug which is not in widespread use in this country, and that patient in this particular case cannot get that drug released through the Customs office.

That drug is being held up in Perth by Mr Staples's office. In just the last 24 hours or so I have been attempting to persuade Minister Staples to release this drug, because there is a doctor in Perth who is prepared to treat this patient, and both the doctor and the patient are being given the runaround. Mr Counihan of Mr Staples's office has indicated that a form needed to be signed for the importation and use of this particular drug. That was also indicated by Dr Ashley Brewster of the relevant department. We are now told that no form is required; that simply a letter which satisfies certain criteria addressed to the Department will satisfy. The doctor is prepared to use this particular drug. Although he says that the drug is not his preferred form of treatment, he recognises the right of the treatment to be used because that is the patient's wish.

Again, I contrast the very unsatisfactory way in which this Department is dealing with two drugs-one which is not recommended for use and which is being used for a purpose not recommended and yet is attracting medical benefits; another drug which a patient wishes to use and has been exposed to and which is being withheld from this patient. This is a very unsatisfactory situation, and I hope that in both cases the Minister will address himself to these matters urgently and find some satisfactory resolution.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I present a letter from the Chairman of the Committee to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, dated 7 November 1990 outlining the Committee's recommendations on the issue of change of status on the basis of marriage. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

At this stage I would like to make quite clear that what I am presenting on behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations is but an interim report. In this letter to the Minister the Committee stressed the point that it is an interim report. The Committee is mindful, as we state in the letter, of the time frame and time constraints under which the Committee is operating and under which the Minister and the Government are also operating in this matter.

At the moment a concession in the regulations allows visitors to Australia who join with a partner for marriage or de facto purposes to make application to remain in Australia whilst they are in Australia. That existing concession is due to expire on 30 November-just over three weeks time. Earlier this year the Minister asked the Committee to investigate and report back to him on the report of the National Population Council. The Committee received this report but at that time it was very heavily engaged in the earlier inquiry into illegal entrants to Australia and let this matter slip. Upon presentation of that first report Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion, the Committee then directed its attention to this particular question.

On a personal basis I have some difficulties with this interim report. I do not accept that we have given this issue the consideration it deserves. It is a very complex issue. Whilst we have deliberated upon it in public hearings, I do not believe that we have got wide enough advice to make determinations and recommendations. Indeed, at the Committee's meeting on Thursday afternoon last week, I moved a motion to the effect that the Committee would not be making any recommendations to the Minister on this matter because I did not believe that we had examined the issue thoroughly enough. Unfortunately for me my motion was not seconded and therefore lapsed.

I have not sought to put in a minority report or to present reservations to the report of the Committee. I do so because on the last occasion on which the Committee's report reached this and the other place, it had five minority reports attached to it. I am of the view that a committee that can attract that amount of divergence of opinion can have some doubt cast upon its ability to do its job. For the sake of consensus-that consensus pervaded through all of the Committee members who were present for discussion-we accepted majority decisions on the report. For the purposes of the record, I put my personal opinions at this time.

Briefly, in summary, in this interim letter to the Minister, the Committee is recommending that the current system of concessions for visitors who seek to change status on the basis of marriage be continued. We call for more extensive interviewing of applicants who seek to change status on the ground of marriage. One of the more controversial aspects of our letter is that we ask that more stringent requirements be placed upon visitors who apply on the basis of a de facto relationship. In the first instance, we recommend to the Minister and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that there be a proven 12-month period of cohabitation between the individuals before the matter is considered. Further, we ask that an additional provision that a 2-year temporary entry permit be granted prior to the granting of permanent residency.

Some of those points we have mentioned are perhaps somewhat unclear and further reinforce the point and my misgivings about putting in a report at this time. Clearly, the Committee is making a distinction between entry on the basis of marriage and on the basis of de facto relationships. I agree that a distinction ought to be made. At the moment there are distinctions and those people who enter into a marriage contract arrangement are disadvantaged by the present recognition of de facto relationships.

In the case of a marriage, before the individual can be properly married in Australia, a period of notice must be given to the authorities or to the officials of the respective creeds who are to conduct the ceremony whereas no such restriction is placed on a de facto arrangement. In some instances no notice is given. I personally favour some distinction. But I felt that the Committee needed much more advice and should have taken a much more detailed examination of how other Australian laws that govern marriage situations would be applicable to this situation before we made the suggestions that we have.

There was unanimity in the Committee concerning spouses or partners who may be blackmailed into a marital or de facto situation through domestic or other forms of violence that may occur between partners in marital or de facto situations. Anecdotal evidence was given to the Committee by people who said they could support with documentation evidence of cases where individuals have been blackmailed by their spouse or partner to remain in a violent situation and that, if they did not, they were told they would be dobbed in to the authorities and deported to their original countries or their applications for permanent residency in Australia would be stopped and they would be asked to remove themselves from this country.

The Committee was certainly sympathetic to any victims who might find themselves in that situation and we have made a recommendation to the Minister that some concessionary arrangements ought to be put in place to look after people who find themselves in that situation. We were also mindful of the fact that in some cases if a woman has come to Australia to enter into a marriage situation or if she enters into a marital situation upon arrival here, should that marriage break down before the permanent residency is granted and she has to return to her country of origin, she could find herself, because of cultural differences, an outcast in her own community.

I think this is something that the Minister, the Department and the Government have to be aware of. We have to make those hard decisions about asking people to return to their home countries. The Committee indicates in its conclusions-there are other matters contained in the report which I will not dwell on in the time available to me-to the Chairman of the Committee, Dr Theophanous, that we intend to put a full report before the Parliament and the Minister early in the Autumn session of the Parliament.

I personally have some misgivings as to whether we will be able to do so because for the next six out of seven weeks the Senate will be sitting and a committee of this nature is not allowed to sit whilst the Senate is sitting. So we will have very little time available to us to examine matters within that time frame. We will then move into the Christmas holiday break and I do not know many members of the Committee who will be all that keen to get together in the early part of the New Year. On the projected program for the sittings of the Parliament next year, it looks as though we will be returning to this place and the other place on 12 February for a two-week session. So the Committee will not have a great deal of time to sit down and fully and deeply examine the questions involved in this issue.

With that misgiving about the time available to the Committee to undertake a full, deep and thorough investigation of the matter, I also allude to the fact that when I presented and spoke to the earlier report from the Committee on illegal migrants in this country, I drew attention to the fact that the resources available to the Committee by way of the secretariat were somewhat limited. I am given to believe that those resources will be increased. But at this point in time, today, the Committee does not have any additional personnel available to it.

I paid tribute on the last occasion to the work of the secretariat and how well it has served the Committee. Robina and Heidi have done an admirable job and still continue to do that valiant job but I believe we are asking too much of those individuals. The matter must be seriously addressed in the early stages. The delays I referred to in the Committee examining this report are in no way attributed to the people I named before but it is a very serious matter that I hope will be addressed before the Committee deliberates much longer.

I think it is a very worthwhile Committee that needs to be continued and supported. It has a lot of work to do. The area of migration is a very complex area which was dramatically changed with the Act of Parliament that we put through this place last year. Not only did we dramatically change the system, but we also introduced a very complex series of regulations that govern permanent and temporary entry to Australia. The Committee has a responsibility to examine each of those matters and each of the changes that continue to occur. The Committee can be in a position to offer valuable advice to the Minister. We have had some problems to date on this matter and not the least has been the resources available to the Committee. Also included is the problem that I alluded to in passing, the fact that the Committee cannot meet when the Senate is sitting which, as I said, is to meet for six out of seven weeks. Mr Deputy President, with those words, I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a sentence at the end of the letter which I shall paraphrase. It says that there are some aspects of the report which I do not agree with. May I say in fairness to the Committee that I was not there when the matter was being discussed and I want to make that clear. The letter said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my intention to table this letter in Parliament as soon as possible. I must also advise you that there are aspects of this report with which Senator Cooney disagrees.

I would have liked to have agreed with it, but there are some aspects of it which I find I am unable to agree with. I want to point out what they are. I do not think, when it is all analysed, that the differences will be all that great and, as Senator McKiernan has properly said, there has been too short a time in which to analyse this problem and to write about it. On the first page, the letter said:
2) it is recognised that because of immediate resource implications it would be impractical for all applicants for change of status and their spouses to be interviewed and that therefore:
a) all applicants where it is suspected that a principal purpose is immigration be interviewed; and
b) all other applicants be interviewed on a random or risk analysis basis;

In my view, the motive for which a person marries is not a good test to apply to decide whether she or he should remain in Australia. The test should, in my view, be whether there has been an attempt to obtain permanent residency by fraud. This may involve consideration of whether two people have gone through a form of marriage that is in fact a sham. But what should draw the penalty of having to leave Australia is corrupt conduct and not marriage. It concerns me a bit. No doubt, being an old Christian Brothers boy, those early lessons--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a Marist boy.

—Or a Marist boy as Senator Richardson was. It comes back to us that we should not use marriage as a test as to whether we should put people out of the country. What we should look at is whether a fraud has been committed, which may manifest itself in a sham marriage. But if the marriage itself is all right, it seems to me to be not a good basis for throwing people out of Australia because people marry for a variety of reasons. They marry for money, for glory, for power and indeed for love, which, of course, is the reason we most want to protect. But if we marry for other motives as well, as long as the marriage is stable and holds together, why should it not be allowed to exist? It seems to extrapolate one motive out of a variety of motives which many people might consider as being fairly poor.

SPEECH.PARA: To extrapolate one motive and put a penalty on that seems to me to be looking at it in the wrong way. We should be saying that if there is fraud and if a relationship has been entered into for the sole purpose of keeping a person in Australia, of course a penalty should follow. But a penalty should not simply attach to a marriage.

It is not simply a question of migration law but the sort of society we are and the sort of approach we want to take to things. It seems to me to be a bit unhappy if people are to be cross-examined about why they married or did not marry. It is not the sort of thing that in a free and liberal society we would want to look at.

That test covers the de facto relationship as well. What should be looked at is whether or not the de facto relationship is a fraud or a sham. If it is, then people who have entered into that relationship simply and solely to defeat the purposes of the Immigration Act and who do not intend to live together once that has been achieved, of course, are committing a fraud. That should be the test. It is, in my view, as Senator McKiernan said, much easier to obtain evidence that a relationship is permanent if there has been a marriage ceremony. Then at least prima facie there is evidence of a relationship of an enduring nature intended. However, with a de facto relationship the evidence is not so readily available.

The other issue about which I had some trouble in regard to the letter related to the situation of a person who comes here as a spouse fully intending to make a go of the marriage but the other partner, for whatever reason, severs that relationship, in which case that person no longer has occasion to stay here under the law and the question arises as to whether he or she should be sent home. The threshold test suggested in the letter is that such a person will be allowed to stay here if he or she is a proven victim of domestic violence or of cruel and unconscionable conduct, is a party to non-ex parte proceedings in a court of law, and can demonstrate the various tests that are set out.

I notice present in the chamber Senator Giles, who has done some magnificent work on behalf of battered women and victims of domestic violence over the years. I would appeal to Senator Giles to agree that it is a terrible burden to ask a woman-or a man, if a man is placed in such a situation-to be required to go through a contested court case, contested because ex parte proceedings are excluded by this test. It would be asking such a person to go through a court case and to have to face, in the formal surroundings of a court, the perpetrator of the violence upon her, or him, and to be successful in that case before it is even considered whether or not he or she should be allowed to remain in Australia. One would have hoped that there are other tests where we as a fair and reasonable society could say that, where a person has been placed in such a situation, it would be quite unjust to ask him or her to return to his or her homeland.

In my view, the test should be whether it would be unconscionable to a fair and reasonably-minded person to send such victims back. Indeed, they may be a victim not of violence but of economic fraud or whatever. That seems to me to be the more appropriate test, rather than asking whether or not people can satisfy a court of law that they are victims of domestic violence or cruel and unconscionable conduct. I would like to see that modified.

The difficulty with this whole area is that, unless things are expressed in the most stringent legal terms and unless people explain what they are about, all sorts of criticisms are heaped upon them. I think that one of the most difficult portfolios to carry out must be that of Mr Hand, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. As an illustration of that before I close, I would refer to a letter from Mr Ron Merkel, who is a silk, and a very good one, in Melbourne and who is also President of the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties. He has taken the Government to task for reintroducing the `White Australia' policy on the basis that there are certain criteria, about which I do not know except through this letter. Certainly I understand that no criteria have been adopted by the Government yet. The letter is based on criteria which Mr Merkel says the Government has adopted in respect of visitors from Lebanon, Tonga, the Philippines, Fiji, Pakistan and Poland. He has obviously got those criteria from somewhere, and on that basis he says that there has been a reintroduction of the `White Australia' policy. I would have hoped that Mr Merkel, for whom I have much admiration, would have checked his facts before he went into his dissertation in the Age newspaper. I would have hoped that he had established exactly what was the Government's position before he made his criticisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least he is consistent.

— Well, one of the fundamentals of civil liberties should be that when people rage about a particular subject they should establish that what they are saying is correct. Mr Merkel then goes on in his letter to talk about de facto relationships and says that the Government is about to make a move in that direction in a way that will greatly disadvantage de facto relationships. Again, the only thing I know about the Government in that respect is that, in looking for proof, it is easier to accept marriage as proof of a stable relationship than to accept a de facto relationship. At least with a marriage there is a ceremony that people have gone through, there are witnesses and there are the trappings of a permanent relationship, whereas with a de facto relationship the evidence can be quite equivocal.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Government may be thinking along those lines, but certainly is not going along the lines that Mr Merkel is suggesting. I hope that when I next see him we can have a reasonable discussion about these issues. I hope that he will have a reasonable discussion with members of the Government rather than rushing off to the press and making statements which, I understand, are quite misconceived.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Ltd is, in a sense, a sad document because OTC, which has been an efficient and effective organisation, is to be wiped out as a result of a deal this Government has done with the trade union movement, or one section of the trade union movement-the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA).

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it quite clear that the deal that is involved in the merger-the totally inappropriate merger of Telecom Australia and OTC-is not on the basis of what is best for Australian users of telecommunications. It is not what is in the best interests of the nation. It is not what is in the best interests even of a large group of unionists. It is simply what is in the best interests of the tough guys from the trade union movement in the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. The union has 26,000 members and has played a crucial role in determining this inappropriate, ludicrous, and I believe inefficient, merger of these two bodies-Telecom and OTC.

There is no doubt that OTC has proved itself to have been a most effective, competent and efficient organisation. The annual report reveals the continual reductions in prices and costs of OTC. It reveals how it has the lowest call charges for both residential and business international calls of 24 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. To establish this the call charges to each country are standardised for differences in the general level of prices. OTC has a proud and effective record as being a lean and efficient organisation. It is now to be swallowed up in a large, overfat, inefficient and union dominated organisation for no good reason other than resolving problems of union power and rivalry.

What concerns me immensely is that in a statement earlier by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-I think it was today-we saw that the organisations are to be totally integrated. I had hoped that at least the Government would have been sensible enough to realise that it was vital to leave the efficient operations of OTC separate, even if it was within the umbrella of the large, bloated bureaucracy that makes up Telecom.

OTC has shown a great deal of enterprise and it has shown what can be done when we get a good external manager in to run the place as if it were a private enterprise. It is tragic that the Government is making no effort to preserve OTC's core business, as it now appears it is going to be swallowed up by the Telecom bureaucracy. OTC has run its organisation with something like 2,000 people. There are 86,000 people in Telecom. If this merger had meant that the tail was going to wag the dog, that would be great, but I fear that the dog is going to continually sit on the tail of OTC. I regret what is going to happen as a result of it.

This merger makes a mockery of micro-economic reform. OTC should have provided the basis, in particular with its much more rational and, I should say, right wing union which is involved, on which competition could have been created in the telecommunications area. The Government's decision to merge Telecom with OTC has prevented OTC, with a reasonable union, ending up as a strong competitor. Instead, we are going to have a bloated Telecom, success for ATEA and union dominance in an area where we must have effective microeconomic reform. It is a tragedy for the entire telecommunications industry that OTC is to be thrown into this pot with Telecom and it is shameful that it has occurred as a result of Government capitulation to the most powerful public sector union in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the National Health and Medical Research Council of 1989. Admittedly, it is for the calendar year 1989. This raises some difficulty for members of parliament in exercising their audit functions in respect of this organisation. At this point we still do not have the details of next year's funding for medical researchers. Millions of dollars are involved in this. This is not to say that there is not some very fine work being done; indeed, some very fine work is being done in the medical research area.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the researchers who have been knocked back, not because of the quality of their proposals but because the funds have not been available, will be very concerned about the fact that the National Health and Medical Research Council in the last three or four years has paid an amount of $450,000 from scarce medical research funds to utilitarian philosopher Peter Singer and his Monash group for a project entitled `Bioethical Issues and the Use of Human Foetal Tissue, Embryos and Gametes'. Of course, Professor Singer has published views that the human embryo and the human foetus, and indeed a newborn child, have no inherent right to exist and, specifically, that a human embryo is of no more inherent worth than a lettuce.

Is it not ludicrous for the Federal Government, through the National Health and Medical Research Council, to pay $450,000 of scarce medical research funds to an organisation such as that? Incidentally, that organisation has used our funds to mount criticism of a select committee of this chamber, namely the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation. I do not mind organisations or groups criticising the work of this Senate at all-that is democracy-but I ask every member of the Senate: is it an appropriate use or a misuse of medical research funds for this enormous amount of money to go to this group of utilitarian philosophers for the purpose of developing an ethic, as it were, for human embryo experimentation and to use part of that for the purposes of mounting a campaign against the work of a Senate select committee?

This is a very serious question indeed. I am concerned that a system of gene screening is being designed and developed in Australia, not for the purpose of curing disorders but for the purpose of eliminating the bearers. Involved in this is taxpayers' money, about which we should be most concerned. Sooner or later it will blow up, and blow up in the face of the Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), unless a serious look is taken at what moneys are going to where and for what purpose. If ever we get to the stage of developing such a system and that system depends on a concept of some lives being unworthy while others are entitled to exist, then we are going down the track of Nazi doctors such as Lebensunwertes Leben.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

Employers may report on a subsidiary or business unit basis, or with a report covering some or all subsidiaries in the group. That is why the number of reporting units is lower than the total number of companies covered by the Act, as shown in Table 2.1.

Of the 2334 reports received in 1990 only 49 per cent were lodged within the statutory period, between 1 February and 30 April. This is slightly up on last year, when only 46 per cent of employers reported on time. While Band 1 and 2 employers were, generally, more timely, only 44 per cent of Band 3 employers lodged reports within the statutory period. This causes the Agency difficulties in managing the workload associated with monitoring reporting compliance and meeting its requirements to report to Parliament by 30 November each year. Means of improving employers' compliance with dates for final lodgement will be explored in 1990-91. (Details of the reports are in Section 2.3: Compliance with the Eight Steps, pages 20-42).
APPLICATION OF THE SANCTION

Employers who fail to comply with the legislation face being named in a report to the Minister for Industrial Relations for tabling in Parliament (section 19 (1) of the Act). The decision to name an employer is not taken lightly and every effort was made to ensure employers were aware of their obligations under the Act.

The Agency sent reminder cards in early May 1990, to those private sector companies which had not reported. Between early June and mid August, the Director of Affirmative Action sent a letter to 808 employers, 55 from Band 1, 47 from Band 2 and 706 from Band 3, who had still not lodged a report. This letter informed companies of the Director's intention to name them if their report was not forthcoming. This letter was sent in accordance with section 19 (2) of the Act, which requires the Director to give a relevant employer at least 28 days notice in writing of an intention to name. A significant number of these Band 1 and 2 companies had received a similar letter last year.
In September and October, Agency staff personally contacted each company which had not yet lodged a report. This included 249 companies and of these:

TALK.START.PARA: —The companies which have not reported are given every opportunity of doing so. That is why I thought it only fair that this information should be included in the record. Of course, the Agency has considerable difficulty in managing the workload when, as happened in 1990, only 49 per cent of the reports were lodged within the statutory period between 1 February and 30 April. The perseverance of the Agency resulted in a considerable number more actually reporting, but reporting late. As the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) observed in his answer at Question Time today, the higher education sector, which is the other large sector covered by the Act and which consists of 70 tertiary institutions, reported-in fact, every one of the institutions reported-but only one-third of those reports were lodged within the statutory reporting period. Since this was the third year in which these institutions have been covered by the Act, the Agency expected a higher standard than that of previous years and the criteria for assessing compliance reflected this.

SPEECH.PARA: The analysis in the report from which I will quote briefly reports compliance with the requirements of the legislation in the third year of coverage. It is very obvious, in talking to those who have close association with the higher education sector, that far too many administrations are failing to give a thorough commitment to affirmative action and not providing either social justice to women employees, or a proper example to the private sector. There are eight steps described in the report which are detailed as those which constitute the implementation of affirmative action.

The first one goes to the issue of a policy statement. Only 33 of the higher education institutions have issued policy statements, having been given three years, I remind the Senate, in which to do so; 27 partly complied with that requirement; and 10 complied not at all. The second step requires the `Appointment of an Affirmative Action Coordinator' and is also a process by which the head of an institution is informed, and a proper representative structure is in place. All of the institutions managed to comply with that step, the only one with which they all complied. `Consultation with Trade Unions', the third step, did not get a particularly good score because only 53 of the institutions complied, three partly complied and 14 did not comply at all. It goes on. In step 4, `Consultation with Employees', 48 complied, 17 partly complied and five did not comply at all. The fifth step, `Establishment and Analysis of an Employment Profile', had only 52 institutions complying, 7 partly complying and 11 not complying at all. Sixty-five of the institutions complied with step 6, which requires a review of personnel policies and practices; four partly complied and one did not comply at all. Step 7, which deals with setting objectives, has only half of the institutions complying and step 8, `Monitoring and Evaluating the Program', once again, sees only half of the institutions complying.

This certainly is not good enough. We look to our higher education institutions to provide a far better example to private enterprise and to the community as a whole. They should be taking the lead in order to not merely score well in a report of this nature but, as I said before, to ensure that the employees of these institutions are getting the benefit of the policies of this Government which are designed to achieve equal opportunity through affirmative action.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (SUBSTANTIATION REQUIREMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Watson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be agreeing to the Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Bill 1990. We understand and are sympathetic to the issue which Senator Watson is trying to resolve by the Bill which he has introduced. The case which has created the problem which he is trying to resolve was one which showed up a shortcoming in the administration of this particular clause and, potentially, in the wording of the clause.
—The legislation or the discretion?

—I think possibly both, and that is one of the significant points to which I wish to refer. Can I say, firstly, that I am not in any way criticising the manner in which Senator Watson has sought to resolve this problem, but it raises one of the several interesting dilemmas which he and I have debated in this chamber before relating to issues concerned with certainty, simplicity and discretions. Sometimes honourable senators opposite and sometimes groups interested in tax law-professional bodies like accountants, lawyers and companies-come pressing the Government and saying, `There are too many Commissioner's discretions in the legislation. We want the number of discretions reduced-we want to take these out'. One of the principal reasons for that is that we may have greater certainty so that people may have-
—You can't use that argument: look at them all here.

—Senator Watson has to wait until I finish the argument. If he misunderstands it so far, I shall make it clearer. We also find people coming to us saying that one of the principal reasons for wanting to take these discretions out of the legislation is so that there may be greater certainty. Particularly in this environment, where we are moving towards self-assessment, people have to know what is going to apply to them. They have to know the law as it is going to apply to them and, therefore, discretions where the Commissioner `may' interpret this way and `may' interpret that way make it harder for an individual taxpayer to be certain of his or her responsibilities in this matter. Therefore, it undermines the certainty and the ease with which one can comply with one's tax obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: We also find people coming to talk about complexity. They say, `We want a simpler tax law'. But then we find, as each problem comes along, that they want another amendment to the Act. However worthwhile each of them may be, the net effect of those several amendments is to make the Act increasingly more complex.

I preface my comments by saying this is not a criticism of the attempt to resolve this matter by way of discretion, by way of this extra complexity, by way of this reduction of certainty, because, as Senator Watson tried to imply by interjection, obviously there are many discretions already in the Act that deal with questions of uncertainty, et cetera. The point I was trying to make is that it highlights the dilemmas we face. It is very easy to wave one's arms generally and say that there are too many discretions and that we need certainty and simplicity, but when it comes to dealing with individual problems in the taxation legislation it is not so easy to meet each of those requirements. When the other requirements of equity and neutrality are added, suddenly we find that trade-offs are involved. Sometimes, to achieve equity there needs to be a trade-off for certainty; sometimes complexity is required; and sometimes a discretion is required to be the balancing item in that equation.

I simply want to put on the record on this occasion, when the Opposition has raised a proposal to deal with a problem which could be criticised on the grounds of adding a discretion, on the grounds that it adds complexity-

TALK.START.PARA: —I say that in my speech.

—I understand that. The proposal could be criticised on the grounds that it reduces certainty, but the Opposition found, when it came to dealing with the particular problem with which it was concerned, that that was the only mechanism open to it. I make that point to indicate that it is not surprising that in other circumstances, as they arise, that is the solution that governments have turned to over the years to deal with the question concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As we turn to this particular matter as it relates to substantiation and to the Evangelist case, in particular, with which Senator Watson's Bill is concerned, we need to deal, firstly, with some of the background to the introduction of the substantiation provisions, because we cannot deal with a proposal to amend the way the substantiation provisions operate and the strict manner in which the substantiation requirements need to be complied with without giving consideration to why they have developed in the way they have, why they were initiated, and why they were initiated in the form in which we now find them.

In the lead-up to the 1985 White Paper and the legislative amendments which followed from it, amongst the many and varied forms of tax avoidance-and, in this instance, very often tax evasion-problems arose from the claims for expenses which could not be properly substantiated, in the contemporary jargon. We found that people were chancing their arms significantly in submitting their returns. We found that there was a lack of what would now be called proper substantiation.

I think it was broadly agreed that, if we were to go into the process of broadening the income tax base and not only introducing fairness but making that fairness more apparent, what we needed to do, amongst a whole range of other changes, was to introduce strict substantiation requirements so that each Australian would know that every other Australian had to substantiate such claims as they might be able to make or as they might seek to make, or that they would not be allowed.

It is against that background that I want to respond to this particular attempt. I understand that Senator Watson is trying to put in the discretion in a manner which says that, in the main, there will continue to be strict requirements, but the Commissioner has the capacity to vary. I understand the attempt but, in our view, the attempt is not going to achieve-or has the danger of failing to achieve-the purpose of striking that right balance between the rigorous application of the substantiation requirements and the flexibility that he seeks to bring into the legislation through this particular amendment.

The Government has, until now, given some consideration to the possible harshness of the measures in the Act as it relates to substantiation and as thrown up by this example, and there are already some reasonableness elements built into the legislation, as Senator Watson would know, but the exceptions to the rules are very deliberately limited so as not to open up avenues for abuse. The Government has, as I said, been looking at possible measures to try to deal with any harshness that might arise and strike the balance between the proper application--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been trying for four months.

—Yes. The Government is looking to strike the balance between the proper application of some lessening of potential problems without jeopardising the fairness and the revenue. It is not an unusual balance for us to have to strike. Generally, though, we have created the situation where taxpayers in Australia are aware that the rules are strict. I believe that it is important that they know that the rules will continue to be strict, or they will lose their effectiveness. As we continue to move towards self-assessment, it is going to be more important that individuals are aware of what the criteria are and how they will be applied. The Tax Office cannot, will not and should not be in a position to check each return to see whether the discretion proposed ought to be exercised, so we start to issue an invitation: `Here is an opportunity. You might get away with it'.
—Not the taxpayer.

—It may well be that we find that the taxpayer says, `I think I comply well enough; I will have a go even though I know what I can provide to substantiate this claim does not fulfil the letter of the law. I think it might be close enough, so I will have a go. I think the Commissioner may exercise his or her discretion on my behalf in this matter'. That option is not open to people at the moment, and we do not want to encourage that sort of recklessness and overenthusiasm in taking the punt on what might be close enough.

SPEECH.PARA: May I say that, as Senator Watson and some other members of the Opposition would know, the Government has been trying very hard to proceed with its consideration of possible changes to the tax legislation-even some administrative matters, but in this instance they are legislative changes-with as broad a consensus as possible among the general community and interested participants in the tax community. There was broad consensus at the National Taxation Liaison Group, at which this matter was discussed with the representatives of, for example, tax, accounting and legal bodies, that it was not appropriate to amend the law. When we had that discussion with them, their view was that it was not appropriate to amend the law, and that is a view that at this stage the Government shares -particularly with the knowledge that the Evangelist case is the only one of its type which has until now reached the tribunals or the courts.

The law is strict, and it is our view that at least at the moment it needs to remain strict-though, like all laws, it needs to be applied with commonsense, and in the main it is. Obviously record keeping imposes a burden on taxpayers. That is part of the whole discussion about compliance costs. But we have to strike the balance between reasonableness of burden and the requirement that the taxation system be and be perceived to be fair for all. The whole thrust of modern tax administration, not just in Australia, is encouraging voluntary compliance, encouraging people voluntarily to meet their proper obligations. And, overwhelmingly, Australians do.

But one of the several factors that research indicates are the most influential in increasing the percentage by which taxpayers in any community will comply voluntarily with their requirements is the perception that the tax burden is fairly distributed. There are other factors, and I have discussed them on other occasions here in the Senate and in other places. But the one that is and must logically be important, and the one which is very sensitive in Australia because of the history of the 1960s and particularly the 1970s and early 1980s, is the perception that the tax system is fair for all, that if you are paying your fair share the person standing next to you is likely to be paying his or her fair share and that there are not loopholes through which buses can be driven.

Having said all that, having said that we are concerned about loosening the strictness of the substantiation rules and requirements because it might encourage people to take a punt, to go back to the near enough is good enough system, and might, as the anecdotal evidence spreads, as it always does, undermine that confidence that is the underpinning of voluntary compliance, I do have to say that the Government is not unaware that we need to look at substantiation, not just because of this particular case but broadly because this case has brought to a head not a shortcoming that we were not aware of-we have all known that these sorts of situations existed-but the fact that there may be some burdens on taxpayers in substantiation that are broader than can reasonably be justified.

There are other possibilities under consideration. The current view of the Government-and I think it is the absolutely correct one, on the balance of evidence-is that the Opposition's discretion measure is not the appropriate answer, certainly not as a one-off exercise like this. It may address the immediate Evangelist case, but it does not go to all the questions that may arise as to the appropriate role of substantiation in the overall scheme of the legislation, the broader issues relating to substantiation rules, and it may be that when we look at those this discretion is entirely inappropriate.

This is not an easy matter. It is not a question of simply rejecting this proposal because the Opposition thought of it. It is not the first time that this idea has been considered by the Government. Not this particular proposal but proposals to respond to this issue have been considered by the National Taxation Liaison Group. Of course, each individual would see this as one obvious mechanism that might be used, because the insertion of discretion into the Act is always a mechanism open to one to deal with circumstances such as this.

The Government's view is and will continue to be that this amendment is not the appropriate mechanism to deal with the problem that we have; that amending the law by way of a general application to deal with one case that has arisen is likely to create more problems than it resolves. Accordingly, it is the view of the Government that the Bill should not be passed, and therefore we will not be supporting it. I believe that the tax Act ought not be so amended at this stage, and for those reasons, as I say, the Government will not be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Watson for reading so diligently the Australian Democrats' alternative Budget document, because the last paragraph in that document sets out almost word for word the terms of his private member's Bill. I am glad that we have found an audience in so erudite and knowledgable a person in tax matters. I am therefore happy to say that as a matter of principle the Australian Democrats will support this private member's Bill put forward by Senator Watson.

SPEECH.PARA: We have some concerns about the specific conditions that he has set down. We feel that the discretion he has specified is too wide and too general, and we believe that taxpayers who have proved that they have a justified tax deduction should not be hindered by a technical breach in their procedure from getting the benefit of that deduction. I believe that is the intent of Senator Watson's private member's Bill; however, it is a little wide of the mark in its execution.

The terms that we would like to include in such a provision-and I will be moving an amendment to the tax legislation later in this session to that effect-are that the taxpayer must have proved and the Commissioner of Taxation must have satisfied himself that the taxpayer has in fact incurred that expense, and secondly that the expense would, apart from the operation of the particular subdivision, constitute an allowable deduction and the fault in the taxpayer's case is simply a technical one. These qualifications and requirements, I believe, are not set out in sufficient detail and with sufficient precision in Senator Watson's Bill, but we accept the principle that he is enunciating through his Bill and it is for that reason that we believe it should be supported.

In answer to the points raised by Senator McMullan, there certainly is a trade-off between equity and simplicity. We feel that rigorous simplicity and bureaucratic provisions can be taken too far when they do not take account of simple human errors which can be proved to be of a technical nature.

We believe that ultimately the tax law to be respected by the community must contain an amount of flexibility which is given to the Commissioner at his or her discretion. As I said, that discretion should not be general and all-embracing. The terms I have outlined, which will be part of our amendment, protect revenue by specifying that the expense must have been incurred and it must also have been proven that deductibility is legally justified. In this situation the Commissioner would issue an income tax ruling specifying the circumstances under which he would be prepared to exercise the discretion to give the taxpayer some guidance. The spectre of floodgates being opened that Senator McMullan has raised is therefore not to be expected.

I believe that little more needs to be said except that on these principles the Opposition supports the Bill and that I will submit our amendments to the Government in the next few days to negotiate an appropriate amendment to the taxation legislation before the Senate, which will meet the same objectives that Senator Watson attempts to meet but, I believe, more adequately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the private member's Bill introduced into the Senate by Senator Watson. In doing so I would like publicly to commend him on the work he has put into this Bill and its background, as, I believe, does the coalition, which is fully supportive of the Bill. It has been through the shadow Cabinet and through the party room, and it has the full endorsement of the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson has introduced a Bill that will not lessen the controls that are necessary-and that we on this side of the chamber fully accept are necessary-to the application and administration of the income tax law. However, at the same time, whilst preserving those disciplines, it introduces into the law a fairness and a basic commonsense in the administration of the law that it lacks at the moment in this area; namely, the enforcement of the substantiation requirements of the Act regarding the provision of written evidence of claims for expenses.

I commend Senator Watson on his Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirement) Amendment Bill. I also point out to the Senate that in the preparation of this private member's Bill Senator Watson consulted very widely indeed with interested parties and expert organisations in the wider community. He consulted with the Australian Society of Certified Practicing Accountants, the Australian Taxpayers Association, some of the major chartered accounting firms, the Taxation Institute of Australia and other organisations.

I understand from Senator Watson that he found agreement amongst all of those with whom he consulted that the existing arrangements are unfair and do require change, and that he had general support for the proposals he has introduced as interim measures pending a full and comprehensive review of the relevant areas of the taxation law.

This Bill has come into the Parliament with probably more consultation than much legislation introduced into this place by the Government of the day, whichever party be in government. For that reason, I believe that the Senate, and I hope the Parliament and in particular the Government, will have another look at this matter and treat it with the seriousness it obviously deserves. The new subsection to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 proposed by this Bill has the purpose of providing the Commissioner of Taxation with discretion to apply the substantiation provisions with, as I said earlier, fairness and commonsense.

It is true, as Senator McMullan has said, that the Bill introduces another discretion into the tax law. The Opposition certainly has difficulties as a general rule with giving the Taxation Commissioner discretions which are too wide. But there are occasions when equity, fairness and commonsense dictate that by far the lesser of the two evils is to give discretion. The Government of the day, regardless of which party is in power, has always seen the need on occasions to give certain discretion to the Commissioner.

The Opposition has been very critical of this Government-I believe correctly-for extending the areas of discretion far too widely. However, here we have the situation where the Government, which has done that over the years, is opposing a proposal to give a modest increase in discretion to the Commissioner where it is quite patently obvious that this will add to the fairness in the taxation system.

Many people have talked about the Evangelist's case. Senator McMullan said this was not necessarily irrelevant to the present situation, but I do not understand that argument because the Evangelist's case really pointed out the absurdity of the present law without the discretion. When he handed down a decision in the Evangelist's case in favour of the Australian Taxation Office, Mr Peter Roach clearly demonstrated the absurdity of the position. I will not read all the decision, but what he said in that decision, among other things, was:

The substantiation provisions have been enacted in terms which emphasise form above substance and which tend to concentrate the attention of those required to enforce the rules on questions of form and to distract attention from the more basic question as to whether what is represented on the forms is true, in the sense of being both honestly stated and accurate. Under such circumstances it is likely that the only persons at risk of being disadvantaged by the `substantiation provisions' will be the honest.
That is what Mr Roach said when handing down his decision in the Evangelist's case. He went on to explain that in the context of the particular case he was dealing with as follows:
The effect of the substantiation provisions may be to deny them deductions . . .
that is, the honest people -
. . . to which they would otherwise be entitled pursuant to sec. 51(1) of the Act.

That, according to the Commissioner, is the result for this applicant. The reason, it is said, is simply that, despite having recorded all relevant details of travel in a logbook and despite having done so in his own handwriting and having been the only person to record information in that logbook, the applicant failed to sign each entry. As a result of that technicality, despite the fact that it was totally accepted that the entries were in his own handwriting and that his recording was honest and accurate, he was denied the legitimate taxation deduction to which he was entitled.

It is often said that the law is an ass. The law is an ass if it is drafted and administered in such a nature that this sort of situation can arise. Senator Watson's proposed amendment in his private member's Bill would remove that problem. It would introduce a minor discretion on behalf of the Taxation Commissioner which would enable such a patently honest and accurate substantiation recording to be legitimately permitted. I think that Senator McMullan quite frankly overstated the position, and in fact I would say that he was wrong in saying that the discretion proposed in this Bill would provide a loophole. I do not think that is the case. The Act would be no less strictly administered than it is now.

For those reasons, the bottom of line of which is fairness, equity and commonsense in the taxation system, I have the pleasure in strongly supporting Senator Watson's private member's Bill. I again commend him for bringing it to the Parliament. I am very pleased indeed to hear that the Australian Democrats will support the Bill. That does not help us much. It will get it through the Senate, and that is good, and it will get it into the House of Representatives but unless the Government is prepared to support it there, of course the Bill will not go through the Parliament.

I hope very much that the Government may have another look at this before it is debated in the House of Representatives. I would be interested to know, and perhaps Senator McMullan or one of the speakers from the Government might answer us before this debate is concluded as to whether the Caucus has considered this matter. If it has been taken to the Labor Party Caucus, I would be very surprised if it would have gone against this proposition because it is patently a fair and sensible one. I do hope that the Government will look at this again before it gets to the House of Representatives. I join Senator Watson in commending the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support my colleague Senator Watson in the presentation of his private member's Bill and, as my colleague Senator Short did, commend him on the extent of the work that he has put into it. Interestingly enough, when the amendments were first argued in 1985, Senator Watson forecast that the sort of problems which have now arisen would in fact arise. I think therefore he is to be commended on following through on his objection to the way the legislation was phrased in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: It was disappointing to hear Senator McMullan's contribution and reasons as to why the Government would not be supporting the Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Bill. It was disappointing from this point of view: that he was arguing that this solution to a problem would not be satisfactory, that it would be inappropriate. Yet the reality is that the present position is inappropriate. The present position has been outlined and adequately described by Mr Peter Roach in the Evangelists' case when he said that certainly there was need for change to take place.

The response of the Taxation Commissioner has simply been to say that he will give assurances that such a situation will not arise again; it will not be repeated. He said that he will apply the substantiation provisions with commonsense. Surely that option was open to him previously, but that is not the point. If he is to do that, he could technically be himself in breach of what the law requires of him, and that is totally inappropriate and not to be condoned.

What Senator Watson has done is to bring before this chamber a simple and interim solution to what is an immediate problem. The immediate problem, as I have said, is that the law is presently inadequate to provide a just administration of the substantiation provisions. For the Commissioner to say that he will simply bend them a bit simply will not do. I think it was Senator McMullan who said that near enough is good enough to provide a solution will not do. I suggest that his refusing to accept Senator Watson's Bill is leaving it in a near enough is good enough situation. This is a solution for an immediate problem which can be an interim solution and can be perhaps better dealt with in a most detailed way which can only be done by those with the resources of Government and not those with the resources of Opposition.

Certainly I would agree with Senator McMullan when he said that there was a need to have certainty and simplicity of the laws so that they may be adhered to, and that the use of discretions is to be avoided where possible. But he is not consistent in his argument because new legislation in the tax area brought before this Parliament continues to introduce new discretions. To say that he cannot accept this Bill because it is introducing a discretion is simply not adhering to his own argument.

The bottom line is this: the present situation is unfair, unjust and inappropriate and it cannot be allowed to continue. His solution to allow the Commissioner to say that he will simply apply the law in a way which is not in the strict interpretation of the law will not do either. It is very pleasing to hear that the Australian Democrats will support this Bill of Senator Watson's which would allow an interim solution and which will give immediate relief to what is a very pressing problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks about this Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Bill introduced by my colleague Senator Watson. The Bill does seek to make the substantiation requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act fairer. Clearly since 30 June 1986 when the current substantiation provisions came into effect, there have been an enormous number of anomalies and cases where people have thought they were acting within the substantiation provisions and after audits were seen to be outside. There is the example of the Evangelists' case, which must have been mentioned a couple of dozen times here already this evening. That is a classic case where there is an honest young volunteer working for a church, filling in his logbook assiduously but because he forgot to sign or did not know he had to sign his pages or each entry in his logbook he was caught. This was clearly a very good case of where there is someone thinking he was acting within the law, but who was indeed acting outside of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan suggested in his discussion that these substantiation provisions need to be maintained as strict and as tight, and that there needs to be no indication from the Parliament or in the legislation that there are loopholes being created. Indeed, in a memo that Senator McMullan sent around to members and senators back on 9 October 1990 he puts it quite succinctly:
There is a necessity that substantiation rules are fairly strict. They would not serve their purpose if taxpayers thought they could ignore them or treat them in a cavalier manner.

Senator McMullan is quite right, and it is important for the Senate to understand that Senator Watson's Bill before us today in no way waters down the substantiation requirements. He does not affect them at all. All he does is allow a little bit of fairness to be injected into them.

It is important, as Senator McMullan said, that people are aware of the substantiation requirements. I put it to Senator McMullan-and I ask other senators and indeed members of the Australian Labor Party to think about this when they come to consider this further before it goes to the House of Representatives-that if members of parliament and senators do not know what the substantiation requirements are, then how can we possibly expect people out in the broader community to understand? One of the things that brought this issue to a head was a seminar held by Senator Watson a few weeks ago to inform members of parliament of the substantiation requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a need to terrorise us all.

—We were all quite terrorised. Senator McMullan's memorandum of 9 October highlights the fact that neither members of parliament nor senators, who should know the law better than anyone else, understand those requirements. How do poor people such as Mr Evangelist have any chance? We are seeking not to weaken the substantiation requirements but to ensure that, in cases where people are trying to abide by the law, to fill in their tax returns properly and to claim what is a deductible item, they can do so in the full knowledge that if they comply with the requirements they will be within the law.

SPEECH.PARA: When we have self-assessment, as we have at the moment, people are required to keep receipts and substantiation documents for five years. The point I have highlighted is that, if many people in the community do not know what the substantiation requirements are-and we have already proved that many members of parliament do not know what they are-and there is an audit at any time in people's taxpaying lives and they do not have the correct substantiation documents, they will be required to repay the tax and to pay penalties.

This is where it hurts. This is where some discretion needs to be given to the Commissioner of Taxation to look after those cases. Otherwise, as the years go by, as selfassessment rolls along and as substantiation stays as it is now, there will be thousands and thousands of cases like Mr Evangelist's, and the Taxation Commissioner's job and the cost of collecting tax will get more expensive. The efficiency of collecting tax and the efficiency of the revenue will get smaller and smaller.

One of the principles of taxation must be that it needs to be fair, but it also needs to be efficiently collected and inexpensively collected. It will not be inexpensive if we have all these cases and all these people such as Mr Evangelist and thousands of others like him-including senators and members of parliament-who need to appeal to the Tax Commissioner. I plead with honourable senators opposite and their colleagues in the other place to have a closer look at the solution to the problem that Senator Watson has proposed with this Bill. I repeat that I am glad to see that the Australian Democrats are supporting us in this proposal. Clearly, its success lies with the Australian Labor Party opposite and their colleagues in the other place. I have pleasure in supporting this move by Senator Watson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in supporting Senator Watson's Bill. I was very disappointed to hear Senator McMullan's comments. I suggest that he might go back to the days when there were pneumatic tubes and we put--
—Go back to the bottom of the harbour. That's where you learned your skills-the bottom of the harbour.

—I pause to acknowledge that personal, offensive interjection which is typical of the Minister for Administrative Services, who has an incapacity to deal with any subject on its merits and whose only contribution, particularly after dinner--
—Patrick Partners.

—I acknowledge that interjection. The only contributions of this Minister, particularly after dinner, are of that personal and offensive nature. When this Minister, who is incompetent anyway, can address the substance of serious matters such as this, he will merit being listened to. But I assure him that every time he interjects with that personal smear stuff, which is all that he can contribute, I will acknowledge his interjections so that it is recorded in the Senate and so that his constituents can see the type of person he really is. We have to put up with him all the time. I do not see why his constituents should not be made aware of the low calibre of this man.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with the incompetence and the old fashioned nature of the Government's approach to this very serious problem. In the days of pneumatic tubes when people's bills were wrapped up with their shilling payment, were given to the attendant and the attendant pulled the string which took the tube and its contents to the accountant and the stamped receipt was returned, a tax law like this was relevant. It is as old-fashioned and incompetent as that. I have here my latest Bankcard bill, which, I am glad to say, I notice I have paid in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unlike you.

—I stop to acknowledge that interjection from the Minister, once again to dramatise the cheap and tawdry nature of his contributions to this chamber. This Bankcard statement, which has been paid, is not acceptable by this incompetent Government and this extraordinarily reactionary Tax Commissioner as an appropriate receipt for tax purposes. Let me read what is written on it. The statement has a date. It also has a date relating to the transaction. One particular transaction on this statement reads: 031090 RTA Queanbeyan-that is, Roads and Traffic Authority at Queanbeyan. It shows the amount for that transaction is $546.45. It meets all the requirements of the taxation Act with the exception that it does not outline the nature of the goods or services.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask: what sorts of goods and services will I buy at the Roads and Traffic Authority if it is not my registration? I am driving a car that is registered. If the Commissioner has any doubts, he can check. It is incredible that under the law this receipt fails only on the basis that it does not say that at the New South Wales State Government Roads and Traffic Authority Office I got a registration certificate which I can produce if the Taxation Commissioner wants to see it. It is not a receipt, though, for tax purposes but it was used to pay for a registration certificate. The Bankcard statement is the receipt for my registration expenses but, were I to present this as evidence of an expenditure for tax purposes, it would be rejected and, even more serious, I face the potential of a penalty for having not provided adequate substantiation.

This is the appalling element, the disgraceful feature, of what is happening at the moment. This Government is doing nothing about it. It will not allow Senator Watson's amendment, which would resolve a situation to give the Commissioner discretion to acknowledge and accept that this clearly is the sort of proper and relevant substantiation that surely is all that is needed. Let us recognise this: stamped on the bottom of the Bankcard statement, it states:
Many local authorities accept credit cards for payment of rates, electricity, telephone and water. No need to write a cheque or pay cash. Payment by credit card is safe and easy.

It may be safe and easy but it is not evidence of a tax deduction. If a proportion of people's telephone bills is to go towards the earning of income, paying by credit card in this form is unacceptable; not only that, but people run the risk of being fined for claiming that expenditure. This is the ludicrous situation that we discovered when we went to the seminar that Senator Watson organised.

Quite frankly, I want to see a discretion there formally-although I generally oppose discretions-for one specific reason: I want to make certain that the discretion is there so that a failure by the Commissioner to exercise it would entitle people who were refused that discretion to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Unless that discretion is there, that right is not available to taxpayers. This is a terribly serious situation. It appals me that this Government simply does not recognise it.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was noting that bankcard receipts are unacceptable as substantiation. I was pointing out that even when it is clear and unequivocal what the bill is for, and it is evident that it is a receipt and the account has been paid, this is not allowable as substantiation. This is absurd. The problem we have is this: as I understand it, the Commissioner of Taxation has indicated that he will apply commonsense. This is the point that Senator McMullan made generally when he said that it is not appropriate to correct what is clearly unacceptable in the way that Senator Watson wants to correct it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan, as I understand what he said, did not, however, present any coherent or proper alternative to provide a resolution to this problem. It is totally inadequate for the Commissioner to say that he will exercise commonsense in applying the law. In other words he will ignore, where it is relevant in his mind, what the law says. The reason it is improper and intolerable to accept that comment from the Commissioner is that if he fails to exercise commonsense, if he refuses to act like a reasonable being, there is no recourse by the person being taxed, the person being unfairly treated, the person even being fined. This is intolerable. If, however, there were a discretion and the Commissioner, as Senator Watson seeks to introduce, refused to exercise his discretion in favour of the taxpayer, and it was unreasonable of the Commissioner not to exercise his discretion, the taxpayer would have recourse. That is the essential difference that I am certain Senator McMullan did not realise when he said that Senator Watson's procedure was not the appropriate procedure to adopt.

Until Senator McMullan can demonstrate to this chamber that there is to be some requirement on the Commissioner to behave according to commonsense-which the Commissioner says he intends to do-in all cases, not simply those that might suit him, with the constraint imposed upon him that a failure to do so could lead to the taxpayer seeking redress, Senator McMullan is not only in a weak position, he is also defending the indefensible.
