I regret to say that my past experience with constituents-both when I was in the House of Representatives and now in the Senate-is laced with examples where those constituents feel they have been effectively blackmailed by the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner. I am not saying the Commissioner as such, I am not saying that Mr Boucher has blackmailed anyone; I am saying that they have been blackmailed by the taxation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some officials.
—As Senator Watson says, they have been effectively blackmailed by some officials to do other things to conform and often to make deals in terms of settlements-
—Ambit claims.

—In response to ambit claims because of the capacity of the Commissioner in some areas of discretion to apply a pretty tough approach. It might be curious that I am saying we need discretion. In this case I am saying we need discretion because if the Commissioner refuses to use his discretion and apply commonsense there is ultimate recourse for the taxpayer to require the Commissioner to do it. That is the essential difference between our position and the Government's position.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan occupies a position in this Government that I occupied in the Fraser Government. It is a very unrewarding position. It certainly does not help us get rich and in a marginal House of Representatives seat like mine it helps ensure our defeat.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't help you get popular either.

—As Senator McMullan says, it does not help you get popular. The Government's response to Senator Watson's reasonable, rational, well-argued and, it seems to me, totally proper approach sounds very much like the sort of response recommended by bureaucrats who do not wish to give up any power. The Government's preparedness to accept that response gives every indication of a government that is tired and, frankly, lacking in direction and competence.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to draw too many parallels between my experience in 1982 and Senator McMullan's in 1990 but I too used to receive lots of advice as to why our lack of preparedness to accept what the Commissioner was putting up would, in the Commissioner's view, lead to disaster, the end of the world as we know it and a collapse of all things true and beautiful. Mostly, that advice tended to be bunkum. I can remember, for example, not finding much merit in a proposition coming from this quarter that there should be a reverse onus of proof on a criminal matter. In this society, one is innocent until proven guilty. I must admit that it left quite an impact on me that any section of the bureaucracy in Australia should have recommended that people, on a criminal matter, should in fact have to prove their innocence.

I am not telling tales out of school; it is well known that that was the sort of advice that was coming to the previous Government. It has increased my concerns about much of the advice that tends to come from people in the bureaucracy who are, quite properly, deeply committed to their task in life-in this case to collect the revenue and prevent crooks from cheating on the revenue. Apparently, it can often lead one to a view that is inappropriate and to giving advice which is just plain wrong.

In this case, the advice is wrong, the Government's response is wrong and it is appalling that the rights of taxpayers to require the Commissioner to apply commonsense-that is basically what we are asking for-to have a discretion and to exercise it unless there is good reason not to are being denied. That requirement of ours is the difference between our position and the position that Senator McMullan is endeavouring-in logical terms unsuccessfully so far and I doubt that he will be successful in numerical terms either, at least in this chamber-to defend.
I shall briefly deal with what the Act actually requires in the form of a receipt. As Senator McMullan has said in a letter to all members and senators, Income Tax Ruling IT2482:
. . . makes it clear that a documentary evidence is defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act as `a receipt, invoice, or similar document-
I stress the phrase `similar document' because that has a significant relevance which I shall come back to-
obtained by or on behalf of the taxpayer at the time the expense was incurred or as soon as reasonably practicable thereafter-that contains the following information:
The date the expense was incurred:
The name of the person who supplied the relevant goods or services, or if supplied by a person conducting a business, the name of that person or the business name of that business;
The amount of the expense;
The nature of goods or services; and
The date of the document.

In the good old days when one went round and exchanged mountains of paper instead of paying things by Bankcard, that had a relevance. It no longer has relevance today. Every one of those requirements is met by my Bankcard bill, except as to the nature of goods or services-which in most cases is self-evident. If it is not self-evident, surely then the Commissioner could require the provision of some additional information. But it is a nonsense now that it breaches the law for the Commissioner to accept a Bankcard statement as evidence of substantiation when, for example, it is clear, self-evident and uncomplicated as to what it was about. I use the example of my New South Wales State government registration form, which appears on my Bankcard statement as `RTA'. It says everything; it meets all these requirements, except as to the nature of the goods and services.

We want to resolve this problem simply. We want to say that a Bankcard statement, for example, is, using commonsense, in most instances a similar document. But we want to say that that application of commonsense must not result in a situation where the Commissioner can use his `commonsense' in instance A and not use it in instance B, yet in instance B that taxpayer will have no recourse whatever. It gives Commissioners and Deputy Commissioners a totally unreasonable power over taxpayers in that, if the Commissioner wishes to use that capacity to exercise his discretion as a weapon or a lever over some other taxpayer, I believe that there is a risk that that will be done.

Senator Watson's proposal is fair, proper, reasonable and deserving of support. It deserves support because it will ensure that there is a uniform approach across Australia, because it requires the exercise of a discretion, and because it gives the taxpayer redress if for some non-commonsense reason that discretion is not exercised. I support Senator Watson's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to thank all those honourable senators who have participated in this debate tonight, in particular the Liberal and Australian Democrats senators who have supported the Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In my second reading speech I acknowledged that the concept of discretions did not fit easily with this new era of self-assessment. Senator McMullan picked up this theme and used it as his prime reason for the Government's rejection of the substantiation amendment. There must have been perhaps not a lack of charity but a tongue in cheek approach, since Senator McMullan then proceeded with a great deal of enthusiasm with his argument. As he did so he reminded me of a great Tasmanian Senator in this place, Sir Reginald Wright, a man who would have no tolerance whatsoever of the idea of any discretions. I remind the Senate that with the evolution of income tax history such an approach was lost many years ago. Let me quote a sentence from Peter Roach, who presided over the churchworker Evangelist's case on this matter. He said:
This issue is no longer open for review.

In other words, the argument for discretions or no discretions was no longer open for review in a practical sense. Given the hundreds of discretions that this Government has introduced, I find that the Government's argument is one of convenience rather than a genuine attempt to rectify the situation. I believe that the enthusiasm of the draftsmen has imposed such strict obligations as to be completely unreasonable given the developments in technology for document presentation and annotation.
I wish to pick up a comment by Peter Roach, a senior former member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) in the important case to which I referred. He said:

I can only conclude by expressing my regret as a result of my disappointment that the Parliament has not found it possible to provide a more appropriate set of requirements as to substantiation of claims honestly made and a more just procedure for mounting a reasonable challenge to a decision of the Commissioner on a matter of substantial importance to a very large number of citizens.

We have given this opportunity to the Parliament. I regret that this Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government has not responded in any way to the window of opportunity that it has been given on this occasion. I am not telling tales out of school when I say that a great number of members of the ALP are wishing me good luck and godspeed with this amendment. I only regret that this matter was not placed before the Caucus.

Given the hundreds of discretions and given the discretions that will be debated next week in that voluminous set of amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill, I must say that there is a lack of genuineness in the line of argument that was used tonight. It was an argument of convenience rather than an argument leading to the heart of the matter.

It is always difficult at times to justify stands that others take, and I acknowledge the role that Senator McMullan has played. This is not a personal criticism. He has to put the point of view of the Government of the day, and on this occasion the Government has failed to respond to the opportunity given.

In response to the argument about a rush of appeals in relation to this matter if this Bill passes, let me say that there will certainly be no rush to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because of the substantial amount of money that a taxpayer now must put up front when lodging appeals.

I thank Senator Spindler for his thoughtful contribution in helping to pass the amendment before the Senate tonight. He has suggested that he will be proceeding with a future amendment in relation to another Act, but I submit that, with this substantiation amendment in place, I do not believe that it will be necessary for him to proceed with that amendment. The Commissioner of Taxation now has the opportunity to put in place a set of income tax rulings to provide the framework under which he will exercise that discretion.

Without my amendment he was unable to proceed. We have now given that opportunity and I trust that the Tax Commissioner will move speedily in this area to provide a new income tax ruling to provide some flesh to the approach that I have used.

May I use this occasion to signal a further private member's Bill which will be called a technical corrections Bill. This will be a device to overcome a further problem that taxpayers find with income tax law-the problem of unintended consequences. This is a device that is used with great success in the United States parliament whereby annually a technical corrections Bill picks up the unintended consequences in situations where there is acknowledged complex legislation and, as a result of the interactions of one section with another, unfortunately unintended consequences are created because of the enthusiasm of the draftsman or the Taxation Office and the inability of parliament, through a lack of resources, to foresee those particular problems.

I will summarise the problems that this Bill intends to overcome. The Bill overcomes situations so the Taxation Office can be satisfied with the genuineness and accuracy of the claim and so that deductions will not be disallowed in a purely technical and unreasonable manner. I believe that my Bill will provide the Commissioner with a discretion where he-not the taxpayer-is satisfied that the expenses have been incurred legitimately and that the compliance requirements have, for all intents and purposes, been met. We do not intend to diminish the thrust of the substantiation requirements. We intend to give the taxpayers and the Commissioner a better life, because I believe that this sort of legislation does not put the integrity of tax laws on a particularly high plane. I believe this is an attempt to overcome that dilemma.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) acknowledges the contribution of the Fraser Government in funding to the States through the Commonwealth Extension Services Grants for soil conservation initiatives;
(b) notes the false statement in the speech of Senator Maguire to the Senate on 11 November 1990 that the Hawke Government was the first Federal Government to provide funding for soil conservation;

(c) notes the misleading statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in answer to a question from Senator Maguire on 18 October 1990 that no Federal Government had previously been involved in soil conservation;
(d) requests Senator Cook and Senator Maguire to withdraw their remarks so as to correct the record; and
(e) requests the Senators in the future, if they wish to gain cheap political points on an issue of vital national importance, at least to get their facts right.

In addressing this motion before the chamber, sadly I find myself having to read it because I do not believe the summary-if I can call it that-in the Notice Paper reflects the motion on two counts. The notice of motion that I sought to move, on the matter of soil conservation funding, reads:
That the Senate-

(a) acknowledges the contribution of the Fraser Government in funding to the States through the Commonwealth Extension Services Grants for soil conservation initiatives was in 1975-76, $616,120; 1976-77, $711,016; 1977-78, $652,676; 1978-79, $396,613; 1979-80, $198,096; 1980-81, $159,412; and in 1981-82 $3m for soil conservation initiatives was included in the funds allocated to the States under general revenue assistance grants following a review of Commonwealth functions;

(b) notes the false statement in the speech of Senator Maguire to the Senate on 11 October 1990 in which he stated, `We were the first government in the history of the nation at the Federal level to provide funds for soil conservation';

(c) notes the misleading statement by Senator Cook in answer to a question from Senator Maguire on 18 October in which he stated, `When we came to power there was no Federal Government involvement in soil conservation and no Federal Government funding';
(d) requests Senator Cook and Senator Maguire to withdraw their remarks so as to correct the record; and
(e) requests the Senators in the future, if they wish to gain cheap political points on an issue of vital national importance, at least to get their facts right.

I have read that out because what was printed on the Notice Paper is, I believe, wrong on two counts. It leaves out the detail of the motion in terms of the funding provided and paragraph (d) misrepresents what I said in the notice of motion concerning Senator Cook. I regret that I have to --

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crane, I understand that the notice of motion that appears on the Notice Paper is in conformance with the Standing Orders. Amendments were made to your original notice of motion so it would conform with the Standing Orders. You may wish to take issue with that, but that was the judgment made at the time by the Clerks.
—I understand that, but I wish to point out to the Senate that it misrepresented the position both in terms of my motion and what I had said with regard to Senator Cook's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with some regret that I have to bring this matter before the chamber. The issue of soil conservation funding is of great importance. One of the most crucial challenges facing us in the period ahead is the adoption of an accurate bipartisan position on soil conservation funding. I acknowledge what Senator Cook said when he made that point. Both at the State and Federal levels-prior to becoming a senator-I have enjoyed a very good working relationship with both Liberal-National Party governments and the Australian Labor Party in that respect.

When considering this motion tonight we are not talking about who did what or what happened; we are talking about whether or not the propositions that were put before us in a speech and in an answer to a question were accurate. I submit that they were not.

I will take the Senate through a number of aspects relating to that. To emphasise the points I want to make tonight I also acknowledge the funding contributions to soil conservation made by the Fraser Government, the Whitlam Government and the Hawke Government and some of the initiatives that have been put into effect. That is very important if we are to have a bipartisan approach to this problem.

In 1983-84 the Hawke Government contributed $1m to soil conservation funding; in 1984-85, $4m; in 1985-86, $4.652m; in 1986-87, $5.5m; in 1987-88, $6m; in 1988-89, $10.634m; and in 1989-90, $23.227m. I will not give details of the following year but there are certain projections.

I also point out-and I think I have made this point about soil conservation and the land care program in this chamber before-that the first soil conservation district was in the Kimberley area of Western Australia. The next one was in the Rocky Valley area-again in Western Australia. The next one was in the Yilgarn area, which happens to be where Senator Panizza lives. These came about as a result of amendments to the Soil Conservation Act which were put in place in 1982 by the Court Government. The Minister responsible for that was Mr Dick Old. That was followed through by the Burke Government, under the auspices of Julian Grill. Out of that came our conservation district committee structure.

I have already talked about the contributions made by the Fraser Government but I would like to make a couple of points about them. The source of the figures contained in my motion is an answer to a question from the now Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden by Mr Peter Nixon. The $3m, which was contributed to soil conservation funding and which today equates to $5,597,283, was granted to the States under the allocation of general revenue assistance grants. This was earmarked for soil conservation measures following a review of Commonwealth functions. But much to my regret, the only States that spent that money on what it was intended for, were South Australia, which had a Liberal government, Western Australia, which had a Liberal-Country Party government, and Queensland, which had a National-Liberal Party government. Victoria, which had a Liberal Party government, did not meet its obligations, nor did New South Wales and Tasmania, which both had Labor governments at that time. I do not agree with the decision made at that time, but the fact is that in 1981-82 $3m was put aside for soil conservation funding. These facts absolutely disprove Senator Maguire's comments and the follow-up statement of Senator Cook.

It would be useful if I were to relate other aspects about soil conservation funding. I find surprising the comments of those opposite who chose to denigrate the previous Labor Government because, on 27 November 1974, in its last years, the Whitlam Government provided, as grants to the States, some $500,000 to June 1975 and another $2 1/2m to June 1976 under the Soil Conservation Act. That is further proof that the statements made by Senator Maguire and Senator Cook are inaccurate.

I refer to a book written by J. R. Bradsen, from the Faculty of Law, University of Adelaide, which was compiled in 1988. That is a very good summary of soil conservation and how it has developed since Federation with particular reference to the period since the 1930s. It draws on some interesting facts and data, which I will go into. The other book I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate and which is important is a report prepared by the Research Directorate of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. It is a basis for soil conservation policy in Australia. Once again, that book contains a very good record of what has occurred. I certainly recommend both those publications to anybody who is interested in the history of soil conservation and land care in this country, particularly those people who wish to make factual comments on this important matter.

I will highlight some aspects of this book by Mr Bradsen. The first part-I will not read it because time is short and the hour is late-spells out very clearly the problems the Commonwealth has with the Commonwealth and State powers involved in soil conservation and land care. The States' attitude to land care and soil conservation is much more finely tuned and much more cooperative now than what it was 10, 15 or 20 years ago. In fact, States' rights is fast ceasing to be an issue when it comes to the land care program. In 1988 Mr Bradsen, in his book, said:

At times the history reads like a monumental exercise in delay. Indeed, there can be no single issue recognised for so long as of such national importance about which the Commonwealth has done so little.

The challenge that has been put before the Government highlights that point. Despite the increased funding during the last years of the Whitlam Government through to the Fraser Government and the increased funding under the Hawke Government, the land care program, in terms of the assessments that have been made, is still grossly under funded.

The first real interest in soil degradation and the problems of land care shown at the Commonwealth level was taken in the 1930s. I draw the attention of the Senate to page 109 of this book. It states that the first meeting held between the Commonwealth and the States was in 1936. A report from that agricultural subcommittee development was presented to this Senate, following a meeting between the Ministers and the Government at that time, by Senator A. J. McLachlan, who was the great uncle of Ian McLachlan, who is now the honourable member for Barker and who sits in the other place. That is the evidence of the earliest meeting that I can find. I am not saying that it is absolute. It is rather difficult to track these things down. There are some other interesting remarks in this book made by members on both sides of the chamber. In 1937 Mr Scullin stated:
It will be nothing short of a crime if we continue to permit the destruction of forests and the erosion of the soil.
Further, in 1945 Mr Lemmon, who was an Australian Labor Party member for the Western Australian electorate of Forrest said:

Soil erosion is much more dangerous to the future of Australia than are the bombs falling on Berlin to the future of Germany. . . We should set up a Commonwealth Commission . . . to tackle soil erosion on a national basis.

I recommend that Senator Maguire go through the history of this matter as it would help him understand the issue far better than he obviously did the other day. It points out a number of things said by a number of people.

There are a number of other aspects that I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate tonight. Unfortunately, the hour is late, so I will not go through all of the things that I had outlined to speak about. In terms of the national soil conservation program that is in place now, what has occurred in the past and whether Federal governments of all colours have done enough is not the point of what we are talking about. I can see little benefit in point scoring as far as this particular exercise is concerned. The issue is too important. It is important in a number of ways. I believe one of the most important pieces of heritage that we have to hand on to future generations is the soil, preservation of it and other aspects of conservation that go along with it.

I was most dismayed when I heard the comments that were made the other day in the Senate, because they were not consistent with what has been occurring in soil conservation in the recent past and even beyond the recent past. Despite the claims that are made in a political context, for a long time an effort has been made to have a bipartisan approach to this aspect of policy development. It is worth noting-and one could go on quoting from this little book-that gradually over the last 15, 16 or 17 years there has been more emphasis placed on this and it has become more important in the political agenda. I would hope that into the future, regardless of who occupies the government benches in the House of Representatives or in this place, increased emphasis continues to be placed on its importance.

I would now like to summarise what I have had to say-and I have cut my speech short, because I know that other senators here tonight wish to speak on this issue. My motion concerns the fact that what Senator Maguire had to say was not correct. I regret that he had not done the research required to be factual but I think it is equally important or more important that Senator Cook, as a Minister, when asked a question that was obviously given to him with some notice-he read a prepared answer-should have been able to do better in putting the matter into its true perspective. I can only be particularly critical of Senator Cook because I think that one of the responsibilities of Ministers in this place when they are asked dorothy dix questions is to get it right. In this particular case I think the evidence is overwhelming.

The first evidence of support by the Commonwealth for the States in the terms of assistance for soil conservation funding occurred around 1946 or 1947, when the first subcommittees on soil conservation expenditure were put together and the Commonwealth provided the secretariat service. In the years from 1948 to 1960 grants were made to the States from the Commonwealth in terms of putting soil conservation issues and measurements in place. I am not making a judgment as to whether those were adequate. In fact, I have already made that judgment; I do not believe they were adequate. But that is not what we are talking about in this place tonight. We are talking about whether the statement by Senator Maguire was accurate, and I submit that it was not because there was significant Federal funding provided for soil conservation. I also submit that during the term of the Fraser Government and in subsequent years there was in fact something in excess of $10m in dollar values at that time spent on soil conservation. If we transmit that figure into today's dollars, it is a figure of $20m or more. I would suggest that that is conclusive proof of the fact that these particular statements were not accurate, and I call upon those gentlemen to correct the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane has moved a motion in the Senate today about soil conservation and statements that I and the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, have made. The claims made by Senator Crane are not true. In fact, he has made ridiculous claims that I have somehow misled Parliament with regard to the national soil conservation program. I reject out of hand the claims that he has made tonight and I oppose the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, he has selectively quoted me in his motion, and he in fact ignores my first statement on the question of soil conservation, which is reported on page 296 of the Hansard of 11 October. He chose a quote which suited his argument. I said that the first ever program at the national level for soil conservation had been brought in under this Government. The key word is `program', and Senator Crane ignored the fact that we were talking about the first national soil conservation program. I am factually correct in saying that.

I know that Senator Crane had to move this motion: he had no option but to do it. We flushed out honourable senators opposite on their record on soil conservation by that speech and by the question to the Minister. We have exposed Liberal and National Party senators, firstly, on their lack of knowledge about soil conservation programs and, secondly, on their poor record on the subject and their total lack of substantial impact on the subject of soil degradation through a structured national program.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are degrading the soil-you are digging a bigger hole for yourself.

—I will quote from the same report from which Senator Crane has quoted and I will damn him with the same report, because I am sure that he has not read all of it. We in fact exposed the lack of knowledge on the other side about the history of soil conservation in this country. One has only to look at the interjections from Senator Short and Senator O'Chee during my initial speech to see that they did not know the facts. Then we exposed their lack of knowledge about the fact that the first national structured soil conservation program was brought in by the Hawke Labor Government. It is abundantly clear if one reads all of the Budget Papers. No doubt, after hearing of this exchange in the Parliament, the constituents of the rural members will be demanding answers from them. They will ask why they did not know the history of soil conservation and why they did not take some action when they were in government. That is what has been going on. Opposition senators have been getting the raspberry from their own members out in the electorate because, clearly, they do not know the facts about the history of soil conservation in this country. They do not have a monopoly on knowledge of rural matters and should have known better.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the substantive issues. After my speech on 11 October-and I knew I was right-I then asked the Minister a question because of these fanciful interjections from Senator Short and Senator O'Chee. In fact, honourable senators opposite were so worried about my question without notice to the Minister that Senator Teague and Senator Alston called points of order. They were so worried about the impact that their own lack of action on soil conservation was going to have on their credibility in the rural areas that they did everything they could to stop the question being asked. I remember it very clearly. I knew that I had a good question when I had two points of order called on me. It was clear from the interjections from Senator Short and Senator O'Chee that they knew as much about the history of soil conservation as Burke and Wills knew about orienteering. That was the reality of it. They did not have a clue what they were talking about.

Before 1983 there was no structured national soil conservation program. That is absolutely true; it is factual. There was no national program to address soil and land degradation. Senator Crane has very carefully ignored that. I turn to the 1983 Budget Paper No. 1. This was not written by members of the House of Representatives or senators-this was written by neutral public servants in the Department of the Treasury. I read these things regularly; I knew where to look and I looked at page 191. It states:
Soil Conservation
The Commonwealth has provided $1m for the implementation of a national soil conservation program.

`Implementation', according to the Oxford Dictionary, means to begin something for the first time-to initiate something. The Commonwealth Government was implementing a national soil conservation program.

TALK.START.PARA: —One million.

—Well, there was nothing before that of a natural structured program on soil conservation. There we have Budget Paper No. 1 from the 1983 Budget Papers. I turn to Budget Paper No. 7 from 1983. It has a very interesting table at page 168. This table is one of those that I read regularly. It is headed `Six States Total Commonwealth and Loan Council Borrowings 1979-80'-Fraser years-`to 1983-84'.

SPEECH.PARA: What do I see in that program? The title is `Soil Conservation'. For 1979-80 the figure is zero; 1980-81, zero. Senator Crane has been quoting figures for these years but they are not here. In 1981-82, another Fraser year, it was zero. In 1982-83, substantially a Fraser year, not a cent was allocated for soil conservation. However, in 1983-84, the first item appears-the $600,000 element of the $1m that is being paid to the States under this structured national program for soil conservation. We spent the other $400,000 of the $1m directly ourselves on soil conservation and awareness campaigns.

There we go. In this table on page 168 of Budget Paper No. 7 from the 1983 Budget set, written by the Public Service-the neutral public servants in the Department of the Treasury-not a bean, not a single cent, was allocated under a soil conservation heading for 1979-80, 1980-81, 1981-82 and 1982-83. Do I need to say any more? I think I will. I will keep going because there is more to say.

The reality was that in the Fraser years there was a Minister called Kevin Newman. At that time he was the Minister for the environment-I think 1976-1977 was the period. He tried valiantly to get Commonwealth funds for a national soil conservation program. He tried everything he could to get some remedial action taken on land degradation in Australia. He got discussions going on soil conservation. But, unfortunately for him, he was thwarted by the razor gang-the so-called inner sanctum of Ministers who went round axing and taxing and slashing, who said there would be no soil conservation program. That is the record. Kevin Newman did try to get a scheme up, and I would be the first to acknowledge that.
Senator Crane in his motion, which attacks me claiming that I have somehow made false statements, refers to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Somehow! That you have.
—I think the evidence against it is pretty damning. He refers to $3m--
—That is what you believe. It is a shame the record does not agree with you.

—If Senator Knowles wants to hear the arguments she should listen. The Budget table shows no cents at all for soil conservation from 1979-80 to 1982-83 under the Liberals-not a single cent paid to the States. Maybe they want to pull some Stalinist trick and rewrite history, but I am not into that. Senator Crane hangs part of his motion--
—He has judged you pretty clearly.

—He has judged Senator Campbell pretty severely. Senator Crane tries to make the centrepiece of his motion the sum of $3m which he said was paid for soil conservation under the Liberals in 1981-82. I am a pretty thorough researcher and I thought, `You cannot take anything the Liberals say at face value; you have got to analyse it very carefully because, generally speaking, it is at odds with the reality', so I had a look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: I discovered that, in fact, those funds have been bunged in with untied grants to the States through the general revenue assistance arrangements. I am fairly familiar with those things. I had a look at those, and that was the situation. They were just thrown in the general pool of funds. The sum of $3m was added to the revenue base for onpayments to the States as part of that general base. Not one cent of that $3m was earmarked specifically for soil conservation. I hope that Senator Campbell is listening to this. I used to work in a Premier's office. I know what goes on with funds, and these funds were available to be used as the States wished. They could be used on any State responsibility. There is another damning indictment of the sort of case that Senator Crane has been trying to mount.

Let us have a look at the Bradsen report. It is a very interesting report. I happen to have met the author; he was at the University of Adelaide. This report, published in 1988, is titled Soil Conservation Legislation in Australia. One of the things it looked at-although I do not think Senator Crane actually referred to it tonight-is the $3m that I have just been talking about. The report actually examines that amount, added to the general base of revenue for the States, and tries to analyse what happened to it-what wonderful soil conservation program or whatever came out of it.

What Mr Bradsen found when he analysed this $3m-again I point out that it is the centrepiece of the case that has been so carefully mounted here by Senator Crane-was that only three of the six States, and I admit Western Australia was one of them and that my State was another, actually passed on any of that $3m to anything at all resembling soil conservation. Three States, New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania-I hope Senator Campbell is still listening-just totally bunged it into the general revenue pool.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not want to listen to your lecture.

—I think Opposition senators should. Somebody has moved a motion here tonight attacking my integrity, saying I made false statements. This is a subject I know something about, even though I do not go around with a hayseed in my teeth and wearing moleskins.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bradsen discovered-and Senator Crane waved that report around tonight but did not use this particular section from it-that only three of the States had actually done anything with the money. The rest of them just threw it into the general revenue pool and did not use it for any such purpose. That is one thing that has to be borne in mind.

I do not know whether Senator Crane actually quoted one of the conclusions from Mr Bradsen's report on page 119, but I found it a very interesting and wonderful conclusion. After he had analysed the fact that this money had not been passed on for the so-called purpose that the Fraser Government had decided it should be spent on, after his analysis of the three States out of six that did something with it and the three that did not, he concluded as follows:
In these circumstances one would have to conclude that at this point any serious national commitment to soil conservation . . . had been abandoned.

That was Mr Bradsen quoting the record of the Fraser years-the record of the Liberals, talking about soil conservation, perhaps, but not acting on it. He was quoting them and saying that, even if they had been talking about it and saying that there had been some sort of commitment to it, any serious national commitment to soil conservation had been abandoned.

So much for the $3m. So much for one of the centrepieces of Senator Crane's motion as it related to 1981-82. So much for the motion, because that is one of the building bricks that he based it on. He should not come in here and think we are going to have our legs pulled. Some of us know what we are talking about and I hope he will learn that in the future.

He also refers to Commonwealth extension service grants in bolstering his case. The facts about these extension service grants are that they were never established for the specific purpose of promoting soil conservation. I assume Senator Crane knows that as well as I do. In fact, extension service grants paid for a range of things in the rural sector but they were never established with the specific purpose of promoting soil conservation.

TALK.START.PARA: —These were established, and you know it.

—I am going to analyse some of Senator Crane's figures in a moment because I find them very interesting. As I said, I never take anything the Liberals say to me at face value. I always check it very carefully because my long experience has shown that it pays dividends. When one really digs into something that is said on the conservative side of politics-usually it is done with a short time horizon in view-and looks at the assumptions and the research foundation, it is generally found to be wanting.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is hurting. I can tell it is really hurting, but I am going to keep it going. Honourable senators opposite have attacked my integrity, and I am going to keep going. We are now going to analyse the Commonwealth extension service grants, which again are one of the pillars on which this very flimsy motion moved by Senator Crane is based, and which somehow suggests that I have been making misleading statements to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that, as I have pointed out, these grants were not established for any specific purpose relating to soil conservation; rather, they were established to promote general agricultural advisory services. They were grants of a general nature to fund general advisory services. Senator Crane claims, for example, in his motion attacking me and Senator Cook that in 1979-80, $198,000 was provided for soil conservation. When I analysed this, I found that in 1979-80-one of the years of the Fraser Administration-general agricultural extension service grants totalled $4.7m. So even if-and I do not necessarily accept this-Senator Crane is right in saying that $198,000 was somehow spent on soil conservation in 1979-80, that was only a minuscule 4 per cent of the Commonwealth extension service grants. What I am really saying is that while Senator Crane is attacking me and is attacking Senator Cook by saying that the Fraser Government provided more money for soil conservation under the Commonwealth extension service grants, in fact in the one financial year I checked, 1979-80, a mere $198,000 out of $4.73m was actually allocated to anything resembling soil conservation. I guess we can say, then, that 96 per cent of the money was not spent on anything resembling soil conservation.

I think we can draw the conclusion from looking at the Liberal's track record in government that soil conservation was hardly a priority. I have been through all of the strands of this motion and have demolished them one after the other. In the very last part of the motion, the Opposition is saying that it boosted soil conservation and that it did something for soil conservation through the Commonwealth extension service grants, but I have been able to show just by analysis of one financial year that 96 per cent of the money was not spent on soil conservation; 4 per cent may have been.

The reality is that it was the Hawke Labour Government which was elected in March 1983 which brought in the first structured national program to lead with land degradation and soil conservation. I would like now to look at our record under that program. Let us not have any more silly motions alleging that people have made misleading statements. The whole of the motion is rather misleading when we analyse it paragraph by paragraph, subparagraph by subparagraph, line by line. There is no factual basis of any substance for giving any credibility at all to this motion. I reject it out of hand and I hope that when Senator Crane comes in here in the future he will not suggest that people on this side of the Chamber make misleading statements. I reject his comments out of hand.

Under the national soil conservation program, introduced by the Hawke Labor Government in 1983, we have allocated some $55m-a vast amount of money compared with the mere hundreds of thousands of dollars talked about by Senator Crane-and the Government has promised to provide some $260m to the program over the next ten years, which of course will be known as the Decade of Land Care. About 80 per cent of the funds provided under the national soil conservation program, which I have pointed out here tonight was the first structured national program to deal with land degradation and soil conservation in Australia, has been directed to State government agencies. The funding under the program has stimulated increased funding for soil conservation by the various State agencies and according to the information now available to the Federal Labor Government the total expenditure by the States on soil conservation, on our best estimate, was $78m in 1987-88. So very substantial amounts of money are being spent-$55m under the Hawke Labor Government since the program was implemented in 1983 and $78m by the States in 1987-88 alone.

We have found that since we introduced this particular scheme, landholder and general public interest in land degradation has increased markedly. That is a welcome development, because land degradation has certainly been one of the major, if not the major, environmental problems in this country. The change in attitude has been profound as have been the adoption rates of conservation farming practices. They are welcome developments, as well.

I am pleased to say that this Government supported the establishment of the Australian Soil Conservation Council and its subsidiary committees in 1986, so that body was set up three years after the big program came into operation. A ministerial task force comprising members of the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation was established in 1988 to consider soil conservation policy initiatives that can be taken by the Commonwealth. Membership of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee has been increased, from seven members to twelve, in order to provide a greater range of expertise to formulate policy advice for the Minister.

A non-profit company, Landcare Australia, has been established to increase awareness and to help develop the land care ethic within the Australian community-a very commendable activity. I am sure there is a lot of bipartisan support for these measures in the community. Under that non-profit company, Landcare Australia, corporate and private sponsorship of activities will be sought, and I am pleased to say that a public awareness campaign is planned for 1990 which will target urban as well as rural Australia. It is important that urban Australia be targeted. Much of the focus on land degradation and soil conservation has been on rural areas, the country and regional areas of Australia. It is important that these matters be brought into the large metropolitan areas of the Australian community to ensure that awareness is raised, to ensure that people in our capital cities are aware of the pressing need to look after our land and ensure that it is not degraded any further.

I reject this motion moved tonight. I have in no way made misleading statements to the Senate. I believe I have, brick by brick, piece by piece, demolished this rather flimsy case that somehow Senator Cook and I misled the Parliament in this matter. The reality is that under the Hawke Labor Government and under Minister Kerin, the first ever structured national soil conservation program to deal with land degradation in Australia was introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are eager to participate in the debate on this motion, not particularly because we are concerned about the trivialities of who wants to claim the credit for being the first to wake up to the fact that the well-being of Australia as a whole is inextricably linked to the well-being of its soil. In fact, we think it is absolutely crucial that this debate occur but not necessarily on the ground on which it is being fought at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to hear Senator Crane say during his contribution that he could see little benefit in point scoring because the substance was too important. It seems to me that from the perspective of the Government benches the whole issue began with an attempt at point scoring, which perhaps backfired, although I am not sure of that. Lest it be seen as point scoring, I want to make the point in passing that the only occasion on which a matter of urgency has ever been debated in the Senate on the issue of soil conservation was in 1987, when it was introduced by Senator Janet Powell and it received all-party support. However, I would not want to try to claim any point scoring on that.

I was disappointed to hear Senator Maguire base his case on the semantics of the qualifiers that he used, such as `structured', `national' and `program' to defend the position he had chosen to take. It seemed to me to open up a situation where the debate could only be about who cares the most about the soil in Australia. Regrettably this motion is not about the substance of the issues relating to soil conservation. The Democrats are in this place, we believe, to debate substantive issues to ensure that Government and the Opposition take decisive action on matters of concern to all Australians and we would rather not have these never ending debates on who did what to whom and when and who was right then or now. I feel that is fairly pointless.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was attacked in this motion. Surely I am allowed to defend myself?

—I acknowledge the interjection that Senator Maguire thinks he needed to defend himself. I would have preferred that debate ensued on the substance of actions that could and should be taken in the whole context of what is the value of soil conservation and, in fact, what are the actions other than funding that should take place. That is what is wrong with this debate; it is tied too closely to the question of funding. Simply to throw money at soil conservation is not to show commitment. The Democrats today would like to place on record as we have on other occasions that we are happy to acknowledge the contributions of all governments-local, State and Federal-as well as community groups, conservation groups such as Greening Australia and the Australian Conservation Foundation, Girl Guide groups, Rotary groups, local land care groups, schools and individuals like the late Ernest `Watershed' Jackson from Victoria. They have made a commitment and a contribution to soil conservation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not argue about which government is responsible for what level of funding but rather which government has led the nation in a commitment to soil conservation. That is sadly lacking in this debate, and that is what is wrong with this debate. As a matter of fact I would have preferred to hear Senator Maguire talk about his colleague Senator John Devereux who, during the weekend, spent most of the flight from Tasmania happily telling about some of the initiatives he has had taken on his property in developing the soil profile of that property. I would have been happier had I received a more charitable reception from honourable senators yesterday when I spoke about research into worms instead of some degree of ridicule from all sides of the chamber for having raised such a matter. In fact, I pointed out yesterday when looking at the report that worms are capable of contributing some 20 per cent to the productivity of pastures in Australia. To be ridiculed for raising that as a matter of importance indicates to me the lack of commitment from both sides of this chamber. I have a lot to say on this matter and I regret that time for this discussion is rapidly drawing to a conclusion. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean there is a written address that he wants to incorporate?
—I assume the honourable senator is referring to verbose notes?
—Yes, to verbose notes and some quotations, which parallel the sorts of quotations we have heard today.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows:

Also with respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, and in all humility we must also acknowledge the efforts of the Australian Democrats and list a few of our initiatives and actions. Our members themselves, as members of communities, as farmers, and as members of conservation and land care groups making their contribution towards trying to arrest Australia's severe land degradation problems.

Back in 1983 a now retired Democrat Senator and a former Democrat deputy leader, Colin Mason, introduced into this chamber an Income Tax Amendment Bill, which was designed to remove tax deductibility for the clearing of trees. When the Hawke Government brought in its own legislation later, the Democrats were happy to support it. These initiatives included:
Soil Conservation-In 1987 Senator Powell initiated an urgency debate on soil conservation, called for the development of national soil conservation legislative framework for adoption by the States.

Sustainable Agriculture-consistently urged the Government to provide support, incentives, information and advice to farmers within to make the transition to ecologically and economically sustainable agriculture. Called for the establishment of a school of sustainable agriculture.

Agricultural Chemicals-initiated establishment of a Senate select committee to inquire into the social, environmental and economic impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.
Sustainable Development-successfully amended primary industry legislation to ensure that the concepts of sustainability and conservation must be consistent.

Just referring to our call for the establishment of a school of sustainable agriculture, one should note the plans of the University of New England, which is engaged in assessing the level of demand for courses in alternative agriculture in order to find out the views of those intending to enrol in agricultural courses in respect of the skills they would like to develop and their preferences for the way such courses are offered. Other measures the Democrats have been calling for include greater Commonwealth responsibility, especially greater legislative responsibility. The Democrats support the views of environmental lawyer, John Bradsen, who has called on the Federal Government to enact effective land conservation legislation where it has exclusive power and to examine all legislation and policies to assess their land conservation significance. Mr Bradsen has said, `For example, taxation deductions should not apply to clearance without a full conservation assessment of the land.' On this point of Mr Bradsen's, my colleague, Senator John Coulter, the environment spokesman for the Democrats has a notice of motion on the Notice Paper immediately under the one we are now debating. Senator Coulter's motion reads:

That the Senate requires that every explanatory memorandum presented to the Senate with a Bill contain a statement explaining the environmental impact, if any, which would result from the implementation of the proposals contained in the Bill, that the statement be headed Statement of Environmental Impact of this Bill, and be in the same form as the financial impact statements currently included in explanatory memoranda.

This is a consistently genuine commitment to and understanding of the interrelatedness of the many factors involved in soil conservation, unlike the disputing funding records we have heard quoted here tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: — The time allocated for General Business has expired. We will now proceed to Government Business.
—For the clarification of the Senate, if the time expires, the question is not put.

—On a point of order, I advise you, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is my view that before you sought to call on the next item of business the time had not expired and it should have been called on before that was done.
—That was not my immediate observation, Senator Reid, but in deference to your judgment and the fact that your eyesight might be better than mine, I propose to put the motion.
—No, you cannot do that. Other people might want to speak.
—I might have wanted to speak.
—Upon sober reflection, I must rely on how I read it so I will not put the motion.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1990-91APPROPRIATION BILL (No.2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an urgent need to promote true justice for the people in less developed countries, particularly the poor people for whom we provide development assistance through our foreign aid budget. The prime task in seeking justice and empowerment for these people is the need to focus attention on what makes them poor. The tendency has been to blame the poor for their poverty and to prescribe for them and impose upon them so-called `solutions' including at times the final solution of getting rid of their unborn. These so-called solutions end up empowering, not the poor, but the governments and international bureaucracies which proceed to further threaten their already fragile rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent focus in our aid program on the environment has the potential to be a welcome and overdue initiative. In the context that I have just referred to-that is, the promotion through our aid allocations of justice for the poor-the new environmental initiatives must not be used as a back door means of using ecological excuses for population control. It is of great concern that of the $5.21m of aid money redirected this financial year for development cooperation on global environment issues, 30 per cent has been allocated for what the Australian International Development Aid Bureau has termed `population stabilisation' and most of the money is going to international population control groups such as International Planned Parenthood Federation the (IPPF) and the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA).

Finally, I would like to address briefly the issue of development education. There has been a call to spend up to $5m on development education in Australia to explain to Australians the rationale for foreign aid. I must express qualified support for a program in development education. Two recent instances of the use of the aid budget for development education to foreclose, not promote, debate on development issues points to the need for vigilance. In last year's aid budget, the Family Planning Federation of Australia-an organisation affiliated with the IPPF-is the population control lobby group which received a grant to produce for parliamentarians a briefing kit on population and development. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) has used aid money to fund an Australian organisation which supports population control to produce a propaganda briefing kit for parliamentarians which will tell us why we should give more money to organisations like it and the IPPF to support such programs from our aid budget. That is a gross misuse, I believe, of development education funds and an insult to our intelligence.

The second abuse arose when AIDAB announced an essay competition for students of years 10, 11 and 12 on the subject `The Challenge of World Population Growth'. The competition was arranged, so we are told, to increase the awareness amongst young people of the impact of population growth on developing countries. But, without exception, all the material provided to the schools by AIDAB promotes the view that people in developing countries are the problem and population control the solution.

There was no mention of the contrary view-a very valid view-that population growth is a symptom, not the cause, of poverty. There was no mention of the implications for poor families of the imposition of population control imperialism. Indeed, there was no in-depth analysis of the basic cause of poverty. There was no mention of the oft forgotten fact that children in developing countries are not the burden that some people in Western countries believe them to be.

This promotion of a population control mentality amongst our youth sets the scene for the future implementation of programs involving massive violations of human rights, as are currently occurring in China and some other countries, and further denials of the true needs of families in the developing countries. Is this what we mean by true development education-promoting the views of international population control organisations?

Indeed, at the Estimates Committee hearings, I had asked for some of the material that was being presented and AIDAB gave me the material, which included an editorial critical of an article which in turn was critical of the population control mentality. But AIDAB did not include that article and so was sending a one-sided piece of information out to the students.

In conclusion, this 1990-91 aid budget has highlighted the age-old adage that the noisy wheel gets the oil, and these are the lobby groups essentially. It is a great shame that many worthwhile aid activities have had to suffer as a consequence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the areas which was not covered in the Budget was the cost to the economy of sending Royal Australian Navy (RAN) warships to the Persian Gulf-a cost of $60m over six months, according to a Department of Defence estimate, or much higher if war breaks out and missiles are fired. Presumably these costs will be added on to the defence budget, which already stands at almost $9 billion or 9.3 per cent of total Budget expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already stated my objections to the decision to send RAN warships to the Gulf and join in the United States initiated blockade there. I particularly object to the unseemly haste with which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided to send these warships without consulting more than a few of his Cabinet colleagues, and certainly not his Party, the Parliament, or the people of Australia. If we are to build a new international order, then it must be new, not just a rehash of the old order when the strong gang up on the weak and impose their will through military might. Furthermore, it would have to take into account a just distribution of resources, fair payment for commodities instead of wheeling and dealing on the futures market and commodity prices, and a genuine attempt to tackle global problems like the greenhouse effect and the ozone depletion on a global basis.

In this respect, I was impressed with some of the ideas expressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, in the address he gave to the United Nations (UN) General Assembly in New York on 2 October this year. He referred to a new era when the UN would be able to carry out a more effective role in conflict resolution and peacekeeping, and mentioned the five such operations that have been carried out over the past two years.
He also referred to Cambodia when he spoke about a foreshadowing of several others in the years ahead. At the practical level-and I quote his words he said because I think they are worth repeating:

The peacekeeping function is still handled by political, legal, financial and administrative problems. Australia advocates the need for greater efficiency and economy in peacekeeping and for the whole peacekeeping area of UN activity to be put on a firmer financial and administrative footing. I welcome the steps the Secretary-General has recently taken to improve coordination and financing of peacekeeping, but note that still more needs to be done.

I would, however, qualify my remarks about Senator Evans's speech because, while his words may have been designed to go down well with the UN community, we do not hear the same words spoken as strongly for domestic consumption. I refer also to the following comments in the same speech:
. . . the arrogance of military power remaining a scourge with which the world will still have to deal.
And his further comments:
. . . the upward spiral of arms procurement and the proliferation of increasingly more destructive weapons.
His words on the subject of arms transfers are again, I feel, worth quoting. He said:

The acquisition of conventional weapons continues at an alarming rate in many parts of the globe. Often scarce resources are diverted from social and economic development to military expenditure. Australia supports measures by all States to reduce military budgets and to the implementation of confidence building measures which will reduce the risk of conflict.

How then, may I ask, does he reconcile such praiseworthy thoughts with his membership of a government which is seeking to double our arms sales from $250m a year to $500m a year, which talks about increasing military expenditure when the economy improves and has certainly not reduced military expenditure, and which continues in membership of an offensive military alliance with a nation that has systematically ignored all Australia's proposals for confidence building measures in the Pacific, as anyone in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will privately inform us? Fine words from the Minister, but meaningless, when Cabinet slashes government spending on health, education and welfare, as well as foreign affairs, but gives the military the positive nod as usual.

Senator Evans worries about the world community finding up to $5 billion to fund the UN peacekeeping operation in Cambodia, but it is his Government which is spending $5.6 billion on six new submarines to combat threats that everyone knows do not exist and which may well favourably consider a request from the Navy to acquire a helicopter carrier for intervention somewhere in the region. As Andrew Mack from the Peace Research Centre at the Australian National University has pointed out, if the Government cut one per cent from the military budget, that would mean a 5 per cent increase for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The kinds of measures that Senator Evans proposes would mean precisely that-strengthening his Department and slashing that of Defence by taking advantage of the peace dividend.

Another aspect of our role in the Gulf that I feel strongly about concerns the double standards applied. If the issue was about self-determination and protecting sovereignty, why has the United States not acted to get Israel out of Gaza and the West Bank since 1967? Why, for that matter, has Australia not taken the same line? What about the Indonesian invasion of East Timor, which must be mentioned over and over again in this respect? The same double standards apply over the US invasion of Grenada and Panama, as well as Iraq's invasion of Iran in 1980. Again, we have our Prime Minister ordering Australia's delegation at the United Nations to reverse our vote on the US resolution to condemn the US for its invasion of Panama and to support that United States invasion instead-outrageous behaviour.

As for Iraq, Australia was on the point of selling $850,000 worth of aircraft spare parts to Saddam Hussein when the invasion of Kuwait caused the abrupt cancellation of the deal. But surely it was these same planes that dropped chemical weapons on Iraq's own population only a couple of years ago, and we did condemn that. The new international order that millions of people-global citizens or planetarians, if you like-are hoping for is centred on the strengthening of the United Nations: the use of diplomacy and negotiation to resolve conflicts instead of armed force; the sharing of world resources; tackling global problems at the global level-problems like greenhouse and ozone depletion and deforestation; and the transfer of money spent on the military to real security needs for ecologically sustainable development, particularly development programs regarding women and the poor.

Instead, what we have is the talk of a nuclear first strike against Iraq; the vilification of Saddam Hussein as another Hitler, as if he was the only bad guy in town and the logical successor to General Noriega and Colonel Gaddafi; and an uncomfortable silence about other abuses by military dictators or quasi-military regimes in places like Myanmar, China in Tibet, the Philippines, Indonesia in East Timor, Cambodia, Ethiopia and Eritrea, Guatemala and so on. It seems from the rhetoric we are hearing now from the Pentagon and Britain that the West feels that it must kill the monster it created; that it is not interested in a negotiated settlement; that it must smash Iraq's military capability even if Saddam Hussein were to agree to a withdrawal from Kuwait; and that that military capability must be completely smashed. Even if the United States is successful in doing that, it will not have solved the problem of the Middle East. Far from it; it will have created another monster which in another few years will require another military solution. It is no answer.

Those who defend the Government's interventionist position need to respond to at least three very crucial questions. One I have already raised and that concerns the selective nature of our protest and the double standards applied, particularly as far as the Arab nations are concerned. If such supporters of the Government's position believe that our role is to protest the invasion of Kuwait, can they explain why we have acquiesced in other situations that I have referred to such as Indonesia's invasion of Timor in 1975, Iraq's invasion of Iran in 1980 and US interventionism in Granada and Panama?

Secondly, I ask: Who armed Iraq? Most of the weapons Iraq acquired between 1980 and 1988 came from the Soviet Union, France and China. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, 26 countries supplied arms to both Iran and Iraq and four countries sold only to Iraq. That is a total of 30 countries which helped to create this monster. Another alarming example of arms cooperation was when Argentina, Brazil and Egypt worked with Iraq on development of the Condor missile-a team effort that was terminated last year. The logic of most of these countries exporting arms is that they need the sales to offset their balance of payments deficit and to help pay for their expensive arms imports-precisely the argument used by the Australian Government since 1988. This was when controls on our exports were slackened in order to try to double our arms exports along the lines recommended by the 1986 Cooksey report which, incidentally, was never discussed in this Parliament.

The Government will deny that its controls have been slackened; but anyone in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will tell honourable senators that they have been slackened, especially since the Mirage sale to Pakistan and the controversial sale of 76 millimetre shells to Sri Lanka, which also had to be stopped at the last moment. It was a very sloppy Department of Defence sales mechanism, I would say. If there is a disagreement between the Departments of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Defence on a particular deal, the Defence Department has the last word through the Minister or through Cabinet. That is where the balance of payments argument counts.

Australia was scrupulous enough not to peddle arms in the Iran-Iraq war but as soon as it ended, the controls were lifted and we were on the point of selling $850,000 worth of aircraft spare parts to Iraq when it blotted its copybook by invading Kuwait. I presume these parts were for planes that may well have been used for dropping chemical weapons and could be used again for that purpose. Apparently that does not matter as long as we are seen to be condemning Iraq after the crime has been committed and then, it is back to business as usual.

In other words, it is no good just abusing Saddam Hussein as another Hitler because we have to ask an uncomfortable question: Who sold him the arms? Basically, it has been our mates. Nor are we exempt from that critique. Australia was quite happy to sell military equipment along with virtually everyone else. However, mention should be made of one exemption. That is the recent decision of the new Government of Czechoslovakia to stop exporting military equipment. Czechoslovakia used to be one of the world's major dealers but it has now decided not to pursue that path despite the perilous state of its economy. I only wish that Australia had the courage to follow Czechoslovakia's example and that the Prime Minister of Australia could take a leaf out of the book of Vaclav Havel, the ex-dissident who is now the president of Czechoslovakia.

Thirdly, the role of the United Nations must be clarified. In the Gulf region at the moment it is a United States lead initiative despite resolution No. 665. I am grateful to the comments of Dr Kevin Clements from the Department of Sociology, University of Canterbury for the following analysis of the United Nations position. He states:

In relation to the current crisis there is agreement in the Security Council that Iraq has committed an act of aggression and that this requires an unconditional withdrawal on the part of Iraq and mandatory economic measures on all member states. (Article 41 has, therefore, been implemented)

Even though the second resolution of the Security Council has resulted in the application of ``appropriate measures'' to help enforce the sanctions (Article 42) we are still largely at the level of non-military enforcement procedures, economic sanctions, an embargo on trade and an accompanying blockade.

There is no UN resolution permitting the massive military build up in the Gulf nor is there any Security Council legitimation for the multinational force or for a pre-emptive or even defensive unilateral or multilateral military assault on Iraq.

The multi-national (largely US) forces on the ground in Saudi Arabia are not under the UN Military Staff Committee. It is illegitimate, therefore, to claim that they are carrying out the will of the Security Council. In fact both China and the Soviet Union while willing to agree to non-military sanctions are currently very wary of military action. It is true that informal relations between the 5 permanent members have been expanded, and the US, UK and French military staff commands are combining their resources into something approximating a de facto UN staff command or at the very least an informal ``crisis'' committee but, at the moment, they have no UN legitimation for anything other than enforcing the blockade and the Security Council would have some difficulty preventing a unilateral strike by the US if Washington wanted to proceed in this direction. (If a unilateral action occurred the Security Council could withdraw the UN legitimation that currently exists and China for example has indicated a reluctance to proceed to military action and would either abstain or exercise the veto. The Soviet Union would probably abstain, although it is not impossible that they would join the other three permanent states in a limited military action)
At the moment, therefore, all that member states have been asked to do by the Security Council is impose economic sanctions.
For military compliance procedures to come into play the following steps have to be followed:
(1) The Security Council would have to resolve to use armed force against Iraq, invoking Article 43.

(2) The current multi-national forces would have to be placed under the existing UN Military Staff Committee and a line of command agreed to between the five permanent members. (This is not terribly complex but it would have to be done for the Charter provisions to be fulfilled) . . .
(3) Member states would then be asked by the Staff Committee--
which does exist on paper but which has not been activated-

for specific kinds of military assistance and agreements would have to be negotiated. It is at this point that each state can exercise its sovereign rights to determine how and what sorts of contribution it wishes to make. The UN would not impose military requirements on a member . . .

Dr Clements also suggests that alternatives such as medical assistance would be options. It is very clear that if the United States goes ahead with a strike against Iraq, under whatever pretext, it does not have the sanction of the United Nations to do that and the military command that exists in the Gulf at the moment is largely a Unites States military command. In no way can it be construed as a United Nations command. That is why Australia should have no part in it whatsoever.

I suggest that security in a post-cold war world must now be seen to be beyond military terms. For most of the people in our region-it is worth remembering that more than half of the world's population lives in an arc stretching between Japan and Afghanistan-security can best be measured in economic terms; that is, sheer human survival.

To this I add another concern: the concern for the environment. Environmental security is far more crucial to our survival in the long term than buying submarines, helicopter carriers and frigates. I compare the tiny amount we are spending on the environment on combating soil erosion, on reafforestation, on improving public transport and, in particular, improving a national railway system, on developing alternative energy sources and so on with the amount that we spend on the military.

I would see the new international order as giving us the ability to work together with our Pacific and Indian Ocean neighbours on their concerns about greenhouse, particularly if they might even cease to exist if the industrialised countries do not get their act together on cleaning up at home first. I would be far more impressed with this cooperation rather than the 22.4 per cent increase in the defence cooperation program that I note in the defence estimates.

The only slightly positive aspect of that program is the provision of patrol boats to some South Pacific island nations which need these vessels to promote their primary resource-the fish swimming in their national waters. The patrol boats are needed to monitor the recent ban on driftnet fishing and to stop poaching of the natural resources of these small island nations. However, I am not impressed by the hidden agenda, which is the role of naval intelligence in the Pacific. It would be far more appropriate were the program to be administered under civilian aid rather than the military; that is, we should provide patrol boats but not out of the defence budget.

I am also concerned about the way in which patrol boats have been used in Papua New Guinea in its campaign against the Bougainville independence movement. There are countless opportunities for Australia to take decisive action here and overseas which would be far more likely to add to global stability than would the purchase and deployment of military equipment.

I have already mentioned greenhouse. The Government has taken considerable credit for its decision on greenhouse gas emission targets for Australia in the lead up to the current meeting of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. We still have not, however, actually committed ourselves to anything and have left wide open the possibility that if it costs this generation too much and interferes with business as usual too much, we will leave future generations to pick up an even larger problem. I do not think that is responsible at all. Why should any of the developing countries, and our closer neighbours in particular, be expected to make any sort of commitment to controlling greenhouse gas emissions from within their boundaries when a comparatively wealthy and grossly energy and resource inefficient country like Australia will not commit itself? At least in regard to limiting greenhouse gas emissions we made some sort of statement without a lead from the United States, and that was a welcome change. What a pity we did not display a similar independence rather than become involved in a military capacity in the Gulf. Any move of independence and Australia taking a separate and single minded line is a welcome one.
