Another clear example of Australia failing to take the opportunity to demonstrate real concern for and solidarity with Pacific nations came recently with the entreaty of the Prime Minister to those nations to accept a continuation of the use of the Pacific as a dumping site. I refer to Australia's stance on the chemical weapons destruction facility on Johnston Atoll.

While welcoming the move towards a global strategy to end the production and use of such weapons, I understand the anger and frustration of the South Pacific people who, through lack of political power, will bear the cost of any mishap or technical failure during the four-year disposal program. Neither is there any guarantee that JACAD's life will be terminated on schedule as promised. It is another case of everybody in the region having to trust the American Government, and it has not got a very good record of keeping to its word on these matters.

The overseas development assistance program has been improved by the inclusion this year of environmental assessment measures aimed at encouraging sustainable development in recipient countries. The concept is admirable, but the level of expenditure is paltry compared with the Defence estimates to which I have already referred. Similarly, although increased in some areas, the level of expenditure on environmental programs within Australia is overshadowed by the enormous defence budget. Evidence of the Government's commitment to the protection of our natural resources is, at best, sporadic. Sustainable development has become a popular phrase but several recent decisions have left serious doubts as to how well the concept of ecological sustainability is understood. Thus we have the situation in which a major decision on the commitment of the south-eastern forests to logging was made before the Government's own tribunal-the Resource Assessment Commission-completed its task and before the Government's working group on sustainable development for the forest industry could even be convened. Talk about putting the cart before the horse!

At the same time, pressure is being applied to erode significantly the power of the Australian Heritage Commission and reduce the protection of our National Estate in the name of resource security. It seems that there are those who still refuse to recognise that sustainable development and, indeed, resource security rely on our having the foresight and intelligence to conserve our natural capital in all its diversity. The importance of conservation of our natural capital cannot be overestimated. Resources which have become increasingly less secure over the past 200 years are soil and water. The entire community has gradually accepted its responsibility for this situation and a willingness to work towards solutions. The allocation of $22.3m for soil conservation, however, also pales into insignificance when compared to Defence estimates. It is interesting that in the previous debate on soil matters the Opposition was keen to get more money out of the Government for soil conservation, with which I would agree, but it probably would not agree with me that it could come from the Defence budget.

Australia would not be in the Gulf right now if it were not for the vulnerability of Western nations to Middle Eastern oil reserves. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change would not be meeting right now if it were not for the dependence on those same oil reserves and other fossil fuels. Australia seemed at one time to be capable of providing the lead to other countries in the development of a solar power industry. Projects at Rottnest Island and Esperance in Western Australia have indicated the scope for the generation of wind power. The technology is there, all set and ready to go, but it needs some encouragement from the Government and the private sector.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and various organisations and individuals funded under, for example, the national energy research, development and demonstration program have shown the enormous possibilities for improving energy efficiency and developing alternative sources. The $17.7m allocated for energy research and conservation does not reflect the importance of these developments in improving both our environmental and economic performance. Nor does it indicate that as yet the Government is seriously considering any major move away from reliance on the burning of fossil fuels.

Last week saw an indication that the States and the Commonwealth may finally look at improving Australia's rail freight system by making it a national system. The reallocation of funds from submarines to land transport and, in particular, the improvement of rail freight and urban public transport systems would help considerably to reduce the transport contribution to greenhouse emissions. If the Government wishes its environmental credentials to be taken seriously, there must be an indication that we are willing to look at all our institutions and question their place in an ecologically sustainable future. Spending a large percentage of the country's budget on hugely expensive weapons with questionable defence value should be challenged in the light of the global move towards an ecologically sustainable future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every Budget time, ordinary Australians agonise over the tax they have to pay and they marvel at how so much money could be spent, in their view so unwisely, by politicians and bureaucrats in far away Canberra. I acknowledge that it is very easy for those of us who live so far away from the national capital not to understand the real expenditure that takes place and to overlook the many essential things that flow from the tax gathering and appropriation of moneys for expenditure by the various government departments. But when one's average take home pay after tax is in the range of $15,000 to $20,000, which for a vast majority of Australians it is, and when one is struggling to pay off a mortgage, some car payments, and school fees, it is difficult to understand all of the expenditures and the billions of dollars that are spent. There is a suspicion in many parts of Australia that moneys are spent unwisely. Unemployment benefit is one expenditure which attracts suspicion from those who toil for very long hours at low pay simply to maintain the dignity of employment, to pay off homes and mortgages and pay for the basic requisites for their kids attending schools and clubs and sporting fixtures.

SPEECH.PARA: In country towns in particular, the rorts of the unemployment system are well known as the knowledge seems to get around much easier. In many cases, people do not work when they are able to and when jobs are available because they find it financially more beneficial to stay on the unemployment benefit than to get a job. There are many instances that I am aware of when people have started work and found that what they are receiving from a regular job is not what they were receiving from the unemployment benefit with all the supplements that go on to it-they have a few kids-and so they have given up work and gone back on the dole. They receive more cash from the dole than they would if they were working for a living.

Of course, the Government has to put some incentive back into working and it is this incentive that will be provided by the Liberal and National parties' program for a complete reform of the taxation system and the other micro-economic reforms that are proposed. The Opposition's radical new proposal for a goods and services tax will give incentive for people to work because personal income tax rates will be lessened. This will mean that those who want to work extra hours at weekends or at night to get ahead, to get a bit more money to pay for a holiday or to pay off a mortgage quicker will be encouraged to do so. They will not be discouraged by the regressive tax scales that we have at the present time. A goods and services tax will tax spending and not earnings. Under the present system, earnings are penalised. If one wants to go out and earn a few more bob, one is penalised and taxed enormously for it. Under the new system what one spends is taxed, giving one, to a certain degree, a choice of how much tax one pays.

The unemployment allocations for this year have increased by 31.7 per cent over the actuals for 1989-90 to a staggering figure of $4 billion. I suggest that the amount allocated by the Government for unemployment benefit will prove to be totally inadequate as more and more businesses go to the wall, as job vacancies continue to fall and as unemployment queues grow longer and longer each year.

Against a background of severe economic recession, which at last the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is able to try to enunciate, and also at a time of severe rural crisis' which Senator Richardson and other senators acknowledged in the Senate today-an acknowledgment that the Chairman of the Prime Minister's Country Task Force, Mr Courtice, can still not bring himself to admit-we have the situation where ordinary, average Australians feel some real depression at the rorts that go on in the expenditure of their hard won money. They are horrified that for them almost a year's salary is spent in a three- or four-hour plane trip for a Government member to open a dog show that had closed down by the time he arrived. People who earn a take-home pay of about $15,000 in a year simply cannot comprehend how a Government member could spend this much on a four-hour trip in what can only be seen as an attempt to gather a few-I might say a very few-votes out of the exercise.

People on average incomes read every day of the continuing Inquiry into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and cannot believe that $11m has been paid to lawyers and bureaucrats in funding just one part of the inquiry-and that is not the total cost. Again, people cannot comprehend how this Government could spend some $16m on war crimes prosecutions to prosecute one 80-year-old man. The whole system seems to be wrong in their minds and they find it incredible and almost impossible to understand that people could waste this sort of money with so little result. They also wonder when $68,000 is spent to rent indoor plants for offices of the Department of Social Security each year-offices which generally in rural Australia hand out the dole cheques and attempt to get jobs for people. These pleasantries for the workers are all very good, but in these tough economic times that we have at the moment many people who frequent those offices may well think that better use could be made of that $68,000.

Also we heard the other day that in the social security area $1.7m was overpaid to a supplier of computer software. Still in the social security area, $3,953,000 was spent on four issues of a self-promoting magazine by the Department called Aged Pension News, which I know from my own experience and from direct experience of others close to me very few pensioners read.

I receive many calls in my electorate office from people who read in the papers that the Government has provided $30,000 to send a delegation of Aboriginals overseas to recover the bones of Aboriginals from European museums. Those people recoil when the suggestion is made that in the next three to four years another $4m will be required to recover those remains. When it is reported that one of those groups that visited London to recover bones on subsidised money provided by the taxpayer-which group included Michael Mansel-then hired another hotel room in London simply to store the bones in, people cannot accept that this is a wise use of taxpayers' money. For heaven's sake, we spend millions of dollars to fund embassies and high commissions in foreign lands and if there is merit in recovering the bones-and I do not enter into that argument-then surely our very well paid and well funded foreign affairs officers could do the work without sending people from Australia on junkets overseas at taxpayers' expense to do what our officials and clerks in the high commissions and embassies could well do, and I suggest do much better.

The rudest example of all which fills hard-working taxpayers with anguish occurs when they read articles such as one that was given to me by a constituent. This constituent said to me, `Why am I paying taxes for this sort of rort?'. This is the article that the constituent gave me:
A plastic toy penis has taken centre stage in a compensation row involving two Federal public servants in Adelaide.
Mr X has been paid full sickness benefits worth more than $45,000 after winning compensation from the Commonwealth's compensation body . . .

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been told that the couple were working in Adelaide when a colleague placed a toy on her desk next to Mr X. He then complained to the sexual harassment officer and said his wife, who worked close by, was also offended by the toy.

The tribunal was told Mrs X had received $14,500 worth of rehabilitation benefits over the past 19 months, including almost $1,000 for gym membership. Comcare had also paid her fees for TAFE courses in house decoration, psychological counselling and travel expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —At that price you could put one next to me any time you like.

—That is exactly it, Minister. What an absolute rort. People are paying money for that sort of thing. In fact, an elector wrote to the Townsville Bulletin and said in relation to that article-and I use just a few excerpts:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I feel I must express my views on the flagrant misuse of taxpayers' hard-earned money in this case.
What right has a bunch of obvious incompetents to pay out $59,500 of this money in such a cavalier fashion to a pair of opportunists? . . .

Admittedly, it was a vulgar prank and one may well have been offended but the immediate reaction would have been to hurl the toy and the prankster or to treat him with disdain-but 19 months of the vapours at the taxpayers expense? Come on!

If these people are so unable to handle everyday situations that they need psychological counselling and coddling by footing the bill for TAFE courses and gym lessons, they were clearly unfit to be holding down the position which they occupied.
They are sickened-what a laugh.
Well, I am sickened too by the thought that the money we work hard for can be handed over with so little reason to a pair of wimps with an eye to the main chance.
Further, may I quote another letter on the same subject to a South Australian paper about the incident:

The whole exercise could cost the taxpayers $500,000 before it is finished what with legal fees, judges, court rooms and wages. I feel stressed after reading the article but I am now thinking of suing someone myself. And if you were to show me a photo of Bob Hawke or Paul Keating, then I'm sure I really would go around the bend with stress and trauma. I have become so confused with the values of our society when the Federal Government so willingly gives our money away over such issues, while former servicemen are dying while still fighting for compensation for war-caused injuries. How much longer can we, the public, put up with these actions from our public servants?
That is typical of the reaction that the taxpayers out in ordinary Australia have when they see those sorts of rorts.

A sum of $1.1m has been provided from taxpayers' funds to 51 conservation groups to assist them-and they are supposedly voluntary conservation groups but still get $1.1m-in the task of raising public awareness of environmental issues, as part of an education process supposedly. What about the education for those who are currently unable to get Austudy because although they are asset rich they are income poor? Of course it is the income that pays the school bills. A sum of $256,000 has been given to conservation groups making submissions into forestry and Kakadu. These are just a few of the monies that are allocated and appropriated from tax collection-and the list goes on and on.

Most of the expenditure that is paid out through governments is of a sensible and necessary nature, but much of it appears to be incomprehensible, particularly when one considers the expenditures I have just been talking about and then considers the town of Ravenshoe. In the small town of Ravenshoe the world is about to collapse for many families. They are about to lose their livelihoods, their homes, their lifestyles, their savings and their life's work. Their children are about to have to leave their school and school friends because they have to shift to foreign towns as their parents become bankrupt, bolstering the bankruptcy statistics and increasing the unemployment pile. The unemployment allocation this year will have to increase for the people in Ravenshoe who are about to become a statistic in the dole queue. They are in this position not because they spent their money on psychiatric help because someone harassed them or said something rude to them. They are not in this position because they did not want to work. They are not in this position because they have taken trips to recover ancestral remains, because they have wasted their money on visiting dog shows in far away places, because they have spent large amounts of money on expensive lawyers and consultants to prepare submissions into an inquiry on their timber mill closure or because they have spent too much money on pot plants in their workshops and homes. They are in this position simply because they trusted the Government. They believed Senator Richardson when he said that no person would be adversely affected by World Heritage listing.

In Ravenshoe, 22 family businesses are owed almost $300,000 by Associated Plywoods Sales Pty Ltd and another $56,000 by an associated company also in receivership. In other parts of north Queensland other small businessmen are owed about the same amount by the same companies. Of the 22 family businesses owed money in Ravenshoe, 12 are owed over $10,000 and two of those are owed over $50,000. These are small businesses with cash flows often not exceeding $100,000 and they simply cannot sustain losses to this extent. If those 12 businesses fail, it means 12 fewer families in the district along with the families of the people they used to employ. A flow-on effect cripples other businesses in the town. It causes reductions in school numbers, which leads to fewer teachers and public servants in the town and less government money going to the town. There is a roller-coaster effect.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may ask what this has to do with the Government. The Government says that these businesses which lent money to this mill which has gone bankrupt did so unwisely. It says they gave credit to a trading company, that it was a bad business decision and that is just bad luck. You might ask why, in those circumstances, the Government should bail out these people. If it does bail out these people, why should it not bail out every other bankrupt small business in Australia as well? Of course, in view of the current number of bankruptcies, if the Government bailed out every bankrupt business it would break the country, even more than is the case now.

I ask honourable senators and Ministers to put themselves in this position: you are running a small business in a small country town where trust and simple honesty are the normal business ethics. It is a town which owes its existence to a major factory-in this instance a timber mill-which gives employment to labourers, contractors, office workers, farmers, loggers, highwaymen and gardeners. In fact, the whole community revolves around this business enterprise. And remember, you are in small business; you are running a business in this town. Your business has only a small turnover-less than $100,000-with a net profit of less than $30,000 a year. That is what many small businessmen in Australia work for. They work all hours, all year, for less than $30,000 a year.

The Government then takes an action which has the effect of ruining the major enterprise in your town. But, after a spontaneous and quite unexpected outcry, which received worldwide publicity, the Government sends up a junior Minister who, because feelings are running so high, is set upon. The Government then realises it has made a mistake and does something to put things right. With all the media it and its highly paid consultants can muster, the Government then announces with a fanfare that no-one will be adversely affected as a result of World Heritage listing. On the front page of every newspaper and on the screen of every television set in the nation the Government promises $75m of compensation and, in particular, $13m for a major enterprise to save this mill and to save this town.

You are in this town. Your town is assured, under the glare of the television lights, that it has been saved; the mill will continue; the Government will provide $13m over 10 years. In your small business, knowing that the Government is propping up the mill over the next 10 years, would you not feel commercially secure in giving credit in relatively small amounts on normal 30-day trading terms? Why would you hesitate? Your business relies on the mill. The mill has been guaranteed for the next 10 years. Of course you would extend credit on normal terms. On the front page of every newspaper the Government has told you and everybody else in Australia that your town has been saved and that $13m of assistance will be provided over the next 10 years. You would not hesitate to offer normal trading credits. After all, if the Government is giving grants and loans of taxpayers' hard earned money, it would surely monitor the grants. It would check them regularly and thoroughly.

However, this was not done. But how could a small businessman, used to dealing with trust and in trust, and with honesty and in honesty, possibly have any inkling that anything was amiss with this company? And so in trust and honesty, they gave credit. Now, for doing that, they suffer incredibly. I ask the Government to make a once-off ex gratia payment to those who innocently and in good faith advanced money to a company they quite reasonably believed was being financially supervised by the government of the day.

In considering the Appropriation Bills I ask the Government again to allocate a minuscule amount of $500,000 out of the Appropriations of some $38 billion. All I ask for is $500,000 out of the Appropriations of $38 billion or more. If the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that this has not been provided for in the Budget Papers, that there is nowhere he can get that money from to assist these 12 families whose livelihood depends on this, I suggest to him that there is a simple way to obtain that money. Some of the $4 billion that is allocated for unemployment could be used. If $500,000 of that $4 billion allocated in the Appropriations for unemployment was used, it would represent about only 0.001 per cent. It is a realistic allocation because, if it is not paid to these people, their businesses will close, they will go on the dole queue and they will probably get the money from the unemployment benefit.

Another way that the Treasurer could find the money to save these 12 families would be to ask Mr Snowdon to take just 20 fewer trips. Twenty fewer VIP flights would save the livelihood of those 12 families. Another suggestion would be to take just a fraction off the $16m that is going to be spent prosecuting one person and allocate that to saving 12 families. Nobody ever wants to justify or take away from the horror of the holocaust some 40 or 50 years ago, but in this day and age could not some of that money spent prosecuting just one person be reallocated to save 12 families?

Another suggestion might be for the Department of Social Security and a few other government departments to give up putting pot plants in their offices. If they could do that, enough money could be collected to save these 12 small families. If the Government cut out just one edition of the Aged Pension News, it would save more than twice the amount needed to save these people. If we got the Australian Embassy and their staffs overseas to collect the bones of the Aboriginal ancestors, plenty of money would be saved to look after these 12 families. If we could get off the payroll people such as those in Adelaide, who I suggest are rorting the system-and there are many others like them-the savings from that little step alone would be sufficient. I hope the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) passes on the message to the Government to give these people in Ravenshoe the money that they have lost through trusting the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —No chance.
—Why is there no chance?
—No chance of finding the time to pass on what you suggest to the Government.
—Is that because the Government wants to go home at half past ten? What an absolutely ridiculous statement.
—I will pass it on.

—I thank the Minister. I also ask him to suggest-I am trying to be helpful about where the money could be allocated from-that the Australian Conservation Foundation give up its privileged grants, which it gets as a voluntary organisation for raising issues. I am sure that the people at the Australian Conservation Foundation, who are so caring and sensitive of Australia's inanimate resources, could easily be charitable and compassionate to save Australia's most valuable resource; that is, its people and its families.

SPEECH.PARA: There is scope for the Government to make this one-off ex gratia payment out of this year's appropriations. It only has to allocate some of the money that it allocates to all those other ridiculous things. I again ask the Government to do this. Senator Richardson could become the hero of Ravenshoe rather than the villain that he now is. Senator Collins, a Minister from the Northern Territory, could put some reality and substance into his image as the Minister caring for northern Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I think there is plenty of substance in my image now.
—There is substance in his build; I do not know about his image. I am sure--
—I was trying to be subtle.

—I am not a very subtle man. The Minister wastes his subtlety on me. He will quickly learn that, so he should not bother in the future. I am a simple and straightforward man. His Darwin subtlety is just too much for me. Everybody likes the Minister; they say what great speeches he makes. But the substance is not there. Here is his chance. It is just a little thing-500,000 measly little dollars out of $38 billion, and he could make himself the hero of Ravenshoe as well. He could really put some substance into his image as a Minister from the Northern Territory. I urge him to do this, not because he wants to have that gratification, and not because Senator Richardson wants to become the hero, but simply to save the livelihood of 12 very real hard working and very distressed Australian families, who are in this position through no fault of their own, except that they trusted the Government. It is not too late. It can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend to the Government the matters I have been talking about. I hope that it can again take the plight of these people to Cabinet to see whether that small allocation can be made out of these otherwise enormous Appropriation Bills to save those families in Ravenshoe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak after my colleague Senator Macdonald from Queensland. He has indeed focused the Senate's attention upon the impact that the Commonwealth Government has had upon the lives of individuals. He has focused upon the lives of 12 families. The debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91 and cognate Bills is a good place to start talking about the impact of government spending as a whole on the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I will briefly talk about the broader issues of the intrusiveness of government spending and the way it has increased so dramatically since Federation only 90 years ago. I will then concentrate on a more micro-economic matter; that is, the Australian Securities Commission and the haste with which this Government and particularly the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) seem to want to get this new body off the ground.

Since Australia's Federation the size of government has increased to a level where it has become all-pervading, intrusive and too powerful. Having said all that, by its very size it has become the most obvious, indeed odious, millstone hanging so heavily around the neck of this great nation. I took the liberty of getting some figures from the research service of the Parliamentary Library on what has happened to Commonwealth government outlays since about 1909-10. The figures have been adjusted for inflation, which, as we all know, has raced very rapidly over those years. In the early years of this century, the Commonwealth outlays, adjusted for inflation, amounted to 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). The per capita amount-that is, per head of Australia-was $159.98. It would not surprise honourable senators in this chamber that by 1989-90 those figures had leapt up alarmingly into the high 20s as far as the percentage of GDP is concerned and up to $5,127.70 per capita. That is only Commonwealth outlays; it does not take into account States and local governments.

If one focuses upon the growth of government expenditure as a proportion of Australia's national production in just the past 20 years one sees that in 1968-69 Commonwealth only government expenditure was 29.9 per cent of gross domestic product. Here we are today, 20 years on, and the figure is about 37.2 per cent-a rise of some $13.7 billion in the past 20 years. When some poor fellow reads about those sorts of macro-economic figures in the newspapers or hears about them on the evening news they mean very little. What Senator Macdonald was referring to earlier-the impact on individual Australians-is far more important.

I guess the figures of the macro-economy, the percentages, the multi-billion dollar Budget gross domestic product figures and the figures on Commonwealth outlays are of interest to students, economists and academics, but I want to look at the impact on individual Australians. Clearly, the more the Australian Government spends the more it affects each Australian. It is fair to say that over the 20 years we have seen that massive increase in government expenditure, 10 of those years were under the control of Liberal governments and 10 were under Labor. So it is not something we can blame on the Labor socialists; it has happened over a period of time under both conservative and socialist governments controlling this nation.

The impact on individuals is important. As I have said, the more the Australian Government spends, the more it affects each Australian. How does it affect them? The more the spending levels increase at a greater rate than Australia's national production, the larger the impact on the lives of individuals. The more the Government spends, the more discretion that bureaucrats, politicians, members of boards and members of quasi-government national bodies have over people spending and the less freedom individuals have to choose how to spend, save and invest their money for their future and collectively as a nation.

There is a quotation that I wanted to refer to which talks about the impact of greater and greater government control and greater and greater government spending upon the lives of individuals. It is by Professor Robert A. Nisbet, who was the Albert Schweitzer Professor of Humanities Fellow at Columbia University. In a 1975 essay entitled `The New Despotism' he states:

What has in fact happened during the past half century is that the bulk of power in our society, as it affects our intellectual, economic, social and cultural existences, has become largely invisible. And the reason this power is so commonly invisible to the eye is that it lies concealed under the humane purposes that have brought it into existence . . .
He continues:

Congresses and legislatures pass laws, executives enforce them and the courts interpret them. These . . . are the visible organs of government to this day, the objects of constant reporting in the media. And I would not question the capacity of each of them to interfere substantially with individual freedom. But of far greater importance in the realm of freedom is that invisible government created in the first instance by legislature and executive but rendered in due time largely autonomous [and] often nearly impervious to the will of elected constitutional bodies. In ways too numerous even to try to list, the invisible government-composed of commissions, bureaus and regulatory agencies of every imaginable kind-enters daily into . . . the minor details of life.

I think that indicates a phenomenon which became quite clear to me as a member of Estimates Committees for the very first time, being very aware of the size of this national government but in the Estimates Committee process being exposed to the minute detail of how government runs itself and seeing the enormous number of programs, boards, government departments and bodies that seem to interfere with the lives of so many.

I guess that the Estimates Committee process is one way in which this Parliament, and we as a Senate, can try to make this expenditure more accountable to the people of Australia. I attended a seminar last week which was organised by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We looked at how effective our Committee processes were at making this expenditure more accountable.

We have to ask all of those government departments and all of the individual programs how effective they are; do they achieve their objectives; what performance criteria do they have; what sort of return on capital do they have? Of course, as a parliament, as Estimates Committees and as senators, we have a lot of trouble doing that because it is very hard, when dealing with government bodies, to have any way of comparing their performance with the performance of like bodies in the private sector. The vagueness of the answers which I received to many of my questions when asking public servants and members of the Government how they assess their performance was of great concern to me. I guess that it is very hard for those hard-working public servants to find the right performance criteria. Sometimes one would ask a public servant, `You spent $10m last year. What did you achieve with that $10m?', and the answer would be vague and non-specific. Then one would ask, `Why do you spend another 5 per cent, 8, 10, 15 or 100 per cent more next year if you don't know whether you have achieved anything last year?', and the answer would be equally vague. That is a matter of great concern to me as a senator and I think the Senate needs to work to make the Public Service and the Government more accountable for the way in which they spend the hard-earned dollars of the taxpayers of Australia.

I want to move to a micro-economic issue. This matter was brought to my attention during the Estimates process, and it relates to the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission. I asked a series of questions, along similar lines to those I have mentioned, about the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission. This is a body that has been established to better the corporate regulatory environment in Australia and to achieve a change, I guess as the Attorney-General would say, in the problems that Australia has had with its reputation, as far as corporate affairs is concerned, in the decade of the 1980s. This Government is centralising all control over corporate affairs under the control of the Attorney-General's Department and under the specific auspices of the Australian Securities Commission.

I am particularly concerned about the ability of the Attorney-General and the Australian Securities Commission to be up and running by 1 January 1991 start-up date which the Attorney-General and the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, have indicated that they will have. I asked a series of questions about the number of staff they had recruited, how they had trained those staff to take up their duties on 1 January, whether the legislation which needs to go through the State parliaments to refer power to the Commonwealth had been introduced and whether that legislation had been seen. I received vague answers once again, and I will be pursuing that matter further in the Committee stages of these Appropriation Bills.

I was assured at these Estimates Committee meetings that, `We will all be ready on January first' and that `We've got no problems and we'll have a good corporate affairs regulatory environment. The Australian Securities Commission will take it all over-so don't you worry about that.'. The facts of the matter are that in my home city of Perth in Western Australia the Australian Securities Commission has leased 4 1/2 thousand square metres of office space, or thereabouts, and that is about all that has happened. The legislation has not been seen in State Parliament and it has only about 12 days left to sit. So this complicated legislation-the referral of powers legislation-needs to be passed through a State Parliament and none of the State parliamentarians has yet seen the legislation; I doubt that it has even been drafted. In fact, I believe this very evening in the other place a wad of legislation about the size of a telephone book is being introduced and I guess that we will be asked to rush that through this place.

The situation in Perth now, when we are told by the Attorney-General that we will have this new corporate affairs structure set up by 1 January, is that an acre of space is set aside in the middle of Perth and, basically, there is a requirement to fit that office space out and to have the Commission up and running before 1 January. The best estimates that one could possibly get from an interior design fit-out consultant or a builder is that it would take until at least March, April or May next year to fit out that sort of space. I am not sure where these people will be put because the Australian Securities Commission, at this stage, has not yet approached one single person in the Corporate Affairs Commission in Perth with an offer of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will it start?

—One January is the date that it is to start. This will all be done in the 35 working days between now and Christmas. It has no staff and it has recruited no external staff to staff these offices; so I do not know who will fill up this acre of plush office accommodation in the middle of Perth. Obviously, the staff have not been trained to use the new powerful computer systems which will provide this great service to the people of Western Australia under the new Australian Securities Commission. It is relying on a new eight digit companies' number for the identification of 800,000 companies around Australia. In Western Australia very few people know about this companies' number and very few people know where they are required to print it. They are required to print it on letterheads, stationery, invoices, statements and cheque butts, but no-one knows about it. So we have this great new Australian Securities Commission which is being set up on 1 January; it has an office but it has no partitions and no staff who know how to use the computers and so I doubt sincerely whether we will have this great new companies and corporate affairs regulatory environment in place by 1 January. I call on the Attorney-General to reconsider his headlong rush to set up this body by 1 January.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that this is only one example of the inefficiency that I exposed during the Estimates Committee hearings and obviously during the Committee stages of the Appropriations legislation we will go into far more detail. The important thing to realise about this is that the Attorney-General has blamed all of the so-called `corporate cowboys' of the 1980s for the problems of corporate Australia and the image we lack now. What he is doing, I think, is reminiscent of the actions of a lot of those so-called corporate cowboys in rushing, like a bull at a gate, to get his new Australian Securities Commission set up. I think it would be in the best interests of Australia's corporate image if we were to delay it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring up briefly tonight a quest by Mrs Sonia Turkington of Como in Western Australia. Probably no-one in this chamber has heard of her but the fiftieth anniversary of the mass internment of Italians during World War II occurs this year. Mrs Sonia Turkington, herself the daughter of one of those interned Italians, started this move by writing to the Premier of Western Australia, various Federal Ministers as well as to me.

SPEECH.PARA: The case of those Italian internees was quite sad. At the time they were rounded up with no notice and treated like criminals. Those Italians were not subversive, but hard working people mostly living in tents or makeshift quarters. It was slightly different in Victoria because of the intervention of Archbishop Mannix at the time who spoke to the Federal Government and prevented such an event happening there.
These people were working hard and mostly in remote areas of the pastoral regions, the goldfields and the agricultural areas to establish themselves in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many in sugar.

—Probably some in sugar as well, but in this case I am putting the point of view of Western Australia. Of course, if the case fits Queensland, Victoria, South Australia or anywhere else, I will include them too.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt whether they were subversive or a danger to Australian security. Some were single but some were married with young children and their wives were left to their own resources with no help except, I presume, that from relatives and friends who took pity on them.

I am old enough to remember the case in my own home town where rounded-up men were paraded around the streets, as each individual was picked up, and out into the outlying areas as if they were criminals. They were paraded and humiliated. Then they were locked up in one of the local disused halls with nothing but a heap of hay thrown in the middle to sleep on. Even our worst criminals are spared this humiliation. This was inflicted on innocent, hard working men who had no knowledge of, or care for, the war half-way around the world.

Also, what senators must remember is that most of these people came from remote mountainous, agricultural regions in Italy. Because of overcrowding and no ability to get a job there where there was no industry, they migrated to different parts of the world. I personally remember the taunts and physical assaults we, as children of these people, had to contend with at school. I remember the discrimination we received from a few teachers and public servants although, amongst them, there were some kind and caring ones.

Then there were the malicious allegations made to the authorities against naturalised Italians not interned to get them locked up as well. Some succeeded in getting those people locked up. They succeeded by the use of malicious rumours and accusations, and those Italians spent the rest of the war interned.

Unfortunately, those allegations are on the public record now that the secret war files are open to everyone. I have looked at only one case where allegations were made against a person and we all know them to be totally untrue, yet they are there on the public record for his children, his children's children and, probably, his children's children's children to look at for all time.

In this age when Australia tries to portray itself to the rest of the world as still a land of opportunity, non-discrimination and equal opportunity the time has come to officially recognise and apologise for the injustices to those people who are still living and the families of those who are not.

I urge the Government, and Government Ministers in this place, to view Mrs Turkington's request-as I said, she is the child of an internee-and to see what she is asking for, and hopefully the Government can see the reasons for granting her what she is asking. The Premier of New South Wales has already done that just in New South Wales. He has, on behalf of the people of New South Wales, taken it on himself to do just that. I believe that this Parliament should look at the idea of following Mr Greiner's lead for all of those involved around Australia. I wish Mrs Turkington every success in her endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am moved by Senator Panizza's speech to very briefly speak to what he has said and associate myself with the sentiments that he has expressed and the call that he has made. I do this because I come from a town which has a very large Italian population, and did in the war years. The examples that Senator Panizza has mentioned today were related to me by my senior partner in my law firm, who was around in the war days. He often related to me how some of the very best citizens of our town then-they are still around and are still the best citizens-were treated in the way that Senator Panizza mentioned. It is a very sad indictment on what we did in those days. I suppose in those days it was done with the right motivation but very wrongly. I am moved by what Senator Panizza says and I want to associate myself with the sentiments he has expressed. These people were very good people then and they are now. I urge the Government to take notice and take heed of the call made by Senator Panizza and look into the action he requests.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks this evening with respect to the operation of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA), and in particular in relation to some remarks that have been made about that Committee and members of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we face some extraordinarily serious circumstances in respect of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. We face a situation where, in my view, Government members, individually and together, are engaging in an unwarranted and unjustified series of attacks on coalition members of that Committee. Why are they doing so? Is it in order to divert attention from the very substantial issues that need to be addressed? Is it to so taint the Committee's proceedings with acrimony and vitriol that it is rendered ineffective? I do not know.

Further, we face the situation where the Committee is being run, in my view, like the Marrickville Branch of the Australian Labor Party. When we look at the situation we see that it is a very ugly picture: Government members engaging, as I say, in unwarranted and unjustified personal attacks on members of the Committee and a Committee that is being disrupted by being run like a New South Wales Labor Party faction. There are ways to run some meetings and ways to run others and that is not the way to run this particular Committee.

The situation gets much uglier. When we realise that much of what is being said is simply untrue, the picture becomes a very ugly one. We know that today a member of the Committee went into the House of House of Representatives and effectively misled the House. We know that by his own admission. He said in part, referring to Mr Justice Phillips, the new Chairman of the National Crime Authority, and some remarks that Mr Justice Phillips had made at his first meeting with the Committee:

He said . . . He had seen the difficulties about the disclosure of sensitive information and the fact that politicians seem to want to rush into the Parliament and blab information through these processes.
Mr O'Keefe drew further conclusions, and said:

Having reached that point, how do we get to a stage when last week Justice Phillips had to say informally to the Committee that he did not see any way that the NCA could deal with the Committee other than on the transcript and totally publicly?

Mr Justice Phillips, or the National Crime Authority, issued a press statement today which occasioned Mr O'Keefe immediately to go into the chamber and withdraw. I congratulate him for doing so-not that he had much choice. Mr Justice Phillips's statement included the following:

At my first meeting with the Parliamentary Joint Committee, I told them that I believed we could come to an accommodation whereby they received all the information that they needed, and that no members of the Authority would be embarrassed in answering questions about operational matters.

Let me interpose here that I have refreshed my memory with respect to that hearing, and it is not my view that Mr Justice Phillips, in saying what he did, was misrepresenting the situation. It is not my view that he told the Committee he was aware of members running into the House and blabbing information at all. But more importantly, other people-not only Mr O'Keefe-have suggested that the NCA is now concerned about whether it can trust this Committee. Mr Justice Phillips felt obliged-obviously, otherwise he would not have done it-to go on in his statement today to say:
I still maintain that belief-
that is, that the Committee can work with the NCA-
and have never indicated any qualification or change of it to the Committee.

There is a very sad series of circumstances in which Government members of the Committee have been portraying the situation that as a consequence of some honourable senators making a dissenting report to one of the Committee's reports, the NCA could no longer trust the Committee. They are very damaging statements to be making-damaging to the Committee-so much so that the Chair of the National Crime Authority has felt obliged to make his position clear.

I would be interested if the Chairman of the Committee would now explain in the other place why it is that he is reported, as I think I mentioned last night or the previous night, as having said that he knew that the NCA was concerned about the use of in camera evidence in that qualifying statement. I would appreciate it if the Chairman of the Committee would tell the House whether the journalist made a mistake, shall we say, or whether the journalist lied-though I am not of the view that that is the situation. I would appreciate the Chairman of the Committee, now that we have Mr Justice Phillips's statement that he still maintains that belief and he has never indicated any qualification of it, explaining to the House his position and I will be more than pleased to entertain in the most calm and rational manner any explanation he wishes to put as to why it is that the paper in my State has reported him as saying that he knows of the NCA's concern about that matter.

Unfortunately Mr O'Keefe, who acknowledged that he had in effect misled the House today, went on to say a few other things which he has not withdrawn. Specifically he has said, firstly, that he moved the motion that this particular report be tabled. He did not do that, nor did he move the motion at the previous meeting that the report be made. The minutes of the meeting make this clear. I do not put much emphasis on that; it could have been a simple mistake on his part. It is not important who did or who did not move it. I mention it only because Mr O'Keefe thinks it is important to mention that he did, when in fact he did not.

He further said that he had provided the vehicle-that is, agreed that a report be made to this chamber-only on the basis that the dissent related only to procedural matters and that specifically it would not include any in camera evidence. He further said that the coalition members had agreed to this, and that is a very serious allegation for him to be making. I want to make it unequivocally clear to this chamber that no discussion as to the content of a qualifying statement took place and, further, that the use of in camera evidence was never raised at that meeting. Nor was it raised with me prior to the release of the report outside the meeting or in its environs. I am not trying to use any trick words to make my point.

I have asked, as is my right, for a typed version of the secretary's notes of that meeting. I believe they will confirm what I have said. I have looked at the minutes of that meeting. They are clear minutes and show that no such discussion or agreement took place. I ask Mr O'Keefe to withdraw those remarks. They are manifestly untrue. There is not a single shred of evidence, there is not a statement that anyone made at that Committee meeting, that could lead him to make those remarks, and I ask that he withdraw them.

Let me now turn to the use of in camera evidence. I ask myself what it is that the Government is so sensitive about. In that dissenting report, or qualifying statement, there is not one scintilla of evidence revealed which could not have been asked and should not have been answered at public hearings by the NCA Committee. Let the Government members who are so upset about the release of that evidence point out what evidence they say should not have been revealed to the Parliament. Let them point out where they say an error of judgment has been made. I am happy to entertain a debate on that basis, and happy to apologise to the House if a case can be satisfied for that information not being revealed. But I do not believe such a case can be made.

Senator Loosley praised the Chairman last night by saying that he refuses to preside over a committee which rushes to judgment, or words to that effect. Yet the Chairman will preside over a committee that can take hours of evidence on two separate occasions and will force a vote on that evidence before the Hansard's of either of those days of evidence are available for honourable senators who wish to reflect on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens in this chamber all the time.

—It may happen in this chamber but the point I am making is that in a committee that is dealing with sensitive matters-and on this occasion it was the most sensitive sort of matter that could have been dealt with-it is appropriate for honourable senators to be able to cast their vote having given very serious consideration to the evidence before them. I do not dispute that some would already have made up their mind. I say good luck to those who can quickly recall evidence from a few weeks before and be satisfied in their minds as to the weight they should give that evidence and compare it to the evidence they have heard on another day and then make up their mind. That is their right and privilege. I maintain it is not their right and privilege to expect other honourable senators to do the same when they want to reflect on these serious matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that some Government members voted on this particular matter that Senator Loosley was referring to without having been at the first day's hearings and, as the Hansard of that day was not available, without having read what had happened. They felt, despite that lack of availability of evidence, satisfied enough to vote on the matter raised on the day in question. That is their decision and I am happy for them to do that if that is what they want. But it was not my decision. That was not the situation I wanted to be pushed into, or that I think any honourable senator should be pushed into.

I will resist the temptation tonight-hopefully in future we can do this-to list the occasions on which the Committee has in my view been badly run, because I still hold some hope that the Committee can be put back on the tracks, that it will be no longer run in the way it has been and we can function as all the other committees I have worked on have, where we have serious disagreements about political issues and nonetheless use the committee as a forum to put our views forward and at least have them heard.

It is unthinkable that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would refuse the right, for example, of some senators to be heard in this place. They might lose on a vote, but they have the right to be heard, and that should not be denied senators in committee meetings.

The thrust of Senator Loosley's remarks last night was basically that coalition members had done something intolerable in releasing some evidence-evidence which could have been sought at a public meeting and which the NCA could be expected to answer at a public meeting. The Committee is not permitted to inquire into operational matters under section 55 of the relevant Act. That section constrains the Committee.

It now seems from the remarks made by Senator Loosley and other Government members of the Committee that the Government does not even want the Committee to report on the administration of the NCA. That begs the question: what does the Government want the Committee to report on? What will the Committee ever be able to put before this Parliament if not matters that relate to the administration of the NCA rather than to operational matters? That is what the qualifying statement of the Committee report deals with-the administrative nightmare and fiasco that the NCA obviously was during the first six months of Mr Faris's chairmanship.

The statement of Justice Phillips is, I believe, very instructive. It displays no lack of trust or confidence in the Committee. Placed next to Senator Loosely's remarks of last night, the latter look a bit thin. I invite anyone who is interested to put the two together and make the judgment themselves. There is no point in me wasting your time, Mr Acting Deputy President, or that of other senators by going through seriatim the allegations made by Senator Loosley. I simply invite honourable senators to put the two statements together to see which one can stand up and which one has to fall down.

Senator Loosley said that the Labor members of the Committee sent Hansard away from a meeting on Monday this week because they did not want to read about anything from a briefing from the NCA in the Adelaide Advertiser. That is an obvious inference that, were such a briefing to take place, presumably I-because I am the South Australian member on that Committee-would have leaked it to the Advertiser. I invite Senator Loosley to tell us when he has ever read anything from a confidential briefing in the Adelaide Advertiser, or, for that matter, in some other newspaper. I invite him to come in and back up his statement. As I said the last time I spoke in this place, let him back it up or back off.

Let Senator Loosley also explain why members of the Committee who were expecting a formal meeting with the NCA-this is the manner in which these meetings are conducted for very good reasons; they are formal meetings with Hansard taken for obvious reasons-found that Hansard had suddenly been despatched. Could he also explain why when they made inquiries at the end of the meeting they were told, as Senator Crichton-Browne said last night, that it was never intended to be an informal meeting and that the NCA had requested an informal meeting?

Let me make something else abundantly clear: I know of no such request by the NCA to have a meeting without Hansard there, nor was that meeting ever intended to be informal. That is clear from the minutes of this Committee. What happened last night was that something much closer to the facts was revealed. Senator Loosley told the chamber that Labor members decided to send Hansard away. I believe they did that to build a picture that the NCA did not trust the Committee, and that deceitful plan came unstuck today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see how embarrassed Justice Phillips looked about it, too?

—It was, as Senator Crichton-Browne says, a very embarrassing meeting. There were some members of the Committee expecting a formal meeting to put questions to the National Crime Authority on its operation over the past three or four months; there came the NCA, with people having flown from other States for a meeting with the Committee; and all of a sudden Hansard is waltzing out the door and no-one is asking anything really important. The reason for the presence of Hansard is that the task of the Committee is to oversee the NCA and report back to Parliament, and it cannot do that on the informal discussions it has had. It has to have transcripts of its discussions with the NCA to be able to report properly to Parliament, to peruse the nature of the discussions at a later date. How embarrassing! These people had been flown from all over the place--
—At a cost.

—At the expense of taxpayers, and effectively nothing happened. Why? Because some dirty little plan was cooked up to try to make it look like some distrust existed between the NCA and the Committee. As I said, the kybosh was put on that deceitful little plan today.

SPEECH.PARA: That, of course, invites further questions. I would be interested in Senator Loosley at some later stage telling the Senate why the Labor members, who, I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President-although I do not need to do so, with your long experience in this place-do not have a majority on the Committee, feel entitled to change a committee's program at will without consulting the other members. Coalition members were not consulted; Senator Spindler was not consulted.

I know that, if the Government wants to have its way on a committee, it can put a motion and when the committee is divided, as it would perhaps have been on this matter, the chairman has a casting vote. In that way, the Government can have what it wants. That is why we were not consulted and why the Democrats were not consulted: the Chairman could not really bring himself to put it formally at a meeting and use a casting vote, which he has when a motion is put, and run the risk of having to put in the minutes the lie that some Government members are peddling-namely, that the NCA could not trust the Committee.

So much for the proper conduct of meetings. The Liberals do not have the numbers in this place; the Democrats do not have the numbers; Senator Harradine does not have the numbers; Senator Vallentine does not have the numbers. However, by virtue of having a place in this chamber, they have a right to speak and be heard. That right should follow through to committees. They will not function if that right is not permitted.

Apparently the Labor members on this Committee-let me not include all Labor members in general, because I have worked on a number of committees and have never had problems like this-do not see a need to show the same courtesy at NCA Committee meetings. The simple facts are these. Government members did not want to pursue matters surrounding Operation Ark. I do not think they would disagree with that. They agreed to report to Parliament on the basis of the Committee's current knowledge. That was an acceptable resolution of a difference of opinion. Government members did not want to go on with the matter; coalition members did. The way to resolve it was to report on what the Committee knew at that stage and let Parliament decide whether the Committee should go further. So they agreed to report to Parliament on the basis of the Committee's current knowledge.

They then tried to shelve the report. That was a very embarrassing incident. We had the Chairman of the Committee saying, `There was never any intention to put this report before Parliament', and paragraphs two and three of the draft report explained why it was going to Parliament. It was a very embarrassing exercise. Nonetheless, that attempt at shelving the report was not successful.

A dissenting report or qualifying statement has been put to Parliament. It revealed the administrative fiasco in the NCA during the first six months of Mr Faris's chairmanship. All the evidence in that report is evidence which could have been sought at a public meeting and which the NCA could have expected to answer at a public meeting, yet Government members have been engaging in a disgraceful bout of baseless attacks on coalition members. They have improperly sought to create the impression that the NCA no longer trusted the Committee. They look stupid for having done so.

Some members have complained, and complained to me, that they were not shown the qualifying statement prior to the tabling of the report. Normally they would have been, I quite agree, but this was not a normal situation. It was a situation where some Government members had tried to suggest that the report should be a report to ourselves. How ridiculous! What a waste of secretariat time-reporting a report to oneself. In other words, Government members changed their minds and did not want to report to Parliament. That can only lead one to wonder why.

What do honourable senators think would happen if those members of the Committee knew that the report would tell Parliament what Government members did not want Parliament to be told-that is, that the tensions in the NCA at that time were intolerable and that this must have impacted on the efficiency of the Authority? That is all that the qualifying statement says.

I will tell honourable senators what would have happened. The Labor fellows would have got together and moved a motion to delay the report by a few months to give them time to move a rescission motion, which, as honourable senators know, they need seven days for. And then none of this material, quite properly put before Parliament, would have seen the light of day.

In relation to the disclosure of evidence before the Committee, I have already said that nothing was disclosed that could not and should not have been given in evidence at a public hearing. It is interesting that Labor members think evidence should be released only if the majority agrees.

None of them has told us when the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties was asked by Mr Melham, very confidently, about the right of individual senators to reveal such information, what Mr Ron Merkel from the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties said. He responded to the effect that it was not so much a right but an obligation. In signing the qualifying statement, I believe that I was fulfilling my obligation as a Committee member to report to the Parliament on the operation of the NCA. This is an important function. The monitoring of a body with the powers the NCA has is a very important protection of our democratic rights. I will not be put off that task by cheap innuendo and unsubstantiated, outrageous allegations by Government members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. I bother to say that only because there were some matters raised last night in the adjournment debate by Senator Loosley and I did not have an opportunity to hear the vast majority of what he said. Only in the last minute or two have I had an opportunity to look at it further and so I will save that for another time. I do not want to retrace the steps that have been adequately covered by Senator Vallentine--
—Vanstone! Rip your tongue out!

—I apologise. It is probably my preoccupation with Senator Vallentine that caused me to say that. I do say that Senator Vanstone was right in absolutely everything she said in substance. It seems to me that, besides all the other sins of the Labor members of this Committee, there is an abysmal lack of understanding of Standing Orders. I do not say that by way of mitigation but in respect of their compounding the sin. If they are going to embark themselves on certain activities and certain conducts they have got to understand-as I said last night-that there is more in politics than numbers when one gets into the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The old adage in the Right of New South Wales that if one has the numbers everything else will follow fails in this place. It fails most of all on committees, where the Standing Orders provide very clearly how one can be accommodated. Mr O'Keefe said that they had indicated that the dissent was simply to be their protest, that we had used the guillotine to get the matter finished, and that there would be no further delay of another three or four weeks to consider the transcript after we had sat there and had about five hours of discussion with a number of Queen's Counsel. I said I was prepared to provide the vehicle, the report on Operation Ark, and I was prepared to wear their dissent on the matter of that procedure, but I was not prepared to have that dissent cover the issues that had been involved in in camera discussions.

I ask the Senate: How could any member or senator who has been in the place for two minutes possibly imagine that being a signatory to a majority report gives one some right to vote on the content of the minority report, or worse still, that, having chosen to sign a report, one has some right to vote as to whether there is going to be a minority report? But perhaps it was best epitomised when he said he would allow a report to be made.

Here was the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, the responsibilities of which are enshrined in section 55 of the National Crime Authority Act, required to inquire into Operation Ark, and there was some consideration as to whether the Committee would report to the Parliament. Now, the very reason that the Committee is dealt with in the Act is to have it report to the Parliament so as to ensure there is some accountability by the National Crime Authority to the Parliament, and through the Parliament to the wider community-to the public.

Here there was some discussion as to whether or not there would be a report on the very issue which the Committee had been addressing at some length. Then there was an absurd proposition that in some gratuitous way Government members of the Committee would allow us to have a minority report, and that we could have a minority report only providing that we said what they wanted. How steeped in ignorance can one be? However, they are the facts. Notwithstanding that that was the claim, as Senator Vanstone says, that is quite untrue. That was not the discussion; that was not the consideration; and that was certainly least of all a deliberation.

I move on to the matter of in camera evidence, which has been discussed. I will save that for another time save to say that the question of the use of in camera evidence and its necessity is very much in the eye of the architects of the majority report and the minority report. To begin now to argue some fundamental principle that there is something wrong with it, and to start at committees to move motions that in camera evidence will not be made public through a report, is simply a manner and mechanism of censorship of minority reports. I suspect that that is one of the reasons that the architects of the Standing Orders provided.

It would be quite simple by virtue of the numbers on a committee to take all evidence in camera and then have the majority of the numbers on the committee decide what in camera evidence would be released in the majority report, but not in the minority report. It is a classic mechanism for censorship, and it is not what I advocate to a government shortly to be in opposition. I remind the Senate that the last report that had a great deal of in camera evidence of a very sensitive and very serious nature was the report on drugs in sport. One of the signatories to that unanimous report was Senator Collins, now a Minister. So it is very much a subjective judgment.

Frankly, I am moved to the temptation of the view that it is not the principle of using in camera evidence that offends the majority on this Committee; it is the fact that the minority report, together with the in camera evidence, exposes the fact that the majority members of the Committee were not prepared to deal with some very serious matters. I suspect that thus far that is why the Government itself, and the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in particular, have been very silent in their response. It has exposed some matters that needed to be exposed, and it has clearly exposed the majority members as seeking to cover up what ought to be exposed. That is more offending and more agitating than the fact that the in camera evidence was used in the first place.

I turn ever so briefly to Mr O'Keefe's comments today. We can thank Justice Phillips that we had Mr O'Keefe go back into the Parliament and apologise to the Parliament-using the parlance of parliamentary language-for misleading the chamber. I rather wonder whether, if Justice Phillips had sat silent, we would have had that apology, or whether those misleading, inaccurate and fundamentally untrue statements would still be sitting on the Hansard record irrefutably undenied. It is important that what was said by Mr O'Keefe be understood. He said:

. . . I do not mind telling the Parliament this-that about two or three weeks ago, or it might be a bit longer than that, the new Chairman of the NCA, Justice Phillips, met with the NCA parliamentary Joint Committee-
that is true-
It was his first meeting with the Joint Committee-
that is true; this is what is pertinent-
He said that he had observed the relationship that had developed over the years-
that is untrue-

He had seen the difficulties about the disclosure of sensitive information and the fact that politicians seem to want to rush into the Parliament and blab information through these processes. This led to a very difficult relationship between the NCA and the parliamentary Joint Committee. He said that he had noticed the shift that had taken place since Mr Faris had taken up his chairmanship.
That is absolutely totally untrue. Not one of those words or the impressions or the inferences was uttered by Justice Phillips. Then we had the further compounding of that untruth. Mr O'Keefe said:

Having reached that point, how do we get to a stage when last week Justice Phillips had to say informally to the Committee that he did not see any way that the NCA could deal with the Committee other than on the transcript and totally publicly? In other words, five years of work went down the drain in two weeks of work by two people-

the two people being Senators Vanstone and Crichton-Browne. Those are the claims made by Mr O'Keefe. I remind honourable senators of the immediate rebuttal of Justice Phillips, the Chairman, who said:

At my first meeting with the PJC committee, I told them that I believed we could come to an accommodation whereby they received all the information that they needed, and that no members of the Authority would be embarrassed in answering questions about operational matters-
not general, informal, casual matters but of an operational nature. He went on to say in conclusion:
I still maintain that belief and have never indicated any qualification or change of it to the Committee.
In other words, Mr Justice Phillips said frankly that Mr O'Keefe was telling lies. His statement declared Mr O'Keefe to be a liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That word should not be used in debate. There are other words that you can use.

—I was not saying that myself, but I defer to you, Mr Deputy President, and Standing Orders. Contrasting the statement of Justice Phillips with that of Mr O'Keefe, it was quite clear that Mr O'Keefe's statement had been untruthful. Mr O'Keefe then went into the chamber-no doubt with a controversy swirling around his ears, with his telephones running hot with every journalist in town ringing him saying, `Who is telling the truth out of you two'. Mr O'Keefe, being politically sensitive, would understand who the public would believe, and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I expressed my grave concerns about the effect of the long term relationship between the National Crime Authority . . . and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority caused by the actions of Senators Vanstone and Crichton-Browne in releasing confidential in camera evidence in breach of the terms under which the Committee agreed to report on Operation Ark.
In that speech, I incorrectly interpreted remarks made by Justice Phillips . . .

He had interpreted them. A fourth grader would have got what Justice Phillip's said right. However, this is a nice way of getting out of a hell of a mess, is it not? Mr O'Keefe misinterpreted his words. He continued:
the new Chairman of the NCA, at a meeting last week and have, in fact,-
-mea culpa-

misled the House about the nature of those remarks. Justice Phillips did not infer that the NCA would now find itself unable to work with the Committee and he did not infer or suggest that there could not be the usual exchange of information between the Parliamentary Committee and the NCA.

Confronted with the truth, Mr O'Keefe regurgitated it. I find it particularly unfortunate that it took the courage and the commitment of Mr Justice Phillips to address this matter. He did make one thing fundamentally clear to our Committee. When asked two provocative, unhelpful and embarrassing questions of a political nature, he made it quite clear that he had no intention of becoming involved in matters of political decisions. He made it quite clear that he would not become involved in matters of conflict between various members of the Committee. I got the impression-I hope this does not provoke a statement from him-when Justice Phillips answered the second time that there was just a touch of steel in his voice. He had been asked two questions and he had been caused to respond that he would not get involved in the politics of the Committee. That was a pretty clear message, I would have thought, to even the insensitive members of that Committee. He was not inviting questions of that nature either then or in the future. Mr Acting Deputy President--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not acting.
—I apologise; I should know.
—But for four votes.
—A rose by any other name shall smell as sweet.

—You are quite right, Mr Deputy President. My problem is that I cannot get used to that title being permanent. I had some matters to respond to in respect of Senator Loosley's contribution. But I have had neither an opportunity to read what he said nor to inform him that I intend so to do. I will save it for the next opportunity.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: World War II: Italian Internees-Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few matters have been raised tonight. Senator Panizza raised the question of treatment of people during the Second World War. From his speech I did not pick up completely what he thought the remedy would be but the Government acknowledges that many people were badly treated during that time by the then United Australia Party and treated a little better under the Labour Party rule during the Second World War-but nothing to be proud about.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the essential problems of the time was that there was no Australian Citizenship Act. Had there been, many of those problems would have been resolved. It is interesting that many of the Italians now about 60 years to 70 years of age are starting to write their memoirs of this period and of their experiences in Australia and during the Second World War.
