Some of it makes very fascinating and intriguing reading. No doubt Senator Panizza will continue to take up these matters and hopefully will be able to progress his views further.

Tonight Senator Vanstone spoke on the National Crime Authority. I do not claim to be able to follow the byzantine intricacies in this particular spat. It seems to be reaching Blue Hills proportions. There are concerns, not necessarily as expressed by the two senators who have addressed the matter tonight about the disclosure of in camera evidence. It is not necessarily to do with whether the evidence is in a minority report or otherwise.

I want to make it quite clear that there are two different issues running: one is minority reports and one is in camera evidence. They are two different principles. If in camera evidence is to be consistently disclosed it would be my attitude and the attitude of all Government members that they will not participate in in camera hearings in future and that all hearings will have to be open. Then there can be no further dispute about disclosure or otherwise. It is very hard to judge, having taken in camera evidence, whether it should be public record. It is to do with committee systems and whether witnesses will come forward in future, et cetera. I now favour all evidence being on the record. If people do not want to give evidence, the committee system will suffer.

I cannot comment on the to-ing and fro-ing between the two chambers on the National Crime Authority. Senator Vanstone says that the committee system is being attacked. I cannot judge that. I can judge one or two other committees in this Parliament and in this chamber that have been so reduced by the behaviour of at least one coalition member that I cringe every time I watch it. That is one of the estimates committees. The treatment of public servants who appear before that committee is one of the biggest disgraces that I have seen in this Parliament in the 10 years I have been here. That is something I will take up another time.

Senator Crichton-Browne blatantly misled the Senate tonight. His opening remarks were that he would be brief. As usual, he went on for about 15 or 20 minutes. I would just like to draw that to your attention, Mr Deputy President. In conclusion, if I had my time over again, I would vote for Senator Crichton-Browne and not you to be in that chair because I would not have to listen to him on the adjournment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is the Australian Government taking to protect Australians who may be living or working in Kuwait.
(2) What is the estimated number of Australians in Kuwait.
(3) Has the Australian Government imposed sanctions against Iraq.
(4) How much oil does Australia import from Kuwait and other countries in the Persian Gulf.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government has pursued every appropriate avenue to promote the safety and welfare of Australians in Kuwait. The Government has made repeated representations to the Iraqi authorities to allow Australians (and other foreign nationals) asking to leave Kuwait to do so. Australian women and children wishing to leave were successfully evacuated from Kuwait with the assistance of several of our Embassies, particularly Baghdad and Amman, and other arms of government, including the RAAF. While our concern now focuses on the Australians remaining in Kuwait, we are equally active and concerned about Australians restrained from leaving Iraq. We do not have a resident Australian Embassy in Kuwait, but have received close cooperation from western missions in Kuwait. Officers from our Embassy in Baghdad have made four visits to Kuwait in difficult circumstances to assist Australians there, and more visits are planned. However, the Iraqi authorities have recently suspended permission for diplomats from Baghdad to travel to Kuwait, a move which we are seeking to have reversed. Our Embassy in Baghdad is managing to maintain indirect contact with Australians in Kuwait, and is continuing to provide other practical assistance such as passing on medicine and messages and mail from next of kin. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has also kept in close touch with next of kin of those Australians unable to leave Kuwait and Iraq. The Government has also broadcast a series of messages of advice and encouragement through Radio Australia to Australians in Kuwait, the most recent being made by the Prime Minister on 4 October. The Prime Minister said that the Government would deal sympathetically with requests for assistance where families of those trapped in Kuwait and Iraq were in particular need, and called upon financial institutions and other organisations to be sympathetic and fair in dealings affecting families with breadwinners held in Kuwait and Iraq. Australia has also lent its full support to the Security Council Resolutions calling for the Iraqi authorities to give immediate and unconditional approval to foreign nationals to depart from Kuwait and Iraq.
(2) We estimate that there are 35 Australians still in Kuwait.

(3) Yes. The Government acted quickly to implement the comprehensive mandatory sanctions on Iraq applied by UN Security Council Resolution 661. Relevant Government departments and authorities are alert to the need for strict enforcement of these measures to ensure adherence to the UN sanctions and are acting accordingly.

(A) 7 August, the Minister for Defence withdrew his permissions under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, effectively blocking all exports of military related equipment to Iraq. (B) The Australian Customs (Prohibited Exports) and (Prohibited Imports) Regulations were amended on 8 August to prohibit the import of goods from, and export of goods to, Iraq and Kuwait
(i) if there is an attempted import or export of goods in breach of these regulations, the relevant goods are subject under the Customs Act to forfeiture to the crown
(ii) Austrade has directed its staff not to engage in any activity in relation to the expansion or promotion of Australian trade to Iraq.

(C) The banking (foreign exchange) regulations were also amended to stop the movement of funds in and out of Australia to or from the Governments of Iraq and Kuwait, their agencies or nationals, without specific approval from the Reserve Bank.

(D) Migration regulations effective from 31 August ensure that prospective visitors to Australia who would be likely to engage in commercial or other activities involving Iraq or Kuwait in breach of Resolution 661 will be precluded from obtaining visas.

(4) In 1989-90 Kuwait was the source of some 5.5% of Australia's crude oil imports and less than 2% of Australia's refined petroleum product imports. In 1989-90 Gulf States provided 21 per cent of total crude oil refinery input in Australia. Consistent with its obligations to abide by UN economic sanctions against Iraq, Australia has ceased importing petroleum from Iraq and Kuwait. Several shiploads of Kuwaiti oil which had been paid for before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and were loaded or on the high seas have been allowed to be landed in Australia after the necessary exemptions were granted under the Australian Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. These shipments were fully consistent with Australia's obligations in relation to UN sanctions against Iraq.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Heritage Listing: North Queensland Rainforest

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 21 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's policy on payment of compensation to those adversely affected by the World Heritage listing of the North Queensland rainforest.
(2) How has the policy been administered.
(3) What payments of compensation have been made to date, in what amounts, and to whom have such payments been made.

(4) In view of the Government's stated aim of assisting tourist development in the Ravenshoe area to compensate for losses of jobs in the timber milling industry, is the Government prepared to make financial assistance by way of grants, long-term low-interest loans or other financial assistance to people wishing to commence tourist operations in the Ravenshoe area.

(5) In view of the Government's stated aim of providing employment in reforestation for people in areas affected by World Heritage Listing of the rainforests: (a) what steps have been taken to commence reforestation projects; (b) what areas of land have been acquired for this purpose; (c) how many people have been employed in this project; and (d) for how long is the project of reforestation to continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Business compensation under the Structural Adjustment Package is paid to any businesses that could demonstrate

(a) that they were logging or sawmilling companies or contractors or closely related businesses which were substantially dependent on the timber industry (ie, their principal activity is/was the direct supply to, or use of the products of, the logging and sawmilling industry); and

(b) that the cessation or substantial reduction of business was directly related to the prohibition of commercial forestry operations (by Regulation dated 20 January 1988 under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983) in the Wet Tropics area nominated by the Commonwealth Government on 18 December 1987 for inscription on the World Heritage List.

Where an initial assessment by the Department confirmed that the applicant met the eligibility test, an independent assessment of the value of the applicant's business was undertaken by Mr M J Empson, a partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse or by staff of Price Waterhouse working under his supervision. Price Waterhouse was required to make assessments of the fair and reasonable value of businesses as going concerns, rather than shut-down valuations. This involved:
(a) a detailed analysis of the earnings in recent years of the business being assessed and an estimate of likely future earnings in the absence of World Heritage listing;
(b) an assessment of the value of the assets used by that business in deriving income from rainforest logging and milling activities;

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Health Department of Western Australia: Heptachlor

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a 1988 Health Department of Western Australia submission to the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority on heptachlor use for the control of Argentine ants and of the substantial contribution the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&RC) made to this submission.

(2) In this submission, did the Health Department of Western Australia allege scientific fraud by prominent United States (US) pathologist, Dr Melvin Reuber, both in relation to 1981 events and a 1987 paper reporting induction of tumours in rats by heptachlor and heptachlor epoxide.

(3) Did Dr Reuber win a court action against his employer in the US in relation to the 1981 allegations and in June 1988, in a second action, was Dr Reuber awarded US$875,000 against the trade journal ``Pesticide &Toxic Chemical News'', including US$250,000 as punitive damages for malicious publication of these allegations which were reproduced by the Health Department of Western Australia in its May 1988 publication.

(4) Does the Minister agree with the criticism by Dr Peter McCullagh, Senior Fellow, Division of Clinical Sciences, John Curtin School of Medical Research, as expressed in his report (tabled), relating to the Health Department of Western Australia's comment on Dr Reuber.

(5) Are any copies of the Health Department's 1988 submission in the possession of the NH&RC and/or the Department of Community Services and Health; if so, will the Minister direct that all accessible copies of the submission containing the allegations against Dr Reuber be destroyed so as to prevent further injustice to Dr Reuber; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister publicly disassociate himself, the Government, the NH&RC and his department from the comments on Dr Reuber by the Health Department of Western Australia; if not, why not.

(7) Will the Minister, through this Parliament, apologise to Dr Reuber for the behaviour of the Health Department of Western Australia, which has refused to withdraw its allegations against Dr Reuber, and in fact continues to distribute them; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that the NH&RC did contribute comment and advice on data supplied to it by the Health Department of Western Australia. The NH&RC paper appears as Attachment One to the submission.
(2)-(4) The issues raised in these questions are matters for the Western Australian authorities.

(5) Copies of the 1988 Health Department Submission on Heptachlor use for the control of Argentine ants are held by the Department of Community Services and Health, and the NH&RC. It is not the Department's policy to destroy any information provided to it.
(6)-(7) The issues raised in these questions are matters for the Western Australian authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the department developed, or is it in the process of developing a strategic plan for the development of biotechnology in Australia: if so, what emphasis is being given to marine biotechnology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department's corporate plan identifies a range of strategic priorities which are delivered through various programs. Biotechnology is seen by the Department as a series of technologies which are encompassed by several of the strategic priorities, rather than as the basis for a strategic plan in its own right. The Department recognises the important contribution biotechnology can make to the competitiveness of Australian firms and supports strategic research and development in biotechnology under the Grants for Industry Research and Development (GIRD) scheme.

The Industry Research and Development Board's Biotechnology Committee consults with industry to identify priority areas for biotechnology research funding. This on-going process has included an assessment of the opportunities for biotechnology to contribute to the development and competitiveness of Australia's marine industries, especially aquaculture. Recent advertisements calling for grant applications specifically encouraged proposals for aquaculture projects.

The role of biotechnology in the marine industries is currently being considered by the Department as part of its contribution to a national strategy for aquaculture coordinated through the Australian Fisheries Service within the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy. A draft of this strategy is expected to be presented to the Australian Fisheries Council in July 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any SAS troops currently in Papua New Guinea (PNG); if so, when were they stationed there and what activities are they involved in.
(2) Does the Australian Government support the current economic and communication blockade enforced against Bougainville by the PNG Government.
(3) Does the Australian Government support a negotiated peace settlement involving all Bougainvilleans including those who seek self-determination.
(4) What actions has the Australian Government taken to bring about a negotiated and peaceful, non-military, solution to the current Bougainville crisis.
(5) Are there any conditions placed on the use of the Australian supplied PNG patrol boats.
(6) What activities are these boats currently involved in with respect to the Bougainville blockade and peace talks.

(7) How does the Australian Government envisage that an increase in military aid, for example, the provision of Australian army advisers and infantry assault weapons will bring about peace on Bougainville.

(8) Has the Australian Government been involved in pressuring the PNG Government to: (a) remove obstacles to the investment and profitability of foreign business; and (b) impose austerity measures on the PNG people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are three Special Air Service personnel in Papua New Guinea at the present time. There is a Captain and a Warrant Officer located at Goldie River Training Depot. They are there in the capacity of instructors, training the PNG infantry in basic infantry procedures. The third member, a Captain is attached to the AIDAB police project and is providing some basic training to members of the PNG police mobile squads. All were posted to Papua New Guinea in January 1990.

(2) Papua New Guinea's policy on Bougainville is an internal matter for the Government of Papua New Guinea and has always been regarded so by the Australian Government. The Australian Government supports the Papua New Guinea Government's stated policy of negotiating a peaceful solution to the Bougainville problem.
(3) Yes.

(4) Bougainville is not a matter for unilateral action by Australia. There has been no scope for Australian `mediation' in this internal PNG issue. But the Australian Government has always made clear its readiness to consider any practical help which might facilitate a solution, and that it is prepared to help where it can in reconstruction on Bougainville once a settlement has been reached. Australia has also offered to provide humanitarian assistance, should our help be required.
(5) No. There is only the normal requirement for Papua New Guinea to seek Australia's agreement before sale or transfer of the patrol boats to a third country.

(6) As has been reported in both the Australian and PNG media, Papua New Guinea has used its patrol boats in patrolling operations around Bougainville and to escort civilian vessels involved in the recent attempt to restore government services to the province.

(7) In providing assistance to Papua New Guinea Australia was responding to requests from the democratically elected and properly constituted Government of Papua New Guinea. Equipment and training assistance provided by Australia under Defence Cooperation arrangements are directed at improving the capacity of the PNG Defence Force to carry out the range of roles assigned to it by the PNG Government.

(8) (a) The Australian Government has not been involved in and (b) pressuring the PNG Government on any issue. Regular high-level dialogue takes place with the Government of Papua New Guinea about the whole range of our interests on the basis of our shared commitment to constructive neighbourly co-operation. Our discussions cover investment issues, and PNG economic policy in the context of Australian provision of development assistance funds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 11 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a form of oestrogen treatment using skin patches for hormone replacement therapy devised by Doctor Ho of the Garvan Institute of Medical Research at St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney, when will the `patch method' be available for use as an alternative to the method of taking oestrogen orally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Ho of the Garvan Institute has not `devised' any skin patches but uses, on a clinical trial basis, those sponsored by the Ciba Geigy company. These patches are designed to be applied to the skin and to deliver a pre-determined dose of oestradiol, one of the most active of the naturally occurring female oestrogen hormones.

These particular patches have been considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC), an independent body of experts whose job it is to advise the Minister as to whether or not a drug should be marketed. The Committee have had concerns about the absorption and safety of the product to be marketed in Australia and, consequently, have not recommended marketing approval be given until these issues are resolved.
The Ciba Geigy company has tried to answer these concerns in its most recent submission that is currently under evaluation prior to ADEC review.
In the meantime, there are alternative forms of oestrogen available for use in the form of oral tablets, subdermal (under the skin) implants, injections and topical creams and gels for vaginal use.

In those women for whom the use of the available forms of oestrogen is accompanied by severe, unacceptable adverse effects, oestradiol patches are available through the Department's Individual Patient Usage Scheme for unmarketed drug products.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 2 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount of aid does Australia give to Papua New Guinea and has this amount increased since last year.
(2) What specific areas of Papua New Guinea does the aid go to and how is it administered.
(3) What proportion of the aid is administered by the Papua New Guinea Government in Port Moresby and is any aid given directly to provinces and areas.
(4) Is any of the aid given in the form of agricultural assistance, i.e. farm machinery, tools, agricultural products, advisers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Total programmed aid to PNG in 1990/91 is estimated at $306.6m compared to expenditure of $313.0m in 1989/90. In addition, unprogrammed aid expenditure (including emergency aid, aid through non-government organisations, the Development Import Finance Facility and aid expenditure by other Departments) was estimated at $24.8M in 1989/90. Accurate estimates of unprogrammed expenditure in 1990/91 are not yet available but are expected to be of roughly the same order.

(2) The bulk of Australia's aid ($275m in 1990/91) is in the form of untied budget support representing at present about 17 per cent of PNG's budget outlays. It is not possible therefore to specify the geographic destination of these funds.

Most of the project aid program ($31.6m in 1990/91) is focused on human resources development and strengthening key institutions (taxation, customs, civil aviation, financial management for Provincial Government staff, the police, agricultural research and extension, and land administration). These activities have nation-wide benefits. However there are two integrated rural development projects focused on specific areas:

- the South Simbu rural development project aims to increase the income and improve the nutritional status of the population of two of the poorest districts in PNG situated in the south of Simbu Province. The project is concentrating on the development of food production, livestock, mixed farming and fisheries. The project will improve farmer access to technical advice, farm inputs and markets. The project is being jointly funded by the International Fund for Agricultural Development ($US3.5m loan) and AIDAB ($A3.3m grant). An appraisal/design study is being conducted in 1990 to prepare for the extension of the project to a number of districts in North Simbu;

- the Kandrian-Gloucester District Development Project Feasibility Study is focused on the Kandrian-Gloucester district of West New Britain province. This region has a very low level of per capita income. It aims to establish the viability of a project which would aim to increase and sustain the rate of economic development within the project area, establish the physical and social infrastructure necessary for an accelerated rate of economic development, improve the provision of health and education services to isolated communities and their nutritional status; and develop an effective management and planning capacity at district and provincial levels of Government. The estimated cost of the feasibility study is $955,000.

Beyond the payment of monthly cheques by AIDAB, budget support is administered by the PNG Government as part of its total budgetary revenue. The Australian Government does not have a say in how these funds are spent, but AIDAB closely monitors PNG's economic management and performance. Project aid is jointly administered by the PNG Government and AIDAB, and is generally tied to the provision of Australian goods and services. Within AIDAB, the PNG program is managed by the Director of a Section (Pacific and Papua New Guinea Branch, Country Programs Division). The Director and staff are responsible for policy development, program delivery, the pipeline of activities and oversight of expenditure. In fulfilling these responsibilities, the Director consults closely with the Counsellor (Development Assistance) and staff, Port Moresby, whose duties centre on liaison with PNG officials, initiation of new activities and the implementation and monitoring of the program.

(3) Budget support, which accounts for approximately 90% of programmable aid in 1990/91, is administered by the PNG Government. All project aid is channelled through the national Government although some provinces and areas benefit from specific projects eg. the South Simbu and proposed North Simbu Rural Development Projects, the proposed KandrianGloucester District Development Project (see above). Also a Financial Management Improvement Project, which Australia is cofinancing with UNDP, includes computerisation of the financial management system of the 19 Provincial Governments and the training of 600 Provincial staff.
(4) Apart from the integrated rural development projects above, there are currently three projects in the agriculture sector:
- the Coffee Development Agency Project (Australian contribution of $3.5M) which aims to assist in the control of coffee leaf rust through the provision of expert advisers and equipment;

- the Coffee Research Institute Project ($3.2M), a collaborative research program between the Coffee Research Institute and the Plant Research Institute of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Victoria, which aims to improve the productivity of PNG coffee growers; and
- the Cocoa Quality Improvement Project ($3.4M) which aims to improve the quality of cocoa grown by smallholders through a program of applied research and extension of existing technology.
Australia's assistance to each of these projects is mainly in the form of advisory services and training.

In addition the Australian Centre for International Agriculture Research, which is funded under the aid program, has undertaken a total of 17 projects with a total financial commitment of $11.3M in PNG and the South Pacific. Projects completed or currently under way in PNG include
- Transport and Storage of Fresh Fruit and Vegetables;
- Export Tree Crops Study;
- Commodity Price Stabilisation;
- Nutrition and Policy Implications of the Spread of Cash Cropping;
- Designing Monitoring Systems for Smallholder Agriculture;
- Research on Baitfish Biology for the Tuna Industry;
- Research Priorities for Agriculture;
- Coconut Improvement;
- Biological Control in the South Pacific; and
- Sweet Potato Improvement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the light of an ABC Television `Four Corners' documentary program of 24 September 1990, which dealt with the transfer of chemical weapons from Germany to Johnston Atoll in the Pacific, what involvement will the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have in monitoring the transfer, transportation and storage of these chemical weapons to Johnston Atoll.

(2) Is it possible for the Minister to confirm whether the allegations contained in the `Four Corners' program, which suggested that the United States does not intend to destroy the weapons, are based on fact.

(3) Will the Australian Government continue supporting the shipment of chemical weapons to Johnston Atoll if the United States has no intention of destroying the chemical weapons but will only use the Atoll as a storage base.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that the vessels carrying the chemical weapons stocks from Germany to Johnston Atoll left Germany on 22 September. The measures the United States Army is taking to ensure that this transfer takes place safely and that the risks of any environmental danger arising from the transport are minimised are outlined in an Environmental Impact Study which is publicly available. The precautions taken are in excess of international requirements. At an earlier point Australian officials were fully briefed by U.S. officials about the measures being implemented to ensure that no leakage or other environmentally damaging incident took place during the shipment.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will nominate a suitably qualified scientist to participate in a scientific delegation to visit Johnston Atoll early next year. The visit will provide the opportunity to assess at first hand both the storage arrangements and operation of the facility. A visit to the facility by senior South Pacific Forum country officials is also being arranged and is expected to take place early next year. Australia will be represented on that visit. The Department is engaged in on-going discussions with United States officials to ensure that environmental and safety standards are continuously applied to all aspects of the destruction program.

(2) In a letter to the Chairman of the South Pacific Forum the U.S. Secretary of Defence Cheney has advised that all chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll will be destroyed and not retained as part of the United States' retaliatory stockpile. Following the `Four Corners' program my Department sought and received confirmation that the position stated by Secretary Cheney was the authoritative U.S. position in relation to the stocks shipped from Germany and those currently on Johnston Atoll. A senior U.S. official described any statements to the contrary in the `Four Corners' Program as misleading and inaccurate. The intention to destroy these weapons was recently reiterated to me at the Australia-United States Ministerial talks held in Washington on 8 October.

(3) As I made clear in the `Four Corners' documentary, the position taken by the Australian Government on the Johnston Atoll facility is contingent on the destruction of the chemical weapons. The Australian Government has also made clear that its support for the destruction program is based on the facility only being used for the destruction of stocks already there, those being brought from Germany and possibly, old Pacific stocks and that it is to be closed down after those operations are finished.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 October 1990-

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Australian Government taken to encourage other countries to apply diplomatic pressure on the Government of Myanmar so that a transition of power to the democratically elected National Assembly might take place.

(2) On his recent visit to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA), did the Minister meet with the leaders of the Myanmar delegation in order to discuss the current situation in that country and is he able to provide details of any such discussions.

(3) Whilst at the UNGA, did the Minister also raise the situation in Myanmar with his ministerial colleagues from other nations including the United States and the countries of the European Community and is he in a position to provide details of any such discussions.

(4) Have members of the United States Senate, including Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, suggested that all governments should consider imposing trade sanctions on the government of Myanmar until such time as a transition to democracy takes place.

(5) Following on from discussions held with his ministerial colleagues in the UNGA, is there sufficient support in the international community to support the introduction of trade sanctions against Myanmar.
(6) Does the Minister intend to meet with the Australian representatives of the Democratic Alliance of Burma in order to familiarise himself with their views.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has maintained close contact with other countries concerned over the situation in Myanmar with the aim of taking joint action whenever this is possible. After the Myanmar elections on 28 May, I wrote to the leader of the Myanmar State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC), Senior General Saw Maung, requesting the SLORC to make an early transfer of power to a democratically-elected government, and release political detainees. I also wrote to the leaders of the National League for Democracy (NLD) which won the majority of seats in the elections, offering the Australian Government's support. At that time, I urged likeminded Governments to take similar action. Australia has been regularly associated with joint diplomatic demarches in Yangon in which the United States and European Community countries have also been prominent. Most recently, Australia joined eighteen other countries, including the US and Japan, in a demarche organised by the European Community. The demarche, which took place on 21 September, expressed the hope that democracy would soon be restored to Myanmar in accordance with the wishes of the people as expressed in the May elections. I also raised the situation in Myanmar with my ASEAN ministerial colleagues at the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference in July. At the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA), I drew attention to the situation in Myanmar in my address to the General Assembly. Australia has also raised the situation in Myanmar in the Third Committee debate on self-determination.

(2) At the UNGA I was able to meet with the leader of the Myanmar delegation, Deputy Foreign Minister U Ohn Gyaw. During our discussions, I expressed great concern that the ruling SLORC are showing no signs of transferring power to a democratic government and observed that the situation in Myanmar appears to be explosive. I was also critical of human rights abuses that are occurring in Myanmar including the detention of a locally employed staff member at the Australian Embassy and the continued detention of the General Secretary of the NLD, Aung San Suu Kyi.

(3) At the UNGA, and during the Australia-United States Ministerial Talks on 8 October in Washington, I also had opportunities to meet with a number of ministerial colleagues from other countries and was able to explore further possibilities for international action. Australia is now taking further action, focused on coordinated statements at the United Nations General Assembly and action in the UN Commission on Human Rights.

(4) It is correct that the US Congress has recently passed a bill calling for the US President to impose appropriate economic sanctions against Myanmar if Myanmar did not end martial law, transfer power to a civilian government, release political prisoners and take effective action against narcotics production by 1 October. The US Government has recently sought Australian support for such action and the possibility of Australia joining the US in applying sanctions is currently under consideration.

(5) The utility of imposing trade sanctions has, among other things, to be measured by the extent of likely international support for them. It is open to doubt whether sufficiently broad support for sanctions yet exists. The Government is assessing this question in consultation with the United States.

(6) I would be happy to meet with the Australian representatives of the Democratic Alliance of Burma should they ask to meet me. I have consistently been supportive of the views of the Burmese community in Australia and their desire for democratic reform in Myanmar.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (l) Have there been reports in the media that fighting between Government troops and Tamil separatist guerillas has recently intensified in Sri Lanka.
(2) How does the Australian Government view these reports, which suggest that cities such as Jaffna have been virtually destroyed by constant bombing by Sri Lankan Government aircraft.

(3) Is it possible for the Australian Government to confirm whether indiscriminate killing of innocent civilians is now taking place and is being carried out by both Sri Lanka's own security forces and by Tamil separatist guerillas.
(4) What action has the Australian Government taken to condemn such indiscriminate killings.

(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that funds provided under Australia's overseas aid program to Sri Lanka are being used to the benefit of all Sri Lankan people and that such funds are not being re-directed by the Sri Lankan Government for other means.
(6) Can the Commonwealth, of which both Australia and Sri Lanka are members, be used to bring about a political settlement to the country; if so, how would such involvement occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (l) There have been media reports to the effect that fighting between the LTTE and the Sri Lankan Government forces has intensified. The intensification of hostilities was the result of an offensive launched on 22 August by the Sri Lankan Government forces against the Jaffna Peninsula, the heartland of the LTTE, to relieve an army garrison that had been besieged in Jaffna Fort since hostilities commenced in June. On 13 September the Sri Lankan Army (SLA) did, in fact, succeed in breaking through to the fort, despite heavy resistance from the LTTE. They were unable to press on further into the peninsula, and thirteen days later the SLA withdrew from the fort itself and evacuated almost all the gains achieved by the offensive. Following the withdrawal, the situation reportedly calmed, and Jaffna returned virtually to normal. On 16 October, however, the SLA launched another major offensive against the Jaffna Peninsula.

(2) There is a considerable degree of confusion about the situation on the ground in the affected areas. The LTTE in particular has worked actively and effectively to focus international attention on its claims of genocide and devastation in Jaffna. Whilst it would be an exaggeration to say that Jaffna and other cities have been `destroyed', during `Operation Fort' in August and September, the level of aerial bombardment did intensify as did the consequent level of material damage and civilian deaths.

(3) The resumption of hostilities between the Sri Lankan Government and the Tamil Tigers has witnessed clear instances of human rights violations by both sides, the incidence of which continues to be high. The LTTE have perpetrated a number of atrocities, especially against Muslim communities in eastern Sri Lanka. There have also been atrocities and other actions involving abuses of human rights perpetrated by individuals or individual units within the Sri Lankan security forces, apparently acting on their own initiative.

(4) The Australian Government has been most disturbed by the indiscriminate killing of civilians that has occurred since hostilities resumed in June. I have made formal public statements expressing concern on three occasions (on 22 June, 7 August and in the Parliament on 19 September). I have condemned the actions of the LTTE in breaking the ceasefire and in perpetrating the massacres against Muslim civilians. The Australian Government believes the Sri Lankan Government has been making genuine efforts to maintain effective discipline amongst its forces. Some units of the Sri Lankan security forces have nonetheless perpetrated a number of excesses, and as a result we have expressed our concern and reminded the Sri Lankan Government of the need for restraint.

(5) Yes. The Australian aid program to Sri Lanka consists of developmental food aid, postgraduate training awards in Australia, a rehabilitation and reconstruction program in the North and North East, and minor activities managed by the Australian High Commission in Colombo, as well as special emergency assistance, worth $200,000, that has been directed through UNICEF, Care Australia and Community Aid Abroad. The nature of these activities is such as to ensure that funds are directed to the intended beneficiaries.

(6) As I outlined to the Senate on 19 September and as the Prime Minister elaborated subsequently in the House on 11 October, following my discussions with President Premadasa during my visit to Sri Lanka in August about ways of making progress towards a peaceful settlement, the Prime Minister wrote to President Premadasa to set out some options in the Commonwealth context which the Sri Lankans might like to pursue. We await a response from President Premadasa to Mr Hawke's letter and, in the interim, continue to follow events in Sri Lanka closely with a sense of deep concern.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transport of US Chemical Weapons from Germany to Johnston Atoll

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government been informed of the route of chemical weapons being shipped from Germany to Australia and the nature of the cargo.
(2) Has the Government received any assurances as to safety of the transportation of these weapons and has an emergency response plan been prepared in the event of an accident.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the United States authorities indicated to the Australian Government their consideration of several alternative routes for the transportation of chemical weapons from Germany to Johnston Atoll. Although there was no obligation for the United States to consult Australia on their final decision, the Government was given to understand that the route most likely to be chosen would maximise transit in international waters and that these routes were classified to improve the safety and security of the operation. I understand that shipment has almost concluded. The nature of the cargo comprised the US stockpile in Germany which consisted of 100,000 steel walled artillery projectiles filled with two nerve agents.

(2) The Government has been provided with information outlining the very stringent precautions being taken to ensure the safety of the operation. In the highly improbable event of an explosion on board either of the vessels used for the shipment, I understand that the cargo would be released to a maximum of two miles downwind before dispersion reduced the risks posed by any leakage to negligible levels. On the other hand, if either of the vessels were to sink, the cargo would eventually leak from the projectiles but be rapidly inactivated through hydrolysis by sea water. Several ships loaded with similar cargoes were scuttled in the Atlantic in the late 1960s, without any recorded adverse environmental impacts. As one of many safeguards against accident, the present convoy is being escorted by United States navy and coastguard vessels equipped to respond to any emergency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans have been made by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) to install computer hardware in Australian pharmacies.
(2) Will there be computer linkage from existing pharmacy computers to the central HIC computer used for the processing of Medicare claims.
(3) What is to be the cost of each hardware item.
(4) What effective penalty may affect those pharmacists without computers.
(5) What obligation will be placed upon pharmacists with computers to link up with a central computer.
(6) Will the names and pension numbers of patients be transmitted by computer from individual pharmacies; if so, what steps will be taken to protect patient confidentiality.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In late 1989 the Health Insurance Commission put forward a new processing strategy for the payment of pharmaceutical benefits. Part of that processing strategy involved installation of a data collection and transmission type device in pharmacies to facilitate the claims processing and payment cycle. This was not continued with. The Government announced in its August 1990 Budget that eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits would be restricted to Australian residents only and that the Commission would provide a computer system whereby pharmacists, if they wished, could check a person's entitlement to subsidised medication. Any such checking arrangements would be the subject of legislative enactment and Privacy Commissioner's approval. The Health Insurance Commission will not develop its plans for the installation of terminal equipment in pharmacies until the Government's legislative package has been approved.
(2) Yes. A pharmacy communications network is proposed for those pharmacies who wish to be connected to the Commission's computer systems.

(3) The cost of each item of equipment will not be known until the precise nature of the function of the equipment has been determined (to be determined at the conclusion of discussions with the Privacy Commissioner) and tenders have been called.

(4) The Government in its August 1990 Budget announced that claims lodged by pharmacies from February 1991 would be required to be lodged in an electronic format. The majority of Australian pharmacies are computerised following an incentive offer provided by the Government in 1987. Nevertheless, the Government is in discussion with the Pharmacy Guild on implementation proposals contained within its Budget package.

(5) There will be no obligation placed upon pharmacists with computers to link up with a central computer. However, in terms of checking a patient's eligibility to drugs under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme the pharmacist will have to satisfy the Commission that eligibility existed at the time of supply.

(6) That information is currently supplied by pharmacists in support of their claims for reimbursement. Data collected under the program is protected by the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling

TALK.START.PARA: asked Senator Gareth Evans representing the Minister for Transport and Communications the following question (During Senate Committee of the Whole deliberations of 21 November 1989):

QUESTION.PARA: ``Similarly, I refer to the Hansard of 3 October with regard to the operations of the Independent Air Fares Committee. A question was asked with regard to any air fare increases that might be caused by the pilots strike, and I sought an assurance that the Government would guarantee that there would be no increases in air fares arising from the present domestic strike. Again it would appear that no further information has been provided on this most important issue and I would ask how that is currently being addressed''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Independent Air Fares Committee:

ANSWER.PARA: A response to the honourable senator's question was provided to Senate Estimates Committee B by the representative of the Independent Air Fares Committee on 3 October 1989 as follows (Hansard, page B193):

``The Independent Air Fares Committee has certain powers to initiate air fare reviews, but normally the committee would adjudicate upon an application by an airline. The committee at the moment is gathering what information it can. I think that is a rather hypothetical question and we would have to adjudicate on what facts were placed before us by the airlines''.
Subsequently, Ansett and Australian Airlines in December 1989 requested substantial fare increases due to the effects of the pilots' dispute.

After a careful review of all factors, and having regard to the requirements of the IAFC Act, the Committee determined (subject to review by the Committee no later than 23 July 1990) that a 5 per cent fare increase, from 24 January 1990, was justified to partly offset the significant additional abnormal costs which Ansett and Australian had incurred in their endeavours to provide a level of service for the travelling public, as required by their obligations under the Airlines Agreement Act.

From the evidence before it, the Committee concluded that it was reasonable and equitable to both the airlines and the travelling public for a relatively small proportion of the significant abnormal costs then being incurred to be recouped through a fare increase, which was substantially below the levels sought by the airlines. The Committee initiated a review of Ansett's and Australia's fare levels on 23 July 1990 and determined that no variation to the fare levels approved in January 1990 was justified.

Subsequently, Australian and Ansett announced that their fares will increase by 7.5 per cent from 1 November 1990 due to costs associated with fuel prices increases. As the fare increase is to apply after 30 October the IAFC's approval was not required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume

TALK.START.PARA: asked Senator Evans representing the Minister for Transport and Communications the following question (During Senate Committee of the Whole deliberations of 21 November 1989):

QUESTION.PARA: ``I am intrigued to note that, although the bad debts written off total $70m, the provision for bad debts has been cut by $21m. Is this because Telecom expects to have a far better bad debt situation in the coming year?''

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The reduction of $21 million in the provision for doubtful (bad) debts (reference page 68 of Telecom's 1988-89 Annual Report), is due to an accounting policy change whereby doubtful debts are now written off automatically after three months rather than over a period of up to twelve months as was the case previously. This allows outstanding debts to be passed to mercantile debt collection agents at a much earlier stage in the collection cycle than previously. With action now taken at a much earlier stage to recover bad debts an increase in recovery rates is likely. Changes in the provision for doubtful debts have no direct effect on the amount of bad debts written off ultimately.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston

TALK.START.PARA: asked Senator Evans representing the Minister for Transport and Communications the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: ``May I move to another section in relation to a question asked by Senator Panizza on the cost of establishing a UHF communications network from Port Hedland with a line running straight east to the Northern Territory border . . . I simply ask, on notice, that the Minister make a further endeavour to come up with a meaningful, quantitative figure''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is understood that the question seeks only an estimate of the cost of establishing a network of stations to provide a UHF service between Port Hedland and the Northern Territory border.

The Department's Communications Operations Division would estimate the cost of providing a UHF communications network from Port Hedland, east to the Northern Territory border, to be in excess of 10 Million dollars.

This estimate does not include the cost of any ongoing support infrastructure or maintenance of such a service. The estimate has been provided by Technical officers who have experience with the communications industry through their dealings on matters related to the allocation of radio frequencies. The estimate is based on their knowledge and experience of typical communications facilities and does not take into account any commercial aspects of such a proposal. It is likely that a commercial estimate could indeed be significantly higher.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston

TALK.START.PARA: asked Senator Evans representing the Minister for Transport and Communications the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: ``Can the Minister explain why 90 per cent of area for 90 per cent of the time does not give a probability of the likelihood of a successful call being made? If not, what is meant by the cute expression `transmission guideline'?''

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The service standard measurements being quoted measure different aspects of the cellular mobile telephone service, and they cannot realistically be compared.
The Pactel standard states a 99% probability of the first call attempt being successful. This measure is calculated as follows:

(i) Each base station in the mobile network is designed to a 5% congestion level. This means that during the busiest hour of the day 95 calls in every hundred capture a radio channel from the base station sending the strongest signal.

(ii) When all radio channels on a base station are occupied, additional calls are redirected to other available base stations. (Unless the customer is on the fringe of the coverage area, it is likely that there are at least two base stations that could service the call).

(iii) Therefore, the customer who misses out on the first base station has a further 95% chance of obtaining service from the second base station. If a channel is not available on the second base station, there is a further 95% chance of obtaining service from a third base station.

(iv) The combination of this series of 95% chances of obtaining a radio circuit is that, on average, a customer has a 99% chance of obtaining a radio channel at first attempt. In a fringe area, where service is provided by only one base station, the chances are 95% but in built up areas, and especially in the CBD where many base stations are available, the chance of obtaining a radio channel is greater than 99%.

Telecom Australia's MobileNet is designed to operate to the same 5% congestion standards on its base stations, and it operates the same call redirection facility. In this respect, there is no significant difference between the design standards of Pactel and the design standards of Telecom Australia.

Telecom Australia works to international standards which state that 90% of the area is covered for 90% of the time at an acceptable signal strength. This refers to the quality of transmission coverage (or, as referred to in the previous answer, transmission guideline) and has no relation to congestion levels-a base station might be heavily congested but the radio transmission could still meet the 90/90 standard.

Transmission Guidelines are internationally accepted standards that are used to determine the amount of equipment required to provide a reasonable grade of service for the amount of traffic being generated.

One of the uses of the 90/90 rule is to define the coverage area of MobileNet. MobileNet service is often available outside of the published coverage areas. However, the coverage quality is not up to the standard of the 90/90 rule, which is why those areas are not included in the coverage maps.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston

TALK.START.PARA: asked Senator Evans representing the Minister for Transport and Communications the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: ``Without the introduction of a fibre optic based pay television service by what year does Telecom expect to have laid optic fibre to hubs in the streets in metropolitan areas?

The only answer which provided a date did so in the context of saying that if we have pay television, 60 per cent of homes could be covered by 1994. That is a straight evasion of the question which has been asked about what would happen without pay television. That is the question I want answered''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom established a corporate objective in 1989 to develop a wideband network capability by providing optical fibre cables to sufficient distribution hubs to serve 60 per cent of homes in metropolitan areas by 1994-95. Because of competing investment priorities, this target may change over time.

A number of projects will be undertaken during 1990-91 for installation of optical fibre cables to distribution hubs. The program will be kept under review with the aim of increasing the penetration of optical fibre cables in street distribution networks in a cost effective manner, so that wideband services can be provided to Telecom's customers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September 1990 (Hansard page 2650) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: If a bank under the supervision of the Reserve Bank becomes insolvent does the Minister believe the public should be informed.
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) would inform the public of a bank's difficulties if it became necessary for the RBA to take over the management of the bank.

Section 14 of the Banking Act relates specifically to banks which are unable to meet their obligations. Among other things, this Section provides for the Reserve Bank to investigate the affairs of and/or assume control of, and carry on the affairs of, a bank which is or is likely to become unable to meet its obligations or to suspend payment. The Banking Act requires the Reserve Bank, in the event it were to assume control of a bank, to notify that fact in the Government Gazette.
